questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department after experiencing several episodes of non-bilious and non-bloody emesis, followed by a sudden onset of intense chest pain radiating to the back. She also notes that she has left arm weakness. The patient states that prior to today, she has been in her usual state of health. She drinks a pint of vodka daily and regularly uses intranasal cocaine. She reports last using cocaine this morning. Her temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 210/120 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. The patient appears disheveled and in significant distress. Physical examination shows 1+ peripheral pulses in the right upper extremity and 2+ pulses in the left upper extremity. Neurological examination shows 3/5 power in the left upper and lower extremities compared to 5/5 power in the right upper and lower extremities. Laboratory markers demonstrate a troponin of 0.7 ng/ml and a WBC of 12,000/mm3. ECG demonstrates ST-depressions in leads II, III, and aVF. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Aneurysmal rupture of the left middle cerebral artery
Longitudinal cleavage of the aortic media
Atherosclerotic rupture of a right coronary artery plaque
Full thickness perforation of the esophagus

questions.solution:
This patient in this vignette has concerning features for an aortic dissection given her risk factors of uncontrolled hypertension, in addition to the associated clinical features of a widened pulse pressure and characteristic neurologic deficits. Patients with aortic dissections classically present with sudden onset, sharp or tearing chest pain that radiates to the back, syncope, widened pulse pressure, and occasionally differing blood pressure in the upper extremities with associated neurologic deficits.  

Aortic dissections are caused by prolonged hydrodynamic shear stress on the intima of the vessel, which eventually creates a tear in the intimal layer and a column of blood gains access into the aortic media. With repetitive hydrodynamic stress the column of blood longitudinally tears through the media either retrograde (towards the heart), anterograde (away from the heart), or both. Eventually, the hematoma compresses on adjacent structures depending on where the dissection travels. For example, it may compress the brachiocephalic trunk or carotid arteries causing a stroke, or if proximal it may compress the right coronary artery causing an inferior wall MI, as in this patient with changes consistent with an NSTEMI. The hematoma may progress into the pericardium, causing pericardial tamponade.  

The most common risk factor aortic dissection is uncontrolled hypertension, likely precipitated by her chronic cocaine. Genetic risk factors include a history of connective tissue diseases likely Ehlers-Danlos syndrome or Marfan syndrome, which predispose to an already weakened aorta from thoracic aortic aneurysms. Infectious or inflammatory risk factors include Takayasu arteritis, giant cell arteritis, Behçet disease, and syphilis, which also weaken the aortic intima and predispose to intimal tearing.  

 


 The diagnosis of aortic dissection is made by careful physical examination, history, in addition to imaging findings of a widened mediastinum on chest X-ray and a visible dissection flap on CT-angiography of the aorta. If left untreated, aortic dissections can lead to end organ ischemia or rupture, causing hemodynamic instability and death.  



Reproduced from: Wikipedia Commons  

Option Analysis

❌ Aneurysmal rupture of the left middle cerebral artery  :
Incorrect: While rupture of a berry aneurysm may lead to neurologic manifestations as in this patient, patients are typically obtunded or endorse a severe “thunderclap” headache prior to the onset of symptoms.    
✅ Longitudinal cleavage of the aortic media:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Atherosclerotic rupture of a right coronary artery plaque:
Incorrect: The ECG changes in this vignette are typical of an NSTEMI of the inferior wall of the heart, which can be seen with rupture of a right coronary artery plaque. However, the patient in this vignette is extremely hypertensive, and she is more likely experiencing vaso-occlusion and subsequent ischemia of the right coronary artery due to compression from an expanding dissection.  
❌ Full thickness perforation of the esophagus :
Incorrect: Boerhaave's syndrome, or full thickness rupture of the esophagus, can present with severe retrosternal chest pain radiating to the back, especially after multiple episodes of vomiting and recent alcoholic binge as in this vignette. However, patients will usually be vomiting copious amounts of blood, which is absent from this patient’s presentation.  
❌ Defect in lung ventilation/perfusion ratio:
Incorrect: Pulmonary embolisms present with a V/Q mismatch, which is a defect in the ratio of ventilation to perfusion. Patients with large pulmonary embolisms will often present with hypoxia, hypotension, and tachycardia, which are not present in this patient.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the clinic due to the recent onset of pain in his left middle finger. He described the pain as sharp and paroxysmal. The patient works as a gardener, and he first noticed the pain after getting hit on the hand. Medical history is unremarkable, and he takes no medications. Examination of the skin and nails shows dystrophic nail and subungual bluish discoloration under the left middle fingernail bed. Applying pressure triggers exquisite pain. This patient’s lesion arises from a structure involved in which of the following physiologic roles?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has a glomus tumor, a benign neoplasm that arises from the modified smooth muscle cells of the glomus body. A glomus body (or glomus apparatus) is an element of the dermis involved in body temperature regulation. Glomus bodies are prevalent in the fingers and toes. Patients with glomus tumors typically present with nail dystrophy and a subungual pink/purple vascular nodule associated with cold sensitivity, paroxysmal pain (i.e. sudden painful attacks), and tenderness. Subungual glomus tumors are particularly painful. Glomus tumors of the fingers and toes can be seen in approximately 5% of patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) or can arise sporadically.  

The diagnosis is usually based upon the clinical appearance and symptoms, and treatment is surgical excision. However, definitive diagnosis can be made only by histopathologic examination. Histologically, glomus tumors are composed of glomus cells, vasculature, and smooth muscle cells.   

Option Analysis

✅ Thermoregulation :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pigment production:
Incorrect: Melanocytes are cells of neural crest origin that are responsible for melanin production in the skin in response to sun exposure. An example of a lesion arising from melanocytes is melanoma. Acral lentiginous melanoma is a subtype of melanoma that arises on the palmar and plantar surfaces, including the nail bed. Although it can also cause nail dystrophy, it is usually seen as a longitudinal brown or black band in the fingernail. Additionally, exquisite pain with pressure is unlikely.   
❌ Forming the capillary wall:
Incorrect: The capillary walls are formed by endothelial cells. An example of a lesion arising from these cells is a cherry hemangioma, a benign capillary proliferation seen in older individuals. They are typically dark red, dome-shaped lesions that appear on the torso and increase with age.  
❌ Maintaining skin barrier and homeostasis:
Incorrect:  The skin barrier is mostly composed of the squamous cells (keratinocytes) of the epidermis, which are the cells responsible for maintaining skin homeostasis by providing a physical barrier from the environment. An example of a lesion arising from these cells is squamous cell carcinoma, which often occurs in sun-exposed areas. Subungual squamous cell carcinoma is rare and is not associated with exquisite pain with pressure.  
❌ Insulation of nerves:
Incorrect: Insulation of nerves is the role of Schwann cells, which compose the myelin nerve sheath of peripheral nerves. An example of lesions arising from these cells includes schwannomas, which typically occur along the peripheral nerve (e.g. vestibular schwannoma). Subungual schwannoma is rare.

questions.text: A 58-year-old Caucasian man comes to the office because of dull abdominal pain and nausea for the past 2 months. The pain is located at the right side of the abdomen, and the patient rates it 4/10 in intensity. The patient has worked as an engineer in a PVC pipe factory for the past 35 years. Medical history is relevant for hypertension, obesity, and recent travel to China. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows pale skin and conjunctiva, hepatomegaly, and shifting dullness to percussion. Abdominal computed tomography reveals a hypoattenuating, solitary mass with nodular enhancement in the liver. Immunostaining is positive for CD31. Serum alpha-fetoprotein is 8 ng/mL (normal value <10 ng/mL). Serology is negative for hepatitis B and C. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of chronic polyvinyl chloride exposure (PVC industry) and nonspecific abdominal pain likely has liver angiosarcoma. Angiosarcoma is a rare malignant vascular neoplasm of the endothelial-type cells that line vessel walls.  

The pathogenesis of angiosarcoma is characterized by a rapid and extensively infiltrating overgrowth of vascular epithelial cells. Common angiosarcoma locations include the liver, kidney, lung, and breast. In the liver, the tumor cells tend to grow along sinusoids and branches of the portal and hepatic veins. Immunostaining typically shows positivity for vascular markers, including ERG transcription factor, CD31, CD34, and factor VIII antigen. The most common cause of liver angiosarcoma is the prolonged exposure to vinyl chloride monomers (i.e., weatherstripping material, plastic pipes) and polyvinyl chloride (PVC). Other less common causes include arsenic, anabolic steroids, radiation, and thorium dioxide.  

The imaging modality of choice for diagnosing angiosarcoma will depend on the location. For liver angiosarcoma, the imaging modality of choice is MRI or enhanced CT scan. On CT scan, findings suggestive of angiosarcoma may include vascular invasion, nodular enhancement (common), and a hypoattenuating mass.      

Option Analysis

❌ Cholangiocarcinoma:
Incorrect: Cholangiocarcinoma is an adenocarcinoma arising from biliary epithelium that lines the bile ducts. It is associated with Clonorchis sinensis infection and primary sclerosing cholangitis. Abdominal ultrasound may demonstrate biliary duct dilatation, but small lesions are difficult to visualize. Immunohistochemically, the majority of cholangiocarcinomas are positive for cytokeratin (CK) 7 and CK19.  
❌ Hepatic adenoma  :
Incorrect: Hepatic adenomas are rare, benign liver tumors arising from hepatocytes. Oral contraceptives and steroids are commonly associated with hepatic adenomas. These tumors are hormone-induced, and thus they tend to regress if the patient stops the medication. The most common symptom is pain due to compression of adjacent structures, but they may result in life-threatening intra-abdominal bleeding. On ultrasound, hepatic adenomas typically present as a solitary, well-demarcated, heterogeneous mass.  
❌ Hepatocellular carcinoma:
Incorrect: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the most common primary liver cancer. HCC is strongly associated with chronic HBV/HCV infections and alcoholic cirrhosis. Increased alpha-fetoprotein (>500 ng/mL) is seen in 70% of patients with HCC. In this case, the patient is negative for hepatitis B/C and has normal alpha-fetoprotein levels, making HCC unlikely.    
✅ Liver angiosarcoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Liver metastasis:
Incorrect: Liver metastasis is far more common than primary liver tumors. Primary tumors that tend to send metastasis to the liver include colon, stomach, and pancreas. Patients with liver metastases are either asymptomatic or present with abdominal pain and unintentional weight loss. On imaging, metastasis usually presents as multiple lesions rather than a solitary mass. In this case, the patient's medical history of polyvinyl chloride exposure favors liver angiosarcoma.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of a sensation of “dryness and tightness” in the skin. The symptoms began six months ago. She has tried vaseline lotion but reports that it does not improve her symptoms. Past medical history is notable for allergies and asthma, for which she is currently taking loratadine and uses an albuterol inhaler. She smokes half-a-pack of cigarettes per day. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F) and blood pressure is 125/71 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for thickened skin over the face, hands, and forearms. There is reduced range of motion in the bilateral hands.  Skin on the chest, abdomen, and back appear normal. Inspection of the patient’s hands reveals the following finding:  



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following additional symptoms would most likely be found on this patient's history and physical examination?

choices.text: Resolution of symptoms with smoking cessation

questions.solution:
The patient has limited cutaneous systemic scleroderma. This variant of scleroderma is characterized by mild internal organ involvement and generally affects only skin of the face and distal extremities.  

In terms of skin findings, the condition can cause calcinosis cutis (cutaneous and subcutaneous deposition of calcium salts) and Raynaud phenomenon (discoloration of the fingers in cold temperatures secondary to vasospasm). Patients can present with sclerodactyly (tightening and thickening of skin on the hands) and telangiectasias (small dilated blood vessels occurring near the skin/mucosa surface). Over time, vasospasm can lead to tissue ischemia and present with digit ulcers similar to the one shown in the image. Internal organ involvement is largely limited to esophageal dysfunction, which can manifest as gastroesophageal reflux disease.

The key symptoms of limited cutaneous systemic scleroderma can be remembered with the acronym CREST: Calcinosis cutis, Raynaud's phenomenon, Esophageal dysfunction, Sclerodactyly, and Telangiectasia.      

Option Analysis

❌ Constipation and bowel dysmotility:
Incorrect: Constipation secondary to bowel dysmotility is seen in diffuse scleroderma. This condition affects visceral organs including the lungs, heart, gastrointestinal tract, and kidneys. In addition, this condition presents with thickening of the skin throughout the body. In contrast, this patient has skin thickening only in the face and distal upper extremities.   
❌ Resolution of symptoms with smoking cessation:
Incorrect: This describes thromboangiitis obliterans (also known as Buerger disease). It is a vasculitis seen in heavy smokers, which can lead to gangrene and autoamputation of the digits. Although this patient has a smoking history and finger ulcers, thromboangiitis obliterans would not explain the thickened skin and reduced range of motion.   
❌ Calf pain exacerbated by walking:
Incorrect: This is seen in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD). PAD can diminish blood flow to the extremities, causing tissue necrosis and ulceration. However, ulcers secondary to PAD are most often found in the lower extremities. In addition, PAD would not account for the patient’s skin thickening and reduced range of motion.  
✅ Calcium deposition at the elbow:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Corneal scarring and blurred vision  :
Incorrect: Sjögren syndrome presents with dry mouth, dry eyes, and systemic symptoms (e.g., fatigue, myalgias). The condition reduces tear production, which predisposes patients to corneal injury. In rare cases, it can contribute to vasculitis and cause skin ulceration. However, it would be atypical for Sjogren syndrome to present with skin thickening or reduce joint motion in the hands.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain. The patient reports dull, cramping pain primarily over his left abdomen for the past three days. He additionally reports several episodes of non-bloody diarrhea, fevers, and chronic constipation. He was seen by his primary care physician for his symptoms and was given a course of antibiotics, but his symptoms have persisted. He reports an episode of diarrhea this morning. His past medical history is significant for hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. His surgical history is notable for a cholecystectomy at age 44. His temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min and blood pressure is 162/94 mmHg. Physical examination shows a non-distended abdomen with tenderness to palpation in the left lower quadrant with rebound and guarding. Laboratory results show an elevated leukocyte count. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this disease process?

choices.text: Rupture of vasa recta into the colonic lumen
Impaction of a fecalith in the distal ileum
Perforation of an outpouching of the ileal mucosa, submucosa, and serosa
Scar tissue resulting in mechanical bowel obstruction
Sudden interruption of blood flow to the small bowel

questions.solution:
Diverticulitis refers to an inflammation of outpouchings in the colon known as diverticula. Diverticulosis and diverticulitis are diseases primarily seen in Western nations, and they are thought to be due to diets low in fiber. The exact pathogenic mechanism for diverticula formation is unknown, but one theory suggests that diverticula form in response to increased intracolonic pressures generated when the colon is processing smaller, non–fiber-containing stools. This increased pressure eventually pushes out part of the colon, forming sac-like appendages at the weakest segments, at the point where the colon is fed by blood vessels called the vasa recta.  

When a diverticulum becomes obstructed with a small amount of stool, this leads to stasis, inflammation, and infection. Most cases of diverticulitis classically present with focal left lower quadrant abdominal pain and the generalized symptoms of malaise, low grade fevers, and alternating constipation and diarrhea. Uncomplicated diverticulitis involving microperforations can be diagnosed clinically and responds well to outpatient oral antibiotic therapy. Patients with concern for complicated diverticulitis involving macro-perforations, failure of outpatient therapy, or diagnostic uncertainty should undergo CT of the abdomen and pelvis with both IV and oral contrast, and they should then be admitted to the hospital for intravenous antibiotics. Risk factors for the development of complicated diverticulitis include older age, failure of outpatient therapy, and immunocompromised patients. If left untreated, diverticulitis can progress to fistula formation and the development of intra-abdominal abscesses, leading to sepsis.  



Option Analysis

❌ Rupture of vasa recta into the colonic lumen:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the pathophysiology of diverticular bleeding, which usually presents with painless hematochezia. The formation of diverticula occurs at the weakest point of the colonic wall, where it is fed by blood vessels called the vasa recta. When these vessels rupture, they can bleed into the colonic lumen.   
❌ Impaction of a fecalith in the distal ileum :
Incorrect: This describes the pathophysiology of appendicitis. While this patient exhibits peritonitis and findings concerning for a surgical abdomen, his pain is primarily in the left lower quadrant, whereas appendicitis typically presents in the right lower quadrant.  
✅ Perforation of an outpouching of the ileal mucosa, submucosa, and serosa  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Scar tissue resulting in mechanical bowel obstruction:
Incorrect: This patient has a prior history of cholecystectomy, making adhesions and subsequent small bowel obstruction a possible cause of his abdominal pain. However, bowel obstruction is unlikely in this patient given his recent passage of stool and non-distended abdomen.   
❌ Sudden interruption of blood flow to the small bowel :
Incorrect: This describes acute mesenteric ischemia, which typically occurs in patients with risk factors for embolus formation (i.e. atrial fibrillation) or preexisting atherosclerosis. Patients typically present with periumbilical pain that is disproportionate to physical findings, as well as nausea and vomiting. This patient’s presentation is suggestive of a different condition.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the emergency department seeking evaluation for abdominal pain which began 12 hours ago. The pain is localized in the right upper quadrant and is rated as 7 out of 10 in severity. In addition, she has had two episodes of non-bloody vomiting. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 152/88 mmHg, and pulse is 76/min. Physical examination shows jaundice, and pain is elicited on palpation of the right upper quadrant. Laboratory testing reveals a total serum bilirubin of 6.7 mg/dL. Ultrasound reveals obstruction in a portion of the common bile duct. No obstruction or dilation of the pancreatic duct or hepatopancreatic duct is observed. Which of the following additional findings will be most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has choledocolithiasis, which occurs when a gallstone lodges in the common bile duct. Patients can present with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting. Since bile outflow is obstructed, patients will develop conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.  

In addition to gallstones, tumors (e.g., cholangiocarcinoma, pancreatic adenocarcinoma), strictures, and parasitic infections can also cause biliary tract obstruction. Patients with chronic biliary tract obstruction can have pale stools (since bilirubin breakdown products give stool its brown color) and dark urine (since the conjugated bilirubin is instead excreted via urine). In addition, patients can have malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins and hypercholesterolemia. The latter is most likely due to leakage of cholesterol and lecithin from ruptured biliary ductules into the bloodstream and increased hepatic cholesterol synthesis.  

On laboratory testing, individuals with biliary tract obstruction can have elevated alkaline phosphatase and gamma-glutamate transpeptidase levels. If the obstruction causes liver injury, then aspartate transaminase (AST) and alanine transaminase (ALT) levels can also be elevated.  

Option Analysis

❌ Elevated lipase:
Incorrect: If the portion of the common bile duct distal to the pancreatic duct is obstructed, then pancreatic enzyme outflow can be impaired. This impairment can cause pancreatitis and elevated lipase levels. However, this patient has an obstruction in a portion of the common bile duct proximal to the pancreatic duct. In this scenario, lipase levels would likely be normal.  
✅ Elevated alkaline phosphatase  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Normal aspartate transaminase levels:
Incorrect: This patient has acute onset right upper quadrant pain, which is concerning for a gallstone-related etiology. If the common bile duct is affected, then the condition is termed choledocolithiasis. Obstruction of the common bile duct will impair bile excretion. This causes bile to backflow into the liver, causing damage and increasing liver enzyme levels.   
❌ Elevated unconjugated bilirubin:
Incorrect: Conditions such as Gilbert syndrome or hemolytic anemias can cause elevated unconjugated bilirubin levels. However, an etiology that affects the common bile duct will likely impair bile outflow, resulting in conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.  
❌ Elevated carbohydrate antigen 19-9:
Incorrect: Carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (CA 19-9) is a tumor marker for pancreatic cancer. A pancreatic mass can potentially obstruct the common bile duct. However, the patient in this vignette has a history of acute onset right upper quadrant pain in the absence of weight loss, night sweats, or other systemic symptoms. This is more consistent with the presentation of a gallstone-related etiology.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a one week history of a red, painful swollen left lower extremity. The patient reports he recently returned from Hawaii, where he was running a marathon. He reports his symptoms began shortly after landing and is worried he may have injured his leg during the race. His medical history is non-contributory. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6 °F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 152/73 mmHg, and oxygen saturation saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination shows a swollen and mildly erythematous left lower extremity that is painful to palpation, with 2+ pitting edema compared to the right lower extremity. Pulses are 2+ with capillary refill <2 seconds bilaterally. WBC is 9000/mm3 and creatine kinase is 30U/L. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: CT-angiogram of the left lower extremity

questions.solution:
This patient likely has a deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which classically presents as a unilateral, swollen, erythematous, and painful lower extremity. Virchow's triad summarizes the pathophysiology leading to thrombosis, and includes endothelial injury, hypercoagulability, and venous stasis. Venous stasis occurs during periods of extended immobility, including long-distance plane flights (as in this patient), hospital stays, post-op, or sedentary lifestyles.  

The differential diagnosis of a deep vein thrombosis includes cellulitis, compartment syndrome, fractures, and a ruptured Baker's cyst. Of all the diagnostic investigations listed, a compression ultrasound with doppler of the deep veins of the leg is the most appropriate diagnostic study to obtain.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Left tibia and fibula x-ray:
Incorrect: While a stress fracture is possible in a patient with a recent long distance run, it is unlikely given the presence of pitting edema on exam.  
✅ Ultrasound of the lower extremities:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ CT-angiogram of the left lower extremity:
Incorrect: CTA of the lower extremity is indicated if there is concern for vaso-occlusive disease of the arteries of the lower extremity. This condition presents with pallor, poor capillary refill, mottled extremities and often non-palpable or diminished pulses, which this patient does not have.   
❌ Measurement of compartment pressures:
Incorrect: Measurement of compartment pressures is indicated when there is concern for compartment syndrome. On physical examination, this condition does present with swelling, but more often there are tense muscles rather than pitting edema. This patient’s CK level is also normal, making this diagnosis unlikely.  
❌ Blood cultures:
Incorrect: Blood cultures would be indicated in the setting of cellulitis. This diagnosis is unlikely in an afebrile patient with a normal white blood cell count.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden onset chest pain. He was sitting at home watching television when he noticed the pain, characterized as a sharp pressure-like sensation in the left side of his chest. He is having difficulty catching his breath. Medical history is significant for hypertension, COPD, chronic kidney disease, and coronary artery disease. He takes amlodipine, lisinopril, aspirin, salmeterol, and albuterol. His father died from a heart attack at age 50. He smokes one pack of cigarettes per day and drinks occasionally. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. He appears pale and diaphoretic. Physical exam shows a holosystolic murmur at the left mid sternal border that increases with supine leg raise. Lung examination is normal. An ECG is obtained and shows the following:  



 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of an acute pulmonary embolism (PE). Pulmonary embolism occurs when a distal thrombus, usually from the deep veins of the legs (DVT), dislodges and enters the pulmonary circulation through the right side of the heart and into the pulmonary arteries. Symptoms include sudden, pleuritic chest pain, tachycardia, and hypoxemia. If the PE is large enough, blood cannot pass through to the left side of the heart, and the decreased left ventricular preload reduces cardiac output, causing severe hypotension, as in this patient. Since the outflow of the right ventricle (RV) is blocked by a clot, the pressure in the RV suddenly increases (causing the murmur of tricuspid regurgitation) and the RV wall stretches, which stretches cardiac conduction fibers, delaying ventricular conduction in the right side of the heart. On ECG, this appears as a right bundle branch block (RBBB).  

RBBB is recognized on ECG by a broad QRS ( >120 msec), RSR’ pattern in V1-3 (‘M-shaped’ QRS complex) and wide, slurred S wave in lateral leads (I, aVL, V5-V6):  



Other causes of RBBB include pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), cor pulmonale (from COPD or interstitial lung disease), and, rarely, myocardial infarction (the right bundle branch is supplied from septal perforators of the LAD coronary artery).    

Left bundle branch block (LBBB) occurs on the left side of the heart, and usually develops over time in the setting of long standing hypertension and coronary artery disease. The left bundle is supplied by the left anterior descending artery (LAD), thus LBBB can sometimes occur in the setting of an acute anterior myocardial infarction. Compared to RBBB, LBBB on ECG goes in the opposite direction with a dominant S wave in V1 and broad monophasic R waves in lateral leads (I, aVL, V5-V6):  



Option Analysis

❌ Acute myocardial infarction:
Incorrect: Acute myocardial infarction is typically associated with a new left bundle branch block. Symptoms include chest pain radiating to the jaw, sweating, and shortness of breath. The left-sided heart dysfunction would cause fluid backup and crackles on lung auscultation.  
✅ Acute pulmonary embolism:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cor pulmonale:
Incorrect: Cor pulmonale refers to pulmonary hypertension with right ventricular dysfunction (often associated with a right bundle branch block on ECG) due to chronic lung disease. This process is chronic and develops over months to years, unlike an acute pulmonary embolism.   
❌ Pulmonary arterial hypertension:
Incorrect: Pulmonary arterial hypertension refers to elevated pressures in the pulmonary artery. Over time, this pressure can lead to right-sided heart failure and can cause a right bundle branch block on ECG. However, it would not suddenly cause chest pain.  
❌ COPD exacerbation:
Incorrect: COPD exacerbation is characterized by acutely worsened cough, increased sputum, or sputum quality change with new shortness of breath. Lung auscultation would reveal diminished breath sounds with wheezes throughout.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician's office by his parents due to headaches and difficulty walking. The parents report that he had a viral infection 2 months ago, and since then he has had a mild headache, especially in the morning. They also state that he has become clumsier, and his school performance has declined. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 121/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows a broad based gait and head bobbing. A horizontal nystagmus is present. Magnetic resonance imaging of the head and spine is obtained and shown below:  






Reproduced from: Radiopaedia

A biopsy of the mass is performed and shows blue cells palisading around a central core. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has metastatic medulloblastoma. The diagnosis is supported by the classic presenting signs of intracranial hypertension (e.g. headache), cerebellar signs (e.g., head titubation, nystagmus, broad-based gait), and imaging revealing a lesion in the cerebellum and spinal cord (“drop metastasis”). In addition, the histological biopsy depicts pathognomonic Homer-Wright rosettes. 

Medulloblastomas, the most common malignant primary brain tumor of childhood, typically occur in the cerebellum (infratentorial). Spreading to the spinal cord is common (“drop metastasis”), as seen in this patient. Medulloblastomas belong to the family of primitive neuroectodermal tumors (PNET), which are tumors of the undifferentiated nerve cells in the brain.  

Presenting symptoms typically include headaches, nausea, vomiting, altered mental status, gait ataxia or truncal instability, limb clumsiness, dizziness, and double vision. Hydrocephalus may occur secondary to obstruction at the level of the fourth ventricle.  

Histopathology shows small blue cells arranged around a central core (Homer-Wright rosettes). This finding distinguishes the tumor from ependymomas, which classically have pervascular pseudorosettes, characterized by neoplastic cells arranged around a blood vessel.  




Credit: Wikimedia Commons 

Option Analysis

❌ Glioblastoma multiforme:
Incorrect: Glioblastoma multiforme theoretically can invade the spinal cord; however, this tumor is seen in the adult population. Also, it typically grows in the cerebral hemispheres and histopathology would show a “pseudopalisading” pattern of pleomorphic tumor cells, not Homer-Wright rosettes.   
❌ Pilocytic astrocytoma  :
Incorrect: Pilocytic astrocytoma, a low-grade astrocytoma, also occurs in the cerebellum and can metastasize to the spinal cord; however, histopathology would show glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) positive staining and Rosenthal Fibers.    
❌ Schwannoma:
Incorrect: Schwannoma is a tumor that typically grows along the peripheral nerves, not in the cerebellum. On histology, the tumor stains positive for S-100 and is characterized by biphasic architecture.  
❌ Meningioma:
Incorrect: Meningiomas commonly grow in the parasagittal region external to the brain parenchyma and may have a dural attachment. Histology shows spindle cells concentrically arranged in a whorled pattern and characteristic psammoma bodies (laminated calcifications).   
❌ Craniopharyngioma:
Incorrect: Craniopharyngioma is a supratentorial tumor derived from remnants of Rathke’s pouch (ectoderm). Histology shows keratin pearls and cysts filled with cholesterol crystals (“motor oil”-like).   
✅ Medulloblastoma :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Ependymoma:
Incorrect: Ependymomas are tumors that arise from the glial cells lining the ventricular system. Most commonly it occurs in the 4th ventricle, leading to hydrocephalus. Similar to medulloblastoma, it can send metastases to the spinal cord; however, on histology, cells form characteristic perivascular pseudorosettes, not Homer-Wright rosettes (see main explanation).

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man comes to the emergency department complaining of shortness of breath. One hour ago, while attending his nephew’s birthday party, the patient suddenly felt chest tightness with dizziness, and he was unable to catch his breath. Medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Medications include insulin, simvastatin, and lisinopril. He quit smoking 20 years ago. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 190/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg. Physical examination reveals the patient to be pale and in mild distress. Lung auscultation demonstrates clear breath sounds bilaterally. ECG shows the following:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Synchronized electrical cardioversion is attempted; however, the patient loses a pulse immediately afterwards. After 10 rounds of cardiopulmonary resuscitation, the patient is pronounced dead. Which of the following processes was the most likely contributor to this patient’s cause of death?
questions.solution:
This patient presented acutely with symptoms of rapidly falling cardiac output (low blood pressure, dizziness) in the setting of unstable sustained monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (SMVT). Because of his hypotension and severe symptoms, synchronized cardioversion was indicated to revert his heart rate back to a normal sinus rhythm, though unfortunately it was unsuccessful. SMVT occurs most commonly in patients with coronary artery disease (CAD), and it can happen with a heart attack. Among patients with diabetes (either type), cardiovascular disease (including CAD and stroke) is the leading cause of death.  

Generally, the chronic complications of diabetes can be broken down into two distinct pathways: 1) non-enzymatic glycosylation, and 2) osmotic cellular damage.  

  1.  Non-enzymatic glycosylation (NEG) occurs when glucose covalently attaches to cell proteins and lipids, without the help of an enzyme.  These sugar coated molecules are pro-inflammatory and can cause damage to the cell.  NEG in small blood vessels like arterioles causes hyaline arteriolosclerosis, in which the walls of arterioles develop protein deposits that make the vessels hard and inflexible. In addition, the basement membrane of blood vessels can thicken, making it hard for oxygen to easily move to the tissues, resulting in hypoxia. NEG causes retinopathy and nodular glomerulosclerosis (microvascular complications), as well as CAD, strokes, and peripheral vascular disease (macrovascular complications).


2. The next mechanism is osmotic cellular damage. Normally, when glucose enters cells, it can be converted to sorbitol by the enzyme aldose reductase. Sorbitol is an osmotic agent, meaning it attracts water into the cells. As a protective mechanism, some cells are able to convert sorbitol to fructose with the enzyme sorbitol dehydrogenase; however, the cells of the lens, the pericytes in the retina, Schwann cells and renal epithelial cells lack this enzyme.  



Therefore, in the lens, sorbitol build up causes cataracts, while damage to the Schwann cells causes diabetic neuropathy (microvascular complications). Autonomic neuropathy, caused by a mix of NEG and osmotic damage to autonomic ganglia, can lead to diabetic gastroparesis, which is weakness of the gastric peristalsis, resulting in nausea and vomiting after meals.  

Option Analysis

❌ Alveolar wall destruction:
Incorrect: Alveolar wall destruction occurs in the setting of emphysema and the inflammation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Although patients with COPD are at higher risk of pneumothorax, this patient’s normal lung examination suggests an alternative etiology for this acute decompensation.   
❌ Epigenetic DNA repair gene silencing:
Incorrect: Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is more common in patients with a history of smoking, even if they quit years ago, and it is often driven by epigenetic silencing of genes that repair DNA. NSCLC would not be expected to cause cardiac arrhythmias, and this patient does not have the weight loss or hemoptysis commonly seen in lung cancer.  
❌ Nodular glomerulosclerosis:
Incorrect: Nodular glomerulosclerosis refers to the appearance of the scarred glomerulus in patients with longstanding diabetes. Although diabetic kidney disease is an important contributor to morbidity and mortality in patients with diabetes, it does not cause death as often as cardiovascular disease.   
❌ Osmotic cellular damage  :
Incorrect: Osmotic cellular damage drives the microvascular complications seen in patients with longstanding diabetes, including retinopathy, nephropathy, and neuropathy. Although these conditions can be severely debilitating, they are less likely to result in death than the macrovascular complications of cardiovascular disease.   
✅ Non-enzymatic glycosylation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: 1-hour-old newborn girl is being evaluated in the nursery. She was born to a 23-year-old woman who did not receive prenatal care and has no significant past medical history. The patient’s mother smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day throughout the pregnancy and did not drink alcohol. The patient’s mother did not take prenatal vitamins. The patient's vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the infant is in no acute distress. Physical examination shows a raw, red lesion on the lower back. Anal sphincter tone is 0 (normal = 3), indicating no discernible pressure. The infant can move the upper extremities but not the lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This infant is presenting with paraplegia, absent anal sphincter tone, and a raw, red lesion on the lower back, favoring the diagnosis of myelomeningocele.  

Open neural tube defects (NTDs) are congenital anomalies that develop when the neural tube fails to close normally during the third and fourth weeks of gestation. NTDs may be open (e.g., myelomeningocele, meningocele, encephalocele, and anencephaly) or closed (e.g. spina bifida occulta).  

Myelomeningocele refers to a neural tube defect (NTD) in which both the meninges and neural tissue herniate through bony defect in the vertebrae. Myelomeningocele (spina bifida) is the most common NTD. The neurologic deficits vary and depend upon the level of the lesion. Signs and symptoms include sensory, motor, bladder, and bowel defects. The condition is often associated with other neurologic abnormalities including Chiari II malformation (which can result in brainstem dysfunction), hydrocephalus, learning disabilities, and tethered cord syndrome.  

Risk factors for developing closed or open neural tube defects include folic acid deficiency, gestational diabetes, maternal obesity, and certain medications (e.g., valproate, carbamazepine). Most isolated NTDs appear to be caused by folate deficiency, likely in combination with genetic or environmental risk factors.  



Option Analysis

❌ Anencephaly:
Incorrect: Anencephaly is a type of open neural tube defect that occurs due to the failure of the rostral neuropore to close, resulting in an absent calvarium and forebrain.    
❌ Meningocele:
Incorrect: Meningocele is a type of spina bifida in which only the meninges herniate through the defect in the spinal cord without neural tissue. At birth, the lesion also appears as red, fleshy growth, but since the lesion does not contain the spinal cord, patients are usually asymptomatic. The lack of anal sphincter tone and the presence of lower extremity paralysis in this patient favors another diagnosis.  
✅ Myelomeningocele:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Myeloschisis:
Incorrect: Myeloschisis refers to a persistence of fibroneural stalk between the spinal cord and the overlying skin. When it extends through the spinal cord, it may result in split cord formation. This lesion instead appears as exposed, unfused neural tissue without skin or meningeal covering.  
❌ Tethered cord syndrome  :
Incorrect: Tethered cord syndrome (TCS) refers to a group of neurological disorders caused by stretch-induced dysfunction of the caudal portion of the spinal cord. It may occur independently or in association with other spinal defects (e.g. spina bifida). In toddlers, tethered cord syndrome typically presents with motor and sensory deficits, and loss of bladder control. However, the presence of unfused neural tissue in the lower back of this patient favors another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents to the emergency department because of decreased urine output and dark urine for the last 2 weeks. She also reports fatigue and a worsening headache associated with visual disturbance for the last 2 days. Her past medical history is significant for hypertension, but she states that she has not taken her medication for the past year. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 222/146 mmHg. Fundoscopic examination shows papilledema and retinal hemorrhages. Urine dipstick is positive for blood. Which of the following laboratory findings is also most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a blood pressure of 222/146 mmHg associated with signs of end organ damage (severe headache, visual disturbance, as well as papilledema and retinal hemorrhages seen on fundoscopy) is most likely experiencing a hypertensive emergency.  Hypertensive emergency is defined as the combination of severely elevated blood pressure (systolic ≥180 mmHg and diastolic ≥120 mmHg) and signs of end-organ damage, such as stroke, myocardial infarction, aortic dissection, retinal hemorrhages and exudates, acute kidney injury, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia.  

This patient’s decreased urine output and darker than normal urine indicate a resultant microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA). MAHA is a type of normocytic hemolytic anemia, defined as having a mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 80-100 fL. In hypertensive emergency, fibrinoid necrosis of blood vessels leads to endothelial damage, which causes vessel narrowing and the formation of platelet-rich microthrombi (causing thrombocytopenia) within small vessels. This leads to RBC damage (hemolysis) as the cells pass through these obstructed blood vessels, causing the MAHA. The damaged RBCs can be seen as sheared erythrocyte fragments, or schistocytes, on peripheral blood smear. The resultant hemolytic anemia then presents with darkened urine, which is caused by hemoglobinuria and hemosiderinuria. This usually occurs a few days later when the renal tubular cells, which absorbed the hemoglobin, slough off into the urine. Hemolytic anemia also presents with elevated reticulocyte count, due to a compensatory increase in erythrocyte production.  








Reproduced from: Wikimedia commons 

Option Analysis

❌ Platelet count of 250,000/μL:
Incorrect: This patient with hypertensive emergency likely has thrombotic microangiopathy. She would be expected to have a decreased platelet count of less than 150,000/μL due to platelet consumption.  
✅ Reticulocyte count of 6%:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Normal levels of haptoglobin:
Incorrect: This patient would be expected to have low haptoglobin levels of less than 50 mg/dL, due to intravascular hemolytic anemia. As hemolysis occurs, hemoglobin is released into the blood and binds to haptoglobin. Both proteins are removed from the blood together and haptoglobin levels decrease.  
❌ Direct bilirubin level of 3 mg/dL:
Incorrect: This patient would be expected to have normal direct bilirubin levels of less than 0.3 mg/dL. Indirect bilirubin levels would be elevated in this patient due to bleeding and hemolytic anemia.   
❌ Hematocrit of 40%:
Incorrect: This patient with dark urine and urine dipstick positive for blood would be expected to have a low hematocrit of less than 37% due to hemolytic anemia. Normal hematocrit levels in women are 37-47% and in men are 42-50%.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to severe abdominal pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting. The patient states that the pain started near the umbilicus yesterday evening, but has since moved towards the lower right side. He also reports that the pain increased in severity overnight, rating it up to a 10 on a 10-point scale. However, he now feels that the pain has diminished slightly. He describes the pain as sharp and states that it was especially bad en route to the hospital when the ambulance drove over bumps in the road. The patient has no past medical history and consumes a vegan diet. His temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), pulse is 124/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 86/60 mmHg. Abdominal examination shows tenderness over the right lower quadrant. The patient is noted to tighten his abdominal muscles to lessen the pain. Which of the following physical examination signs is most likely to be present in this patient?

choices.text: Inspiratory arrest with palpation of the right upper quadrant
Nontender, palpable gallbladder in the right upper quadrant

questions.solution:
This 32-year-old man has severe migratory abdominal pain, fever, nausea, vomiting, and right lower quadrant pain. He most likely has acute appendicitis. Additionally, there is evidence of hemodynamic instability (e.g., tachycardia, decreased blood pressure) and abdominal guarding, which means that this patient likely has peritonitis secondary to appendiceal rupture. Patients with peritonitis classically complain of increased pain with sudden movements, such as bumps in the road en route to the hospital or maneuvering of the stretcher. They also might describe a relative decrease in their pain after the appendix has ruptured.  

Appendiceal rupture is a severe complication of appendicitis, as it can quickly lead to peritonitis and sepsis. Vital signs typically show hemodynamic instability, with decreased blood pressure and compensatory tachycardia. Physical exam findings include abdominal guarding, rigidity, and Blumberg sign. Abdominal guarding is defined as voluntary tightening of the abdominal muscles with palpation of the abdomen to lessen the pain. Rigidity is defined as involuntary muscle tightening at rest. Blumberg sign, also known as rebound tenderness, is defined as pain during release following deep palpation.  



Option Analysis

❌ Costovertebral angle tenderness:
Incorrect: Costovertebral angle (CVA) tenderness is associated with acute pyelonephritis. This patient’s presentation is more characteristic of appendicitis, which may present with flank pain but not CVA tenderness.  
❌ Inspiratory arrest with palpation of the right upper quadrant:
Incorrect: Inspiratory arrest with palpation of the right upper quadrant, also called Murphy sign, is associated with acute cholecystitis. Acute cholecystitis is inflammation of the gallbladder, which can result from obstruction by gallstones or bile stasis. A patient with cholecystitis is unlikely to have signs of peritonitis (e.g. guarding).  
✅ Rebound tenderness :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Nontender, palpable gallbladder in the right upper quadrant :
Incorrect: The presence of a nontender, palpable gallbladder palpated in the right upper quadrant, also called Courvoisier sign, is associated with gallbladder or pancreatic malignancy, which would not explain this otherwise healthy patient’s acute presentation with peritonitis.   
❌ Periumbilical edema and ecchymosis :
Incorrect: Periumbilical edema and ecchymosis, also called Cullen sign, is associated with acute pancreatitis. Pancreatitis presents with epigastric abdominal pain radiating to the back, rather than the classic right lower quadrant abdominal pain of appendicitis shown here.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine health evaluation. While sitting in the waiting room, the patient experiences an episode of crying during which she falls to the ground and starts rolling side-to-side. The patient’s eyes are closed shut and could not be opened by a nurse. The episode lasts for about 3 minutes, after which the patient is able to stand up and sit in a chair. The patient has experienced similar episodes several times in front of family members before. The patient has suffered from post-traumatic stress disorder after a sexual assault several years ago; the condition is now being managed with sertraline. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is alert and oriented. Oral examination reveals no tongue lesions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s findings of jactitation (rolling from side to side), forced closure of eyes, vocalization (crying) and rapid reorientation, together with the history of sexual assault, makes the diagnosis of Psychogenic Non-Epileptic Seizures (PNES) most likely in this case.

PNES is defined as sudden disruption of motor, sensory, autonomic or cognitive function that is of psychologic origin (instead of excessive synchronous neuronal activity seen in seizures). It is most common in the third decade of life and has female predominance. Risk factors include learning disabilities, or a history of physical or psychosocial trauma (unwanted pregnancy, physical, verbal or sexual abuse, or assault). It typically lasts longer than 2 minutes and presents with inconsistent findings (e.g., variable motor activity, pelvic thrusting, and forced closure of eyes). According to DSM-V criteria, the diagnosis does not require a provider to judge whether the episode was intentionally produced, as this aspect of the presentation may not be reliably discerned, and such a judgement would not change management, which consists of psychological evaluation.  



Option Analysis

❌ Generalized tonic-clonic seizure (GTCS):
Incorrect: Psychogenic Non-Epileptic Seizure (PNES) is commonly misdiagnosed as GTCS because of generalized motor symptoms. However, GTCS is characterized by loss of consciousness, diffuse, bilateral muscle stiffening and rhythmic jerking, and postictal confusion. Eyes are usually open during GTCS, and it is typically associated with frothing at the mouth, tongue biting, and incontinence.  
❌ Medication side effect:
Incorrect: Sertraline does not precipitate seizures or PNES. Common side effects include flu-like symptoms, GI distress, and sexual dysfunction.  
❌ Factitious disorder:
Incorrect: Factitious disorder involves voluntary and intentional production of symptoms to achieve a primary internal gain (medical attention, sympathy, or, sometimes, relief from emotional conflict). These patients commonly falsify somatic symptoms or commonly known disorders (like hyperthyroidism).  
✅ Psychogenic Non-Epileptic Seizure (PNES):
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Malingering:
Incorrect: Malingering involves conscious and motivational faking of symptoms to attain a specific external gain (avoid work, obtain compensation). Even if the patient feigned the symptoms to get the doctor’s attention, PNES is still a more specific diagnosis in this case.

questions.text:
An 83-year-old man comes to the office for a routine evaluation. The patient recently noticed that his urine has pinkish tinge, but he denies dysuria or abdominal pain. Medical history is unremarkable, and physical examination shows no abnormalities. Repeated urinalysis shows 5-10 RBC/hpf, and the urine is pinkish-red in color. Cystoscopy with biopsy is obtained, and the results are shown below.  

 

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most common risk factor associated with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with painless gross hematuria, a classic presentation of bladder cancer. The biopsy results confirm the diagnosis of transitional cell carcinoma.   

In the industrialized world, about 90% of bladder cancers are transitional cell carcinoma, also known as urothelial cell carcinoma. Squamous cell carcinoma accounts for up to 7% of bladder cancers in the United States but is much more common in countries where schistosomiasis is endemic (e.g. Egypt). Adenocarcinomas of the bladder are rare. Up to 80% of bladder cancer cases are associated with an environmental exposure. Tobacco use is by far the most common cause of transitional cell bladder cancer in the United States and is increasing in importance in some developing countries. Smoking duration and intensity are directly related to increased risk. Tobacco use is also associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder but to a lesser extent. Other risk factors include exposure to aromatic amines, phenacetin, pelvic radiation, and treatment with cyclophosphamide.  

In patients presenting with painless, gross hematuria, bladder cancer should be suspected, and  cystoscopy should be performed.   

Option Analysis

❌ Exposure to aromatic amines:
Incorrect: Exposure to aromatic amines such as benzidine in the paint industry does increase the risk for bladder cancer; however, tobacco use is the most common cause of bladder cancer.   
❌ Pelvic radiation:
Incorrect: Pelvic radiation has been associated with an increased risk for bladder cancer. However, this relationship has not been established in all studies, and the magnitude of the risk appears to be minute. Tobacco use is the most common cause of bladder cancer.  
❌ Recurrent urinary tract infections:
Incorrect: Recurrent urinary tract infections may increase the risk for pyelonephritis. While chronic urinary irritation may cause squamous metaplasia and squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder, this process is not the most common risk factor for bladder cancer.  
✅ Smoking history:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Cyclophosphamide use:
While cyclophosphamide is a risk factor for hemorrhagic cystitis and bladder cancer, tobacco use is the most common cause of bladder cancer. The risk of bladder cancer in patients taking cyclophosphamide can be reduced with the co-administration of mesna.

questions.text: A scientist is investigating different types of mutations and their associated thrombophilias. The scientist identifies a single point mutation in the terminal nucleotide of the 3’ untranslated region of a specific gene, which corresponds to the messenger RNA (mRNA) sequence responsible for polyadenylation. A patient with this mutation will most likely have which of the following findings?

choices.text: Hemarthroses; low levels of factor VIII
Easy bruising; low levels of factor IX
Deep vein thrombosis; No change in PTT following heparin administration
Venous thromboembolism; activated protein C resistance

questions.solution:
Prothrombin gene mutation G20210A is the second most common inherited thrombophilia following factor V Leiden. Transmission occurs in an autosomal dominant fashion. Prothrombin, also known as factor II, is the precursor of thrombin, the end product of the coagulation cascade. Thrombin’s main role is to proteolytically cleave fibrinogen to fibrin, which in turn crosslinks to form a fibrin clot. Thrombin also interacts with other hemostatic components.  

Prothrombin deficiency occurs due to a point mutation in which adenine (A) is substituted for guanine (G) at position 20210. Hence the condition is named prothrombin gene mutation G20210A. The base change occurs in the terminal nucleotide of the 3’ untranslated gene region, which corresponds to the messenger RNA sequence used for polyadenylation. The end result is a gain-of-function mutation, increased prothrombin production, and hypercoagulability.  

Patients may be heterozygous or homozygous. Patients are at increased risk for venous or arterial thromboembolism, MI, stroke, and obstetric complications. Laboratory testing will show normal or elevated PTT. Prothrombin levels are often elevated but are not used for diagnosis since there is too much overlap between the upper limit of normal and the levels in individuals carrying the mutation. A definitive diagnosis is made via polymerase chain reaction (PCR).    

 

Option Analysis

❌ Hemarthroses; low levels of factor VIII:
Incorrect: These findings are seen in hemophilia A, an inherited X-linked recessive disorder characterized by easy bruising, hemarthrosis (bleeding into joints), and bleeding after trauma or surgery. The pathogenesis involves defects in factor 8, most commonly due to an inversion of part of the tip of X chromosome long arm within intron 22 of the F8 gene.  
❌ Easy bruising; low levels of factor IX :
Incorrect: These findings are seen in hemophilia B, an inherited X-linked recessive disorder characterized by easy bruising, hemarthrosis (bleeding into joints), and bleeding after trauma or surgery. The pathogenesis involves defects in factor 9, most commonly due to missense mutations in the F9 gene.  
❌ Deep vein thrombosis; No change in PTT following heparin administration  :
Incorrect: Antithrombin (AT, previously called AT III) deficiency may be acquired or inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion with variable penetration. Antithrombin is a natural anticoagulant that inhibits thrombin (factor IIa), factor Xa, and other factors in the coagulation cascade. A variety of mutations have been recognized in the gene encoding AT, which often cause reduced synthesis of AT or production of a defective version.   
❌ Venous thromboembolism; activated protein C resistance:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with Factor V Leiden deficiency, an autosomal dominant condition and the most common cause of inherited hypercoagulability in Caucasians. The pathogenesis involves a single point mutation in the factor V gene in which guanine is switched to adenine. The corresponding mRNA codon forms a polypeptide chain in which arginine is replaced by glutamine at position Arg506. Consequently, the cleavage site is altered and factor V can no longer be degraded by protein C.   
✅ Arterial thrombosis; elevated prothrombin levels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to limping and pain in the right leg. The patient is a very active child who likes to run and play, but during the past few weeks, he was reluctant to go out and play. The patient’s parent also noticed he was limping. He often complains of night pain, which his parents attributed to growing pain. They gave him some acetaminophen, which provided relief. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, there is tenderness over the lower part of the right fibula. The range of motion is full, and the rest of the physical exam is within normal limits. An x-ray is obtained and reveals a 1.5 cm lucent nidus surrounded by a rim of osteosclerotic reaction. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with pain that is relieved by medication and a characteristic nidus surrounded by a sclerotic bone rim, favoring the diagnosis of osteoid osteoma (OO).   

Both OO and osteoblastoma (OB) are types of benign bone producing tumors that share similar histologic features but differ clinically and exhibit different radiologic appearance. On histology, they are well-circumscribed and composed of haphazardly interconnecting delicate trabeculae with surrounding fibrovascular tissue. Osteoid osteomas also elicit reactive sclerosis which surrounds the lesion. Malignant transformation is rare.  



Option Analysis

✅ Osteoid osteoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Osteoblastoma :
Incorrect: Both osteoid osteoma and osteoblastoma are types of benign bone producing tumors that share similar histologic features but differ clinically and exhibit different radiologic appearance. Osteoblastoma typically occurs at the vertebrae, is larger than 2 cm, and is unresponsive to aspirin or other NSAIDs. Also, it does not cause a marked osteosclerotic reaction.  
❌ Ewing sarcoma:
Incorrect: Ewing sarcoma is a highly malignant tumor that accounts for approximately 10% of primary malignant bone tumors. The majority of Ewing sarcomas contain a balanced t(11;22) translocation. The tumor commonly affects children, 5 to 15 years of age. It usually arises in the diaphysis of long bones. Symptoms include bony pain, tissue swelling, fever, fatigue, weight loss, anemia, and pathologic fractures. On x-ray, it is seen as a large lytic lesion with a significant periosteal reaction deposited in an “onion-skin” or "moth-eaten" fashion. This patient’s age and tumor location favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Osteochondroma:
Incorrect: Osteochondroma (exostosis) is a benign overgrowth of cartilage which can be sessile or pedunculated. It typically arises in the metaphysis of long tubular bones and often around the knee. It occurs in individuals at ages 10-30 and is more common in men. Osteochondroma may cause pain if it impinges the surrounding tissue or nerve. It can occur as a single lesion or multiple as part of the multiple hereditary exostoses syndrome. This patient’s imaging findings suggest another diagnosis.  
❌ Osteosarcoma :
Incorrect: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the bone. The tumor produces an osteoid matrix or mineralized bone. Osteosarcoma has a bimodal age distribution, with a first peak seen in persons younger than 20 years of age and a smaller peak in older adults. In adolescents, it often arises in the metaphyseal regions of the distal femur and proximal tibia. Radiographs usually show a destructive, mixed lytic and sclerotic mass with reactive subperiosteal bone formation. This leads to the elevation of the periosteum and characteristic appearance known radiographically as Codman’s triangle (not pathognomonic). This patient’s presentation and imaging findings suggest another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy comes to the clinic because of progressively worsening dyspnea upon exertion and chest pain for the past 6 months. He has not had prior episodes of syncope, but he does describe moments in which he felt lightheaded and weak which improved with rest. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows an athletic young man in mild distress. Cardiac examination shows a 4/6 systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard between the apex and the left sternal border on auscultation. Palpation of the precordium leads to a sustained impulse best felt at the apex. Which of the following will most likely decrease the intensity of the murmur heard on the physical examination?
questions.solution:
This patient with dyspnea on exertion, chest pain, and a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard between the apex and left sternal border most likely has hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM). HOCM is characterized by concentric hypertrophy and growth of the interventricular septum near the mitral valve. Asymmetric growth of the septum leads to a left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction during systole that causes blood to flow quickly through a small opening. This rapid flow lowers the pressure in this area (Venturi effect) and pulls the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve toward the septum, worsening the obstruction.  

An increase in preload or afterload would decrease the obstruction and murmur. A decrease in preload or afterload would increase the obstruction and murmur. Squatting or handgrip decreases the obstruction by obstructing the femoral artery, increasing total peripheral resistance, and increasing afterload.  
 
HOCM is a familial, autosomal dominant condition. Sudden cardiac death can occur due to sustained ventricular arrhythmias; therefore, a family history of sudden cardiac death at a young age is a big clue suggesting HOCM, especially on USMLE exams. HOCM is associated with Friedreich's ataxia and mutations involving the beta-myosin heavy chain and myosin-binding protein C.  



Diagnosis may be achieved based on the constellation of symptoms, cardiomegaly on chest X-ray, genetic testing, enlarged heart chambers and decreased ejection fraction on echocardiography, and electrocardiogram (ECG) showing left ventricular hypertrophy. Gross pathology shows global hypertrophy and asymmetric septal hypertrophy on the left, whereas microscopically, there is myocyte hypertrophy and myocardial fiber disarray.  



HOCM should be treated urgently due to increased risk of syncope and SCD. Treatment includes β-blockers and non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers such as verapamil. These therapies are mainly directed at reducing LVOT obstruction; the reduced heart rates at rest and during exercise permits improved LV filling, which reduces LVOT obstruction. Additionally, the negative inotropy caused by these medications also alleviates LVOT obstruction.  

Option Analysis

❌ Diuretics:
Incorrect: Diuretics such as furosemide and hydrochlorothiazide act in the kidneys by increasing water excretion and decreasing preload. This effect would increase obstruction on the left ventricular outflow tract and increase the intensity of a hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur.   
❌ Nitroglycerin:
Incorrect: Nitroglycerin induces vasodilation and venodilation and decreases preload. This effect would increase obstruction on the left ventricular outflow tract and increase the intensity of a hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur.   
✅ Squatting :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Standing up:
Incorrect: Standing up decreases both preload and afterload. This effect would increase obstruction on the left ventricular outflow tract and increase the intensity of a hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur.   
❌ Valsalva maneuver :
Incorrect: The Valsalva maneuver, which is defined as forceful expiration against a closed airway, would decrease right ventricular filling and preload. This effect would increase obstruction on the left ventricular outflow tract and increase the intensity of a hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes for a follow-up meeting after she was diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma breast cancer. A 2-cm spiculated lesion was seen on mammography and confirmed with biopsy. She would like to know what the prognosis is for her condition. Which of the following findings is the worse prognostic factor for her conditions?
questions.solution:
A prognostic factor is able to provide information about the clinical outcome at the time of diagnosis, regardless of therapy. By contrast, a predictive factor is able to provide information on the response of a given therapeutic modality. For women with non-metastatic, newly diagnosed breast cancer the following factors are often used to determine the prognosis:    
  •  Age and race - Both younger (<35 years) and older age (>65 years) at the time of diagnosis is associated with a worse prognosis. Black women tend to have a worse prognosis compared to white women.  
  •  Pathologic factors include tumor stage, histological grade and tumor morphology. Breast cancer is staged according to tumor size, lymph nodes involvement, and metastatic disease (Tumor, Node, Metastasis [TNM] system). Tumor size < 2 cm and the absence of lymph node involvement or metastasis is associated with a better prognosis. In general, staging is considered a more important prognostic factor than grading, hence, among the answers above, a large tumor size is the worst prognostic factor. Tumor morphology is also important; for example, inflammatory breast cancer is associated with a poorer prognosis.  
  •  Tissue markers - Estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) expression are generally associated with better outcomes, while overexpression and/or amplification of human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) is associated with a poorer prognosis.  




Option Analysis

❌ HER2 receptor underexpression:
Incorrect: Human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) is part of the epidermal growth factor (EGF) family with tyrosine kinase activity that is involved in cell signaling and proliferation. Overexpression of HER2 is associated with poor prognosis, not underexpression.   
❌ High grade of cellular differentiation  :
Incorrect: Tumor grade refers to the degree of cellular differentiation and mitotic activity as seen on histology. It can range from low grade (well differentiated) to high grade (poorly differentiated, or anaplastic). A tumor that is poorly differentiated does not resemble the tissue of origin. However, although poorly differentiated tumors are associated with poor prognosis, staging is a more important prognostic factor.   
❌ High mitotic activity  :
Incorrect: Tumor grade refers to the degree of cellular differentiation and mitotic activity as seen on histology. It can range from low grade (low mitotic activity, well differentiated) to high grade (high mitotic activity, poorly differentiated or anaplastic). A tumor that has high mitotic activity is rapidly dividing, and therefore carries a worse prognosis. However, although poorly differentiated tumors are associated with poor prognosis, staging is a more important prognostic factor.   
✅ Large tumor size:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ 1:1 nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio:
Incorrect: Tumor grade refers to the degree of cellular differentiation and mitotic activity as seen on histology. It can range from low grade (well differentiated) to high grade (poorly differentiated or anaplastic). Anaplasia is the lack of differentiation. Anaplastic cells often display certain morphologic features including 1:1 nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, pleomorphism (size and shape), nuclear abnormalities, tumor giant cells, atypical mitoses, and loss of polarity. Although anaplastic tumors are associated with a poorer prognosis, staging is a more important prognostic factor.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to an itchy, oozing rash from the left nipple for the past few weeks. It first started as a small ulcer which then spread to the areola, with a copious clear yellowish exudative discharge. Medical history is significant for allergic rhinitis, for which she takes nasal corticosteroids and antihistamines as needed. She has tried some steroid cream, but she did not notice any improvement. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the left nipple is ulcerated and oozing yellowish fluid. There is no palpable mass, and the right nipple appears normal. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s skin condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with an ulcerated, oozing lesion of the nipple, raising concerns for an underlying condition. Although further evaluation is required for a definitive diagnosis, from the answers above, only underlying adenocarcinoma can present as Paget disease of the breast (PDB).  

PDB refers to a scaly, raw, vesicular, or ulcerated lesion affecting the nipple and areola as a direct extension of underlying ductal carcinoma in situ to the overlying skin. Nipple pain, nipple retraction, bloody discharge and/or pruritus may also be present. Some patients can present without a mammogram or mass on a physical exam. Patients should be evaluated with imaging and biopsy. Nipple scrape cytology is sufficient for diagnosis, but full-thickness wedge or punch biopsy of the nipple is often performed to establish the diagnosis. Wedge biopsy, which includes the lactiferous ducts, can help identify underlying ductal carcinoma as the etiology. The histologic hallmark of PDB is the presence of clusters of malignant, intraepithelial Paget cells (adenocarcinoma cells) within the epidermis of the nipple.  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons   

Option Analysis

❌ Intertrigo:
Incorrect: Intertrigo, or intertriginous dermatitis, is an inflammatory condition of skin folds characterized by moist, red-brown lesions that are accompanied by pruritus and tenderness. It is often caused by a candida yeast infection. This patient has no involvement of the skin folds, and intertrigo would be improved with topical steroid cream.   
❌ Mastitis :
Incorrect: Mastitis is an inflammation of the breast tissue that can occur in the setting of nipple injury from breastfeeding or inflammation of the subareolar ducts as periductal mastitis. Symptoms include pain, redness, fever, myalgia, with/without reactive axillary lymphadenopathy. Treatment involves symptomatic treatment, antibiotics, and continuation of breastfeeding. This patient has an oozing rash, which favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Eczema :
Incorrect: Eczema, or atopic dermatitis, is an inflammatory skin condition characterized by itchy, poorly-defined erythema with edema, vesicles, and oozing rash during the acute stage. Chronic inflammation ultimately results in skin thickening (lichenification). Although this patient’s rash can be explained by eczema, eczema has a predilection for the skin flexures rather than the nipple, and topical steroid cream usually improves the symptoms.   
✅ Adenocarcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intraductal papilloma:
Incorrect: Intraductal papilloma is a small fibroepithelial tumor that grows within lactiferous ducts, commonly, beneath the areola. It usually presents with serous or bloody nipple discharge. Intraductal papilloma is associated with a slight increase in risk for cancer. However, an intraductal papilloma would not explain this patient’s oozing, ulcerated lesion.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his roommate due to progressive dyspnea and chest tightness. A week ago, he had an upper viral respiratory infection that resolved spontaneously without treatment. The patient describes the chest pain as sharp, 7/10 in intensity, and relieved by leaning forward. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg. On physical examination, heart sounds are weak and jugular venous distention is present. During inspiration, a drop of 10 mmHg in the systolic pressure is noted. Which of the following can explain the drop in blood pressure observed in this patient?

choices.text: Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve
Beat-to-beat variation in the QRS complex

questions.solution:
This patient has muffled heart sounds, jugular venous distention, and hypotension (Beck’s triad), a presentation consistent with cardiac tamponade, most likely due to pericarditis secondary to a viral illness. Cardiac tamponade occurs when large amounts of fluid accumulates between the layers of the pericardium (pericardial effusion) resulting in external compression of the heart. Common etiologies include infectious, trauma, metabolic, autoimmune, cancer or idiopathic. The presentation may be acute and develop over minutes (e.g. trauma) or subacute, which develops over hours to days (e.g., uremia, post-viral) when enough fluid accumulates.  

Pulsus paradoxus is defined as a large decrease in systolic blood pressure (>10 mmHg) on inspiration, a finding often observed in cardiac tamponade; it is the direct consequence of ventricular interdependence. During inspiration, the fall in intrathoracic pressure produces a “sucking effect” which increases the venous return to the right heart. Under normal conditions, the pericardium can accommodate minor changes in heart volume with little impact on the left side of the heart. However, in conditions that limit the ability of the heart to expand (e.g., tamponade, constrictive pericarditis), the increased volume during inspiration causes bowing of the interventricular septum towards the left ventricle. This results in decreased end-diastolic volume (diastolic dysfunction) and lower stroke volume, manifested by a drop in systolic blood pressure.  







Option Analysis

✅ Ventricular interdependence:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve:
