Incorrect: Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve can be observed in hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM), the most common cause of death in young athletes. The anterior motion of the valve contributes to the left ventricular outlet obstruction seen in HOCM. This patient's presentation is instead consistent with cardiac tamponade.   
❌ Beat-to-beat variation in the QRS complex  :
Incorrect: Beat-to-beat variation in the QRS complex, also known as electrical alternans, is a typical ECG finding in patients with cardiac tamponade. It is a phenomenon that reflects the swinging of the heart in the pericardial fluid. It is not the cause of pulsus paradoxus.   
❌ Dilation of the aortic root:
Incorrect: Dilation of the aortic root is a possible cause of aortic regurgitation (AR). AR can present with a diastolic decrescendo murmur, hyperdynamic pulse, head bobbing, and widened pulse pressure. AR is not associated with pulsus paradoxus.    
❌ Dilated cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Viral myocarditis can cause dilated cardiomyopathy and subsequently heart failure. Symptoms of heart failure include progressive dyspnea, impaired exercise capacity, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and peripheral edema. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to chest pain that started 12 hours ago while watching television. The patient describes the pain as “heavy pressure” located in the center of the chest that radiates up to the neck and jaw. He states that the pain has waxed and waned, although he has felt some relief from taking sublingual nitroglycerin. Medical history is significant for coronary artery disease, stable angina, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient’s temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 135/93 mmHg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Chest x-ray shows no abnormalities, cardiac enzymes are negative, and ECG shows ST-segment depression in the anterior leads. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with substernal chest pain at rest, which has not improved completely with nitroglycerin, on a background history of stable angina. This change in his usual chest pain, as well as his ECG findings and negative cardiac biomarkers, all favor the diagnosis of unstable angina.   

Unstable angina is defined as an increase in frequency or intensity of prior chest pain (stable angina) or any chest pain at rest, and it usually lasts more than 20 minutes. Unstable angina is usually related to atherosclerotic plaque rupture leading to incomplete occlusion of the coronary arteries. ECG findings typically include ST-depression and/or T-wave inversion, but cardiac biomarkers are negative. Although unstable angina and non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) are treated the same, they differ primarily based on whether the ischemia is severe enough to cause the irreversible cellular injury (infarction) which causes cardiac biomarker release from myocytes. If cardiac biomarkers were elevated, the diagnosis would be an NSTEMI, which is not seen in this case.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Diffuse esophageal spasm:
Incorrect: Diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) is a neuromuscular disorder in which non-peristaltic contractions of the esophagus cause chest pain. Patients typically complain of dysphagia, heartburn, and regurgitation. Manometry shows non-peristaltic, uncoordinated esophageal contractions, and barium swallow test shows a “corkscrew” pattern. Although DES also causes chest pain, it does not cause ECG changes, and this patient has no history of dysphagia.   
❌ Non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction  :
Incorrect: Both unstable angina and non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) are caused by atherosclerotic plaque rupture and present with ST-segment depression on ECG; however, unlike unstable angina, NSTEMI is associated with an increase in troponins and other cardiac enzymes. This patient had negative cardiac biomarkers.   
❌ Prinzmetal angina  :
Incorrect: Vasospastic angina (formerly “Prinzmetal angina”) is a clinical entity characterized by episodic chest pain attributable to coronary artery vasospasm, resulting in obstruction. These episodes are not related to increased myocardial oxygen demand, such as exertion. Instead, common triggers include use of alcohol, tobacco, cocaine and triptans. ECG typically shows ST-segment elevation with negative cardiac biomarkers. This patient has a history of stable angina and multiple coronary artery disease risk factors, favoring another diagnosis.  
❌ Stable angina:
Incorrect: Stable angina is ischemic chest pain that occurs with exertion and abates with rest or nitroglycerin. Unless an electrocardiogram (ECG) is done at the time of chest pain, there are very rarely ECG changes. Cardiac biomarkers are negative. This patient’s pain occurred at rest, and his pain did not abate with nitroglycerin, which favors another diagnosis.   
✅ Unstable angina:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 72-year-old hospitalized man is evaluated for abdominal pain, jaundice, and fever. He was admitted two weeks ago for coronary artery bypass surgery, which was complicated by mediastinitis. He underwent surgical debridement and is now receiving IV antibiotics and total parenteral nutrition. Medical history is significant for hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and congestive heart failure. He has had no history of gallstones or abdominal pain. For the past 24 hours, the patient has been experiencing fever, abdominal pain, right shoulder pain, nausea, and vomiting. Today, the nurse noticed he began to develop mild jaundice of the skin. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. BMI is 35 kg/m2. Leukocyte count is 17,000 mm3. During imaging, respiratory arrest is observed when the ultrasound probe is applied over the right subcostal area; ultrasound results are equivocal due to body habitus. Laparoscopic surgery is planned. Which of the following set of findings is most likely to be seen in this patient during surgery?

choices.text: Fibrosed and thickened gallbladder; cholesterol gallstones

questions.solution:
This severely ill patient, now presenting with fever, jaundice, leukocytosis, and abdominal pain with positive sonographic Murphy sign, is most likely suffering from acalculous cholecystitis.  

Acalculous cholecystitis (a-calculous = no stone) refers to an acute necroinflammatory disease of the gallbladder in the absence of gallstones due to various causes. The condition is associated with high morbidity and mortality rates. It is thought to occur due to gallbladder stasis and ischemia, leading to a local inflammatory response of the gallbladder wall. Risk factors include causes of gallbladder stasis:  

  •  Infections (e.g. CMV) 
  •  Immunosuppression (e.g. AIDS) 
  •  Trauma  
  •  Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) 
  •  Sepsis 
  •  Burns 
It is commonly seen in critically ill patients, as seen here. The clinical presentation varies and depends on the severity of illness and underlying condition. Patients may present with unexplained fever or classic right upper abdominal pain associated with jaundice. Laboratory tests are non-specific, but leukocytosis is present in the majority of the cases. Abnormal liver tests with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, mild increase in serum alkaline phosphatase and serum aminotransferases can also be seen. Complications of acalculous cholecystitis include emphysematous cholecystitis, gangrene, and perforation. Treatment of acalculous cholecystitis consists of supportive care with intravenous fluids, pain control, and antibiotics, followed by definitive therapy with either gallbladder drainage (cholecystostomy) or cholecystectomy.    

Option Analysis

❌ Gallbladder inflammation; pigment gallstones:
Incorrect: Pigment stones can be either black, due hemolysis, or brown, due to a liver fluke. Both can cause cholecystitis; however, this patient has no history of hemolysis or travel to endemic areas with liver fluke (Asia). In addition, this patient is severely ill and receiving total parenteral nutrition, favoring another diagnosis.
❌ Gallbladder inflammation; cholesterol gallstones:
Incorrect: Cholesterol gallstones are the most common cause of cholecystitis. Risk factors for cholesterol gallstones include obesity, Crohn disease, advanced age, estrogen therapy, multiparity, and rapid weight loss. Although the patient has some of the risk factors for cholesterol gallstones, he has no prior history. Also, this patient is severely ill and receiving total parenteral nutrition, favoring another diagnosis.
✅ Gallbladder inflammation; no gallstones:
Correct: See main explanation.
❌ Porcelain gallbladder; cholesterol gallstones:
Incorrect: Porcelain gallbladder is caused by calcification of the gallbladder due to chronic cholecystitis and is usually found incidentally on imaging. Patients are often asymptomatic. It has been associated with increased risk for gallbladder cancer (mostly adenocarcinoma).
❌ Fibrosed and thickened gallbladder; cholesterol gallstones :
Incorrect: Fibrosis and thickening gallbladder can be seen in chronic cholecystitis. It is thought to be the result of mechanical irritation or recurrent attacks of acute cholecystitis, leading to fibrosis and thickening of the gallbladder wall. However, its presence does not always correlate with symptoms.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a near syncopal episode. The patient was outside mowing the lawn when he felt sudden-onset light-headedness, dizziness, and palpitations. The symptoms lasted approximately 30 seconds. He has no significant medical history and does not take any medications. The patient was adopted and does not know his biological family’s past medical history. Vitals are within normal limits, and cardiopulmonary exam is without evidence of gallops, rubs, or murmurs. The initial electrocardiogram is demonstrated below.  

 


Which of the following best describes the inheritance pattern of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This otherwise healthy male presents after a near syncopal episode with associated light-headedness, dizziness, and palpitations. The electrocardiogram demonstrates a prolonged QT interval of approximately 640 ms. These findings are concerning for the disorder Romano-Ward syndrome, which is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion.   

There are multiple inherited QT prolongation syndromes, although the two most common are Romano-Ward syndrome and Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome. Both diseases are due to potassium or sodium channelopathies, which result in abnormal flow and transport of these positively charged ions during repolarization of the action potential, resulting in QT prolongation. Under cardiac stress, or with an additional QT prolongation insult (e.g. concomitant use of QT prolonging medication), patients with these disorders can degenerate into dangerous arrhythmias such as polymorphic ventricular tachycardia, ventricular fibrillation, and sudden cardiac death.   

These disorders may present similarly, with some patients being discovered incidentally on routine ECG testing or after a presyncopal/syncopal episode. These disorders can be differentiated by the presence of sensorineural hearing loss, which is only present with Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome. Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, whereas Romano-Ward syndrome is inherited in autosomal dominant fashion.   

Option Analysis

✅ Autosomal dominant:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ X-linked recessive:
Incorrect: QT prolongation syndromes are inherited in an autosomal dominant or autosomal recessive fashion. Examples of X-linked recessive diseases include Fabry disease, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, Hemophilia A and B, as well as Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophy.   
❌ Autosomal recessive:
Incorrect: Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome is an inherited QT prolongation syndrome. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion. Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome can be differentiated from the more common Romano-Ward syndrome by a clinical history of sensorineural hearing loss, which this patient lacks.   
❌ X-linked dominant :
Incorrect: Disorders that are x-linked dominant include Alport syndrome, Rett syndrome, and Fragile X syndrome. QT prolongation syndromes are not typically inherited in a X-linked autosomal dominant pattern.  
❌ Mitochondrial :
Incorrect: Inherited mitochondrial disorders include neurodegenerative diseases as well as inherited forms of cardiovascular disease. In contrast, QT prolongation syndromes are not typically inherited in this pattern.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parent due to acute-onset wheezing and shortness of breath. The patient was visiting her neighbor, who recently got a pet kitten, when she suddenly started feeling short of breath. Past medical history is significant for asthma, and she has normally found relief after using an albuterol inhaler. However, the inhaler has been ineffective during the current episode. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Physical examination reveals accessory muscle use while breathing. Diffuse expiratory wheezes are heard bilaterally on chest auscultation. The patient is re-evaluated in 10 minutes. Which of the following findings, if present on repeat examination, is most concerning for impending respiratory failure?

choices.text: Drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration

questions.solution:
Asthma is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the airways that causes recurrent episodes of wheezing, dyspnea, chest tightness, and cough. Asthma typically presents as an episodic disorder caused by inflammation and hyperresponsiveness of the bronchial smooth muscle, leading to reversible bronchoconstriction. Although the specific causes of asthma are ultimately unknown, it is thought to be due to a combination of genetic and environmental factors (e.g., air pollution, cigarette smoke, allergens).  

An asthma attack is characterized by severe dyspnea and wheezing due to bronchoconstriction and mucus plugging, which leads to trapping of air in distal airways with progressive hyperinflation of the lungs. Most cases of asthma exacerbations can be treated with bronchodilators (e.g. albuterol) and glucocorticoids. In rare cases, patients with attacks refractory to treatment may show signs of impending respiratory failure such as absence of breath sounds due to respiratory fatigue, inappropriately low respiratory rate, and depressed mental status (lethargy or agitation) due to increasing partial pressure of carbon dioxide. These patients require immediate intubation and ventilatory support.  



Option Analysis

✅ Absent wheezing :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Tachypnea:
Incorrect: Tachypnea is a common finding in patients with mild to severe asthma exacerbations. In contrast, decreasing respiratory rate is suggestive of imminent respiratory arrest due to respiratory muscle fatigue. 
❌ Wheezing throughout expiration and inspiration:
Incorrect: Asthma exacerbations occur due to widespread bronchoconstriction. Narrowing of the airway lumen can cause wheezing, which is more commonly heard on expiration. Inspiratory and expiratory wheezing is suggestive of a severe asthma exacerbation. However, another clinical finding is more suggestive of imminent respiratory arrest.
❌ Accessory muscle use:
Incorrect: The use of respiratory accessory muscles is usually seen in moderate and severe cases of asthma exacerbations. However, another clinical finding is more suggestive of imminent respiratory arrest.
❌ Drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration :
Incorrect: Pulsus paradoxus may be seen in cases of severe asthma; this is caused by a drop in intrathoracic pressure during inspiration, which leads to pooling of blood in the pulmonary vasculature, decrease in left ventricular preload, and subsequent drop in blood pressure. In contrast, it is the absence of pulsus paradoxus that is concerning for impending respiratory failure secondary to respiratory muscle fatigue.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of fatigue for the last several weeks. He has been feeling dizzy and short of breath when climbing the stairs to his 2nd-floor apartment. He has not visited a physician in years because he has “always felt healthy.” He has no paresthesias, cognitive impairment, joint pains, or abnormal bleeding episodes. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 144/88 mmHg. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. The neck is nontender, and no mass is palpated. Oropharyngeal examination reveals an enlarged, erythematous tongue, and no gingival pigmentation is noted. Laboratory investigations show a hemoglobin level of 9.9 g/dL. A stool guaiac test is positive. Which of the following is the likely pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Impaired heme synthesis due to decreased substrate availability
Impaired heme synthesis due to enzyme inhibition

questions.solution:
This elderly male is presenting with fatigue and dyspnea, along with physical examination findings of conjunctival pallor and glossitis. The low hemoglobin and positive fecal occult blood test (FOBT) raise concern for iron-deficiency anemia secondary to an underlying gastrointestinal malignancy. Given this patient has not visited a physician in many years, he likely missed opportunities to be screened for colon cancer via colonoscopy.  

Iron is an integral substrate involved in the synthesis of heme. Therefore, chronic blood loss (e.g., colon cancer, bleeding gastric ulcers, heavy menstruation) can result in iron-deficiency anemia. Iron-deficiency anemia can also be caused by reduced intake (e.g. vegan diet), reduced absorption (e.g., inflammatory bowel disease, celiac disease), and increased demand (e.g. pregnancy)  

Regardless of the cause, laboratory testing in patients with iron-deficiency anemia will demonstrate decreased hemoglobin levels, microcytosis (decreased mean corpuscular volume), hypochromia (decreased mean corpuscular hemoglobin), and decreased reticulocyte count.   




Image reproduced from Flickr

Option Analysis

✅ Impaired heme synthesis due to decreased substrate availability:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Overproduction of cytokines:
Incorrect: Anemia of chronic disease typically occurs in chronic inflammatory states (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus) or in cases of underlying malignancies (e.g., lymphoma, lung cancer). During these chronic states of inflammation, there is increased production of cytokines, in particular hepcidin. Hepcidin causes reduced iron uptake from the gastrointestinal tract, as well as decreased release of iron from macrophages. Although this patient likely has an underlying malignancy, another cause of anemia is more probable. 
❌ Defective globin synthesis :
Incorrect: Thalassemias are characterized by defective globin chain production, which results in faulty hemoglobin, ultimately leading to anemia. Based on the globin chain that is affected, thalassemias can be classified as either alpha or beta. Although thalassemias can cause anemia, this patient’s positive stool guaiac test raises greater concern for iron deficiency secondary to an underlying malignancy.
❌ Impaired heme synthesis due to enzyme inhibition :
Incorrect: Lead poisoning can cause anemia by inhibiting ferrochelatase and ALA dehydratase, two vital enzymes involved in heme synthesis. Lead poisoning typically presents with nervous system involvement, notably polyneuropathy and encephalopathy. This patient lacks any significant exposure to lead, lacks paresthesias or cognitive impairment, and has no pigmentation of the gums (termed lead line). As a result, lead poisoning is unlikely in this patient.
❌ Destruction of myeloid stem cells :
Incorrect: Aplastic anemia is characterized by failure or destruction of myeloid stem cells. This loss typically results in pancytopenia, which is characterized by anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia since the stem cell precursor for all 3 lineages is destroyed. Thrombocytopenia can present as spontaneous purpura, petechiae, and mucosal bleeding. Leukopenia can present as recurrent infections. Although this patient has signs of anemia, he lacks signs of thrombocytopenia or leukopenia.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man comes to the office because of progressive lower back pain. He first noticed the pain a few months ago at the grocery store. It is most severe at night and is not relieved by rest, exercise, medication or change in position. He has not had any recent trauma. He also reports difficulty initiating urination and dysuria for the past 6 months. He is a retired veteran and lives alone. Past medical history is noncontributory. Family history is significant for colorectal cancer in his father. Vitals are within normal limits. Neurological examination and straight leg raise test are normal. MRI of the lumbar spine is performed and shown below:  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  

Further evaluation of this patient will most likely show which of the following?

choices.text: Irregular prostate on digital rectal examination

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with chronic back pain which is worse at night, not relieved by rest or change in position, in combination with lower urinary tract symptoms and MRI showing vertebral metastases is consistent with metastatic prostate adenocarcinoma. 

Prostate adenocarcinoma is among the most common cancers in men worldwide and is more commonly seen in patients of African-American descent. The risk of developing prostate cancer increases with age, peaking between ages 65 and 74 years. Most prostate cancers are asymptomatic at the time of diagnosis but may present with non-specific urinary symptoms (hematuria, difficulty initiating urine, dysuria and pain with ejaculation) and back pain (in advanced, metastatic disease). Bone metastases in men with advanced prostate cancer are usually osteoblastic (i.e. characterized by new bone formation). This finding is indicated by the red arrows in the MRI. The precise mechanisms by which prostate cancer tumor cells induce osteoblastic changes are uncertain but are believed to involve excess activation of osteoblast mitogens that induce bone growth.    

A nodular, asymmetric or indurated posterior prostate is observed on digital rectal exam (DRE). Peripheral posterior prostate (away from the urethra) is the most common location for prostate cancers; this phenomenon is the reason urinary symptoms occur late in the disease course, when the periurethral region becomes involved. Serum prostate specific antigen (PSA) may be elevated but is not specific for malignancy.  

 




Option Analysis

❌ Paraspinal tenderness:
Incorrect: Paraspinal tenderness is commonly observed in lumbosacral strain, wherein the back pain is aggravated by physical exertion and relieved with rest and pain medications like nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
✅ Irregular prostate on digital rectal examination:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Reduced chest expansion:
Incorrect: Reduced chest expansion is a complication of ankylosing spondylitis. It causes chronic back pain in young adults which is relieved with exercise. It is unlikely in this elderly patient with lower urinary tract symptoms.
❌ Perianal anesthesia:
Incorrect: Perianal anesthesia is a clinical finding of cauda equina syndrome and other neurologic diseases involving the sacral spinal roots. It is a surgical emergency and is associated with marked neurologic disability (bilateral leg weakness, bladder bowel and sexual dysfunction). Straight leg raise is typically positive.
❌ Inguinal lymphadenopathy:
Incorrect: Inguinal lymphadenopathy is common in lower extremity infections, sexually transmitted diseases or cancers. Common associated cancers include skin of the trunk, rectum, anus and penis. The prostate gland drains into the iliac and paraaortic nodes, not inguinal nodes.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old female presents to the emergency department with a worsening cough, shortness of breath, and night sweats. In addition, the patient has experienced a 10 lb weight loss over the past 2 months despite having made no changes to her diet. She was recently released from incarceration and smokes one pack of cigarettes per day. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient was born in Mexico and had a positive PPD test as an adolescent. Chest x-ray is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  

Which of the following best describes the radiographic finding above?

choices.text: Calcified mycobacterial lesion and bilateral calcified hilar lymph nodes
Hilar lymphadenopathy and a primary focus of mycobacterial infection
Fibrocaseous cavitary lesion in the upper lobes

questions.solution:
This patient has findings concerning for pulmonary tuberculosis including night sweats, fevers, and cough. The chest x-ray demonstrates a calcified lesion in the axillary region of the right lung field and ipsilateral calcified hilar lymph nodes, which is referred to as a Ranke complex.   

There are three progressive lesions noted in pulmonary tuberculosis: Ghon focus, Ghon complex, and Ranke Complex. A Ghon focus appears first and is characterized by a primary granulomatous infection filled with mycobacteria. As mycobacteria escape into nearby pulmonary lymph nodes, they enlarge and can become radiographically apparent. Together, a Ghon focus and hilar lymphadenopathy is referred to as a Ghon complex and is typical of primary pulmonary tuberculosis. Over time, the Ghon complex scars, becomes calcified, and is even more radiographically apparent. This pathologic variant is then referred to as a Ranke complex, which generally contains less mycobacteria than a Ghon complex but can still yield features of active pulmonary tuberculosis.  

Figure 1: Calcified granuloma (circle) and calcified hilar lymph nodes (arrows) consistent with Ranke complex


Option Analysis

✅ Calcified mycobacterial lesion and bilateral calcified hilar lymph nodes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hilar lymphadenopathy and a primary focus of mycobacterial infection:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the findings associated with a Ghon complex, which is associated with primary pulmonary tuberculosis and is the precursor to a Ranke complex. However, this patient has a calcified granuloma in the axillary region of the right lung field and calcified right hilar lymph nodes, which is more consistent with the presentation of a Ranke complex.
❌ Primary focus of mycobacterial infection :
Incorrect: A primary focus of mycobacterial infection is referred to as a Ghon focus. It is essentially a granuloma filled with mycobacteria. This pathologic feature is usually not visible on plain radiographs unless it becomes large. In contrast, this patient has a calcified granuloma in the axillary region of the right lung field and calcified right hilar lymph nodes, which is more consistent with the presentation of a Ranke complex.
❌ Cavitary caseating lesion:
Incorrect: Cavitary necrotic tuberculous lesions more typically occur due to secondary tuberculosis. Radiographically they appear as a hyperlucent region of the lung contained within a consolidation or mass.  
❌ Fibrocaseous cavitary lesion in the upper lobes:
Incorrect: A lesion of the upper lobes of the lung is more indicative of secondary or reactivation tuberculosis. Typically, patients will have a history of untreated tuberculosis with recrudescent symptoms.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 1, presents to the office with complaints of abnormal vaginal bleeding for the past two days. The patient states that she soaked 4 sanitary pads yesterday. Menarche was at age 14, and her menstrual periods had been irregular for the last few years before menopause, which she underwent at the age of 51. Past medical history is significant for generalized anxiety disorder managed by paroxetine for the last 15 years. Family history is significant for diabetes mellitus in her father and hypertension in her paternal grandmother. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 33.5 kg/m2. Pelvic examination shows blood clots in the vagina. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Endometrial biopsy is shown below:    


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following risk factors in this patient’s history is the most significant in the development of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with obesity (BMI 33.5 kg/m2) with postmenopausal bleeding and endometrial biopsy findings of glandular hyperplasia and nuclear atypia is most likely suffering from endometrial hyperplasia.  

Endometrial hyperplasia is defined as the proliferation of endometrial glands that results in an increased number of glands relative to the stroma as compared to normal endometrium. It occurs when there is an increase in estrogen levels without accompanying increase in progesterone. Obesity is a significant risk factor for this condition because it increases the conversion of androgens into estrogens. Other common risk factors include causes that result in increased exposure to estrogen, such as:  

  •  early menarche 
  •  late menopause 
  •  chronic anovulation 
  •  nulliparity 
  •  estrogen-producing tumors  
  •  certain medications, such as tamoxifen or estrogen-only hormone replacement therapy. 
Endometrial hyperplasia increases the risk of developing endometrial cancer. Histologically, hyperplasia can be divided into simple, which consists of glands that are only mildly crowded with occasional outpouching, or complex, in which gland-to-stroma ratio is higher and glands appear disorganized with frequent luminal out-pouching. Cells lining the glands may show nuclear atypia, characterized by enlarged nuclei with hyper-chromatic nucleoli. Nuclear atypia is the most important factor for the progression to endometrial carcinoma.


Simple hyperplasia (Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons)


Complex hyperplasia (Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons)  

Option Analysis

❌ Age of menarche:
Incorrect: Early age of menarche is a risk factor of endometrial hyperplasia due to increased number of menstrual cycles, meaning increased estrogenic stimulation of the endometrium. This patient’s menarche occurred at the appropriate age.
❌ Age of menopause:
Incorrect: Late age of menopause is a risk factor for endometrial hyperplasia due to increased number of menstrual cycles, meaning increased estrogenic stimulation of the endometrium. This patient’s menopause occurred at the appropriate age.
✅ Body mass index:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Family history of diabetes:
Incorrect: Personal history, rather than family history, of diabetes is a risk factor for endometrial hyperplasia. This phenomenon is likely caused by hyperinsulinemia, which triggers endometrial growth. This patient does not have diabetes. 
❌ Paroxetine:
Incorrect: Medications that increase the risk of endometrial hyperplasia include estrogen stimulating agents like tamoxifen and estrogen-only hormone replacement therapy. Paroxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) and has no effect on the endometrium.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic because of increasing abdominal girth and constipation for the past 3 months. She reports no associated nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain or abnormal vaginal bleeding. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She is sexually active with one male partner and denies any pain during intercourse. Past medical and surgical history is unremarkable. Current medications include combined oral contraceptives and multivitamins. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an enlarged, mobile, nontender, irregular uterus corresponding to 12-week sized gestation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with bulk related symptoms (constipation) and an irregularly enlarged (12-week sized) uterus is consistent with uterine leiomyoma.  

Uterine leiomyoma (fibroids) are noncancerous monoclonal tumors of uterine smooth muscle cells. They are the most common pelvic tumor in females, with dominance among women of African descent. The tumor upregulates estrogen and progesterone receptors and increases the production of myometrial aromatase, promoting its growth on stimulation by these hormones, which is why it typically affects pre-menopausal women, grows rapidly during pregnancy, and is more common in nulliparous women. It usually presents with heavy and/or prolonged menstrual bleeding, bulk-related symptoms (constipation, urinary incontinence, and pelvic pain), and reproductive dysfunction. The symptoms, however, may vary based on the location and size of the fibroid(s).  


Physical examination typically shows an enlarged, mobile and irregular uterus. Occasionally, fibroids undergo degeneration or torsion (common during pregnancy) resulting in an acute abdomen, low-grade fever ,and uterine tenderness. Additionally, they can sometimes distort the uterine cavity, causing infertility or increasing the risk of miscarriage.  

Option Analysis

✅ Uterine leiomyoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Adenomyosis:
Incorrect: Adenomyosis usually presents with abnormal uterine bleeding, painful menses, pelvic pain and a uniformly enlarged boggy uterus. This patient’s bulk related symptoms (constipation) and an irregularly enlarged uterus would be atypical.          
❌ Pregnancy:
Incorrect: Although pregnancy should be excluded (using urine β-hCG) in all women of reproductive age with abdominal distension, this patient’s symptom duration, recent menstruation, and contraceptive history makes pregnancy unlikely.
❌ Hypothyroidism:
Incorrect: Although hypothyroidism may present with increased abdominal girth and constipation, the presence of an irregularly enlarged uterus and absence of other symptoms of hypothyroidism (fatigue, cold intolerance, goiter) makes this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Endometriosis:
Incorrect: Endometriosis involving the rectovaginal septum or bowel can present with constipation. However, a fixed uterus with posterior cul-de-sac nodularity is usually observed. An irregularly enlarged uterus is not usually seen.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to altered mental status and headaches for the past day. His roommate states that he was in his usual state until yesterday, when he started complaining of headaches, fever, and abnormal behavior. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 124/80 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is lethargic but arousable. The neck is supple with full range of motion. The patient responds to questions, but the speech is incomprehensible. Hyperreflexia is present. MRI of the head shows edema and hyperintensities in the temporal lobes. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with nonspecific symptoms such as fever and headache, which raises concern for a central nervous system (CNS) infection. The presence of altered mentation and incomprehensible speech imply the involvement of the brain parenchyma and favors the diagnosis of encephalitis.   

Encephalitis refers to the inflammation of the brain parenchyma that leads to neurologic dysfunction, including altered mental status (behavior or personality), motor or sensory deficits, and speech or movement disorders. Encephalitis may be caused by viruses, bacteria, parasites, autoimmune conditions, etc. Abnormal brain function helps to distinguish encephalitis from meningitis. Additionally, imaging (specifically an MRI) can help determine specific etiologies; this patient’s MRI shows temporal lobe irregularities, suggesting herpes simplex encephalitis as the potential diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Meningitis :
Incorrect: Meningitis refers to inflammation of the brain meninges, which manifests by cerebrospinal fluid pleocytosis. Meningitis typically presents with meningeal signs (e.g., nuchal rigidity, positive Brudzinski sign); additionally, the presence of altered mentation in this case favors another diagnosis. 
❌ Aseptic meningitis:
Incorrect: Aseptic meningitis refers to patients who present with clinical signs and laboratory evidence of meningeal inflammation but have negative routine bacterial cultures. The most common cause of aseptic meningitis is the enteroviruses family. Meningitis typically presents with meningeal signs (e.g., nuchal rigidity, positive Brudzinski sign); additionally, the presence of altered mentation in this case favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Brain abscess:
Incorrect: A brain abscess is a collection of pus within the brain parenchyma which can occur from direct spread of infection or from bacteremia, trauma, or surgery. Classic presentation may include headache, fever, and focal neurologic deficits. However, the head MRI showing temporal lobe irregularities in this case favors another diagnosis. 
✅ Encephalitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Myelitis :
Incorrect: Myelitis refers to the inflammation of the spinal cord, which may manifest as weakness, bladder dysfunction, flaccid paralysis, and weak/absent reflexes. This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 2-day-old male newborn is being evaluated in the neonatal intensive care unit for progressive cyanosis, breathing difficulty and poor feeding. He was born to a 22-year-old mother who received no prenatal care. Temperature is 37.0° C (98.6° F), pulse is 160/min, blood pressure is 87/55 mm Hg, and respiration rate is 55/min. On physical examination, no craniofacial deformities are seen. Central cyanosis is present, and cardiac auscultation reveals fixed splitting of the second heart sound (S2) over the left upper sternal border. Chest radiograph is obtained and shown below:  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia    
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This newborn infant presents with progressive cyanosis, breathing difficulty and poor feeding, as well as a classic chest radiograph showing a “snowman sign.” He most likely has total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR).  

TAPVR is cyanotic heart disease of the newborn in which all four pulmonary veins fail to make their normal connection to the left atrium and instead drain into the systemic venous circulation. The clinical manifestations vary and mainly depend upon the presence and degree of pulmonary venous obstruction and interatrial communication. For the condition to be compatible with life, there is a need for a right to left shunt such as ASD or PDA. Without treatment, the survival rate is poor, with a mortality rate of 80% by 1 year of age.  

This classic chest radiograph shows “snowman sign” (figure of 8) due to dilation of the superior vena cava, pulmonary vein, and brachiocephalic artery which forms the snowman's “head,” while the dilated right atrium forms the snowman's “body.”  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia    

On physical examination, a fixed split second heart sound (S2) is heard due to right ventricular overload, which delays the pulmonary valve closure. Other physical findings include hepatomegaly (due to right-sided failure), tachypnea, and cyanosis. Diagnosis is generally made by echocardiography, and initial medical management is focused on stabilization of the patients prior to surgical correction.  

Option Analysis

❌ D-transposition of the great vessels:
Incorrect: D-transposition of the great vessels (D-TGA) is another cause of cyanotic heart disease of the newborn in which the aorta arises from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. This dual circulation is incompatible with life unless there is communication between the two parallel circuits, such as a ventricular septal defect (VSD), atrial septal defect (ASD) or patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). D-TGA often presents with a classic chest radiograph revealing an “egg on a string” appearance rather than the “snowman sign” seen in this patient. 
❌ Persistent truncus arteriosus:
Incorrect: Persistent truncus arteriosus (TA) is another cause of cyanotic heart disease of the newborn, in which there is a failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to form, resulting in a common arterial trunk. Chest radiography in TA typically shows cardiac enlargement and increased pulmonary vascular markings, rather than the “snowman sign” seen in this patient. Other findings of TA include prominent second heart sounds, ejection clink, and bounding pulses. TA is also often associated with DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion), and other features would be expected.
✅ Total anomalous pulmonary venous return:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Tetralogy of Fallot:
Incorrect: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is another cause of cyanotic heart disease of the newborn, and it includes the following features: pulmonary infundibular stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, overriding aorta, ventricular septal defect. The classic chest radiograph of a patient with TOF depicts a "boot-shaped" heart with an upturned apex rather than the “snowman sign” seen in this patient. Also, the murmur of TOF is typically a harsh systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur. TOF is often associated with DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion), and other craniofacial features would be expected.
❌ Tricuspid atresia:
Incorrect: Tricuspid atresia is another cause of cyanotic heart disease of the newborn, and it is characterized by congenital agenesis or absence of the tricuspid valve. On chest radiograph, the smooth convexity of the right heart border is absent, and the right heart border does not cross beyond the spine. On auscultation, a single second heart sound (S2) is heard, rather than fixed splitting.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to irritability, low mood and abnormal movements of the arms. She has worked as a banker for many years, and over the past several months, she has been receiving poor performance reviews. The patient also describes a jerking movement of the right hand that has been progressively worsening in the past few months. Medical history is unremarkable. The patient mentions her father had some conditions which she cannot recall, and he committed suicide at the age of 61. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient appears anxious with a low mood. The patient is unable to sit still during the examination and makes repetitive, involuntary movements that are prominent in both the arms and hands. Which of the following will most likely help in establishing the diagnosis of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain

questions.solution:
The presence of depression, personality changes, cognitive decline, and chorea, in light of this patient’s father's unknown medical condition, raises concern for Huntington disease (HD).  

The diagnosis of HD is based upon the common clinical features, positive family history (such as this patient’s father who committed suicide, likely secondary to neuropsychiatric problems secondary to HD), and genetic confirmation demonstrating the cytosine-adenine-guanine (CAG) trinucleotide expansion of ≥36 repeats in the HTT gene on chromosome 4. Of these, genetic testing is sensitive and specific for HD and allows easy confirmation of atypical patients.  

HD is an autosomal dominant progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by choreiform movements, neuropsychiatric problems, and early dementia. The underlying pathophysiology is an increased number of CAG repeats in the huntingtin (HTT) gene on chromosome 4. Mutant huntingtin contains an expanded tract of glutamine residues which results in an abnormal protein toxic to neurons. The condition is characterized by anticipation, which refers to increased severity and earlier onset in succeeding generations due to expansion of CAG repeats. On brain imaging, atrophy of the caudate and putamen with ex vacuo ventriculomegaly can be seen. The latter refers to the apparent enlargement of the ventricles when the brain itself is actually atrophied. Symptoms manifest between the ages of 20 and 50 and include chorea, athetosis (slow, involuntary, writhing movements of the extremities), aggression, depression, and dementia. There is no cure for Huntington disease, and treatment is aimed to control the symptoms.  

 

PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.

Option Analysis

❌ Lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: Cerebrospinal (CSF) analysis and detection of 14-3-3 protein is an adjunctive test used for the diagnosis of prion diseases (e.g. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease). It has no role in establishing the diagnosis of Huntington disease.
❌ Brain biopsy:
Incorrect: Brain biopsy and neuropathologic examination is the gold-standard diagnostic test for Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease; however, it is rarely used because of the invasiveness, and a probable diagnosis of sporadic CJD can be made with noninvasive testing. Biopsy has no role in establishing the diagnosis of Huntington disease.
❌ Family history and physical examination:
Incorrect: Family history and physical examination is important for establishing the diagnosis of Huntington disease; however, it will not confirm the diagnosis -- whereas Parkinson disease, for example, is mainly a clinical diagnosis (i.e. the diagnosis is dependent on the patient’s history and physical examination). 
✅ Genetic testing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain:
Incorrect: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain can help in the diagnosis of Huntington disease by demonstrating caudate atrophy and by excluding other conditions. However, caudate atrophy occurs late in the course, and it will not confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to sleeping disturbances for the past 2 months. The patient reports an uncomfortable sensation of the legs that occurs especially at night or during prolonged inactivity. She describes the sensation as a “crawling” and “tingling” sensation which makes her wake up multiple times throughout the night. After waking up, walking and moving her legs provides temporary relief. Medical history is significant for hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2. The patient’s most recent HbA1C was 7.0% one month ago. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows bilateral flat foot, for which she uses orthoses. Monofilament examination of the foot is within normal limits. Achilles reflex is 2+ bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has restless legs syndrome (RLS), a sleep-related movement disorder characterized by an unpleasant or uncomfortable urge to move the legs that occurs particularly during the evening and times of inactivity which is transiently relieved by movement.  

The pathophysiology of RLS remains incompletely understood, but studies have identified central and peripheral nervous system abnormalities in patients with the disorder. Currently, there is no evidence that neurodegeneration plays a role in RLS. Risk factors include positive family history, sleep deprivation, iron deficiency, uremia secondary to renal failure, spinal cord disease, pregnancy, multiple sclerosis, and Parkinson disease. RLS is a clinical diagnosis and no additional testing is required, with the exception of iron stores evaluation (all patients) and blood urea nitrogen and creatinine if uremia is suspected.  

Mild symptoms may be addressed with behavioral strategies (e.g., exercise, reduced caffeine intake) and avoidance of aggravating factors (e.g. sleep deprivation). However, more severe symptoms that do not respond to nonpharmacologic therapy and correction of iron deficiency require pharmacological intervention such as dopamine agonists (e.g. pramipexole).

 

Option Analysis

❌ Akathisia :
Incorrect: Akathisia refers to an inner sense of restlessness that manifests as an intense desire to move. The restlessness is typically generalized but may be more prominent in the legs; however, complaints of paresthesias and other unpleasant sensations are uncommon.   
❌ Diabetic neuropathy:
Incorrect: Diabetic neuropathies are caused by microvascular injury involving small blood vessels that supply nerves (vasa nervorum). Patients often present with negative symptoms (e.g., numbness, weakness) and positive symptoms (e.g., tingling, pain). Physical examination typically shows "stocking-glove" sensory loss, decreased or absent ankle reflexes, and as the disease progresses, weakness may develop. This patient has normal monofilament examination, intact reflexes and is at the target value of HbA1C for diabetic patients, all favoring a different diagnosis.   
❌ Tarsal tunnel syndrome:
Incorrect: Tarsal tunnel syndrome (TTS) is a type of neuropathy caused by compression of the tibial nerve as it travels through the tarsal tunnel. Patients often complain of numbness, aching, burning, tingling on the sole of the foot, distal foot, toes, and heel pain. Although there is an association between TTS and flat feet, TTS symptoms are exacerbated by weight-bearing rather than sleeping. Moreover, TTS does not typically cause symptoms above the ankle.  
❌ Nocturnal leg cramps:
Incorrect: Nocturnal leg cramps are a common, multifactorial condition that manifests as paroxysmal spasms involving the muscles of the feet or calf. In contrast to the symptoms of restless leg syndrome, nocturnal leg cramps are sudden, short in duration, and are associated with pain and a palpable muscle contraction.
✅ Restless leg syndrome :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents due to personality changes, difficulty speaking, and impaired balance over the past year. They describe the patient as a previously bright, cheerful child who enjoyed activities at school and socializing with friends. Over the last several months, he has become very impulsive and irritable and is also having significant trouble completing homework on time. The patient also used to be an avid soccer player but recently dropped out of the team due to poor performance and lack of interest. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination of the patient shows significant loss of coordination and dysarthric speech. Slit-lamp examination of the eyes is shown below:  

 

 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
   
Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be found in this patient on further testing?

choices.text: Basal ganglia atrophy on brain imaging
Increased GAA trinucleotide repeat on genetic testing

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with dysarthria, impaired balance, and personality changes, along with a slit-lamp eye examination showing Kayser-Fleischer rings; the most likely diagnosis is Wilson disease.   

Wilson disease, also known as hepatolenticular degeneration, is an autosomal recessive disorder resulting from mutations in hepatocyte copper-transporting ATPase (ATP7B gene on chromosome 13). As a result, there is a decrease in copper incorporation into apoceruloplasmin and excretion into bile. Copper accumulates within the liver, brain, cornea, kidneys, and other organs. Kayser-Fleischer rings refer to the deposition of copper (which appears dark brown) within the Descemet membrane in the cornea; the rings are a characteristic feature of Wilson disease.  

There are numerous clinical manifestations associated with Wilson's disease due to copper accumulation in various organs:  

  •  Neurologic manifestations occur largely due to the atrophy of the basal ganglia; these include parkinsonism, dysarthria, tremor, dystonia, and polyneuropathy.  
  •  Psychiatric symptoms can include irritability, psychosis, emotional lability, difficulty concentrating and personality changes.  
  •  Hepatic dysfunction includes hepatitis, hepatomegaly, and eventual liver cirrhosis.         
In patients with clinical features suggestive of Wilson disease, a complete blood count, liver biochemical tests, serum ceruloplasmin and copper levels, and ocular slit-lamp examination, as well as 24-hour urinary copper excretion, help to establish the diagnosis. Treatment includes copper chelation with penicillamine or trientine and oral zinc. A liver transplant is indicated in patients with acute liver failure.




Option Analysis

❌ Insulin resistance:
Incorrect: The insulin resistance of diabetes mellitus is associated with hemochromatosis, a genetic or acquired condition that results in increased iron absorption. Patients often present with a classic triad of cirrhosis, diabetes mellitus, and skin pigmentation (“bronze diabetes”). It can also cause restrictive cardiomyopathy or dilated cardiomyopathy, hypogonadism, and arthropathy. Kayser-Fleischer rings are not seen. 
✅ Basal ganglia atrophy on brain imaging:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased GAA trinucleotide repeat on genetic testing:
Incorrect: Increased GAA trinucleotide repeat can be found in patients with Friedreich ataxia, an autosomal recessive condition characterized by degeneration of lateral corticospinal tract, spinocerebellar tract, dorsal columns, and dorsal root ganglia. Patients often present with staggering gait, falling, nystagmus, dysarthria, pes cavus, hammertoes, diabetes mellitus, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and kyphoscoliosis. Kayser-Fleischer rings are not seen. 
❌ Tumor in the adrenal medulla :
Incorrect: Pheochromocytomas are tumors that arise from chromaffin cells of the adrenal gland and secrete catecholamines. These tumors are associated with neurofibromatosis type I and von Hippel-Lindau disease. Patients often present with paroxysmal elevated blood pressure, palpitations, and diaphoresis. Neurofibromatosis type I is associated with Lisch nodules, which are pigmented hamartomatous nodules in the iris, not Kayser-Fleischer rings. 
❌ Hypogonadism:
Incorrect: Hypogonadism is associated with hemochromatosis, a genetic or acquired condition that results in increased iron absorption. Patients often present with a classic triad of cirrhosis, diabetes mellitus, and skin pigmentation (“bronze diabetes”). It can also cause restrictive cardiomyopathy or dilated cardiomyopathy, hypogonadism, and arthropathy. Kayser-Fleischer rings are not seen.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old female comes to her outpatient provider’s office for symptoms of fatigue, headaches, and pruritus that is worse with showering. The symptoms began three months ago. The patient consumes half-a-pack of cigarettes per day, has a 30-pack-year smoking history, and drinks 3-4 beers per week. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 120/73 mmHg, pulse is 71/min, and respiratory rate is 14/min. On physical exam, the patient is observed to have a reddish face. Cardiac and pulmonary exams are non-contributory. Abdominal examination reveals an enlarged spleen. Laboratory testing is ordered and the results are as follows:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  19.0 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  57% 
 Erythrocytes  7.2 million/mm3 
 Leukocytes  12,900/mm3 
 Platelets  440,000/mm3 

Which of the following additional sets of findings would be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Given this patient’s history, splenomegaly, facial plethora, and laboratory findings, she most likely has polycythemia vera. This condition is most commonly caused by a Janus Kinase 2 (JAK2) gene mutation.  

In healthy individuals, the kidneys release erythropoietin (EPO), a hormone that binds to receptors on the hematopoietic stem cells, activating the JAK2 gene. This causes the hematopoietic stem cells to divide and produce more red blood cells (RBCs). However, when this mutation occurs, the JAK2 gene stays activated, and the hematopoietic stem cells are able to divide in the absence of EPO.  

The mutated cells rapidly proliferate and increase RBC mass. The body will notice the elevated RBC mass and reduce EPO production in an attempt to halt the process. The reason why polycythemia vera causes increased plasma volume is unclear. One hypothesis is that over time, a large number of RBCs pool in the spleen causing splenomegaly. In response there is a compensatory plasma volume increase in the rest of the circulation. Lastly, even though the RBCs are “mutated,” their oxygen binding ability remains intact. Hence, patients with polycythemia vera have a normal blood oxygen saturation.  

Option Analysis

❌   Plasma Volume  RBC Mass  O2 Saturation  Erythropoietin Level  Unchanged  ↑  97%  ↑ :
Incorrect: These laboratory findings would be expected in a patient with secondary polycythemia due to elevated erythropoietin (EPO) levels. This could be due to EPO-secreting tumors (e.g. renal cell carcinoma), or exogenous EPO injections. While this patient’s smoking history places her at increased risk of developing renal cell carcinoma, additional symptoms such as a palpable flank mass, hematuria, and weight loss would also be expected.
❌   Plasma Volume  RBC Mass  O2 Saturation  Erythropoietin Level  Unchanged  ↑  89%  ↑ :
Incorrect: These laboratory findings would be seen as part of the body’s normal response to hypoxia. Hypoxia may be secondary to environmental factors (e.g. high altitude) or disease pathologies (e.g. emphysema). However, hypoxia would not account for the leukocytosis, thrombocytosis, and splenomegaly observed in this patient.
❌   Plasma Volume  RBC Mass  O2 Saturation  Erythropoietin Level   ↓  Unchanged  97%  Unchanged :
Incorrect: These laboratory findings would be seen in relative polycythemia. This condition can be caused by dehydration or fluid loss via burns. In either case, the individual’s blood plasma volume decreases dramatically while the RBC count remains roughly the same. The net result is hemoconcentration and an increased hematocrit. However, no part of this patient’s history or physical exam suggests that he is volume depleted.
✅   Plasma Volume  RBC Mass  O2 Saturation  Erythropoietin Level   ↑  ↑  97%  ↓ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Plasma Volume  RBC Mass  O2 Saturation  Erythropoietin Level   ↑  ↑  89%  ↓ :
Incorrect: These laboratory findings are suggestive of erythropoiesis that is independent of EPO, which is consistent with the patient’s diagnosis of polycythemia vera. However, patients with polycythemia vera have normal oxygen saturation levels since the “mutated” RBCs have intact oxygen binding ability.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy is brought by his parents to the pediatrician’s office for evaluation of poor weight gain. The patient has failed to meet motor and cognitive milestones. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 103/72 mmHg, pulse is 116/min, and respirations are 32/min. On physical exam, the patient’s height, weight, and head circumference are below the 5th percentile. Laboratory testing reveals the following results:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  7.6 g/dL 
 Mean Corpuscular Volume  107 mm3 
 Ammonia*  43 µmol/L  
*Normal < 55 µmol/L   

The patient is started on a trial of vitamin B12 and folate supplements. However, a follow-up visit one month later reveals no improvement of symptoms. The enzyme deficient in this patient is normally involved in the production of which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
This patient has orotic aciduria, an autosomal recessive condition characterized by the impaired conversion of orotic acid to uridine monophosphate (UMP). The condition presents in children as failure to thrive, developmental delays, and a macrocytic megaloblastic anemia that is refractive to folate and vitamin B12 treatment. The anemia is due to the impaired production of UMP, a molecule that is transformed into DNA nucleotides. The deficiency of UMP disrupts red blood cell (RBC) DNA replication and maturation. As a result, large and immature RBCs will be seen in the bloodstream of patients with orotic aciduria.  

The diagnosis can be made using a combination of the patient’s history and laboratory testing. Laboratory testing will reveal a reduced hemoglobin, enlarged RBCs, and a normal serum ammonia level. Urinalysis in patients with orotic aciduria will show elevated orotic acid levels. Advanced molecular testing can be used to confirm the presence of the mutation. It is worth noting that board-exams often ask students to distinguish orotic aciduria from OTC deficiency (Option A), a condition affecting the urea cycle which presents with hyperammonemia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Citrulline:
Incorrect: The synthesis of citrulline is impaired in patients with ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency. Patients with the condition can present with nausea, vomiting, delayed growth, and cognitive impairment. However, OTC deficiency would not account for the macrocytic anemia. Moreover, the condition typically presents with elevated ammonia levels.
✅ Uridine monophosphate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Deoxythymidine monophosphate:
Incorrect: The synthesis of deoxythymidine monophosphate (dTMP) is imapired in patients with folate deficiency. This in turn results in a macrocytic anemia. However, if folate deficiency were the underlying cause, then the patient’s symptoms would have improved after being prescribed the supplements.  
❌ Guanosine monophosphate:
Incorrect: The production of guanosine monophosphate (GMP), as well as inosine monophosphate (IMP), is impaired in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, due to a purine salvage defect caused by the absence of the enzyme HGPRT. Patients with Lesch-Nyhan can present with cognitive and motor delays. However, they also tend to present with aggression, self-mutilation, and gout secondary to hyperuricemia. These symptoms are not observed in this patient, and Lesch-Nyhan would not account for the patient’s macrocytic anemia.
❌ Orotic acid:
Incorrect: The production of orotic acid can be impaired by medications such as leflunomide, an immunosuppressive disease-modifying rheumatic drug. However, this patient has no medical history that would require the administration of leflunomide or a similar medication. In contrast, this patient has orotic aciduria, which is caused by the impaired conversion of orotic acid to uridine monophosphate, resulting instead in elevated levels of orotic acid.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old man comes to the office because of progressive lower back pain for the past 4 months. The pain is relatively constant, non-radiating, aching and interferes with his sleep at night. It is not relieved by rest or change in position. He also reports feeling tired all day and not being able to get out of bed without help. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows point tenderness at the level of L4-L5 vertebrae. Forward flexion does not alleviate the pain. A hard lump is palpated on digital rectal examination. Hemoglobin is 9.8 g/dL, and leukocyte count is 10,000/mm3. Serum chemistry is shown below:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum chemistry 
 Sodium   139 mEq/L 
 Potassium   3.5 mEq/L 
 Chloride   95 mEq/L 
 Calcium, serum  9.2 mg/dL 
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)  7 mm/hr 
 Creatinine  1.1 g/dL 
 Alkaline phosphatase  157 U/L 

Serum prostate specific antigen is 15 ng/mL. Further evaluation of this patient will show which of the following?

choices.text: Neoplastic plasma cells on bone marrow biopsy
Total fusion of spine on plain x-ray

questions.solution:
This patient with progressive lower back pain that is worse at night and is not relieved by rest and elevated prostate specific antigen (PSA) levels, in combination with point tenderness and a palpable hard lump on digital rectal examination (DRE), is most likely suffering from metastatic prostate adenocarcinoma.  

It is among the most common cancers in men worldwide and is more commonly seen in patients of African-American descent. It spreads via the vertebral venous plexus (Batson plexus) to the bones of the axial skeleton, like the vertebrae or pelvis, resulting in hip or lower back pain. The metastasis results in osteoblastic (bone forming) lesions in most cases. The precise mechanisms by which prostate cancer tumor cells induce osteoblastic changes are uncertain but are believed to involve excess activation of osteoblast mitogens that induce bone growth. Vertebral compression fracture and spinal cord compression may also occur less commonly. This patient should be evaluated with a radionuclide bone scan, which is effective in detecting osteoblastic metastases as foci of abnormal uptake throughout the skeleton. In the presence of osteoblastic lesions on bone scan, bone-specific alkaline phosphatase can also be elevated and can be used as a screening tool to detect recurrence after treatment. If bone scan is inconclusive, an MRI or CT scan can be used.  



Option Analysis

✅ Osteoblastic lesions on bone scan:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Neoplastic plasma cells on bone marrow biopsy:
Incorrect: Neoplastic plasma cells on bone marrow biopsy are characteristic of multiple myeloma. Although these patients present with long-standing bone pain, a normal serum creatinine and calcium levels make this diagnosis less likely.
❌ Blood culture growing Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: S. aureus is commonly isolated from blood culture of patients with vertebral osteomyelitis, which usually presents with fever, back pain, and focal spinal tenderness. Although leukocyte count may be normal, ESR and CRP are elevated. It is unlikely in this patient with chronic back pain and a hard lump on DRE.  
❌ Ligamentum flavum hypertrophy on MRI:
Incorrect: Ligamentum flavum hypertrophy on MRI is a common finding in spinal stenosis. It usually manifests with radiating back pain which is relieved by bending forward (flexing). This patient’s pain is not affected by change in position.
❌ Total fusion of spine on plain x-ray:
Incorrect: Total fusion of spine on plain x-ray (bamboo spine) is a classic finding of advanced ankylosing spondylitis, which usually presents in young adults with insidious onset back pain. Associated enthesitis, dactylitis and extra-articular manifestations are common. It is unlikely in this elderly patient with a hard lump on DRE.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, comes to the labor and delivery triage at 37 weeks gestation due to mild vaginal bleeding for the past 2 hours. She has not had any pain but has had occasional, non-painful contractions. She did not receive prenatal care but states that she took prenatal vitamins throughout the pregnancy. The patient’s firstborn was delivered via cesarean section. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 115/80 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears comfortable. The uterus is soft and nontender. Streaks of blood are seen in the vaginal vault with no active bleeding. The fetus is in a vertex position. The fetal heart rate is 150 bpm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with painless vaginal bleeding in the 3rd trimester, favoring the diagnosis of placenta previa.    

Placenta previa refers to placental tissue implantation over the internal cervical os, covering all or part of the cervix. The classic presentation is painless late-pregnancy vaginal bleeding. Normally, the placenta implants in the upper uterus, and although it is unclear why it implants in the lower uterus in placenta previa, one hypothesis suggests that areas of suboptimal vascularity in the upper uterine cavity from previous damage (e.g. surgery) promotes implantation in the lower part. Significant risk factors include previous cesarean deliveries, previous uterine surgery, multiple gestations, and previous placenta previa. It is important to note that the presence of pain and tender uterus makes the diagnosis of placenta previa unlikely.  

The vast majority of placenta previas are identified on ultrasound examination before 20 weeks gestation and typically resolve spontaneously before delivery. In asymptomatic patients < 37 weeks of gestation, management includes follow up with transvaginal ultrasound. If the previa resolves, routine prenatal care can resume. In unstable patients with severe bleeding or evidence of fetal distress, emergent cesarean surgery is indicated. In patients whose previa does not resolve, cesarean section is the preferred method of delivery to avoid postpartum hemorrhage.



Option Analysis

❌ False labor :
Incorrect: "False labor," also known as Braxton-Hicks contractions, refers to regular or irregular painful contractions without cervical dilation. This patient had occasional, non-painful contractions, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.  
❌ True labor:
Incorrect: True labor is characterized by progressive painful contractions and cervical dilation that occur at the latent phase of labor every 3-5 minutes. A small amount of blood often accompanies labor and is known as “bloody show”. This patient has had irregular, non-painful contractions, and her bleeding has stopped, making this diagnosis less likely. 
❌ Placental abruption :
Incorrect: Placental abruption is the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall that occurs after 20 weeks gestation. Typical presentation includes acute onset of abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding (although bleeding may be concealed), uterine contractions, and uterine tenderness.
✅ Placenta previa :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Placenta accreta :
Incorrect: Placenta accreta refers to a placenta that attaches to the myometrium without penetrating it. Placenta accreta presents as a life-threatening hemorrhage that occurs after delivery when manual placental separation is attempted. This patient has not yet delivered, making this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of severe pain in the right knee for the past day. He states the knee is swollen, warm, and red. The patient had a similar episode that occurred in his right ankle last year, which resolved spontaneously without treatment. He also complains of increasing “tiredness” and loss of libido over the last 2 months, but he attributes the symptoms to recent stress at work. The patient has no significant past medical history. His father had a bleeding disorder, but the patient is unaware of the details. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 54/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 110/82 mmHg. Physical examination shows diffuse hyperpigmentation of the skin. The liver is palpated 3.5 cm below the costal margin. Laboratory studies reveal the following findings:



Arthrocentesis of the right knee joint would most likely show which of the following?

choices.text: Large numbers of red blood cells

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with joint pain, loss of libido, hyperpigmentation, hepatomegaly, and elevated liver enzymes. He likely has underlying hemochromatosis.    

Hemochromatosis is caused by a mutation in the HFE gene and results in uncontrolled reabsorption of iron in the intestines. The excess iron deposits in various locations of the body, manifesting as a constellation of symptoms: pituitary deposition leads to hypopituitarism (e.g., hypothyroidism, loss of libido), dermal deposition leads to hyperpigmentation, and hepatic deposition leads to hepatomegaly, hepatocyte dysfunction, and elevated liver enzymes.   

Recurrent joint pain may be caused by deposition of calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals in joint spaces. Pyrophosphate is a byproduct of adenosine triphosphate (ATP); excess iron in hemochromatosis may interfere with pyrophosphatase, an essential enzyme involved in metabolism of the byproduct. On polarized light microscopy, CPP crystals appear as rhomboid-shaped, positively birefringent crystals. 


Option Analysis

✅ Calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Monosodium urate crystals:
Incorrect: Monosodium urate crystal deposition occurs in acute gout attacks. Although this patient is presenting with gout-like episodes, he also has symptoms suggestive of underlying hemochromatosis (e.g., hepatomegaly, hyperpigmentation, loss of libido). Hemochromatosis would predispose him to another crystal deposition disease.
❌ Gram-negative diplococci:
Incorrect: Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative diplococci that can cause disseminated gonococcal infection, which can present as a migratory, asymmetric polyarthritis. Patients with disseminated gonococcal infection typically present with fever, chills, and dermatitis, which this patient lacks. In addition, this patient is presenting with other signs and symptoms (e.g., hepatomegaly, hyperpigmentation, loss of libido) which disseminated gonococcal infection cannot explain.
❌ Gram-positive cocci forming clusters:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive cocci that can cause septic arthritis and appears as clusters under the microscope. Septic arthritis can present as an acutely swollen, painful joint. However, it also causes a high fever, which the patient in this vignette lacks. In addition, this patient is presenting with other signs and symptoms (e.g., hepatomegaly, hyperpigmentation, loss of libido) which septic arthritis cannot explain.
❌ Large numbers of red blood cells:
Incorrect: A large number of red blood cells may be present in patients with hemarthrosis, which can occur after joint trauma or due to an underlying bleeding disorder. This patient lacks any history of trauma, and although his father has a bleeding disorder, the patient himself has no history of increased bleeding frequency or severity.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to pelvic discomfort over the past few months. She states she generally feels well and denies any unintentional weight loss and fatigue. Medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type 2 and smoking 1 pack per day for 30 years. The patient is in a monogamous relationship with her partner of 37 years and denies any history of sexually transmitted diseases. Family history is notable for colon cancer in her father at age 55. Last menstrual cycle was 7 years ago. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a right-sided, non-tender adnexal mass is noted. Which of the following features would most likely indicate the presence of a malignant mass?
questions.solution:
This postmenopausal woman is presenting with pelvic discomfort and an adnexal mass. Adnexal mass can be simple or complex. The main concern in postmenopausal women who present with an adnexal mass is to exclude malignancy.  

Following a thorough history and physical exam, there are 4 steps that can assist in determining the management. First, an ultrasound should be obtained to determine if the mass is likely benign (simple cyst) or malignant (complex cyst). The differences in sonographic features are summarized in the table below. Complex cysts typically have internal vascularity, which can be seen on Doppler ultrasonography. As neoplastic cells proliferate and grow, their metabolic needs increase, resulting in increased blood vessel formation and growth.  

The next step is to determine if there is a physiological process that can account for the mass (e.g. hemorrhagic physiologic cyst). The third step is to determine if there are characteristics of a specific entity (e.g. endometrioma usually demonstrates echoes in a cystic mass). The last step is to determine if there is a need for a follow-up ultrasound or additional testing. A repeat of pelvic ultrasound is useful when physiologic processes are still in the differential diagnosis. An MRI should be considered if the results on ultrasound are equivocal.  

If the mass appears to be malignant, testing for serum CA-125 has a higher specificity for ovarian malignancy when combined with imaging. Lastly, surgical exploration is indicated if the initial evaluation demonstrated sufficient suspicion of a malignant adnexal mass.  



Option Analysis

❌ Round cystic shape on ultrasound:
Incorrect: A round or oval shaped cyst on pelvic ultrasound is indicative of a simple, benign cyst. In contrast, a cyst with solid components and thick septations requires further work up, due to the increasing chance of malignancy.
❌ Unilocular cyst on ultrasound:
Incorrect: Unilocular cysts are associated with benign ovarian processes, whereas the presence of multiple loculations and septations suggests a malignant ovarian process.
❌ Thin cystic wall on ultrasound:
Incorrect: Thin cystic walls are a common feature of benign, simple ovarian cysts. In contrast, the presence of thick septations can indicate a malignant process.
✅ Internal flow on Doppler imaging:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old female comes to the clinic complaining of gingival bleeding and dark purple spots on her legs. The patient first noticed the dark spots on her legs 2 months ago, but the gingival bleeding started 5 days ago. Past history is notable for intravenous drug use and hepatitis C infection. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 128/76 mmHg. Examination of the patient’s oropharynx and gingiva reveals petechiae with pinpoint bleeding. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are noncontributory. Purpura are observed on the bilateral legs. Laboratory testing is obtained, and the results are shown below.  
 
Laboratory value   Result 
 Platelet count  25,000/mm3  
 Hemoglobin (Hb)  13.5 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  11,000/mm3 
Which of the following serological findings would most likely be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has petechiae and bleeding from the gums, purpura on the legs, and severe thrombocytopenia. She most likely has immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP).   

ITP can be acquired or inherited. It typically occurs secondary to hepatitis C, HIV, or systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Patients with ITP typically have isolated thrombocytopenia. ITP is caused by autoantibodies that bind the Gp2b3a platelet receptor and mark platelets for destruction in the spleen.  In this way, it is similar to autoimmune hemolytic anemia, in which antibodies bind and mark erythrocytes for destruction in the spleen. In rare circumstances, both of these diseases may occur together in what is known as Evans syndrome.   


Reproduced from: Wikipedia


Reproduced from: Wikipedia

Reproduced from: Wikipedia
Treatment of patients with ITP includes steroids, intravenous immunoglobulins (IVIG), and rituximab. If the condition persists despite medical management, then a splenectomy may be necessary.  

Option Analysis

❌ Anti-ADAMTS13 antibodies:
