Incorrect: Anti-ADAMTS13 antibodies are associated with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). Patients with TTP have both thrombocytopenia and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. In contrast, this patient has a normal hemoglobin level.
✅ Anti-Gp2b3a receptor antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Antiphospholipid antibodies:
Incorrect: These antibodies are associated with antiphospholipid syndrome and systemic lupus erythematosus. Patients with antiphospholipid syndrome typically present with clinical features related to hypercoagulability, such as deep vein thrombosis, stroke, or recurrent pregnancy miscarriages due to thrombosis of the placental vessels.
❌ Lupus anticoagulant:
Incorrect: Lupus anticoagulant antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Patients with lupus anticoagulant antibodies and SLE would present with clinical features related to increased clotting, such as deep vein thrombosis or stroke. The term “anticoagulant” is a misnomer and refers to the molecule’s action in vitro, where it prolongs the partial thromboplastin time.
❌ Anti-Ro antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-Ro antibodies, also termed anti-SSA antibodies, are associated with Sjogren syndrome. The condition can cause xerostomia (dry mouth) and xerophthalmia (dry eyes) but would not cause thrombocytopenia or increased bleeding risk.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to increased facial hair growth. The patient states that over the past 6 months, hair started growing on her face and abdomen. She also describes mild pelvic discomfort that has minimal impact on her daily routine. Medical history is notable for a chlamydia infection at age 20, which was managed with antibiotics, and asthma, for which the patient takes albuterol and inhaled corticosteroids. She is sexually active with her partner of 6 months and uses condoms for contraception. The patient’s last Pap smear 6 months ago was normal. Menstrual cycles occur at regular 28 days intervals and last for 3 days of mild flow. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 30 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Physical examination shows coarse dark hair on the chin and abdomen. On vaginal examination, clitoromegaly is noted. Which of the following is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with the recent onset of virilization and normal pattern of menstrual cycles. From the answers above, only Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor is associated with hyperandrogenism (regarding PCOS, see choice A).  

Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors are a type of rare sex cord-stromal tumors. These tumors are typically benign, but malignant behavior is also possible. They are usually seen in women in the 2nd and 3rd decades of life. On histology, the tumor is composed of tubules lined with Sertoli cells, and surrounded by stroma interspersed with Leydig cells. Macroscopically, they are yellow and lobulated, with a smooth surface. The tumor commonly produces androgens resulting in virilization (e.g., hirsutism, clitoromegaly). Estrogen production and side effects have also been observed, but this phenomenon is less common. AFP and inhibin tumor markers may be elevated. It should be noted that AFP is mostly associated with yolk sac tumors and embryonal carcinomas.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor of the ovary  



Option Analysis

❌ Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS):
Incorrect: PCOS, the most common cause of infertility in women, is characterized by ovulatory dysfunction and symptoms of hyperandrogenism. The criteria to diagnose PCOS include a pattern of abnormal uterine bleeding for age, which is persistent for at least a year, as well as evidence of hyperandrogenism (e.g., acne, hirsutism). While this patient is obese and is showing signs of excess androgens, the normal menstrual pattern essentially eliminates PCOS as a diagnosis.
❌ Adverse effect of medication:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids are associated with a variety of side effects throughout the body including skin thinning and ecchymoses, Cushingoid appearance, acne, weight gain, striae, facial erythema, and hirsutism. While this patient shows some of these features, inhaled corticosteroids are less likely to cause systemic symptoms, and additional features would be expected.
✅ Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Granulosa cell tumor:
Incorrect: Granulosa cell tumors are a type of potentially malignant ovarian sex cord tumors. These include 2 subtypes, adult and juvenile. Histology shows granulosa cells arranged around collections of eosinophilic fluid, known as Call-Exner bodies, which resemble primordial follicles. These tumors often produce estrogen and/or progesterone, leading to symptoms of hyperestrogenism (e.g., abnormal uterine bleeding, breast tenderness) and sexual precocity in children. Virilization, however, rarely occurs with granulosa cell tumors.
❌ Thecoma:
Incorrect: Thecomas are benign, solid and fibromatous neoplasms, composed of theca cells arising from the ovarian stroma. They are usually seen in postmenopausal women. Thecomas may produce estrogen, and therefore often present with abnormal uterine bleeding; up to 20% of patients have concomitant endometrial cancer. Grossly, they appear yellow from accumulated lipids. Histologically, they are primarily composed of theca cells. This patient is young and instead showing signs of hyperandrogenism.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to pelvic heaviness and discomfort for the past few months. The patient also discloses bloody spotting on her underwear, which has required intermittently changing throughout the day. The patient has had no urinary symptoms or weight loss. She does not smoke or use alcohol or illicit drugs. The patient’s last menstrual cycle was 6 years ago. Her last Pap smear 2 years ago was normal. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a right-sided adnexal mass is palpated. Pelvic ultrasound shows a thickened endometrial stripe. Endometrial biopsy reveals an early stage, well-differentiated adenocarcinoma. The patient subsequently undergoes excision of the mass. The histopathological analysis is shown below:


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is most likely to be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
This postmenopausal woman is presenting with signs of excess estrogens (i.e., thickened endometrial stripe, spotting) along with an adnexal mass. The pathohistological analysis demonstrates a classic picture of Call-Exner bodies, confirming the diagnosis of a granulosa cell tumor.  

Granulosa cell tumors are a type of potentially malignant ovarian sex cord tumor. They include 2 subtypes, adult and juvenile. Histology shows granulosa cells arranged around collections of eosinophilic fluid, known as Call-Exner bodies, which resemble primordial follicles. Granulosa cells appear round, pale, with scant cytoplasm, and characteristic "coffee-bean" nuclei. Grossly, the tumors are usually large (> 12 cm), tan or yellow, and can be soft or firm. On ultrasound, the tumor appears as a unilateral, echogenic, septated, cystic or solid mass that may be similar to mucinous cystadenoma.  

These tumors often produce estrogen and/or progesterone, leading to symptoms of hyperestrogenism including abnormal uterine bleeding (due to endometrial gland hypertrophy), breast tenderness, and endometrial adenocarcinomas (due to uninhibited endometrial gland hypertrophy). In children, the elevated estrogen or progesterone levels may lead to sexual precocity. Virilization is also possible, but rare. Markers that may be found elevated in patients’ serum include inhibin, anti-Mullerian hormone, and CA-125.  

Option Analysis

✅ Inhibin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lactate dehydrogenase:
Incorrect: Serum concentration of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) may be elevated in many types of cancer. LDH elevation is characteristically seen in dysgerminomas and less commonly in yolk sac tumors. This patient’s presentation and histological results are consistent with a granulosa cell tumor, which is not associated with elevated LDH.
❌ Human chorionic gonadotropin:
Incorrect: Serum concentration of human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG) may be elevated in embryonal cell carcinomas, ovarian choriocarcinomas, mixed germ cell tumors, and dysgerminomas. This patient’s presentation and histological results are consistent with a granulosa cell tumor, which is not associated with elevated hCG.
❌ Alpha-fetoprotein:
Incorrect: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) may be elevated in yolk cell tumors, Sertoli-Leydig tumors, embryonal carcinomas, and immature teratomas. This patient’s presentation and histological results are consistent with a granulosa cell tumor, which is not associated with elevated AFP.
❌ Testosterone:
Incorrect: Testosterone may be elevated Sertoli-Leydig tumors and granulosa cell tumors. Although this patient’s diagnosis is consistent with granulosa cell tumor, she does not show signs of excess androgens (e.g. hirsutism), and therefore an elevated testosterone level would be unlikely.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 2, comes to the clinic due to pelvic discomfort and fatigue over the past 6 months. The patient was previously healthy, other than a history of polycystic ovarian syndrome. Menarche occurred at age 12, and menopause occurred 2 years ago. Both of the patient’s children were delivered via Cesarean sections due to personal preference. Family history is significant for breast cancer in her cousin at age 56 and colon cancer in her father at age 55. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 35 kg/m2. On physical examination, the abdomen is bloated, and shifting dullness is present. Pelvic examination reveals a left-sided adnexal mass. The patient undergoes a hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, followed by adjuvant chemotherapy. A pathohistological analysis is consistent with serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary. Which of the following is the most significant risk factor for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ovarian cancer is the 2nd most common gynecologic malignancy in developed countries and 3rd in developing countries (cervical cancer is most common). In the United States, ovarian cancer is the most common cause of gynecologic cancer death. Surface epithelial tumors (EOC) account for the majority of ovarian tumors, of which, the serous subtype is the most common. Epithelial carcinomas of the ovary, fallopian tube, and peritoneum are considered a single clinical entity.  

Risk factors for developing EOC are detailed in the table below. In general, increased number of lifetime ovulations is associated with increased risk of developing ovarian cancer, due to the repeated damage to the surface epithelium with the subsequent repair and regeneration that predisposes to mutations. Nulliparity, early menarche, and late menopause result in increased lifetime ovulations and therefore are associated with increased risk of EOC. It follows that protective factors are typically associated with decreased lifetime ovulation, such as oral contraceptive pills, multiparity, and breastfeeding.  



Option Analysis

❌ The patient’s family history:
Incorrect: There is an increased risk of ovarian cancer for women with no personal history of cancer but with either:  
  • 1st or 2nd degree relative with any of the following: breast cancer ≤45 years, ovarian cancer, male breast cancer, pancreatic cancer, or metastatic prostate cancer.  
  • Or ≥2 primary breast cancer in a single individual Or occurring on the same side of the family with at least one diagnosed ≤50 years.  
A cousin is a 3rd-degree relative, and colon cancer is not associated with increased risk for ovarian cancer.  
❌ The patient’s medical history:
Incorrect: Findings regarding whether polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) increases the risk for ovarian cancer are currently inconclusive.
❌ The patient’s BMI:
Incorrect: Findings regarding whether obesity increases the risk for ovarian cancer are currently inconclusive.
❌ Age of menarche:
Incorrect: Early menarche (before age 12) has been associated with a mildly increased risk of ovarian cancer, due to an increased number of total ovulations. This patient experienced menarche at 12.
✅ Age of menopause:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the clinic due to back pain. Upon entering the clinic, the patient is observed to be limping and appears in pain. He discloses back pain for the past few months that has been progressively worsening. Two days ago, he felt severe pain while lifting a box at home. The patient now describes the pain as dull, 7/10 in severity, which worsens with movement and radiates to the left thigh. He has noticed numbness in the perianal region while using the toilet. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, focal tenderness is noticed over the lumbar and paraspinal area. There is a loss of sensation around the perianal area but a normal anal sphincter tone. Knee jerk reflex is normal but the ankle reflex is absent on the left. Strength is 5/5 on the right and 4/5 in the left gluteus maximus and hamstring muscles. Which of the following features will prompt the need for emergent imaging?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with acute lumbar radiculopathy and loss of sensation in the perianal area (saddle anesthesia) which raises concerns for cauda equina syndrome, a medical emergency.    

The spinal cord travels through the spinal canal to the 2nd lumbar vertebra, where it ends in a cone, called the conus medullaris. Because the spinal cord is shorter than the spinal canal, nerves of the lumbar, sacral, and coccygeal regions have to travel down the spinal canal to reach their corresponding openings, forming a nerve bundle below the spinal cord called the cauda equina. These nerves carry motor innervation for the genitals, internal and external anal sphincter, detrusor muscle, leg muscles, and sensory fibers of the legs and pelvis.    

Cauda equina syndrome is caused by compression, trauma, or damage to multiple nerves of the cauda equina. Large lumbar disc herniation is the most common cause of cauda equina syndrome. Other causes include spinal stenosis, spondylolisthesis, cancer, abscess, ankylosing spondylitis, and trauma. Symptoms of cauda equina syndrome include loss of bowel and bladder control, saddle anesthesia, sexual dysfunction, motor weakness, loss of knee and ankle reflexes, radiating pain, and even paraplegia.   

Patients with back pain presenting with a progressive or severe motor deficit not localized to a single nerve root, urinary retention or fecal incontinence, saddle anesthesia, bilateral signs and symptoms (not localized to a single nerve root), or suspected malignancy or abscess should undergo emergency MRI or CT with contrast (if MRI is contraindicated). If cauda equina syndrome is confirmed, an emergency decompression should be performed within 24 hours (12 hours if possible).  



Option Analysis

❌ The patient’s back pain intensity:
Incorrect: Back pain intensity is subjective and is not an indication for imaging and further evaluation in acute settings. Instead, different levels of pain might help in directing the pharmacological choice.
❌ The patient’s back pain characteristics:
Incorrect: Pain characteristic is subjective information that can help the physician to differentiate between different etiologies (e.g. nociceptive pain vs. neuropathic pain). However, it is not an indication for imaging and further evaluation.
❌ The patient’s motor weakness:
Incorrect: Severe motor weakness or significant motor deficits that cannot be localized to a single nerve root are indications for imaging. However, this patient’s weakness is moderate, and the pain has not worsened since onset two days ago.
✅ The patient’s loss of sensation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ The patient’s absent reflex:
Incorrect: Absent reflexes are a common finding in acute lumbar radiculopathy and are not an indication for imaging. Babinski and clonus are upper motor neuron signs that should prompt further evaluation.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents to the office because of a dragging sensation in the abdomen for the past 2 months. He also reports easy fatigability in this same time period. Past medical history is significant for an upper respiratory tract infection treated with antibiotics 6 months ago. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 27 years. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows splenomegaly. Laboratory results are as follows:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin   10 g/dL 
 Platelets   600,000/mm3 
 Leukocytes   60,100/mm3 
 Neutrophils  35% 
 Myelocytes  32% 
 Metamyelocytes  10% 
 Band forms  1% 
 Blast cells  1% 
 Basophils  6% 
 Eosinophils  6% 
 Lymphocytes  9% 
Peripheral blood smear is shown below:

 

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with dragging sensation in abdomen (due to splenomegaly), in combination with the laboratory findings of anemia, thrombocytosis and leukocytosis (particularly basophilia), is indicative of a myeloproliferative disorder. Of the options listed, chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is the most likely diagnosis.  

CML is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by uncontrolled proliferation of mature granulocytes. It accounts for 15-20% of leukemia in adults, with a slight male predominance. It arises from t(9;22) (Philadelphia chromosome) which encodes the bcr-abl fusion protein with increased tyrosine kinase activity causing growth-factor-independent proliferation of granulocytes.  


 CML can manifest in 3 different phases: 
  •  Chronic phase: Usually at the time of diagnosis, when patients present with fatigue, weight loss, abdominal fullness (splenomegaly). 
  •  Accelerated phase: When granulocyte differentiation and proliferation is accelerated, clinically manifesting as enlarging spleen. 
  •  Blast crisis: Transformation into acute myeloid leukemia or acute lymphoblastic leukemia. 
Laboratory evaluation is typical for leukocytosis (particularly basophilia), with a differential showing all cells of neutrophilic series (as in this patient). Additionally, the presence of a greater percentage of myelocytes than the more mature metamyelocytes is another classic finding in CML. The neutrophils are functionally abnormal with a low leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score (as compared to leukemoid reaction). Diagnosis is established by identification of Philadelphia chromosome on genetic analysis. Treatment option is imatinib, which is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor.  

Option Analysis

❌ Hairy cell leukemia:
Incorrect: Although patients with hairy cell leukemia usually presents with symptomatic splenomegaly and pancytopenia, peripheral blood smear shows a mononuclear cell with indistinct cytoplasmic outline, giving it a hairy appearance.
❌ Acute myeloid leukemia:
Incorrect: Acute myeloid leukemia can also present with signs and symptoms of pancytopenia (eg, fatigue, dyspnea); however, peripheral blood smear shows myeloblasts with Auer rods and azurophilic granules in contrast to the mature neutrophils seen in this patient.
✅ Chronic myeloid leukemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Acute lymphoblastic leukemia:
Incorrect: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia can present with signs and symptoms of pancytopenia and splenomegaly; however, these findings are usually accompanied by lymphadenopathy, bone pain or mediastinal mass. Peripheral blood smear shows lymphoblasts (as opposed to mature cells in this patient’s smear).
❌ Chronic lymphocytic leukemia:
Incorrect: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia is a lymphoid neoplasm that can present with painless lymphadenopathy and “B symptoms” (weight loss, fevers, night sweats). Peripheral blood smear typically shows smudge cells, in contrast to the mature granulocytes seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to progressive neck swelling and discomfort over the past few months. She first noticed it after a viral infection, but she did not seek care as she thought it would self-resolve. She generally feels well, and medical history is unremarkable other than 2 C-sections at the ages of 31 and 33. Family history is non-contributory. She has not had palpitations, weight loss, or skin changes. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg. On physical examination, a non-tender goiter with an irregular surface is noted. The rest of the physical exam is within normal limits. Laboratory tests show low TSH and elevated free T3 and T4 serum levels. A radioactive iodine uptake test is performed, and the results are shown below:


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with an irregular goiter, low TSH, and high thyroid hormones; she most likely has subclinical hyperthyroidism. The radioactive iodine uptake test (RAIU) shows multiple foci of increased uptake, which is consistent with the diagnosis of toxic multinodular goiter.  

Toxic multinodular goiter is characterized by the presence of multiple hyperfunctioning nodules (“hot”). Some patients may present with classic signs of hyperthyroidism such as tachycardia, sweating, fine hair, and a hand tremor, whereas others can be asymptomatic. On physical examination, multiple nodules can often be palpated.  

The pathogenesis involves somatic mutations in the TSH receptor signaling pathway, which enable follicular cells to secrete thyroid hormone independent of TSH stimulation. The elevated hormone levels increase negative feedback to the pituitary gland, which decreases TSH secretion. Ultrasound imaging can be used to detect the nodules, and RAIU will show multiple regions of increased uptake if the nodules are active. Treatment may include antithyroid drugs, radioiodine ablation, or surgery.


Option Analysis

❌ Toxic adenoma:
Incorrect: Toxic adenoma is a thyroid nodule that causes hyperthyroidism. Patients typically present with classic signs of hyperthyroidism in addition to a thyroid nodule found on physical examination or imaging. Laboratory values typically show low TSH levels and high free T3 and T4. Although toxic adenoma may present as subclinical hyperthyroidism as seen here, these radioactive iodine uptake test results favor another diagnosis. Also, on physical examination, a discrete nodule would be palpated rather than an irregular surface.  
✅ Toxic multinodular goiter:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Subacute granulomatous (de Quervain) thyroiditis:
Incorrect: Subacute granulomatous (de Quervain) thyroiditis is an inflammatory condition of the thyroid gland that usually follows a viral infection. It is characterized by neck pain, a tender goiter, and a predictable course of hyperthyroidism, followed by euthyroidism, hypothyroidism, and eventually restoration of normal thyroid function. Laboratory values typically show low TSH levels and high free T3 and T4, as well as elevated CRP and ESR. A radioactive iodine uptake test will show decreased uptake rather than increased.
❌ Graves disease:
Incorrect: Graves disease is an autoimmune condition that is caused by the production of autoantibodies to the TSH receptor (TRAb), which stimulates the receptors and leads to increased thyroid hormone synthesis. Patients typically present with classic signs of hyperthyroidism, as well as exophthalmos and pretibial myxedema. Laboratory values typically show low TSH levels and high free T3 and T4. However, a radioactive iodine uptake test will likely show diffuse uptake rather than multiple foci. Also, on physical examination, the goiter is diffusely enlarged.
❌ Euthyroid sick syndrome:
Incorrect: Euthyroid sick syndrome is a condition characterized by low serum levels of thyroid hormones in clinically euthyroid patients with nonthyroidal systemic conditions. Laboratory values typically show low TSH, low T3 and T4, and elevated reverse T3.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 33 weeks gestation comes to the emergency department complaining of nausea, vomiting, headache, blurry vision, and severe abdominal pain for the last hour. The abdominal pain is described as a 10/10 stabbing pain that radiates to the back. Her temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 178/106 mmHg. Laboratory tests are obtained and results are shown below. Antiphospholipid antibody titers are negative.  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Hematologic  
 Platelet count  56,000/mm3  
 Hemoglobin  9.8 g/dL 
 Reticulocyte count   4.2% 
 Haptoglobin  10 mg/dL 
 Prothrombin time  11 seconds  
 Partial thromboplastin time  29 seconds 
 Bleeding time  8 minutes  
Blood, plasma, serum  
 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)  380 U/L 
 Total bilirubin  5.1 mg/dL 
 Direct bilirubin  0.3 mg/dL 
 Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)  980 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)  530 U/L 
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This pregnant woman in her third trimester who presents with microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes most likely has HELLP syndrome. HELLP syndrome is a potential complication of severe preeclampsia and is defined by Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, and Low Platelets.  




Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is a type of extrinsic, intravascular hemolytic anemia that is due to mechanical destruction of erythrocytes in small blood vessels. Common causes of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia include HELLP syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), hypertensive emergency, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), and hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). Laboratory findings show hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia. Peripheral blood smear shows schistocytes, which are sheared erythrocyte fragments.  



Option Analysis

❌ Preeclampsia :
Incorrect: Preeclampsia is defined by new-onset hypertension greater than 140/90 with proteinuria or end-organ damage after week 20 of gestation. However, patients with preeclampsia alone would not present with hemolysis, thrombocytopenia, or elevated AST and ALT.    
❌ Ruptured ectopic pregnancy  :
Incorrect: Ruptured ectopic pregnancy is defined by a pregnancy outside of the uterus, most commonly in the ampulla of the fallopian tube, which leads to rupture of the fallopian tube. Patients would not present with thrombocytopenia and elevated liver enzymes, and ectopic pregnancies are generally diagnosed much earlier than the third trimester.    
✅ HELLP syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Eclampsia:
Incorrect: Eclampsia is defined by the combination of preeclampsia (new-onset hypertension with proteinuria or end-organ damage after week 20 of gestation) and seizures. However, patients with eclampsia alone would not present with hemolysis, thrombocytopenia, or elevated AST and ALT.    
❌ Gestational hypertension:
Incorrect: Gestational hypertension is defined as a new-onset hypertension greater than 140/90 after week 20 of gestation without signs of end-organ damage. However, patients would not present with hemolysis, thrombocytopenia, or elevated AST and ALT.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to upper neck and jaw pain that started gradually a week ago. The patient is generally healthy, and medical history is unremarkable other than dysmenorrhea, for which she takes acetaminophen. Two weeks ago, she had an upper respiratory infection that resolved without treatment. During the past week, she has noticed that she sweats more than usual and has difficulty sleeping. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged and very sensitive to touch. Laboratory tests are obtained and reveal the following:


Radioactive iodine uptake test is performed and reveals diffusely decreased uptake. Which of the following is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This previously healthy patient is presenting with a painful and enlarged thyroid gland following a viral infection, as well as symptoms of hyperthyroidism (e.g., tachycardia, sweating, insomnia). The laboratory results are also consistent with hyperthyroidism, showing low TSH and high free T3 and T4. Finally, the radioactive iodine uptake test shows diffusely decreased uptake, confirming the diagnosis of subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (de Quervain).  

Subacute granulomatous thyroiditis is an inflammatory condition of the thyroid gland that usually follows a viral infection. It is characterized by neck pain, a tender goiter, and a predictable course of hyperthyroidism, followed by euthyroidism, hypothyroidism, and eventually restoration of normal thyroid function. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein (CRP) are usually elevated.  

The majority of patients are treated with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or prednisone, although some patients with mild symptoms require no treatment. Propranolol may be added to patients who have bothersome symptoms of hyperthyroidism. Levothyroxine may be administered if the hypothyroidism phase is more pronounced.  


Option Analysis

❌ Circulating TSH receptor antibodies:
Incorrect: Circulating TSH receptor antibodies are present in patients with Graves disease. Patients with Graves hyperthyroidism can have neck pain or tenderness; however, the pain is much less severe than in subacute thyroiditis. Also, in Graves hyperthyroidism, radioactive iodine uptake is high, not low.
❌ Circulating thyroid peroxidase antibodies:
Incorrect: Circulating thyroid peroxidase antibodies are the pathogenesis behind Hashimoto thyroiditis (or antibodies to thyroglobulin or TSH-blocking antibodies). Hashimoto thyroiditis rarely causes pain.
✅ Granulomatous inflammation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Suppurative inflammation:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes acute infectious (or “suppurative”) thyroiditis and hemorrhage into a thyroid nodule. While both can present with severe thyroid pain, these abnormalities are predominantly unilateral. Moreover, a cyst is usually found on imaging in patients with acute infectious thyroiditis.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man comes to the primary care office because of fatigue, shortness of breath, pallor, and increased respiratory infections for the past six months. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 108/68 mmHg. Physical examination shows scleral icterus. Laboratory tests are obtained, and the results are shown below.

Acidified serum lysis test is positive. Which of the following is a potential complication of this patient’s disease?
questions.solution:
This patient with pancytopenia and positive acidified serum lysis test has paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). PNH is a genetic disorder caused by a somatic mutation of the PIG-A gene in myeloid stem cells. This gene encodes for a protein called phosphatidylinositol glycan A that is required to synthesize another protein called GPI anchor. GPI anchor is found on the membrane of all blood cells and serves to anchor proteins like decay accelerating factor (DAF), also known as CD55 and CD59, to the cell membrane. These DAF proteins normally inactivate complement and protect the cell from complement-mediated lysis.  



Therefore, in patients with PNH, there is complement-mediated lysis of myeloid stem cells, which leads to aplastic anemia and pancytopenia. Severe complications of PNH include pulmonary embolism, myelodysplastic disorders, and leukemia. The exact reason for an increased risk of thrombosis in patients with PNH is uncertain, but it is likely multifactorial. One explanation is a complement-mediated attack on CD55- and CD59-deficient platelets, which results in the generation of factors Va, Xa and prothrombin complex.  

Definitive diagnosis is achieved by flow cytometry, Ham (acidified serum lysis) test or sucrose hemolysis test. Treatment includes anti-complement therapy with eculizumab and hematopoietic stem cell transplant.  

Option Analysis

❌ Acute chest syndrome:
Incorrect: Acute chest syndrome is a type of vaso-occlusive crisis that is characteristic of sickle cell disease. This patient with pancytopenia and positive acidified serum lysis test has paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria.
❌ Splenic sequestration  :
Incorrect: Splenic sequestration, which is caused by large blood volumes being trapped in the spleen, is a potential complication of sickle cell disease. This patient with pancytopenia and positive acidified serum lysis test has paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria.
✅ Pulmonary embolism:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Priapism:
Incorrect: Priapism is a persistent penile erection in the absence of sexual stimulation. It is characterized by an extremely painful erection and can be seen in men with sickle cell disease (and less commonly, sickle cell trait). Priapism occurs due to decreased blood flow in the penile arteries caused by impaired venous outflow in the corpora cavernosa, which leads to penile rigidity and pain; this is similar to compartment syndromes in other parts of the body.  
❌ Myocardial infarction:
Incorrect: This patient with pancytopenia and positive acidified serum lysis test has paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria. Myocardial infarction is not associated with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman comes to the clinic complaining of headaches, palpitations, and muscle pain for the last 2 months. The patient’s medical history is non-contributory, and she is not currently taking any medications. The patient’s temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 186/92 mmHg. The physician prescribes lisinopril 10 mg and recommends a follow up in one month. One month later, the patient returns to the clinic with persistent symptoms. Upon further questioning, the patient admits to consumption of five cups of Egpytian licorice tea daily for the past six months. Laboratory tests are obtained, and the results are shown below:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
Blood, serum, plasma 
Potassium   3.2 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  44 mEq/L 
 Aldosterone  decreased 
 Renin  decreased 
Which of the following enzymes is most likely inhibited in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with headaches, palpitations, muscle pain, treatment-resistant hypertension, and chronic licorice (glycyrrhetinic acid) consumption most likely has an acquired form of the syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess (SAME).   

SAME can be hereditary or acquired. In its inherited form, SAME is an autosomal recessive disorder that is caused by an inhibition or deficiency of 11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase in the collecting duct of the nephron. Normally, this enzyme converts cortisol to cortisone, a less potent hormone; therefore, a decrease in enzyme activity leads to increased levels of cortisol. Excess cortisol binds and over-activates mineralocorticoid receptors in the collecting duct of the kidneys, which mimics the effects of aldosterone.

Thus serum aldosterone levels are low, but the patient’s clinical presentation is consistent with hyperaldosteronism. This includes increased sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion, leading to hypertension and hypokalemia. The kidneys will attempt to compensate for these changes by increasing the activity of the K+/H+ ATPase in the collecting duct. This will lead to increased hydrogen ion secretion and metabolic alkalosis.  

One common cause of acquired SAME is chronic licorice consumption, because licorice contains glycyrrhetinic acid, which can inhibit 11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase.  Treatment for SAME includes normalizing potassium levels, identifying the underlying cause, discontinuing the offending agent, and regular monitoring of patient’s blood pressure.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ 17α-hydroxylase:
Incorrect: 17α-hydroxylase deficiency is associated with a type of congenital adrenal hyperplasia with increased mineralocorticoids, decreased cortisol, and decreased sex hormones. The patient’s age decreases the likelihood of a congenital adrenal hyperplasia.  
❌ 21-hydroxylase:
Incorrect: 21-hydroxylase deficiency is associated with a type of congenital adrenal hyperplasia with decreased mineralocorticoids, decreased cortisol, and increased sex hormones. The patient’s hypertension and age decrease the likelihood of a congenital adrenal hyperplasia.  
✅ 11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ 11β-hydroxylase:
Incorrect: 11β-hydroxylase deficiency is associated with a type of congenital adrenal hyperplasia with decreased aldosterone, increased 11-deoxycorticosterone (which functions as a mineralocorticoid in excess), decreased cortisol, and increased sex hormones. The patient’s age decreases the likelihood of this diagnosis.  
❌ 5α-reductase:
Incorrect: 5α-reductase deficiency is associated with an inability to convert testosterone into dihydrotestosterone. The patient’s age and symptoms suggest a different diagnosis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female presents to the pulmonologist due to ongoing difficulty breathing. She was recently hospitalized due to a secondary spontaneous pneumothorax that was successfully treated with a tube thoracostomy. The patient reports dyspnea with exertion, which began almost a year ago and has progressively worsened. She has a twenty pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 82/min, blood pressure is 147/86 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 17/min. Physical examination reveals an increased anterior-posterior chest diameter and hyperresonant lungs bilaterally. Spirometry testing reveals a markedly reduced FEV<sub>1</sub>/FVC ratio. Which of the following best describes the altered physiologic feature contributing to this patient's underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has increased anterior-posterior chest diameter, hyperresonant lungs, and a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio in the setting of a long smoking history. She most likely has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), a condition characterized by loss of elastic tissue in the lungs. COPD contributes to the development of secondary spontaneous pneumothorax by promoting the formation of bullae, which are large air-filled sacs that can rupture and release air into the pleural cavity.  

In healthy individuals, spontaneous lung collapse is prevented by a combination of 1) chest wall and diaphragmatic muscle tension, 2) elastic recoil of the lungs, and 3) negative pleural pressure. The chest wall muscles and diaphragm exert an outward tension on the lungs. Elastic recoil arises secondary to connective tissue within the lungs and exerts an inward tension. In between the chest wall and lungs is the pleural space, which contains around 10-20 ml of pleural fluid. The muscle tension and elastic recoil pulling in opposite directions creates a slight vacuum in the pleural space with a pressure of -5 cm H2O, relative to 0 cm H2O in both the thoracic cavity and the lungs. The difference in pressure aids air exchange during breathing and further prevents the lungs from collapsing.  

Option Analysis

✅ Decreased elastic recoil:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased muscle tension:
Incorrect: This patient likely had a spontaneous pneumothorax secondary to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Although muscle tension is an important physiologic characteristic that helps maintain ribcage stability, it remains largely unchanged from baseline in patients with COPD.
❌ Surfactant dysfunction:
Incorrect: Surfactant helps reduce surface tension, thereby preventing the alveolar walls from adhering to one another. It is commonly disrupted in acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS). Although surfactant production can be reduced in patients with COPD, it is not the primary physiologic change contributing to the condition.
❌ Increased intrapleural pressure:
Incorrect: Increased intrapleural pressure can occur in conditions that disrupt the integrity of the pleural cavity (e.g. stab wound, pneumothorax). However, changes in intrapleural pressure would not contribute to the development of this patient’s underlying COPD.
❌ Increased elastic recoil:
Incorrect: Increased elastic recoil is observed in patients with restrictive lung diseases. These patients will have a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio. In contrast, this patient has a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio, which is suggestive of obstructive lung disease.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to his outpatient provider because of “yellowing of the skin.” Two days earlier, the patient was started on trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for bacterial cystitis. The patient previously had a similar episode during college after a viral upper respiratory tract infection. Past medical history is notable for asthma, for which he currently uses an albuterol inhaler. Family history is notable for hypertension in his mother and peripheral vascular disease in his father. The patient’s vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and jaundice of the skin. Peripheral blood smear reveals Heinz bodies and bite cells. Which of the following laboratory findings will be most likely present in this patient?

choices.text: Unconjugated bilirubin  Conjugated bilirubin  Urine hemoglobin  ↑  Normal  ↑
Unconjugated bilirubin  Conjugated bilirubin  Urine hemoglobin  ↑  Normal  Normal
Unconjugated bilirubin  Conjugated bilirubin  Urine hemoglobin  ↑  ↑  Normal

questions.solution:
This patient likely has glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, a condition characterized by red blood cells that are vulnerable to hemolysis when exposed to oxidative stress. Potential triggers include fava beans, medications (e.g. TMP-SMX), and infections. The hemoglobin released from lysed cells is either converted to unconjugated bilirubin or excreted via urine. As a result, G6PD deficiency causes unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and increased urine hemoglobin levels.  

Other causes of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia include conditions that increase hemoglobin breakdown (e.g. hemolytic disease of the newborn), impaired hepatic bilirubin uptake (e.g. congestive heart failure), or impaired bilirubin conjugation (e.g. Crigler-Najjar syndrome).  

Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia can cause jaundice and scleral icterus. Since unconjugated bilirubin is lipid-soluble, it can also deposit in the brain when concentrations are high enough. This phenomenon causes kernicterus, also termed bilirubin encephalopathy, which is a potentially fatal condition characterized by jaundice and neurological problems. In addition, patients will have increased concentrations of unconjugated bilirubin in the bile, which can result in the formation of small, black, pigmented gallstones.  

Option Analysis

✅   Unconjugated bilirubin  Conjugated bilirubin  Urine hemoglobin  ↑  Normal  ↑ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Unconjugated bilirubin  Conjugated bilirubin  Urine hemoglobin  ↑  Normal  Normal:
Incorrect: This patient likely has increased hemolysis secondary to glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency. Hemolysis causes increased quantities of hemoglobin to be released. The hemoglobin is either converted into unconjugated bilirubin or excreted in the urine. The latter will cause patients to have elevated urine hemoglobin levels. 
❌   Unconjugated bilirubin  Conjugated bilirubin  Urine hemoglobin  Normal ↑  ↑ :
Incorrect: Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia can be caused by impaired bilirubin excretion or biliary tract obstruction. Potential causes range from Crigler-Najjar syndrome (unlikely in this adult patient) to primary sclerosing cholangitis. However, none of those potential etiologies would cause Heinz bodies or bite cells.
❌   Unconjugated bilirubin  Conjugated bilirubin  Urine hemoglobin  ↑  ↑  Normal:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with mixed hyperbilirubinemia, which is most often caused by hepatitis or cirrhosis. However, this patient lacks risk factors for either of these conditions. Moreover, this patient has no physical examination findings, such as ascites or hepatosplenomegaly, that would be concerning for hepatitis or cirrhosis.
❌   Unconjugated bilirubin  Conjugated bilirubin  Urine hemoglobin  Normal Normal  Normal:
Incorrect: These findings would be seen in a healthy individual. However, this patient has jaundice and scleral icterus, which are indicative of elevated bilirubin levels.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a high speed motor vehicle accident. The patient is agitated and in respiratory distress. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 98/63 mmHg. Respirations are 25/min, and the patient has an oxygen saturation of 87% on room air. An immediate chest x-ray is obtained and demonstrates the following findings:

Image reproduced from

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s chest radiograph shows several left-sided rib fractures and the deep sulcus sign, which is strongly associated with pneumothorax. The deep sulcus sign describes when the costophrenic angle of the affected side appears more deep and lucent than usual.  

Pneumothorax, or air in the pleural cavity, is defined radiographically by a visible visceral pleural edge, which appears as a thin, sharp white line with no lung markings peripheral to this line. A spontaneous pneumothorax typically presents with this feature alone, without other evidence of trauma or associated disease. A tension pneumothorax will show tracheal deviation, shift of mediastinal structures, and usually near to complete collapse of the affected lung.  

Most pneumothoraces can be diagnosed via chest radiograph. However, a chest CT scan can be utilized in uncertain cases.  

Option Analysis

✅ Traumatic pneumothorax:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Tension pneumothorax:
Incorrect: Tension pneumothorax presents radiographically with tracheal deviation, shift of mediastinal structures, and usually near-to-complete collapse of the affected lung. In contrast, this patient’s mediastinum and trachea appear to be midline.
❌ Primary spontaneous pneumothorax:
Incorrect: Primary spontaneous pneumothorax occurs in otherwise healthy patients without evidence or history of trauma. The presence of multiple rib fractures in the inferior portion of the patient’s left chest wall makes this diagnosis incorrect.
❌ Pulmonary contusion:
Incorrect: Pulmonary contusions are a common complication of blunt trauma to the chest. The condition may present with features of consolidation or incomplete opacification of the lung. In contrast, there is no evidence of consolidation on this patient’s x-ray.
❌ Re-expansion pulmonary edema:
Incorrect: Re-expansion pulmonary edema occurs when a collapsed lung is rapidly re-expanded. The condition, like pulmonary contusion, presents with radiographic features of partial lung opacification. In contrast, this patient’s x-ray shows the deep sulcus sign, which is strongly associated with pneumothorax.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the office because of facial puffiness. Her parent states that the patient has been easily fatigued and has had red-colored urine for the past several days. Past medical history is significant for a throat infection 3 weeks ago that was treated with amoxicillin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 150/95 mmHg. Physical examination shows periorbital edema and 2+ pitting edema along the ankles bilaterally. Blood urea nitrogen is 30 mg/dL, and serum creatinine is 1.6 mg/dL. Which of the following sets of findings will most likely be seen on urinalysis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with edema, hematuria, fatigue and hypertension, together with increased blood urea nitrogen (azotemia) makes nephritic syndrome the most likely diagnosis. The recent history of throat infection treated with amoxicillin points towards poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).  

Nephritic syndrome is the result of glomerular inflammation that can be due to a number of causes, such as PSGN. It causes glomerular basement membrane (GBM) damage that results in leaking of red blood cells (hematuria) and albumin (proteinuria) into urine. Hematuria and red blood cell (RBC) casts disrupt the glomerular filtration, leading to oliguria, pyuria, azotemia, increased renin release, and consequent hypertension. Hematuria due to glomerular disease can be distinguished from that due to other causes (e.g., nephrolithiasis, cancer) by urinalysis findings showing RBC casts and dysmorphic RBCs, which are only seen in glomerulonephritis.  


The findings mentioned above can be seen on urinalysis. Additional investigations helpful in determining the specific cause include serum complement levels (usually decreased in diseases involving immune complex formation, such as PSGN) and antibody screening (e.g., antistreptolysin O, anti-double stranded DNA). Definitive diagnosis of a particular disease process requires renal biopsy.

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: These findings are seen in acute interstitial nephritis. This condition is usually the result of a hypersensitivity to certain drugs (e.g., diuretics, NSAIDs, penicillin) and often presents with fever, rash, hematuria and costovertebral angle tenderness. The interstitial inflammation results in pyuria (classically eosinophils) and the formation of white blood cells casts.
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: This set of findings is classic for nephrotic syndrome. This condition usually occurs due to glomerular podocyte damage resulting in an impaired charge barrier and subsequent proteinuria. It is associated with a hypercoagulable state (due to renal loss of antithrombin III) and increased risk of infection (due to renal loss of immunoglobulins and complement factors), not hypertension, azotemia and hematuria as seen in this patient.
❌ :
Incorrect: Hyaline casts are nonspecific and can be seen on a normal urinalysis. These casts are the result of solidification of Tamm-Horsfall mucoprotein that is secreted by renal tubular cells. The sloughing can sometimes be increased during exercise or diuretics use.
❌ :
Incorrect: Granular “muddy-brown” casts of tubular epithelial cells are seen in acute tubular necrosis. This condition is usually a result of ischemic or nephrotoxic injury to kidney tubules that clinically presents with oliguria and uremia, followed by a recovery phase in which polyuria is seen. It does not cause nephritic syndrome.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man is brought to office because of bumps on his arms and blood in his urine for the past 2 weeks. The bumps are non-pruritic but painful to touch. He has not had a recent upper respiratory infection, hemoptysis, or facial rashes. Past medical history is significant for allergic rhinitis and poorly-controlled asthma, diagnosed 10 years ago. He takes doses of inhaled corticosteroids. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows periorbital edema and a transverse nasal crease. Subcutaneous nodules are noted on the extensor surface of the arms and forearms and are tender to palpation. Laboratory evaluation is shown:

Renal biopsy findings show glomerular crescent formation. Which of the following additional laboratory findings is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has nephritic syndrome (hematuria, edema, proteinuria and red blood cell casts) in association with a history of atopic disorders (rhinitis, asthma), eosinophilia, and subcutaneous tender nodules. Together with renal biopsy findings of glomerular crescent formation, the most likely diagnosis is eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA).  

EGPA, formerly called Churg-Strauss syndrome, is a multisystem small-vessel vasculitis that occurs due to abnormalities in immune function that are not well-understood. The result is eosinophilic infiltration and formation of necrotizing granulomas in the involved organs. It is usually associated with atopic disorders (allergic rhinitis, asthma) and can present with nephritic syndrome (rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis), skin nodules or purpura (cutaneous), wrist/foot drop (neuropathy) and abdominal pain/diarrhea (gastrointestinal). Laboratory findings include normocytic anemia, leukocytosis, eosinophilia, and myeloperoxidase antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (MPO-ANCA), also known as p-ANCA, which are found in up to 60 percent cases of EGPA.  

Definitive diagnosis is usually made on biopsy of the involved organs (e.g. skin), which reveals eosinophilic infiltration and noncaseating granulomas. Renal biopsy reveals characteristic fibrin and C3 deposition in the form of a crescent.


Glucocorticoids are the mainstay of treatment for EGPA due to their immunosuppressive effects. Severe or refractory disease requires addition of cyclophosphamide or immunosuppressive agents (azathioprine, methotrexate).

Option Analysis

✅ Myeloperoxidase antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Proteinase 3 antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies:
Incorrect: PR3-ANCA/c-ANCA autoantibodies against neutrophil granule proteins are seen in granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), formerly called Wegener granulomatosis. Though the condition does cause crescentic glomerulonephritis, eosinophilia is not present and skin nodules are uncommon. Additionally, since GPA also affects the pulmonary parenchyma, hemoptysis is commonly seen.
❌ Elevated antistreptolysin O (ASO) titers:
Incorrect: Antistreptolysin O (ASO) titers are usually high in poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN), which is commonly seen in children with a history of group A streptococcus pharyngitis or impetigo. Although the patient presents with nephritic syndrome, eosinophilia is atypical and renal biopsy instead shows hypercellular glomeruli and subepithelial humps.
❌ Anti-double stranded DNA antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-dsDNA antibodies are usually found in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). When it involves kidneys, SLE causes diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis, which is seen on renal biopsy specimen as GBM thickening and wire-looping of capillaries. Common skin manifestations include the classic malar rash and discoid rash. Tender subcutaneous nodules are rare.
❌ Hepatitis B surface antigen:
Incorrect: Hepatitis B virus seropositivity is associated with several conditions like type I membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) and polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). The former is differentiated on renal biopsy findings of subepithelial deposits and tram-track appearance of the GBM, while the latter is a vasculitis that can cause renal microaneurysms but does not involve glomeruli.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman with a history of chronic alcohol use disorder comes to the office because of diarrhea, generalized weakness, and a 6.8-kg (15-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. She reports intermittent dull upper abdominal pain that will last for days at a time and is not improved with antacids. After meals, she feels that her abdomen is distended. She characterizes her multiple daily bowel movements as greasy, foul-smelling, and oily. She recently was the driver involved in a minor traffic accident, which she attributes to worsening eyesight at night. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Abdominal examination shows resonance to percussion throughout and a mildly tender epigastrium. Bowel sounds are hyperactive. Laboratory values show the following:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Calcium, serum  7.6 mg/dL 
 Partial thromboplastin time  60 seconds 
 Prothrombin time  28 seconds 

Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's diarrhea?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has pancreatic exocrine dysfunction secondary to chronic pancreatitis from chronic heavy alcohol consumption. Continuous inflammation or repeated episodes of acute pancreatitis results in replacement of normal pancreatic parenchyma with fibrotic tissue, leading to the loss of pancreatic exocrine acinar cells. These cells contain digestive enzymes (including trypsinogen) that are secreted into the pancreatic ducts and subsequently activated in the duodenum to digest food into its absorbable components. When these cells and enzymes are lost, dietary lipids cannot be absorbed. As a consequence, patients may experience features of fat malabsorption including fatty diarrhea (steatorrhea) and fat-soluble vitamin (A, D, E, & K) deficiency. Malabsorption of the fat-soluble vitamins may cause their respective deficiency symptoms:  


This patient is experiencing visual difficulties while driving most likely due to vitamin A deficiency. Her laboratory values show hypocalcemia due to vitamin D deficiency, and a prolonged PT and aPTT due to vitamin K deficiency. Appropriate pancreatic enzyme replacement will improve this patient’s ability to absorb these fat-soluble vitamins and improve her steatorrhea.  

Option Analysis

❌ Carcinoid tumor:
Incorrect: Carcinoid tumors most commonly occur in the gastrointestinal tract and can cause carcinoid syndrome, which is characterized by secretory diarrhea, flushing, tachycardia, and right-sided heart failure. 
❌ Celiac disease:
Incorrect: Celiac disease causes malabsorption via an inflammatory autoimmune response to dietary gluten; however, in the setting of chronic heavy alcohol use, pancreatic insufficiency secondary to chronic alcohol-related pancreatitis is a more likely diagnosis.
❌ Chronic gastritis:
Incorrect: Chronic gastritis is common with long standing heavy alcohol intake and may cause epigastric pain; however, it does not cause malabsorption or diarrhea.
✅ Chronic pancreatitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pancreatic adenocarcinoma:
Incorrect: Pancreatic adenocarcinoma can produce weight loss and abdominal discomfort but would be unlikely to cause diarrhea. A mass in the head of the pancreas may cause obstructive jaundice and elevations in serum liver enzymes.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for evaluation of persistent low back pain and stiffness of several weeks duration. The pain is worse in the morning and gradually improves with activity throughout the day. The patient is sexually active and has had four partners in the past year. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates limited spine flexion and tenderness to palpation of the lumbar spine. Laboratory results show a microcytic anemia and an elevated platelet count. An x-ray of the lumbar spine is demonstrated below. Further history is most likely to reveal which of the following clinical features?  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Acute unilateral eye pain and blurring of vision
Erythema in a malar distribution over the cheeks and nose
Chronic dry cough, dyspnea, and chest pain
Unilateral or bilateral external ear inflammation

questions.solution:
Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy (negative rheumatoid factor) resulting in destruction of articular cartilage and bony ankylosis (fusion of joints)--particularly the sacroiliac joints. The disease commonly presents with low back pain that is worse in the morning and gradually improves throughout the day. In addition, this patient has an radiograph suggestive of AS, given the  “bamboo spine” appearance due to vertebral body fusion. Of the choices listed, only acute unilateral eye pain and blurring of vision, reflective of uveitis, is associated with AS.  

Uveitis is defined by the inflammation of the uvea, which includes the iris, ciliary body, and choroid. Clinically, this condition is characterized by painful red eyes, photophobia, increased tear production, and blurry vision. Uveitis is characterized by the anatomic location of inflammation:  

  •  inflammation of the anterior uveal tract (e.g. iris and ciliary body) is referred to as anterior uveitis and can be seen in systemic inflammatory disorders, such as HLA-B27-associated entities (e.g. ankylosing spondylitis), inflammatory bowel disease, and sarcoidosis. 
  •  inflammation of the posterior uveal tract (e.g. choroid) is referred to as posterior uveitis (synonymous with choroiditis or chorioretinitis) and can be caused by infectious agents (e.g., toxoplasmosis, syphilis) or due to systemic inflammatory conditions (e.g. sarcoidosis).  
Anterior uveitis is characterized by red, painful eye(s), whereas posterior uveitis presents as worsening vision and visual field changes. Eye examination in patients with anterior uveitis reveals a constricted pupil, with leukocytes in the anterior chamber of the eye on slit lamp examination. Ophthalmic examination in posterior uveitis can reveal chorioretinal lesions.   

Option Analysis

✅ Acute unilateral eye pain and blurring of vision:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Genital ulcerations:
Incorrect: Genital ulcerations are common in patients with Behçet syndrome, an autoimmune vasculitis characterized by recurrent aphthae, ocular disease, skin lesions, gastrointestinal symptoms, and arthritis. Instead, the patient in this vignette has ankylosing spondylitis.
❌ Erythema in a malar distribution over the cheeks and nose:
Incorrect: The “butterfly rash” is the most common dermatologic manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus that often appears after sun exposure. 
❌ Chronic dry cough, dyspnea, and chest pain:
Incorrect: A chronic dry cough with dyspnea and chest pain is a common presenting sign in patients with sarcoidosis, not ankylosing spondylitis. 
❌ Unilateral or bilateral external ear inflammation:
Incorrect: Relapsing polychondritis is an immune-mediated condition associated with inflammation in cartilaginous structures. This patient’s symptoms and radiograph suggest ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old male presents to the emergency department after having an abnormal electrocardiogram during a routine outpatient visit. He is currently training for a marathon and had a pre-screening evaluation performed today. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit substances. Past medical history is notable for hypothyroidism, for which he takes levothyroxine. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 52/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 112/72 mmHg. Physical examination is significant for a well-conditioned male in no acute distress without evidence of gallops, rubs, or murmurs on cardiac auscultation. Electrocardiogram is demonstrated below:  

 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons    

Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s electrocardiographic findings?
questions.solution:
This patient is currently training for a marathon and presents with an electrocardiogram demonstrating sinus bradycardia. In the absence of other underlying factors, the sinus bradycardia is most likely due to increased vagal tone from physical conditioning.  

Sinus bradycardia is characterized by sinus rhythm (meaning there are P and T-waves for every QRS complex) and a slow heart rate (less than 60 beats per minute). Etiologies of sinus bradycardia include both physiologic and pathologic conditions. Endurance athletes often have physiologically lower resting heart rates due to increased vagal tone from exercise conditioning. Pathologic conditions include hypothyroidism, inferior wall myocardial infarction, anorexia nervosa, and the Cushing reflex. Additional etiologies include medications such as ꞵ-blocking agents, opiates, parasympathetic agents, digoxin, and antiarrhythmic agents such as amiodarone.    

Treatment involves correcting the underlying etiology and initiating targeted therapy in symptomatic patients, such as those experiencing lightheadedness, dizziness, or shortness of breath. Patients should first be treated with the antimuscarinic agent atropine. In those who fail medical management, surgical placement of a pacemaker in the right atrium should be considered.  



Option Analysis

✅ Increased vagal tone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypothyroidism:
Incorrect: While this patient has a history of hypothyroidism, he is currently medicated with recombinant thyroid hormone. Thus it is unlikely this patient’s sinus bradycardia is due to hypothyroidism.
❌ Inferior wall myocardial infarction:
Incorrect: Sinus bradycardia can manifest due to an inferior wall myocardial infarction and subsequent ischemia to the SA and AV node. However, this patient has no chest pain, ST-elevations, or evidence of Q-waves in the inferior leads. 
❌ Obstructive sleep apnea:
Incorrect: Obstructive sleep apnea is associated with sinus bradycardia through vagal stimulation. This patient does not have clinical features of obstructive sleep apnea (e.g., daytime sleepiness, elevated BMI), thus making this diagnosis unlikely. 
❌ Increased intracranial pressure:
Incorrect: Increased intracranial pressure can be caused by ischemic stroke, intracerebral hemorrhage, or cerebral trauma. It results in the Cushing triad, which is characterized by bradycardia, hypertension, and irregular breathing.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old man comes to the office for follow up regarding pulmonary function testing for ongoing  shortness of breath. The pulmonary function testing was notable for decreased total lung capacity, an increased FEV1/FVC, and decreased residual volume. He subsequently undergoes a lung biopsy that demonstrates the following histologic image:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia    

Which of the following diseases is implicated in the above microscopic lesion?
questions.solution:
This patient’s pulmonary function testing is notable for decreased total lung capacity, an increased FEV1/FVC, and decreased residual volume, consistent with restrictive lung disease. The lung biopsy demonstrates alveolar septae thickening with the presence of non-caseating granulomas (as indicated by the yellow arrows). Of the diagnoses listed, only hypersensitivity pneumonitis is associated with non-caseating granulomas.  

Restrictive lung diseases implicated in granulomatous lung disease include sarcoidosis, hypersensitivity pneumonitis, and berylliosis. Regardless, the development of granulomas in these diseases is similar and mediated via a type IV hypersensitivity reaction. In this process, antigen presenting cells like macrophages present antigens to CD4+ T-cells and secrete IL-12. Secretion of IL-12 by the macrophage induces differentiation of these CD4 cells into type 1 helper cells (Th1), which migrate to sites of antigen deposition where they release interferon-gamma, activating additional macrophages. As more macrophages become activated, they recruit even more macrophages and neutrophils through release of TNF-alpha. These cells surround the antigen and differentiated into epithelioid histiocytes and multinucleated Langhans giant cells, ultimately forming granulomas.

In these diseases, the granulomas are considered non-caseating due to the absence of central necrosis. This finding is in contrast to caseating granulomatous diseases such as tuberculosis, where the center of the granuloma becomes necrotic. Over time, the continued immunological reactions cause scarring and fibrosis, resulting in a pattern of restrictive lung disease.    

Option Analysis

✅ Hypersensitivity pneumonitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease :
Incorrect: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is a type of obstructive lung disease that presents with increased total lung capacity, decreased FEV1/FVC, and increased residual volume. It is not associated with granulomatous formation. 
❌ Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis :
Incorrect: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a type of restrictive lung disease that will typically demonstrate decreased total lung capacity, an increased FEV1/FVC, and decreased residual volume; however, it is not associated with granulomatous formation.
❌ Amiodarone toxicity :
Incorrect: Amiodarone toxicity can result in pulmonary fibrosis and restrictive lung disease that will typically demonstrate decreased total lung capacity, an increased FEV1/FVC, and decreased residual volume; however, it is not associated with granulomatous formation.
❌ Asthma :
Incorrect: Asthma is a type of obstructive lung disease that presents with increased total lung capacity, decreased FEV1/FVC, and increased residual volume. Histologically, it is characterized by  Curschmann spirals and Charcot-Leyden crystals.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old-male presents to the emergency department with increased work of breathing. He was walking to his car when he suddenly became short of breath. Past medical history includes diabetes, hypertension, and a twenty pack year smoking history. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 121/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 87/60 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 93% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is, in moderate respiratory distress, and has his left hand held over the sternum. Cardiopulmonary exam is notable for bilateral rales without gallops, rubs, or murmurs. Distal extremities are cool to the touch. The patient’s chest x-ray and electrocardiogram are demonstrated below:

Image reproduced from



Image reproduced from

Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical findings?

choices.text: Occlusion of the left anterior descending coronary artery
Large thrombus in the pulmonary artery
Systemic release of histamine and associated inflammatory mediators
Disseminated infection due to a Gram positive cocci

questions.solution:
This patient has respiratory distress, Levine sign (a clenched fist held over the chest commonly associated with anginal chest pain), hemodynamic instability, and cool extremities consistent with “cold shock.”  The differential diagnosis for cold shock includes obstructive shock, cardiogenic shock, and hypovolemic shock. Clues to elucidate the subtype of cold shock rests on clinical history, as well as laboratory, imaging, and electrocardiographic findings. For example, this patient has an ECG demonstrating ST-elevations in the antero-lateral leads and a chest x-ray demonstrating acute pulmonary edema. Together, these clinical findings are consistent with cardiogenic shock, of which the most common cause is acute myocardial infarction.  

Cardiogenic shock refers to inadequate systemic organ perfusion that arises due to cardiac dysfunction. Etiologies include myocardial infarction, congestive heart failure, valvular dysfunction, and myocardial contusion. When cardiac myocytes suffer an insult, cardiac output diminishes, and peripheral vascular beds vasoconstrict to increase systemic vascular resistance and divert blood flow to central organs (e.g., heart, kidneys). Due to this shift in vascular flow, patients develop cold peripheral extremities, pallor, and clammy skin. Additionally, the heart's diminished ability to pump blood forward causes pooling of blood in the pulmonary vasculature, resulting in acute pulmonary edema and an increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure.  

Treatment of cardiogenic shock is dependent on the underlying cause (e.g. revascularization in the case of acute myocardial infarction). In the interim, medications and support devices can be used to assist the patient’s physiology. For instance, inotropic medications and mechanical support devices (e.g. intra-aortic balloon pump) are often utilized.  

Option Analysis

✅ Occlusion of the left anterior descending coronary artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Large thrombus in the pulmonary artery:
Incorrect: A large pulmonary embolus is in the differential of obstructive shock and results in hemodynamic compromise due to profound ventilation perfusion mismatch. A large pulmonary embolism can present with a normal chest radiograph, hypoxemia, and an S1Q3T3 pattern on electrocardiogram. However, the condition would not present with ST segment elevation in V1-V5.
❌ Systemic release of histamine and associated inflammatory mediators:
Incorrect: Anaphylaxis falls under the category of distributive or “warm” shock. It arises due to systemic release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators. Unlike cardiogenic shock, which is associated with cool extremities, anaphylaxis is associated with warm extremities. Additional clues for anaphylactic shock include a history of exposure to an allergen (e.g. bee sting) or presence of a diffuse erythematous rash.  
❌ Disseminated infection due to a Gram positive cocci:
Incorrect: Sepsis falls under the category of distributive or “warm” shock. The most common cause of septic shock is bacterial pneumonia, which tends to demonstrate a focal consolidation on chest x-ray, as opposed to the diffuse interstitial pattern seen on this patient’s x-ray.  
❌ Lung collapse and tension physiology:
Incorrect: Tension pneumothorax can cause obstructive shock via compression of mediastinal structures, resulting in impaired venous return and aortic outflow obstruction. This patient has no evidence of pneumothorax on the chest x-ray.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man presents to the emergency department with retrosternal chest pain. ECG reveals ST-segment elevations in leads I and aVL suggestive of anterolateral myocardial infarction. Enroute to the cardiac catheterization lab, he undergoes ventricular fibrillation arrest and cannot be resuscitated. His post-mortem analysis demonstrates fibrotic nodules in the upper lobes of the lung, and a pathological specimen is shown below:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia  

Review of his past medical history demonstrates hypertension, diabetes, as well as a 5-pack-year smoking history and work as a sandblaster. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of his lung findings on post-mortem analysis?

choices.text: Alveolar insult and formation of hyaline membranes
Hypertrophy and hyperplasia of mucous secreting glands in bronchi
Neutrophil-mediated destruction of connective tissue in the alveolar walls

questions.solution:
This patient demonstrates fibrotic nodules in the upper lobes of the lung and has a history of working as a sandblaster -- findings consistent with silicosis, a type of pneumoconiosis. This spectrum of diseases is largely due to the impaired ability of alveolar macrophages to ingest and properly dispose of inhaled particulate matter. On pathological examination, silicotic nodules demonstrate concentrically arranged hyalinized collagen fibers surrounding an amorphous center. This “whorled” appearance of collagen fibers is characteristic of silicosis.  

Pneumoconiosis refers to a set of restrictive lung diseases and interstitial fibrosis induced by types of inhaled inorganic particulate matter. The major types of pneumoconiosis are asbestosis, silicosis, and coal workers pneumoconiosis. Berylliosis is often classified as a pneumoconiosis as well; however, its pathogenesis is mediated by a type IV hypersensitivity reaction.    

Regardless of the type, the pathogenesis of disease is similar. Inhaled particulate matter becomes impacted at distal airway bifurcations, where alveolar macrophages attempt to phagocytose and digest the foreign material. More often than not, the alveolar macrophage is unable to effectively clear the foreign material, triggering an immune response. Secretion of inflammatory cytokines and growth factors results in collagen deposition by fibroblasts, scar tissue formation, and interstitial hardening. Over time, this process manifests with an impaired diffusion interface for gas exchange, decreased lung compliance, and a restrictive lung disease pattern.    

Option Analysis

✅ Failure to phagocytose inhaled particles :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Alveolar insult and formation of hyaline membranes :
Incorrect: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) results in the development of hyaline membranes and diffuse interstitial edema. Autopsy specimens demonstrate diffuse alveolar damage.
❌ Hypertrophy and hyperplasia of mucous secreting glands in bronchi :
Incorrect: Chronic bronchitis results from long-standing smoking and causes hypertrophy and hyperplasia of mucous secreting glands. It does not induce formation of fibrotic nodules in the upper lung lobes. 
❌ Neutrophil-mediated destruction of connective tissue in the alveolar walls  :
Incorrect: Emphysema describes permanent alveoli enlargement and loss of alveolar wall elasticity. It is most commonly caused by an irritant, such as tobacco smoke, which triggers inflammation in the alveoli. Inflammatory cells (e.g. neutrophils) gather in the lungs and release destructive proteases, which degrade connective tissue in the alveolar walls. This patient’s smoking history is relatively short, and the pathological specimen showing nodular collagenous fibrosis is suggestive of another etiology. 
❌ Proliferation of undifferentiated neuroendocrine cells :
Incorrect: Small cell carcinoma of the lung results in an amorphous mass usually arising from central bronchi. This patient’s upper lung nodules and pathological specimen showing nodular collagenous fibrosis with anthracotic pigment and a peripheral rim of lymphocytes is suggestive of another etiology.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man comes to his primary care physician’s office for evaluation of right knee pain, red eyes, and lesions on soles of his feet. The patient states he had a “urinary tract infection” that was treated with antibiotics 3 weeks ago, and his symptoms appeared shortly thereafter. He has multiple sexual partners, and he uses condoms occasionally. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows bilateral conjunctival injection with scant purulent discharge at the lid margins. The right knee is mildly swollen with associated tenderness to palpation. Examination of the soles of feet is demonstrated below. Arthrocentesis of the right knee joint shows a leukocyte count of 40,000/mm3 but no organisms on gram-stain or culture. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with right knee pain and swelling, bilateral conjunctivitis and a history suspicious for chlamydial urethritis, consistent with reactive arthritis (formerly called Reiter syndrome). The erythematous scaly lesions on the soles are keratoderma blennorrhagica, the cutaneous manifestation of reactive arthritis.  
Reactive arthritis occurs days to weeks following a urinary tract or gastrointestinal tract infection, and it is thought to be an autoimmune process triggered by molecular mimicry, rather than a pathogen directly infecting the joint. It is highly associated with HLA-B27 haplotype. Causative organisms include Chlamydia, Yersinia, Salmonella, Shigella, and Campylobacter. It usually presents with a triad of asymmetric oligoarthritis (especially involving knee joint), conjunctivitis and urethritis.
