Other features include enthesitis (inflammation at the tendon or ligament insertion site), dactylitis (sausage digits) and sacroiliitis. Common extra-articular manifestations include oral ulcers, keratoderma blennorrhagica (as in this patient) and circinate balanitis (painless erythematous lesions with small, shallow ulcers on the glans penis).  

Option Analysis

❌ Ankylosing spondylitis:
Incorrect: Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory condition that presents with low back pain and morning stiffness. Although it is also a seronegative arthropathy, it is not associated with a recent infectious process. 
✅ Reactive arthritis:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Psoriatic arthritis:
Incorrect: Psoriatic arthritis is another seronegative arthropathy that occurs in conjunction with psoriatic skin lesions, which are well-defined scaly erythematous plaques on extensor surfaces. An antecedent urinary tract infection and hyperkeratotic vesicles on palms and soles are atypical.
❌ Septic arthritis:
Incorrect: Septic arthritis usually results from inoculation of Staph aureus and presents with fever and severe, focal joint pain. Examination typically shows an erythematous tender swollen joint with associated effusion. Arthrocentesis normally reveals synovial fluid leukocytes >50,000/mm3 and gram positive organisms on gram stain as well as culture. 
❌ Gout:
Incorrect: Gout typically presents with acute onset (<12 hours) pain and swelling in the affected joint--usually the great toe. Synovial fluid analysis reveals negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals. Vesicular lesions and conjunctivitis are not associated with gout.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old male presents for evaluation of intense pruritus and fatigue over the last 5 weeks. He is a construction worker and has found it difficult to complete tasks due to constant tiredness. He has not been to a physician in over 10 years because of financial concerns. The patient has not had any recent abdominal pain or diarrhea, but has had multiple episodes of bloody diarrhea that self-resolved several years ago. He drinks 2-3 beers on the weekends but does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit substances. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 126/85 mmHg. Physical examination reveals scleral icterus and multiple excoriations over the trunk and arms. There is no tenderness to palpation of the abdomen. Laboratory testing reveals the following:



Which of the following additional findings is likely present in this patient?

choices.text: Colonoscopy showing friable mucosa with superficial ulcerations
Right upper quadrant abdominal ultrasound showing gallbladder wall thickening and edema
Intestinal biopsy showing noncaseating granulomas and lymphoid aggregates
Positive anti-hepatitis A virus IgM antibodies

questions.solution:
This patient has pruritus, fatigue, scleral icterus, and positive p-ANCA antibodies as well as a history of intermittent bloody bowel movements. These findings are suggestive of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and undiagnosed ulcerative colitis, which manifests with an inflamed, reddened mucosa with superficial ulcerations on colonoscopy.  

PSC is characterized by chronic autoimmune-mediated inflammation of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts. Although the precise etiology is unclear, there is a strong association with autoimmune diseases, and in particular ulcerative colitis (UC). 90% of patients with PSC have an underlying diagnosis of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD); nearly 90% of these IBD patients have UC while the remaining 10% have Crohn disease. The autoimmune nature of PSC is further reinforced by the presence of T-cells in the periductal stroma on biopsy.  

Clinical symptoms may include jaundice, pruritus, and fatigue. If untreated, patients may go on to develop cirrhosis. Laboratory testing will typically be positive for perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA). Since PSC affects both intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts, irregular biliary strictures and dilations result in a characteristic “beading” pattern on MRCP. Unlike primary biliary cholangitis, there is no medication that can consistently prevent disease progression; currently, ursodeoxycholic acid is commonly given to help decrease inflammation by mechanisms that are not completely understood.  



Option Analysis

✅ Colonoscopy showing friable mucosa with superficial ulcerations:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Positive anti-mitochondrial antibodies  :
Incorrect: Primary biliary cholangitis is another bile duct-related condition. It primarily affects middle-aged women, and individuals are typically positive for anti-mitochondrial antibodies. In contrast, this patient is p-ANCA positive and more likely has primary sclerosing cholangitis.
❌ Right upper quadrant abdominal ultrasound showing gallbladder wall thickening and edema:
Incorrect: Cholecystitis is due to inflammation of the gallbladder and presents with severe abdominal pain and fever. The chronicity of this patient’s symptoms and lack of abdominal tenderness makes this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Intestinal biopsy showing noncaseating granulomas and lymphoid aggregates:
Incorrect: Crohn disease results in noncaseating granuloma formation in the gastrointestinal tract. This patient has a history of bloody diarrhea, which may be consistent with Crohn disease. However, patients with Crohn disease are less likely to have p-ANCA antibodies or to have primary sclerosing cholangitis than those with ulcerative colitis.
❌ Positive anti-hepatitis A virus IgM antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-HAV IgM antibodies are seen in patients with acute hepatitis A. Hepatitis A typically results in acute jaundice as well as severe abdominal pain, nausea, and fever.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man comes to the clinic because of increased urination and thirst for the past three months. He mentions that he urinates approximately 10 times per day, including 3-4 times at night, and he drinks about 6 liters of water per day. Past medical history is noncontributory, and the patient does not take any medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory studies are as follows:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
Sodium  150 mEq/L 
 Serum osmolality  309 mOsmol/kg 
 Urine osmolality  187 mOsmol/kg 

There is inadequate change in the values after two hours of water deprivation. Desmopressin (antidiuretic hormone analog) is then administered. Laboratory studies one hour later revealed serum osmolality of 282 mOsmol/kg and urine osmolality of 500 mOsmol/kg. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings of polydipsia and polyuria, together with significant rise in urine osmolality after a trial of vasopressin makes the diagnosis of central DI most likely in this patient.  

Diabetes insipidus (DI) can be categorized into central DI, where there is a lack of ADH secretion from the posterior pituitary, or nephrogenic DI, where the V2 receptors in the kidney do not respond to ADH. Individuals with DI present with mild hypernatremia, high-normal serum osmolality, and low urine osmolality.  

It is crucial to distinguish between primary polydipsia, central DI and nephrogenic DI since each of them is managed differently. The first step is a water deprivation test. In patients with a normal ADH axis and low serum and urine osmolality, water deprivation will lead to an elevation in serum and urine osmolality, making primary polydipsia the most likely diagnosis. The next step is a trial of desmopressin (an ADH analog) administration, which helps in differentiating central from nephrogenic DI. In the former, the urine osmolality tends to rise after administering desmopressin, while there is no change in the latter. This patient’s low urine osmolality and high serum osmolality that corrected following the administration of desmopressin suggests the diagnosis of central DI. Treatment consists of proper hydration and desmopressin.  



Option Analysis

❌ Primary polydipsia:
Incorrect: Primary polydipsia is caused by abnormally increased thirst that leads to an excessive intake of fluids and frequent urination. It is usually associated with psychiatric conditions (e.g. schizophrenia). Low serum sodium and low urine osmolality are expected, neither of which is seen in this patient.
✅ Central diabetes insipidus:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus:
Incorrect: Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI) also presents with polydipsia, polyuria, and thirst, but the condition is due to the failure of the kidney to respond to circulating antidiuretic hormone (ADH). No change is expected in serum and urine osmolality after ADH administration. This patient’s urine osmolality rose from 187 mOsmol/kg H2O to 500 mOsmol/kg H2O, indicating an appropriate ADH response.
❌ Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH):
Incorrect: SIADH usually presents with low serum osmolality, as it causes euvolemic hyponatremia. Moreover, it does not manifest as polydipsia and polyuria. Causes of SIADH include ectopic secretion (e.g., small cell lung cancer), CNS disorders/trauma, pulmonary disease, and certain drugs (e.g., cyclophosphamide, SSRIs).
❌ Diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Diabetes mellitus can present with polydipsia and polyuria due to osmotic diuresis (glucosuria). However, the findings after the water deprivation test and desmopressin administration suggest another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man comes to the outpatient provider because of a 5-month history of weakness in the shoulders and hip muscles. The patient reports having difficulty getting out of a chair and climbing stairs. The patient has no other medical conditions and previously led an active lifestyle. Temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), blood pressure is 122/68 mmHg, pulse is 67/min, and respiratory rate is 12/min. Physical examination is notable for tenderness and weakness in the shoulder and hip muscles. The following is also noted on bilateral ocular examination:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following findings is most specific to the patient’s condition?

choices.text: Muscle biopsy revealing perimysial CD4+ lymphocyte infiltration
Muscle biopsy revealing endomysial CD8+ lymphocyte infiltration
Radiograph revealing vertebral body erosion with reactive sclerosis

questions.solution:
Dermatomyositis is an antibody-mediated autoimmune myopathy characterized by proximal skeletal muscle weakness and skin findings. The pelvic and shoulder muscles are most commonly affected. This weakness can present as difficult rising from a chair, lifting one’s arms, climbing stairs, or combing one’s hair.  

Several skin findings may be present. A purplish rash on the upper eyelids, called a “heliotrope rash,” can often be observed. Patients can also have the “shawl sign,” which is a rash involving the shoulders, upper chest, and back. Less commonly, the patient may have a malar rash (erythema of the cheeks and bridge of the nose with sparing of the nasolabial folds), classically in the shape of butterfly. Another classic finding is the Gottron sign which consists of flat, red, scaly papules over the back of the fingers, elbows, or knees.  

Dermatomyositis occurs when the body produces self-antibodies against autoantigens in the muscle and skin. Many of the autoantibodies attach to endothelial cells lining the capillaries near the perimysium (connective tissue sheath surrounding groups of muscle fibers). This process activates the complement cascade and causes the targeted cells to lyse. Dermatomyositis can occur secondarily as a paraneoplastic syndrome of an underlying malignancy, such as Hodgkin lymphoma as well as lung, stomach, colorectal, and ovarian cancer; therefore, patients with additional constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss, night sweats) should be suspected of having an underlying malignancy.    .

Muscle biopsies are often performed in the work-up and reveal perimysial infiltration. Given the condition’s antibody-mediated pathogenesis, the infiltrate will consist of CD4+ T-cells (which regulate antibody production) and antibody-producing B-cells.   


Option Analysis

✅ Muscle biopsy revealing perimysial CD4+ lymphocyte infiltration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Muscle biopsy revealing endomysial CD8+ lymphocyte infiltration:
 Incorrect: Endomysial infiltration by CD8+ lymphocytes is consistent with the presentation of polymyositis. Polymyositis also presents with proximal muscle weakness, most often affecting the hips and shoulders. However, polymyositis does not present with skin findings, whereas this patient’s physical examination reveals a heliotrope rash on the eyelids.  
❌ Elevated serum creatinine kinase level:
Incorrect: Increased serum creatinine kinase levels would be expected in pathologies that cause muscle injury. These include trauma, rhabdomyolysis, and autoimmune myopathies such as dermatomyositis and polymyositis. However, this finding is non-specific and would have limited utility in distinguishing this patient’s likely diagnosis (dermatomyositis) from other conditions with a similar presentation.
❌ Elevated peripheral blood eosinophil count:
Incorrect: Eosinophilic infiltration may be observed in vasculitides such as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA). This condition was formerly named Churg-Strauss syndrome. EGPA can manifest with skin symptoms and potentially muscle weakness secondary to systemic inflammation. However, patients with EGPA would be expected to also have respiratory symptoms such as sinusitis and asthma.
❌ Radiograph revealing vertebral body erosion with reactive sclerosis:
Incorrect: This finding is termed the “bamboo sign” and found in patients with ankylosing spondylitis. The condition most often affects young men and presents with back pain that is worse in the morning. Ankylosing spondylitis can also affect the hip and shoulder joints, which may account for the tenderness noted on physical exam. However, it would be atypical for ankylosing spondylitis to present with the purple-red eyelid rash observed in this patient.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of fevers and a productive cough that have been ongoing for the past three days. She has not experienced hemoptysis, recent weight loss, or night sweats. Past medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus. She has a 20-pack-year smoking history. She worked as a plumber for 30 years. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 106/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 132/88 mmHg. Physical examination reveals dullness to percussion and bronchial breath sounds over the right lung. Chest radiograph reveals a right lower lobe consolidation. Sputum microscopy shows Gram-positive diplococci. Which of the following histopathological changes is most likely present in the affected lung lobe?

choices.text: Hyaline membrane formation and intraalveolar protein-rich edema
Enlargement of air spaces with destruction of alveolar septa
Interstitial fibrosis with golden-brown beaded rods
Accumulation of eosinophils within lung parenchyma
Alveolar spaces filled with neutrophils and fibrin

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with fevers, productive cough, and lobar consolidation, which are suggestive of pneumonia. Additionally, the presence of Gram-positive diplococci in the sputum indicates the underlying pathogen is likely Streptococcus pneumoniae, a common cause of community-acquired pneumonia.

Pneumonia is an infectious process resulting from the invasion and overgrowth of microorganisms in the lung parenchyma, which leads to intraalveolar exudate formation. Lobar pneumonia is classically described as having 4 stages:

  1.  The first stage is congestion. It occurs between days 1-2 and is when blood vessels and alveoli start filling with excess fluid.  
  2.  The next stage is red hepatization and occurs between days 3-4. This stage is when exudate, which contains red blood cells, neutrophils, and fibrin, starts filling airspaces and makes them more solid. The term hepatization refers to the lungs taking on a liver-like appearance due to the accumulation of reddish-brown exudate.  
  3.  The third stage is gray hepatization, which occurs around days 5-7. In this stage, the lungs are still firm but become pale gray because the red blood cells in the exudate begin breaking down.  
  4. The last stage is resolution, which occurs around day 8 and can continue for 3 weeks. In this stage, the exudate is digested by enzymes, ingested by macrophages, or coughed up.


Option Analysis

❌ Hyaline membrane formation and intraalveolar protein-rich edema:
Incorrect: This finding is seen in patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), which could be a severe complication in some cases of pneumonia. However, this patient’s chest radiograph lacks the bilateral patchy infiltrates that are characteristic of ARDS.
❌ Enlargement of air spaces with destruction of alveolar septa :
Incorrect: This finding is consistent with pulmonary emphysema. Although this patient has an extensive smoking history, the acute nature of the illness and radiographic findings demonstrating lobar consolidation are more consistent with community-acquired pneumonia.
❌ Interstitial fibrosis with golden-brown beaded rods :
Incorrect: This histopathological finding can be seen in patients with asbestosis. Although this patient may have had occupational exposure to asbestos (e.g. as a plumber), the acute nature of the illness is more consistent with community-acquired pneumonia. 
❌ Accumulation of eosinophils within lung parenchyma:
Incorrect: This histopathological finding is consistent with eosinophilic lung disease. The condition can be idiopathic, due to autoimmune reactions, or due to drug side effects. However, this patient has a fever, productive cough, and chest radiograph demonstrating lobar consolidation, which is more consistent with bacterial pneumonia. 
✅ Alveolar spaces filled with neutrophils and fibrin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of diarrhea for the last several weeks. He describes his stool as bulky, greasy, and “tends to float on top of the water in the toilet.” The patient has not had similar symptoms in the past. He also unintentionally lost 11-lb over the past month. He is an avid hiker and most recently went on a hike in the Appalachians, where he regularly cooked his own meat and drank water from nearby fresh-water springs. The patient has not had fever, rashes, or any bloody stools. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a mildly tender abdomen with hyperactive bowel sounds. There are patches of skin with hyperkeratosis as well as several bruises. Stool samples are taken and stain positively with Sudan III. If this patient goes untreated, which of the following complications is he most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
This patient has signs of fat-malabsorption (e.g. bulky, greasy stools) as well as symptomatic fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies (e.g., hyperkeratosis, bruising). Taking into account his recent hiking trip and ingestion of unfiltered fresh-water, he likely has giardiasis, which is a parasitic infection that results in small-bowel dysfunction.

The fat-soluble vitamins are vitamins A, D, E, and K. Fat-soluble vitamins normally dissolve in dietary fats and migrate through the lymphatic systemic before entering the bloodstream. In patients with fat-malabsorption, this process is interrupted, and over time, a deficiency of these vitamins may develop. The patient in this vignette has signs of vitamin A deficiency, given the patches of hyperkeratosis, and vitamin K deficiency, given the bruising. If untreated, this patient is also at risk of developing vitamin D deficiency, which can lead to poor bone mineralization and increased risk of pathologic fractures.

In suspected patients, a fecal fat test, also known as Sudan III staining, can be used to evaluate for fat-malabsorption.





Option Analysis

✅ Pathologic fractures:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Sideroblastic anemia:
Incorrect: Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) is used as a cofactor by several enzymes involved in heme synthesis. Vitamin B6 deficiency can impair the addition of iron to hemoglobin. Iron eventually accumulates within the red blood cells, resulting in ring sideroblasts. However, vitamin B6 is a water-soluble vitamin, whereas this patient has symptoms of fat malabsorption. As a result, it is unlikely this patient is deficient in vitamin B6.  
❌ Dilated cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Thiamine (vitamin B1) is heavily involved in energy generation, especially during oxidative metabolism. Since cardiac tissue relies on oxidative metabolism, deficiency of vitamin B1 can lead to cardiac dysfunction and, eventually, dilated cardiomyopathy. Thiamine deficiency tends to occur in patients who are malnourished or have a history of chronic alcohol use.
❌ Adrenal insufficiency:
Incorrect: Pantothenic acid (vitamin B5) deficiency is extremely rare in humans and can occur during periods of famine in underdeveloped countries. Vitamin B5 deficiency can result in paresthesias, and if severe, adrenal gland hemorrhage and necrosis. However, pantothenic acid is a water-soluble vitamin, whereas this patient has symptoms of fat malabsorption. As a result, it is unlikely this patient has a pantothenic acid deficiency.
❌ Swollen gums and perifollicular hemorrhage:
Incorrect: Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) is heavily involved in collagen synthesis, specifically, hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues during post-translational modification of the collagen protein. The earliest and most specific sign of deficiency is follicular hyperkeratosis and perifollicular hemorrhage. Vitamin C, however, is a water-soluble vitamin, and its absorption would be unaffected in this patient who has symptoms of fat-malabsorption.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician because of worsening muscle cramps for the past few weeks. The patient was adopted, and his family history is unknown. He failed to meet multiple cognitive and developmental milestones. Past medical history is unremarkable, and the patient does not have any history of infections. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 93/min, respirations are 29/min and blood pressure is 103/72 mmHg. On the physical exam, the patient’s height is below the 5th percentile and weight exceeds the 90th percentile. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Examination of the bilateral hands reveals hypoplastic 4th and 5th digits. Gentle tapping anterior to the ear causes twitching of the lower facial muscles. Which of the following findings would most likely be observed on laboratory testing?
questions.solution:
In this vignette, a 5-year-old boy is presented with intellectual disability, developmental delay, obesity, short stature, short 4th/5th metacarpal bones with an acute complaint of muscle cramps. The examination finding of a positive Chvostek sign (gentle tapping anterior to the ear causes twitching of the lower facial muscles) is suggestive of hypocalcemia. This constellation of findings is termed Albright hereditary osteodystrophy (AHO).  

AHO is frequently associated with pseudohypoparathyroidism type 1a, an autosomal dominant condition caused by a mutation in the GNAS gene (encodes for a G-protein) that is transmitted by a mother to her offspring. Pseudohypoparathyroidism type 1a causes end-organ resistance to parathyroid hormone (PTH), leading to hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia. The body tries to correct the serum calcium by releasing more PTH; thus patients also have elevated PTH levels.  

Blood tests will reveal hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia and increased PTH levels. In cases that are difficult to diagnose, biosynthetic PTH can be infused, and urinary excretion of phosphate can be monitored. Patients with pseudohypoparathyroidism type 1a will not have an increase in excreted phosphate. Lastly, genetic testing can be used to identify the GNAS mutation and confirm the diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

❌   Parathyroid Hormone  Serum Calcium  Serum Phosphate  ↑  ↑  ↓  :
Incorrect: This set of findings would be observed in primary hyperparathyroidism, which is usually due to parathyroid adenomas. Increased PTH release causes increased calcium uptake from the kidneys and intestines. Likewise, it reduces reuptake of phosphate in the kidneys. However, hypercalcemia would not account for the positive Chvostek sign observed in this patient.
❌    Parathyroid Hormone  Serum Calcium  Serum Phosphate  Normal Normal Normal :
Incorrect: This set of laboratory results would be observed in healthy individuals and those with pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism. In the latter case, individuals present with obesity, short stature, and hypoplastic 4th/5th fingers. However, patients with pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism have normal serum calcium levels. In contrast, this patient’s clinical findings are suggestive of hypocalcemia.
✅    Parathyroid Hormone  Serum Calcium  Serum Phosphate  ↑  ↓ ↑ :
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌    Parathyroid Hormone  Serum Calcium  Serum Phosphate  ↓ ↓ ↑ :
Incorrect: A patient with hypoparathyroidism would present with this set of findings. Surgical resection (e.g., thyroidectomy, parathyroidectomy, etc.) is the most common cause of hypoparathyroidism in the United States. Hypoparathyroidism would account for the patient’s muscle cramps and spasms. However, it would not account for the developmental delays and hand abnormalities.
❌    Parathyroid Hormone  Serum Calcium  Serum Phosphate  ↓ ↑  ↓  :
Incorrect: A patient with PTH-independent hypercalcemia would present with this set of findings. Excess calcium intake, vitamin D intake, and malignancies producing parathyroid-hormone related peptide can be the cause. None of these etiologies would explain the patient’s developmental delays and hand abnormalities.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after being stabbed in the back. On primary survey, his Glasgow coma score is 15 with his airway, breathing, and circulation intact. Secondary survey is notable for a stab wound to the midline of his lumbar spine at the L1 level. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 11/min, blood pressure is 110/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 96% on room air. Neurologic examination is notable for ipsilateral loss of motor function, vibration, and proprioception below the L1 level, with contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning approximately at the L3-L4 level. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with ipsilateral loss of motor function, vibration sense, and proprioception below the level of injury along with contralateral loss of temperature and pain sensation after sustaining a stab wound to the spine. His findings are consistent with Brown-Sequard syndrome, which refers to hemi-section of the spinal cord.    

Brown-Sequard syndrome is a rare spinal cord injury pattern that occurs following a stab wound, penetrating injury, or less commonly fracture or blunt trauma. It results in ipsilateral loss of motor function, vibration sense, and proprioception due to damage of the dorsal columns and corticospinal tract. Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation occurs at one or two levels below the lesion due to damage of the spinothalamic tracts (which decussate at the anterior commissure). Furthermore, Brown-Sequard syndrome may be associated with Horner syndrome (ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis) if the lesion occurs above the T1 level and causes damage to the oculosympathetic pathway.

   

Option Analysis

✅  Brown-Sequard syndrome :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Central cord syndrome:
Incorrect: Central cord syndrome commonly occurs due to forced hyperextension injury or syringomyelia. The condition results in sensory and motor deficits, with the upper extremities affected more than the lower extremities. Stab wounds, as in the case of this patient, would not usually cause central cord syndrome.  
❌ Anterior cord syndrome :
Incorrect: Anterior cord syndrome typically results from anterior spinal artery occlusion, which leads to bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation and motor function below the lesion. It would not manifest with ipsilateral loss of motor function, vibration sense, and proprioception combined with contralateral loss of temperature and pain sensation. 
❌ Cauda equina syndrome :
Incorrect: Cauda equina syndrome results from compression of spinal roots at the L2 level or below. It is usually due to mass effect or a fracture. Cauda equina syndrome tends to present with radicular pain, urinary incontinence, and saddle anesthesia.  
❌ Complete cord syndrome:
Incorrect: Complete cord syndrome refers to complete transection of the spinal cord, of which the most common etiology is trauma. Patients with complete transection of the spinal cord will present with signs of neurogenic shock including decreased systemic vascular resistance and increased vagal tone, which result in hypotension with paradoxical bradycardia. Additionally, patients will have complete loss of motor function, sensation, and proprioception below the level of the injury.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider for evaluation of joint pain and stiffness. Her symptoms began 7 months ago. She reports that the symptoms are worse in the morning and improve after about two-hours of physical activity. In addition, the patient describes feeling tired in the morning despite getting over eight hours of sleep each night. She has had no sensation of dry eyes. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure is 140/83 mmHg, and BMI is 29 kg/m2. Physical examination is notable for swelling and pain on passive motion of the bilateral proximal interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints. No rash is observed on the patient’s body. The remainder of the examination is noncontributory. Which of the following antibodies is most specific to her condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has rheumatoid arthritis, which is characterized by immune destruction of the joints. Patients often present with symmetrical pain that improves with use, morning stiffness lasting more than an hour, and extra-articular symptoms (e.g., fatigue, uveitis). There are three antibodies associated with rheumatoid arthritis: rheumatoid factor, anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide, and antinuclear antibodies.  

Rheumatoid factor is an IgM antibody that targets the constant Fc component of human IgG antibodies. It is not specific and can be present in other conditions ranging from Sjögren syndrome to hepatitis B infection.  

Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) is an IgG antibody that targets citrullinated proteins. These are proteins whose arginine residues have been chemically modified to citrulline through a process called citrullination. Anti-CCP antibodies attach to self-proteins, such as vimentin, fibronectin, and collagen. Binding of antibodies to proteins leads to complement activation. The presence of antibodies in rheumatoid arthritis is associated with severe disease and progressive joint damage. Anti-CCP antibodies can be present in the serum up to 10 years before the onset of clinical symptoms. It has a specificity of 96%.   

Lastly, a minority of individuals can develop antinuclear antibodies, which are formed against the normal proteins of a cell’s nucleus.  



Option Analysis

❌ Antinuclear antibody:
Incorrect: This patient has symmetric joint pain that improves with movement, which is consistent with rheumatoid arthritis. Antinuclear antibodies may be found in around one-third patients with the condition. However, anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies are more specific for rheumatoid arthritis.  
❌ Rheumatoid factor:
Incorrect: Rheumatoid factor can be found in many autoimmune conditions, including rheumatoid arthritis, Sjögren syndrome, and systemic lupus erythematosus. As a result, it is not highly specific for rheumatoid arthritis.
✅ Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibody:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anti-double stranded DNA antibody:
Incorrect: This antibody is found in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which can present with a malar rash, photosensitivity, and arthritis. Although this patient has arthritis, she lacks the other symptoms associated with SLE.  
❌ Anti-Ro antibody:
Incorrect: This antibody is associated with Sjögren syndrome, which can present with dryness of the mouth and eyes due to exocrine gland destruction. However, this patient does not have any of these symptoms.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician because of progressively worsening pain, stiffness, and swelling in her joints. The patient endorses morning stiffness that improves after about two hours. In addition, she reports generalized fatigue despite getting adequate rest each evening. She has tried ibuprofen and acetaminophen for the pain, but neither was effective in improving her symptoms. Social history is notable for a 30-pack-year smoking history. Serology testing is positive for antinuclear and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies. Which of the following joints will most likely be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has rheumatoid arthritis, which is characterized by autoimmune destruction of the joint cartilage. Patients present with symmetrical involvement of three or more joints. The hallmark symptom of rheumatoid arthritis is chronic morning stiffness lasting more than an hour that subsequently improves with use. In the upper extremities, the proximal interphalangeal joints, metacarpophalangeal joints, and wrists are frequently affected. In contrast, the first carpometacarpal joint and the distal interphalangeal joints are rarely involved because they contain very little synovium. In the lower extremities, the metatarsophalangeal joints are often affected.

Patients may also exhibit reduced grip strength, reduced range of motion, pain, and swelling. Of note, rheumatoid arthritis does not usually cause redness or warmth, because the inflammation is gradual and chronic. However, it can occasionally present with acute inflammatory signs such as edema, redness, and warmth when there is an acute episode of rheumatoid arthritis, termed a flare.



Option Analysis

❌ Sacroiliac joint:
Incorrect: The sacroiliac joint is frequently affected in patients with ankylosing spondylitis, a chronic inflammatory disease of the axial skeleton. The condition most often affects young males and presents with stiffness in the neck and back. It would be atypical for ankylosing spondylitis to present in a middle-aged woman.
❌ Hip joint:
Incorrect: The hip is a weight-bearing joint that is often affected in patients with osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis causes joint pain that is exacerbated with activity. In contrast, this patient’s history of joint symptoms that improve with activity is more consistent with rheumatoid arthritis. While rheumatoid arthritis can also affect the hip joint, it tends to occur only in more severe and long-standing cases.
❌ Distal interphalangeal joint:
Incorrect: Osteoarthritis can affect the distal interphalangeal joints (DIP). However, this patient’s history of joint pain and stiffness that improves with activity is more consistent with rheumatoid arthritis. The DIPs are rarely affected in rheumatoid arthritis since they contain very little synovium.
❌ Shoulder joint:
Incorrect: This patient’s history of joint stiffness that improves with activity and constitutional symptoms, in combination with her serology results, are most consistent with rheumatoid arthritis. The shoulder joint can be affected in this condition. However, other joints in the body (e.g., metacarpophalangeal joint, proximal interphalangeal joint) are more commonly affected.
✅ Metacarpophalangeal joint:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency room for evaluation of left-arm weakness that began three-hours ago. Two-days ago, the patient returned from an overseas conference. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 71/min, and blood pressure is 143/87 mmHg. Physical examination reveals motor strength of 3/5 in the left upper and lower extremities and 5/5 in the right upper and lower extremities. Cardiac examination reveals a fixed-split S2 heart sound. Ultrasound of the lower extremities shows a blood clot in the right popliteal vein. Which of the following findings will most likely be present in this patient?

choices.text: Presence of bruit on carotid auscultation
Increased oxygen saturation in the right atrium

questions.solution:
This patient recently took a long flight after which he developed a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his popliteal vein. In addition, he most likely has an atrial septal defect (ASD), given examination finding of a fixed split S2 heart sound. The combination of these two factors means that the clot likely travelled to the right atrium and passed through the defect into the arterial circulation, ending up in cerebral vasculature, causing a stroke. This phenomenon is termed paradoxical embolism, which is a known complication of ASD.  

ASD is an acyanotic congenital heart defect that arises from impaired growth or excess resorption of the atrial septum. Most patients are asymptomatic. However, some can exhibit poor weight gain or exercise intolerance. It can cause a systolic ejection murmur loudest over the left upper sternal border. In addition, patients can have fixed-splitting of the S2 heart sound, which occurs due to ASD equalizing the effect that inspiration and expiration has on right and left ventricular output. Cardiac catheterization will show elevated oxygen saturation in the right atrium, right ventricle, and pulmonary artery. As mentioned above, ASDs can contribute to the development of paradoxical emboli.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Weakened bilateral femoral pulses :
Incorrect: Coarctation of the aorta can reduce blood flow to the lower extremity, resulting in weakened femoral pulses. In addition, the condition can cause hypertension and cerebral aneurysms. However, coarctation of the aorta would cause a continuous murmur and not a fixed-splitting of the S2 heart sound. 
❌ Elevated activated partial thromboplastin time :
Incorrect: This finding can be observed in patients with antiphospholipid syndrome (APLS). APLS can potentially explain the patient’s DVT. However, it would neither explain the heart murmur nor how an embolus from the popliteal vein ended up getting lodged in the cerebral vasculature, rather than the pulmonary vasculature. 
❌ Presence of bruit on carotid auscultation :
Incorrect: This answer describes carotid stenosis, which occurs due to build up of athersclerotic plaque inside the carotid vessels. If a portion of the plaque breaks off, it can cause a stroke. However, this patient’s heart murmur and DVT are more consistent with the presentation of a paradoxical emboli. 
✅ Increased oxygen saturation in the right atrium :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Irregularly irregular rhythm on electrocardiography :
Incorrect: This answer describes atrial fibrillation, a condition which increases the risk of thrombus formation. If a portion of the thrombus breaks off and travels to the brain, it can cause a stroke. However, atrial fibrillation would not present with fixed-splitting of the S2 heart sound.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman returns to her physician 1 week after a screening colonoscopy revealed invasive colorectal cancer. The physician discusses various treatment options, including surgical management and adjuvant chemotherapy. The patient inquires about her carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) level, which she noticed on her laboratory report, and asks why the doctor ordered it. Which of the following is the most appropriate response to the patient?

choices.text: “CEA levels will help us monitor the effectiveness of our treatment.”
“An elevated level of CEA is diagnostic for colorectal cancer.”
“CEA levels help us determine the staging of the tumor.”
“CEA levels help us determine the grading of the tumor.”
“CEA levels will help us determine what type of chemotherapy to use.”

questions.solution:
Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a glycoprotein that is involved in cell adhesion; it is produced in the embryonic pancreas, intestine, and liver. Elevated CEA levels are often detected in patients with colorectal cancer (CRC). However, the CEA level is not specific for colon cancer, and it is often elevated in patients who smoke, as well as patients with other conditions, such as inflammatory bowel disease, cirrhosis, and pancreatitis. Therefore, because of its poor specificity, CEA levels cannot be used for screening or diagnostic purposes. Due to these limitations, CEA levels can be only used to monitor the effectiveness of current treatment, as well as to monitor for future recurrence of colorectal cancer. A rising CEA level after surgical resection and adjuvant chemotherapy suggests recurrent disease and should prompt follow-up imaging.  

A complete colonoscopy is the gold standard for the diagnosis of CRC, due to its high sensitivity and specificity. Colonoscopy also allows for biopsy of suspicious masses, and subsequent histological analysis can determine whether they are indeed cancer and the depth of invasion.  

Option Analysis

✅ “CEA levels will help us monitor the effectiveness of our treatment.”:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ “An elevated level of CEA is diagnostic for colorectal cancer.”:
Incorrect: Although elevated levels of CEA are seen in patients with colorectal cancer (CRC), the finding is not diagnostic for CRC, due to significant overlap with benign disease. A colonoscopy with subsequent pathological examination is required for the diagnosis of CRC. 
❌ “CEA levels help us determine the staging of the tumor.”:
Incorrect: Although elevated levels of CEA are seen in patients with colorectal cancer, the test is not used for staging of the tumor. Staging requires assessing the size and extent of the main tumor, the number of nearby lymph nodes involved, and evaluation for metastasis. 
❌ “CEA levels help us determine the grading of the tumor.”:
Incorrect: CEA levels do not help in determining the tumor’s grade. Grading of a tumor describes the degree of tumor differentiation, which can only be determined histologically. 
❌ “CEA levels will help us determine what type of chemotherapy to use.”:
Incorrect: Although elevated levels of CEA are seen in patients with colorectal cancer, the test is not useful in determining the treatment plan. Most patients with CRC require surgical resection of the tumor, along with adjuvant chemotherapy, regardless of the CEA levels.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his partner for evaluation of worsening confusion and changes in personality. Symptoms began three months ago. The patient has had multiple falls over this same time period, which the partner attributes to his “unsteady gait.” He has not had urinary incontinence, fevers, or hallucinations. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. He has never consumed alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient demonstrates nystagmus at rest. He is unable to perform rapidly alternating pronation and supination movements with his hands. The patient scores 17/30 on the Mini-Mental State Examination (normal: ≥24). Brain biopsy from a deceased patient with the same condition is shown below:  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following additional physical exam findings is likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Sudden involuntary contraction of muscles after a loud sound
Unilateral, violent, flailing motion of the arm
Flapping motion of the hands when arms are extended
Restlessness and intense urge to move
Slow, writhing movements of the fingers

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD). CJD is a neurodegenerative condition caused by prions (misfolded proteins that transmit their misfolded shape onto normal variants of the protein) demonstrating an increase in ꞵ-sheet structures. These ꞵ-sheets are resistant to proteolysis and form insoluble plaques that deposit in the brain. These plaques have a toxic effect on surrounding neurons, leading to neural cell death and development of multiple “holes” in the brain. As a result, CJD produces a characteristic spongy appearance of the brain termed spongiform encephalopathy. There are four types of CJD: familial (due to PRNP gene mutation), variant (due to consumption of contaminated animal meat), iatrogenic (due to medical procedures such as corneal transplants), and sporadic (appears without clear cause).  

Patients with CJD have long incubation periods but once symptoms manifest, individuals develop rapidly progressive dementia within weeks to months. It is classically associated with ataxia (lack of coordination of voluntary movements) and myoclonus (jerking movement of a muscle group). In CJD, the myoclonus is usually generalized and can be triggered when the person is startled by a loud noise -- the response is therefore termed “startle myoclonus.” There is no effective treatment for CJD, and it is uniformly fatal. Death commonly occurs within one year of symptom onset.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Sudden involuntary contraction of muscles after a loud sound :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Unilateral, violent, flailing motion of the arm:
Incorrect: Hemiballismus is characterized by sudden, wild flailing of an extremity. It occurs following a stroke affecting the subthalamic nucleus. However, a stroke would not account for the spongiform brain tissue seen in the above image.
❌ Flapping motion of the hands when arms are extended:
Incorrect: Asterixis is characterized by a “flapping” tremor of the hands that occurs with extension of the wrists. It is associated with hepatic encephalopathy and can also be seen in conditions causing liver cirrhosis (e.g., chronic alcohol use, viral hepatitis, Wilson disease). 
❌ Restlessness and intense urge to move:
Incorrect: Akathisia presents as an inability to sit still with a constant urge to move. It can be seen in patients chronically using first-generation antipsychotics, such as haloperidol. 
❌ Slow, writhing movements of the fingers:
Incorrect: Athetosis presents as a slow, snake-like writhing movement, especially of the fingers. It can be seen in patients with Huntington disease. However, Huntington disease would not account for the spongiform brain tissue seen in the above image.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female comes to the office for evaluation of abnormal vaginal discharge. The patient has been experiencing increasing amounts of malodorous vaginal discharge for the past 4-5 days. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago, and she did not have any postcoital or intermenstrual bleeding. Past medical history is significant for chlamydial cervicitis at the age of 17. The patient has been sexually active with a new male partner for the past 3 weeks, and they consistently use barrier contraception. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals off-white, watery discharge throughout the vaginal vault. There is no vulvar or vaginal erythema. A sample of the discharge is collected and mixed with potassium hydroxide, which produces a fish-like smell. A saline wet mount examination is performed. Which of the following would most likely be visualized under microscopy?

choices.text: Squamous cells with nuclear enlargement and hyperchromasia
Squamous cells and rare polymorphonuclear leukocytes

questions.solution:
This patient presents with off-white, foul-smelling, watery vaginal discharge without associated vulvar or vaginal erythema. She likely has bacterial vaginosis (BV).    

BV results from an imbalance in vaginal flora, which leads to a decreased number of lactobacilli and increased vaginal pH. These changes allow for the proliferation of anaerobic bacteria, most notably Gardnerella vaginalis, which generate malodorous vaginal discharge. Major risk factors include new or multiple sexual partners (though bacterial vaginosis is not considered a sexually transmitted infection), vaginal douching, antibiotic use, and intrauterine device use. Wet mount microscopy of the vaginal discharge will show clue cells (see below image), which are squamous epithelial cells covered with bacteria.

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

 BV can be diagnosed if three of the following criteria are met:
 
1. Presence of clue cells on wet mount  
2. Vaginal pH > 4.5  
3. Positive amine test, which is when a fishy-smell is produced after potassium hydroxide is added to the sample  
4. Increased homogenous, thin vaginal discharge  

The condition is usually treated with oral metronidazole or clindamycin.  

In contrast, another notable cause of abnormal vaginal discharge is candidiasis, which is an infection caused by the fungi Candida albicans. Risk factors for candidiasis include pregnancy, diabetes, and broad-spectrum antibiotic or corticosteroid use. Patients typically present with thick ‘cottage cheese’ discharge as well as vaginal erythema and pruritus. A wet mount would demonstrate budding yeast with pseudohyphae. A brief summary of different types of vaginitis is as follows:

Option Analysis

❌ Leukocytes and pear-shaped organisms:
Incorrect: Leukocytes and pear-shaped organisms on wet mount microscopy is suggestive of trichomoniasis. Patients typically present with frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge and vulvovaginal erythema. Furthermore, patients may present with the classic finding of punctate hemorrhages on the cervix, which is termed a “strawberry” cervix.  
❌ Leukocytes with pseudohyphae:
Incorrect: Leukocytes with pseudohyphae on wet mount microscopy is suggestive of candida vaginitis. Patients typically present with a thick, white discharge as well as vaginal erythema and pruritus. In contrast, this patient is presenting with off-white, watery vaginal discharge, which is more concerning for bacterial vaginosis. 
❌ Squamous cells with nuclear enlargement and hyperchromasia:
Incorrect: Squamous cells with nuclear enlargement and hyperchromasia are suggestive of koilocytes, which are squamous epithelial cells infected by the human papillomavirus (HPV). Some patients may be asymptomatic, whereas others may present with postcoital or intermenstrual bleeding. However, HPV infection would not lead to abnormal vaginal discharge that produces a fishy odor when mixed with potassium hydroxide. 
✅ Epithelial cells covered with bacteria:
 Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Squamous cells and rare polymorphonuclear leukocytes:
Incorrect: Physiologic leukorrhea, which presents with squamous cells and rare polymorphonuclear leukocytes on wet mount microscopy, is a normal finding that occurs due to estrogen stimulation of the vagina. It occurs most often around the menstrual cycle when estrogen levels are highest. Physiologic leukorrhea presents with white or transparent, odorless vaginal discharge.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to his physician due to progressive weight gain over the past 6 months. The patient has moderate, persistent bronchial asthma, which is well-controlled with as-needed inhaled corticosteroids and albuterol. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 161/96 mmHg. There are scattered ecchymoses on the extremities and mild proximal muscle weakness is present. Laboratory testing and imaging is performed to confirm the diagnosis. Abdominal CT reveals an adrenal tumor on the right side, with mild atrophy of the left adrenal gland. This patient most likely has which of the following laboratory patterns of hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis activity?
questions.solution:
This patient has weight gain, muscle weakness, skin ecchymosis, and hypertension. CT imaging reveals a right-sided adrenal mass. These findings are consistent with Cushing syndrome secondary to a cortisol-producing adrenal tumor, which would manifest with elevated serum cortisol levels. The high cortisol levels suppress hypothalamic corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) production and anterior pituitary adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) production.

The first step in the work-up of hypercortisolism is to measure free cortisol in a 24-hour urine sample. Alternatively, blood or saliva tests at midnight can help check if there is a normal daily rise and fall of cortisol levels. Another option is the low-dose dexamethasone suppression test. During the test, the individual is given a low dose of dexamethasone, an exogenous steroid that suppresses pituitary ACTH production. In healthy individuals, this would cause a decrease in serum cortisol levels.

If any of the aforementioned tests yield abnormal results, the next step is to determine the exact cause of excess cortisol production. This involves measuring plasma ACTH levels. Low ACTH levels are seen in adrenal adenomas, adrenal carcinomas, and exogenous glucocorticoid use. In contrast, high ACTH levels are seen in patients with Cushing disease (ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma) and ectopic ACTH production. Finally, if an adrenal tumor is suspected, then abdominal CT or MRI can confirm the tumor’s location and differentiate benign from malignant tumors.

 



Option Analysis

✅   Corticotropin-Releasing Hormone (CRH)  Adrenocorticotropic Hormone (ACTH)  Cortisol  ↓  ↓  ↑ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Corticotropin-Releasing Hormone (CRH)  Adrenocorticotropic Hormone (ACTH)  Cortisol  ↓  ↓ ↓:
Incorrect: These laboratory findings can be seen in patients with adrenal insufficiency due to suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis. Patients with adrenal insufficiency typically present with hypotension, as opposed to hypertension. 
❌   Corticotropin-Releasing Hormone (CRH)  Adrenocorticotropic Hormone (ACTH)  Cortisol  ↓  ↑ ↑:
Incorrect: Elevated ACTH and cortisol with decreased CRH levels are concerning for secondary hypercortisolism due to an ACTH-secreting anterior pituitary adenoma. However, this diagnosis is unlikely in this patient who has a right adrenal tumor and atrophied left adrenal gland, which is more concerning for primary hypercortisolism.
❌   Corticotropin-Releasing Hormone (CRH)  Adrenocorticotropic Hormone (ACTH)  Cortisol  ↑↑ ↓:
Incorrect: Increased levels of CRH and ACTH with decreased cortisol suggest primary adrenal insufficiency. In contrast, this patient has hypertension, increased bruising, and muscle weakness, which are more consistent with the symptoms of hypercortisolism.
❌   Corticotropin-Releasing Hormone (CRH)  Adrenocorticotropic Hormone (ACTH)  Cortisol  ↑  ↓  ↑ :
Incorrect: This patient has symptoms of hypercortisolism in the setting of a right adrenal mass, which is concerning for a cortisol-secreting adrenal tumor. Patients with this condition would have elevated serum cortisol, decreased ACTH, and decreased CRH levels.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden onset left-sided weakness for the past two hours. She does not have chest pain, shortness of breath, or lower extremity pain. Past medical history includes self-resolved “recurrent infections'' while growing up in India. She immigrated to the United States in her twenties and was informed she has a cardiac murmur by several physicians. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is irregularly irregular at 121/min, and blood pressure is 108/68 mmHg. The patient’s pulse oximetry is 99% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates 2/5 weakness and sensory loss in the left upper extremity and left lower extremity. Cardiac auscultation demonstrates a low pitched-diastolic rumbling murmur appreciated at the apex. There is no warmth, swelling, or erythema of the lower extremities bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely anatomic source of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of a large vessel occlusion and sudden onset stroke in the setting of atrial fibrillation -- consistent with an embolic source. This patient’s history and murmur raises concern for rheumatic fever and subsequent mitral stenosis, respectively. In conjunction, these findings reflect an embolic source that most likely originated in the left atrium.

Ischemic and hemorrhagic comprise the two major types of strokes, with the majority of strokes being  ischemic in nature. Ischemic strokes are broadly defined as any stroke that arises from decreased blood flow to the brain and are further sub-classified into thrombotic, embolic, and hypoxic strokes.

  •  Embolic strokes occur when a cerebral blood vessel becomes occluded by an embolus, or a blood clot originating in a different anatomic region of the body. If the clot arises from the heart, it is called a cardioembolism, and these often occur in the left atrium in the setting of atrial fibrillation. Other causes of cardioembolic strokes include infective endocarditis and a left ventricular thrombus following myocardial infarction. Regardless, emboli from one of these sources can dislodge, travel to blood vessels supplying the brain, occlude them, and induce symptoms of a stroke.  
  •  Thrombotic strokes occur when a blood clot forms secondary to a ruptured atherosclerotic plaque. These thrombi can form anywhere atherosclerosis develops but particularly in the large cerebral blood vessels such as the middle cerebral artery, areas of vessel bifurcation, and the lenticulostriate arteries that supply the striatum and internal capsule. When strokes occur in these deep brain structures, they are termed lacunar strokes.
  • Hypoxic strokes, aka hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy, or global cerebral ischemia, develop secondary to systemic hypoperfusion or hypoxia. This type of stroke commonly occurs during cardiac arrest, shock states, or during invasive procedures with significant blood loss. The pattern of injury observed with this type of stroke often includes watershed infarctions, since the areas of the brain most susceptible to ischemic injury exist at the border of blood supply between two separate cerebral arteries. The three primary watershed areas include the vascular territories between the anterior cerebral and the middle cerebral arteries,the posterior cerebral and the middle cerebral arteries, and the external and internal branches of the middle cerebral arteries.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Popliteal vein:
Incorrect: The popliteal vein is often implicated in patients with a deep vein thrombosis and subsequent pulmonary embolism. In very rare cases, the clot can travel to the systemic circulation via a patent foramen ovale in the heart. This patient has no evidence of deep vein thrombosis or a murmur characteristic of a patent foramen ovale.
❌ Femoral vein:
Incorrect: The femoral vein is implicated in patients with a deep vein thrombosis of the lower extremities. In very rare cases, the clot can travel to the systemic circulation via a patent foramen ovale in the heart.
✅ Left atrium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Left ventricle:
Incorrect: The left ventricle can be a source of a thrombus, especially in patients with prior myocardial infarction. Dead, immobile cardiac tissue augments hemostasis and subsequent thrombus formation. This patient does not have a history or presentation concerning for acute or previous myocardial infarction.
❌ Pulmonary artery:
Incorrect: In patients with a pulmonary embolism (PE), an embolus from the lower extremities typically travels via the venous system into the pulmonary artery via the inferior vena cava. Patients with a PE typically present with pleuritic chest pain, shortness of breath, and hypoxia.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the clinician's office by his parent because of a 1-day history of rash, nausea, and stomach pain. The parent reports the patient had a throat infection several weeks ago which resolved spontaneously. A few days later, he developed a hip pain that subsided and was followed by right knee and ankle pain. At the same time, he developed a rash on his legs, buttocks, and forearms. Immunizations are up to date. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a rash, as shown in the image below. Musculoskeletal examination reveals a swollen right knee without effusion, erythema, or warmth. Scrotal swelling and sensitivity are noted on the left side. Urinalysis shows microscopic hematuria with proteinuria. Serum electrolytes, including creatinine, are within normal limits.

Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

 Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child, who is presenting with palpable purpura/petechiae, migratory arthritis, and abdominal pain that all occurred following an upper respiratory/throat infection, most likely has IgA vasculitis, formerly known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP). Other possible manifestations may include hematuria, proteinuria, intussusception, gastrointestinal hemorrhage, scrotal swelling and pain, as well as CNS and eye involvement.    

IgA-antibody immune complexes caused by antigenic exposure from an infection (such as a Streptococcal infection) or medication, deposit in the small vessels (usually capillaries) of the skin, joints, kidneys, and GI tract. This deposition results in an influx of inflammatory mediators such as prostaglandins. If the immune complexes are deposited in the intestinal wall, they may cause GI hemorrhage; intussusception is a major complication of HSP. Renal involvement of IgA-mediated immune complexes may result in crescentic glomerulonephritis. Immune complex deposits in the skin cause palpable purpura and petechiae.  

The management of HSP is mainly symptomatic and supportive, with therapy directed toward adequate oral hydration, bed rest, and symptomatic relief of joint and abdominal pain. Patients with joint pain can be treated with NSAIDs; in severe cases, oral steroids may be indicated.  

Option Analysis

✅ IgA vasculitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌  Juvenile idiopathic arthritis :
Incorrect: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis is a systemic condition characterized by daily fever in a quotidian pattern (occurring daily), lymphadenopathy, rash, and arthritis. The rash is usually a macular, salmon-pink rash. This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Mumps infection:
Incorrect: Mumps is a viral illness that mostly can be prevented by vaccination. Vaccination is given in 3 doses as the MMR vaccine (mumps, measles, rubella) and is completed by 6 years of age. Patients typically present with a few days of fever, headache, myalgia, fatigue, and anorexia, followed by parotitis and orchitis. Mumps is not associated with rash, and this child is fully vaccinated, which makes mumps unlikely.  
❌ Rheumatic fever:
Incorrect: Rheumatic fever is an inflammatory disease that typically develops two to four weeks after a streptococcal throat infection and can involve the heart, joints, skin, and brain. The rash, known as erythema marginatum, is pink, non-itchy, and usually found on the torso and inner surfaces of the limbs. This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Childhood-onset systemic lupus erythematosus:
Incorrect: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a chronic autoimmune inflammatory disease of unknown cause that can involve any organ system, most commonly the joints, skin, kidneys, and the nervous, hematologic, and cardiovascular systems. Childhood-onset systemic lupus erythematosus presents similar to adults but tends to be more severe. Patients may present with serositis, oral ulcers, arthritis, photosensitivity, blood cytopenias, renal disease, neurologic symptoms, and malar rash/discoid rash.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man comes to the office because of generalized weakness for several months. His past medical history includes hypertension and type 1 diabetes mellitus. His renal function has gradually declined over the past three years. Current medications include carvedilol, insulin, and calcitriol. Physical examination demonstrates an ill-appearing male with pale conjunctiva, mucosal pallor and 2+ bilateral lower extremity edema. Glomerular filtration rate assessed 3 months ago was 40 ml/min/1.73 m2. Hemoglobin is 9 g/dL. The remainder of the laboratory evaluation is demonstrated below.

 
Laboratory value  Results 
 Serum chemistry 
 Sodium  132 mEq/L 
 Potassium  4.2 mEq/L 
 Chloride  95 mEq/L 
 Magnesium  1.7 mEq/L 
 Creatinine  6 mg/dL 
 Blood urea nitrogen  70 mg/dL 
 Serum 25-OH Vitamin D (D2)  45 ng/mL (normal: 25-80 ng/mL) 
 Serum 1,25-OH Vitamin D (D3)  30 pg/mL (normal: 18-64 pg/mL) 
   
Which of the following additional sets of laboratory findings are most likely to be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension, together with the laboratory findings of anemia, decreased glomerular filtration rate (GFR), and elevated serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN), is indicative of chronic kidney disease (CKD).  

CKD is defined as a chronic decline in renal function evidenced by either a decreased GFR <60 mL/min/1.73 m2 or renal damage as indicated by laboratory evaluation or imaging. Risk factors include systemic hypertension, uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, polycystic kidney disease, and congenital renal anomalies. Patients with CKD may be asymptomatic, but if concomitant metabolic abnormalities arise, they generally present with fatigue, muscle weakness, edema and, in advanced stages, with secondary hyperparathyroidism (2˚ HPTH), uremia, or one of its complications (e.g., pericarditis, encephalopathy).  

Secondary HPTH results from impaired renal excretion of phosphate, which results in hyperphosphatemia. The excess phosphate binds to circulating calcium, causing hypocalcemia, which then stimulates the release of parathyroid hormone (PTH)--mobilizing bony calcium via stimulation of osteolytic activity. If left untreated, this disease can result in profound osteopenia and eventually osteitis fibrosa cystica (subperiosteal bone resorption). Other complications include anemia, due to decreased erythropoietin synthesis, and platelet dysfunction, secondary to uremia. 

Option Analysis

✅   Serum calcium  Serum phosphorus  Parathyroid hormone  ↓  ↑  ↑  :
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌   Serum calcium  Serum phosphorus  Parathyroid hormone  ↓  ↑  ↓   :
Incorrect: These findings are observed in patients with primary hypoparathyroidism, where low levels of parathyroid hormone decrease serum calcium levels and increase serum phosphorus. Clinically, this disease presents with features of hypocalcemia. Generalized weakness in the setting of long-standing diabetes, hypertension, and worsening renal function suggests an alternative diagnosis for this patient.
❌   Serum calcium  Serum phosphorus  Parathyroid hormone  ↓  ↓   ↑  :
Incorrect: These laboratory findings are suggestive of vitamin D deficiency. Low levels of vitamin D reduce intestinal calcium and phosphorus absorption, thereby stimulating the release of PTH, which in turn increases the excretion of phosphorus. This patient with normal serum vitamin D levels is unlikely to have hypophosphatemia.
❌   Serum calcium  Serum phosphorus  Parathyroid hormone  ↑ ↓   ↑  :
Incorrect: These laboratory findings are indicative of primary hyperparathyroidism (most commonly caused by a parathyroid adenoma). Elevated PTH increases bone resorption, resulting in hypercalcemia. Moreover, it increases renal excretion of phosphorus. This patient’s laboratory findings instead indicate abnormal renal function.
❌   Serum calcium  Serum phosphorus  Parathyroid hormone  ↑  Normal  Normal  :
Incorrect: An elevated serum calcium level with normal serum phosphorus and PTH levels are observed in familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia. Most cases are asymptomatic, and serum magnesium levels are also elevated. This patient’s magnesium is normal.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old man comes to the office with a pigmented lesion on his torso. He first noted the lesion 2 years ago and says that it has recently increased in size. He works as a tour guide in Miami and spends most of his time outdoors. Past medical history is significant for frequent sunburns during childhood. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 124/74 mmHg. Physical examination shows a hyperpigmented lesion measuring 10-mm on the torso, which is shown in the image below:


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

Excisional biopsy of the lesion is performed. Mutations in which of the following genes are most likely to be present in this tissue?
questions.solution:
This patient, who has a history of multiple sunburns as a child and spends most of his time outdoors as a tour guide, is at increased risk of having a dermatologic malignancy. The examination finding of an evolving hyperpigmented lesion with irregular borders measuring 10-mm in diameter is classic for melanoma.

Melanoma is the most aggressive form of skin malignancy. It usually arises from a melanocytic nevus (mole) under the effects of certain environmental risk factors (e.g., excessive sunlight exposure, indoor tanning). The most common genetic mutation seen in the neoplastic tissues involves BRAF (up to 60% of cases). BRAF encodes a protein kinase involved in activating signaling pathways for melanocyte proliferation. A point mutation results in a valine to glutamic acid substitution at position 600 of the protein, resulting in continuous activation of BRAF, which causes uncontrolled proliferation of atypical melanocytes. Other genes that are less commonly involved are NRAS and KIT.

Surgical excision with appropriate margins is the mainstay of management for localized lesions. Melanoma with BRAF-positive mutation usually responds well to mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway-targeted adjuvant therapy (dabrafenib + trametinib).  

Option Analysis

✅ BRAF:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ RB1:
Incorrect: RB1 is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes for retinoblastoma protein. Inactivating mutations in RB1 are associated with the development of retinoblastoma and osteosarcoma, not melanoma.
❌ RET:
Incorrect: Multiple endocrine neoplasia 2 (MEN2) results from germ-line mutations in RET proto-oncogene. MEN2 is associated with the development of pheochromocytoma, medullary thyroid cancer, parathyroid hyperplasia, and mucosal neuromas. Examination findings of this patient suggests melanoma.
❌ HER2:
Incorrect: HER2 overexpression is involved in the pathogenesis of invasive breast cancers. It is not related in the development of melanoma.
❌ VHL:
Incorrect: Loss of function mutations in VHL are seen in renal cell carcinoma (presenting with abdominal mass and hematuria) or Von Hippel-Landau syndrome (associated with hemangioblastomas, pheochromocytomas and bilateral renal cell carcinomas). This patient’s presentation is suggestive of a melanoma.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to his family physician for a routine checkup. Upon walking the short distance from the waiting room to the exam room, the patient becomes short of breath. He states that he frequently feels tired throughout the day and has had these symptoms for years. His previous physician performed a full cardiac workup, which was unremarkable. Temperature is 99.0°F, blood pressure is 150/110 mm Hg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 25/min and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. The patient has a BMI of 42 kg/m2. The patient undergoes in-laboratory polysomnography testing, which demonstrates hypoventilation during sleep. Further laboratory testing demonstrates an elevated serum bicarbonate level. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Inflammation and obstruction of distal airways

questions.solution:
This patient with morbid obesity is suffering from obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS). This restrictive lung disease occurs secondary to increased mass of the abdomen and thoracic cavity, preventing the chest wall from adequately expanding with respiration. Due to these altered respiratory mechanics, patients with OHS have reduced ventilation--primarily in the lower lobes of the lung. This restriction causes a mismatching in the ventilation-perfusion ratio, triggering hypoxemia. In addition, total lung capacity, expiratory reserve volume, and residual functional capacity are reduced in patients with OHS.

OHS is a diagnosis of exclusion, as patients often suffer also with concomitant obstructive sleep apnea and, to a lesser extent, central sleep apnea. The distinguishing feature of OHS includes the presence of hypercapnic symptoms during the daytime, as evidenced in this patient by his increased serum bicarbonate levels--suggestive of chronic hypercapnia. Polysomnography may also help distinguish between OHS and obstructive sleep apnea. Importantly, excluding other cardiac and pulmonary disorders such including COPD or congestive heart failure is critical. First line therapy includes positive airway pressure therapy, bilevel positive airway pressure, and weight reduction. Second line measures include  pharmacologic adjuncts such as medroxyprogesterone or acetazolamide or surgery.  

Option Analysis

❌ Obstruction of the oropharynx:
Incorrect: This answer describes obstructive sleep apnea, which presents with episodes of apnea during sleep in addition to hypoventilation.
❌ Desensitization of chemoreceptors :
Incorrect: This answer describes central sleep apnea, which is characterized by irregular patterns of apnea and hyperventilation caused by desensitization to PCO2 chemoreceptors.
❌ Inflammation and obstruction of distal airways:
Incorrect: This answer describes asthma, which is unlikely in this patient given his age and other associated findings on exam and polysomnography.
❌ Increased pulmonary artery pressure:
Incorrect: Pulmonary hypertension can occur secondary to sleep apnea and obesity hypoventilation syndrome; however, it is a late manifestation of the disease and is not the primary pathophysiologic driver.
✅ Imparied lung expansion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of acute testicular pain. The pain has been progressively worsening over three days. He has no pain with urination, but he has significant tenderness with manipulation of the scrotum. Past medical history includes a urinary tract infection that was treated with antibiotics two years ago. He is not sexually active. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation of the right testis posteriorly. Manual elevation of the right testis results in some alleviation of the pain. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this condition?

choices.text: Inadequate fixation of the lower pole of the testis
Intraprostatic reflux of urine and infection with E. coli
Urinary tract infection with S. saprophyticus

questions.solution:
Epididymitis refers to an infection of the epididymis. In males less than 35 years old, this infection is most commonly associated with sexually transmitted organisms including Chlamydia trachomatis and, less commonly, Neisseria gonorrhoeae. In males older than 35 years, and those without sexual partners, the most common organisms are gram-negative bacteria, predominantly Escherichia coli. In some patients, the infection can spread to the testicle, resulting in orchitis. Isolated cases of orchitis are rare and are more often seen with viral etiologies (e.g. mumps).

Common symptoms of epididymitis include testicular pain and swelling of the affected epididymis, which is located on the posterior aspect of the testis. Epididymitis rarely causes systemic symptoms (e.g., fevers, chills, myalgias), and most patients are afebrile. The diagnosis of acute epididymitis is based on history and physical examination after ruling out other etiologies such as testicular torsion. In all suspected cases, a urinalysis, urine culture, and a urine nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) for N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis should be performed.  

Option Analysis

✅ Retrograde ascent of E. coli:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Retrograde ascent of N. gonorrhoeae:
Incorrect: In males less than 35 years old, sexually transmitted organisms such as Chlamydia trachomatis and, less commonly, Neisseriagonorrhoeae are the predominant culprits of epididymitis. This patient is over the age of 35 and is not sexually active, making another microbe more likely.
❌ Inadequate fixation of the lower pole of the testis:
Incorrect: This answer describes the pathophysiology of testicular torsion. These patients present with acute scrotal pain that is not relieved with elevation of the testicle and an absent cremasteric reflex.
❌ Intraprostatic reflux of urine and infection with E. coli:
Incorrect: This answer describes prostatitis, which presents with fevers, chills, dysuria, and pelvic or perineal pain.
❌ Urinary tract infection with S. saprophyticus:
Incorrect: S. saprophyticus is a less commonly implicated pathogen in urinary tract infections. This patient’s symptoms (testicular pain, no dysuria) suggest a different etiology.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman comes to the office due to persistent cough, dyspnea and unintentional weight loss. She states she is generally healthy and has never smoked. She works as a secretary in a law firm. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, there are reduced breath sounds and dullness to percussion on the lower right lung field. Chest radiograph shows a mass in the lower right lung field and a mild right pleural effusion. A needle biopsy is performed, and the results are shown below:



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This non-smoking patient is presenting with symptoms suggestive of malignancy (e.g. weight loss), in addition to the imaging finding of a peripherally located tumor on chest x-ray, and histopathology results showing a glandular pattern -- all supporting the diagnosis of lung adenocarcinoma.

Lung adenocarcinoma is the most common primary lung cancer. It is more common in women than men, and it is most likely to arise in nonsmokers. It is typically located in the periphery of the lungs. Common causes include activating mutations in KRAS, EGFR, and ALK genes. Histopathology will likely show a glandular pattern, which often stains positive for mucin. Typical presentation includes cough, weight loss, and hemoptysis. Some patients may present with hypertrophic osteoarthropathy of the fingers (clubbing). Similar to other malignancies, involvement of the pleura will result in pleural effusion, as seen here.





Option Analysis

❌ Squamous cell carcinoma:
Incorrect: Squamous cell carcinoma arises from the bronchus and presents as a central hilar mass. It is associated with smoking, and histopathology will likely show keratin pearls and intercellular bridges.
✅ Adenocarcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Large cell carcinoma:
