Incorrect: Large cell carcinoma is a highly anaplastic, undifferentiated tumor that carries a poor prognosis. It usually arises in the periphery of the lung. It is strongly associated with smoking. Histopathology will instead show pleomorphic giant cells.
❌ Small cell carcinoma:
Incorrect: Small cell carcinoma arises from neuroendocrine cells (Kulchitsky cells), which appear as dark blue cells and stain positive for chromogranin A, neuron-specific enolase, and synaptophysin on histopathology. The tumor is centrally located and is often associated with smoking.
❌ Pulmonary hamartoma:
Incorrect: Pulmonary hamartoma is a benign neoplasm composed of connective tissue, cartilage, muscle, fat, and bone. It is one of the most common benign tumors of the lung and is often recognized as an incidental mass on chest x-ray. Histopathology will show a variable mixture of mature hyaline cartilage, fat, or smooth muscle, as opposed to this patient’s histopathology showing proliferation of glandular tissue. Symptoms are dependent on the location of the hamartoma.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of abdominal pain and altered mental status. His partner states he has a history of lung cancer, which is currently being treated with chemotherapy. The partner also states that over the past week the patient has seemed “more confused,” and he was frequently going to the bathroom to urinate. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6 °F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 105/65 mmHg. Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes and decreased skin turgor. ECG is obtained and shows shortened QT-intervals, as well as positive deflection at the junction of the QRS-complexes and ST-segments in leads V1-V6. Which of the following is the most likely responsible for this patient’s observed ECG changes?
questions.solution:
This patient has severe hypercalcemia, which is characterized by signs and symptoms such as polyuria (and subsequent dehydration), abdominal pain, bone pain, renal stones, and cognitive dysfunction. In the setting of malignancy, this electrolyte disturbance can occur from bony metastasis or a paraneoplastic release of parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP), which mimics the effects of PTH. This paraneoplastic syndrome is most commonly associated with squamous cell cancer, a non-small cell lung carcinoma. The diagnosis of squamous cell cancer depends on biopsy and histopathological examination; features characteristic of squamous cell cancer include the presence of keratin production by tumor cells and intercellular desmosomes (referred to as "intercellular bridges").

The primary ECG abnormality in the setting of hypercalcemia is the shortening of the QT-interval. This finding is due to an acceleration of both ventricular depolarization and ventricular repolarization. In severe hypercalcemia, J-waves, or Osborne waves, can be seen. This finding refers to a positive deflection at the J-point, where the QRS-complex meets the ST-segment.  

Option Analysis

✅ Hypercalcemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hyperkalemia:
Incorrect: Hyperkalemia is characterized by muscle weakness or paralysis and cardiac abnormalities. ECG tracings would show characteristic peaked T-waves with a shortened QT-interval.
❌ Hypermagnesemia:
Incorrect: Hypermagnesemia is a rare disorder that may present with nausea, flushing, and lethargy. Severely high levels of magnesium may lead to the absence of deep tendon reflexes, bradycardia, and hypotension. ECG would show PR-prolongation, U waves, as well as increases in QRS-duration and QT-interval.
❌ Hypocalcemia:
Incorrect: Hypocalcemia is characterized by Trousseau or Chvostek sign (spasms in response to blood pressure cuff or facial tapping, respectively), seizures, or altered mental status. ECG tracing would show prolongation of the QT-interval on ECG.
❌ Hypokalemia:
Incorrect: The most common manifestation of hypokalemia is severe muscle weakness. Classic ECG findings include ST-segment depression, decreased T-wave, and increased U-wave, which are not seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to the office for the evaluation of amenorrhea. The patient’s menarche was at the age of 13, and her menstrual cycle has been regular with menses occurring every 28 days. For the past 8 months, the patient has not menstruated. She is sexually active with her boyfriend and uses condoms consistently. The patient plays on the high school soccer team and frequently competes in local beauty pageants. She follows a calorie-restricted dietary regimen and exercises 3 hours every day. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min and blood pressure is 90/55 mmHg. BMI is 16 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Physical examination shows a pale, thin girl of normal stature with fine hair and Tanner stage III breast and pubic hair growth. Rest of the examination is within normal limits. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following set of hormonal changes will be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with functional hypothalamic amenorrhea (FHA), suggested by secondary amenorrhea, low body weight, the following of a low-calorie diet and intense exercise regimen, and examination finding of lanugo (fine hair indicating calorie restriction).

FHA can be seen in competitive athletes, dancers and models or others that maintain a very low calorie diet. It is characterized by decrease in hypothalamic gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) secretion, leading to decreased amplitude and/or frequency of gonadotropin pulses, absence of normal follicular development, absent midcycle surge in luteinizing hormone (LH) secretion, absent follicular stimulating hormone (FSH) secretion, anovulation, and low serum estradiol concentrations. Common associated conditions include anorexia nervosa and celiac disease (secondary to malabsorption).

Such patients are at increased risk of consequences of estrogen deficiency, including low bone density, infertility, breast and/or vaginal atrophy, and sexual dysfunction.  

Option Analysis

❌   GnRH  FSH LH  Estradiol  Prolactin  Normal  Increased  Increased  Decreased  Normal :
Incorrect: These findings are suggestive of amenorrhea seen in Turner syndrome. The patients have low estrogen levels leading to amenorrhea and absent breast development. The FSH and LH levels are elevated due to lack of negative feedback from estrogen. This patient had a normal menstrual cycle previously and has well-developed secondary sexual characteristics.
✅   GnRH  FSH  LH  Estradiol  Prolactin  Decreased  Decreased or normal Decreased Decreased  Normal :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  GnRH  FSH  LH Estradiol  Prolactin  Normal DecreasedDecreased Decreased Increased:
Incorrect: An elevated prolactin with decreased levels of FSH, LH and estradiol are suggestive of prolactinoma. Patients usually present with bilateral breast discharge, visual changes and frequent headaches, in combination with amenorrhea.
❌  GnRH FSH  LH  Estradiol  Prolactin  Normal  Normal/decreasedNormal/ElevatedNormal Normal :
Incorrect: The LH/FSH ratio of ≥2 is usually seen in polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), a disorder that is characterized by failure of follicle maturation and oocyte release. Patients usually present with obesity, amenorrhea, infertility and/or signs of hyperandrogenism (e.g., acne and hirsutism).
❌  GnRH FSH LH Estradiol Prolactin Decreased Undetectable UndetectableUndetectable Normal :
Incorrect: Patients with congenital GnRH deficiency (Kallman syndrome) can present with very low or undetectable levels of GnRH, FSH and LH. It is unlikely in this patient, as she had a normal menstrual cycle previously.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man comes to his primary care physicians office for evaluation of chronic diarrhea and associated nausea and bloating. He visited a local health care clinic and was prescribed a course of antibiotics, without relief of symptoms. Past medical history is significant for asthma, eczema and an anaphylactic reaction to blood transfusion two years ago. Family history is noncontributory. He does not use tobacco, alcohol or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.2 C (99.0 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. Microscopic examination of his stool for ova and parasites is shown.



Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following pathophysiologic findings is most strongly associated with this patient’s disease?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a history of recurrent diarrhea, atopy (eczema and asthma) and anaphylaxis during blood transfusions. The presence of pear-shaped organisms with multiple flagella is indicative of Giardia lamblia. Together, these findings are suggestive of selective IgA deficiency, the most common primary immune deficiency.

IgA is produced when B cells are stimulated by interleukin- 5 (IL-5) or transforming growth factor- β, with subsequent class switching occurring in mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue. From here, IgA is secreted into the saliva, sweat, or intestines.




In IgA deficiency, both secretory and serum IgA levels are low. The exact mechanism underlying this deficiency is not well-established; however, it is thought to result from a cytokine defect in B cells or T cells. Multiple members of the same family are commonly affected, implicating a genetic component.




Most individuals with selective IgA deficiency are asymptomatic, although some may have recurrent sinopulmonary infections (e.g. sinusitis) or gastrointestinal infections (Giardia lamblia). There is also an increased frequency of atopy, as well as autoimmune diseases (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis and SLE), and increased risk of some malignancies (e.g. gastric and colon cancer). Some patients with severe IgA deficiency develop IgE antibodies against IgA, manifesting in fatal anaphylactic reactions.



Diagnosis is based on low or undetectable levels of serum IgA (due to the failure of B-cells to differentiate into IgA secreting plasma cells) and normal levels of other immunoglobulins (IgM, IgG and IgE). There is no effective treatment for selective IgA deficiency. Patients with severe deficiency should wear a medical alert bracelet, and if a blood transfusion is necessary, washed erythrocytes should be administered. 

Option Analysis

❌ Eosinophil-mediated cytotoxicity:
Incorrect: Eosinophils are important for defense against intestinal helminthic infections. They are not an essential component for defense against Giardia.
❌ Complement deficiency:
Incorrect: Early complement deficiencies are associated with infections with encapsulated species, while Neisseria gonorrhoeae or meningitidis infection is seen with late complement (C5–C9) deficiencies.
✅ Selective immunoglobulin deficiency:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ T-cell dysfunction:
Incorrect: An example of pure T-cell dysfunction is DiGeorge syndrome (thymic hypoplasia). Affected patients have congenital absence of thymus and parathyroid glands secondary to maldevelopment of third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. Absence of T-cells causes bacterial and viral infections, while absence of the parathyroid gland causes hypocalcemia.
❌ Defect of NADPH oxidase:
Incorrect: A defect of NADPH oxidase results in decreased production of reactive oxygen species and respiratory burst. Affected patients are susceptible to infections with catalase positive organisms (e.g. Staphylococcus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa).

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to his primary pediatrician for evaluation of recurrent infections. The parents report the patient had two episodes of severe pneumonia, an episode of otitis media, and herpes labialis in the past nine months. He was born at 38 weeks gestation to a 28-year-old otherwise healthy woman. He eats and drinks normally and has achieved the normal developmental milestones. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a well-developed and well-nourished child with fair complexion. He has eczema on his cheeks and trunk as well as petechiae on the bilateral lower extremities. Laboratory evaluation reveals a leukocyte count of 8,000/mm3 and a platelet count of 70,000/mm3. Flow cytometry of peripheral lymphocytes reveal absence of the WAS protein. Which of the following immunologic processes is most likely affected given this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with recurrent infections, eczema, and symptomatic thrombocytopenia in the setting of an absent WAS protein on lymphocytes--consistent with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS). This X-linked recessive disorder is caused by a mutation in the gene that encodes the WAS protein (WASp).

Normally, all hematopoietic cells produce WASp (stabilized by WAS/WASL-interacting protein family member 1 gene), which helps organize the cell’s cytoskeleton.



In WAS, leukocytes cannot reorganize the actin cytoskeleton, resulting in impaired immune cell migration and synapse formation. Therefore, patients are at increased risk for recurrent bacterial, viral, and fungal infections. Similarly, the cytoskeleton of platelets is also dysfunctional, resulting in thrombocytopenia. Affected patients have significantly decreased platelet count and size, manifesting with petechiae, purpura, or severe bleeding. Moreover, eczema of variable severity is classically seen. Affected individuals are more prone to developing autoimmune conditions such as idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura or leukemias and lymphomas.




Laboratory investigation demonstrates low to normal IgG, IgM, and high IgA and IgE.  Peripheral blood smear demonstrates thrombocytopenia with small platelets. Flow-cytometry can be used to identify mutated WASp, and a genetic sequence analysis of the WAS gene confirms the diagnosis. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is the definitive treatment.



Option Analysis

❌ Antibody class switching:
Incorrect: Antibody class switching defects are usually seen in hyper-IgM syndrome. In addition to severe pyogenic infections, affected patients are susceptible to opportunistic infections with Pneumocystis, Cryptosporidium and CMV. Thrombocytopenia and eczema are not observed in this condition.
❌ Phagosome-lysosome fusion:
Incorrect: A defective lysosomal trafficking regulator gene (LYST) in Chédiak-Higashi syndrome can lead to microtubule dysfunction and imparied phagosome-lysosome fusion. In addition to recurrent infections, progressive neurodegeneration, lymphohistiocytosis and peripheral neuropathy are commonly observed. Pancytopenia (instead of just thrombocytopenia) is a characteristic finding of this condition.
❌ DNA repair:
Incorrect: A DNA repair defect is associated with ataxia-telangiectasia, which presents with a triad of ataxia, spider angiomas, and IgA deficiency. Lymphopenia, rather than thrombocytopenia, is a typical finding.
❌ Hydrogen peroxide production:
Incorrect: A defect in NADPH oxidase in chronic granulomatous disease results in an inability of phagocytes to produce hydrogen peroxide. Abscesses due to catalase positive organisms are classic features. Eczema and thrombocytopenia are atypical.  
✅ Cytoskeletal regulation:
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of penile pain of six hours duration. Past medical history is significant for sickle cell disease. He does not use illicit drugs or take any medications daily. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates an engorged penis that is painful with manipulation. No urethral discharge is noted. The testicles are nontender, and the cremasteric reflex is intact. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Paralysis of cavernosal smooth muscle and impaired venous outflow
Fistula formation between the cavernosal artery and corpus cavernosum
Excessive collagen deposition in the tunica albuginea
Testicular ischemia due to arterial inflow and venous outflow obstruction

questions.solution:
Priapism refers to a pathological penile erection in the absence of sexual arousal; it is a urological emergency.  Identifying priapism and prompt treatment is paramount, as delayed urologic care may result in permanent erectile dysfunction. There are two main types of priapism: ischemic and nonischemic:

  •  Ischemic (low-flow) priapism presents with a painful, rigid erection secondary to impaired relaxation and paralysis of cavernosal smooth muscle. This process results in a compartment syndrome of the penis, with resultant hypoxemia and acidemia in cavernosal tissue. 
  • Nonischemic (high-flow) priapism usually presents following genital trauma, without a painful or rigid erection. It occurs less commonly than ischemic priapism and results from a fistula between the cavernosal artery and corpus cavernosum.
Ischemic priapism is far more common, and it occurs secondary to hypercoagulable states (e.g., sickle cell disease, thalassemia), neurologic diseases (e.g. spinal cord stenosis), metastatic disease (e.g., prostate cancer, bladder cancer) and medications that relax smooth muscles (e.g., trazodone, prostaglandins, hydralazine). The precise pathophysiology of priapism secondary to sickle cell disease is not fully understood; however, is thought to be due to a combination vaso-occlusion and a regulatory defect in the nitric oxide pathway.

Enhancement of venous outflow is the goal in management of ischemic priapism, and intracavernosal injection of phenylephrine is commonly performed. The alpha-agonist effects of phenylephrine contract the cavernosal smooth muscle, allowing for reentry of oxygenated blood through the penis. In addition, aspiration of static cavernosal blood is performed to further promote venous outflow and detumescence.

Option Analysis

✅ Paralysis of cavernosal smooth muscle and impaired venous outflow:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Fistula formation between the cavernosal artery and corpus cavernosum:
Incorrect: Nonischemic priapism (also known as high-flow) occurs less commonly than ischemic priapism and is usually the result of a fistula between the cavernosal artery and corpus cavernosum. Nonischemic priapism is more commonly related to penile trauma than underlying sickle cell disease.
❌ Excessive collagen deposition in the tunica albuginea:
Incorrect: Peyronie disease is a condition caused by microtrauma and subsequent collagen and scar formation in the tunica albuginea. Patients present with a visibly curved penis, penile pain, and erectile dysfunction.
❌ Anterior urethral injury:
Incorrect: Anterior urethral injury can be seen in patients with blunt trauma or saddle injuries to the perineum. Blood at the urethral meatus, difficulty voiding, and perineal/genital ecchymosis are suggestive of urethral injury.
❌ Testicular ischemia due to arterial inflow and venous outflow obstruction:
Incorrect: Testicular torsion occurs when the testis torses (twists) on the spermatic cord, resulting in ischemia from reduced arterial inflow and venous outflow obstruction. Testicular torsion typically results in sudden-onset, acute, unilateral testicular pain with an absent cremasteric reflex.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to his pediatrician for evaluation of sore throat. Around a week ago, he began experiencing difficulty swallowing due to pain. He has also had associated fevers, fatigue, and anorexia. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. He does not consume tobacco, alcohol, or illicit substances. The patient is sexually active with one female partner. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/71 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates tender posterior auricular and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, as well as bilateral tonsillar swelling with exudates. A screening heterophile antibody test returns positive. Which of the following clinical features represents a potentially life-threatening complication of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Left upper quadrant pain referred to the left shoulder
Pseudomembrane formation in the posterior oropharynx
Descending paralysis affecting the facial muscles

questions.solution:
This adolescent patient presents with sore throat, fevers, malaise, and posterior lymphadenopathy. Furthermore, the heterophile antibody screen is positive. In combination, these findings are suggestive of infectious mononucleosis. One potentially lethal post-infectious complication is splenic rupture, which can present with pain in the left upper abdominal quadrant with referred pain to the shoulder due to subdiaphragmatic hemoperitoneum.

Infectious mononucleosis refers to an acute illness caused most commonly by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). The disease is usually transmitted via oral secretions, such as from kissing or sharing glasses. It can present with fever, fatigue, lymphadenopathy, tonsillitis, and tonsillar swelling with exudate. In addition to the aforementioned clinical features, an important differentiating finding includes the presence of posterior cervical or auricular lymphadenopathy, which is rare in streptococcal pharyngitis or other forms of viral pharyngitis. Furthermore, patients with infectious mononucleosis can develop hepatomegaly and splenomegaly.

The most important complication associated with infectious mononucleosis is splenic rupture. To avoid this potentially fatal complication, patients should be instructed to avoid all sports-related activities for at least three weeks after symptom onset and all contact sports for at least four weeks.

Option Analysis

✅ Left upper quadrant pain referred to the left shoulder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bilateral facial nerve palsy:
Incorrect: Infection by Borrelia burgdorferi can result in Lyme disease. If untreated, Lyme disease can cause sequelae including facial nerve palsy, arthritis, and atrioventricular heart block. However, facial nerve palsy is largely non-lethal and is overall a rare post-infectious complication of infectious mononucleosis.
❌ Pseudomembrane formation in the posterior oropharynx:
Incorrect: Pseudomembranes are composed of necrotic fibrin, leukocytes, erythrocytes, epithelial cells, and bacteria. The finding develops after infection by Corynebacterium diphtheriae and can potentially cause respiratory distress. However, pseudomembranes do not develop following Epstein-Barr virus infection.
❌ Choreiform and repetitive motor movements :
Incorrect: Pediatric autoimmune neuropsychiatric disorder associated with group A streptococci  (PANDAS) refers to a rare post-infectious complication of streptococcal pharyngitis. Patients with PANDAS can manifest with obsessive-compulsive behavior, tics, and motor hyperactivity (e.g. fidgeting). However, the condition is not a complication of infectious mononucleosis caused by the Epsitein-Barr virus.
❌ Descending paralysis affecting the facial muscles:
Incorrect: In rare cases, the Epstein-Barr virus can cause Guillain-Barre syndrome, which manifests with an ascending paralysis. In contrast, a descending paralysis is more concerning for botulism caused by the bacteria Clostridium botulinum.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman is admitted to the emergency room for facial pain, weakness, and malaise. She also has a throbbing headache. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and HIV infection. Home medications include zidovudine, lamivudine, lopinavir, ritonavir and metformin. However, she admits to poor compliance with the medications. The patient’s CD4 count is 121 cells/mm3, and viral load is 50,000. Physical examination shows exquisite tenderness to palpation over the right maxillary sinus. Additionally, there is a black eschar over her nares and palate. Which of the following symptoms would suggest a severe complication of the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has facial pain, headache, and a black eschar in the setting of poorly controlled HIV and diabetes. She most likely has rhinosinusitis secondary to mucormycosis infection.

Rhinosinusitis describes inflammation of the mucosal lining of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses. It can lead to edema, increased mucus production, hyposmia, and erythema over the affected sinuses. Infection of the ethmoid sinuses can result in nasal bridge and retro-orbital pain. Likewise, infections in the sphenoid or ethmoid sinuses may present similarly, but these infections can extend to the cavernous sinus and cause cavernous sinus syndrome, a severe complication that can manifest with multiple cranial nerve palsies.

This patient’s history of immunosuppression (e.g. poorly controlled HIV) and diabetes places her at risk of mucormycosis, which is an infection caused by fungi in the order Mucorales. Mucor and Rhizopus species are most frequently implicated. The condition classically presents with a black necrotic eschar on the face. The infection is aggressive and can spread to adjacent structures such as the orbits and brain. As a result, it is typically managed with surgical debridement and amphotericin B administration. 

Option Analysis

❌ Altered mental status:
Incorrect: Altered mental status can be due to a variety of factors, including severe illness, medications, malnutrition, and pain. The finding is fairly nonspecific and, by itself, would not raise concerns for a severe complication of mucormycosis sinusitis.
❌ Blood-tinged nasal discharge:
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms are most consistent with mucormycosis sinusitis. The pathogen is aggressive and can invade surrounding tissue, resulting in blood-tinged nasal discharge. However, this would not be the most severe complication amongst the answer choices.
✅ Impaired extraocular eye movements:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Retro-orbital pain:
Incorrect: Sinusitis affecting the ethmoid sinuses can manifest with nasal bridge or retro-orbital pain. While this symptom may cause discomfort to the patient, it would not be the most severe complication amongst the answer choices.
❌ Reduced ability to detect odors:
Incorrect: Inflammation of the nasal mucosa can result in hyposmia or anosmia. This symptom is a relatively mild finding and would not suggest that there is a major complication of the patient’s mucormycosis sinusitis.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being found down on the side of the street. The patient is able to provide her name and date of birth but no additional information. Review of the medical record reveals a history of alcohol use disorder, hypertension, and type II diabetes mellitus. Her medications include acetazolamide, furosemide, and insulin. Her temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 141/76 mmHg. The patient is oriented to self but not time or place. The abdomen is nondistended and nontender. Vomitus and the smell of alcohol is noticed on the patient’s clothing. Laboratory testing is ordered and reveals the following findings:

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum chemistry 
 Sodium   139 mEq/L 
 Potassium   3.4 mEq/L 
 Chloride   93 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  31 mEq/L 
 Calcium  9.9 mg/dL 
 Arterial blood gas  
 pH  7.49 
 PaCO2  42 mmHg 
 PaO2  104 mmHg 

Which of the following pathophysiologic mechanisms is the most likely cause of this patient’s laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
This patient’s laboratory findings reveal an isolated metabolic alkalosis. In addition, she has low potassium and chloride levels, suggesting gastric acid loss due to repeated vomiting. Of note, while loop-diuretic overdose may also cause a hypokalemic, hypochloremic, metabolic alkalosis, the patient’s normal calcium level makes this explanation less likely.

Metabolic alkalosis arises due to loss of H+ ions or gain of HCO3− ions. Loss of H+ ions commonly occurs following repeated episodes of vomiting, since gastric secretions are highly acidic. Hydrogen H+ ions may also be lost via the urine, such as in the case of hyperaldosteronism.

Gain of HCO3− is usually caused by increased reabsorption from the kidneys. One way this commonly occurs is via volume contraction (e.g., dehydration, loop diuretic use), where fluid but not as much HCO3− is lost. In other cases, the excess HCO3− comes from exogenous sources, such as antacids.



Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of Na+/K+/2Cl- transporter:
Incorrect: Loop diuretics, such as furosemide, work by blocking Na+/K+/2Cl- transporters in the thick ascending loop of Henle. These medications increase the amount of sodium reaching the collecting tubules, where sodium is reabsorbed in exchange for potassium and hydrogen ions. As a result, patients develop a metabolic alkalosis. However, loop diuretics increase calcium excretion and would cause hypocalcemia.
❌ Increased mineralocorticoid production:
Incorrect: Hyperaldosteronism can result in a metabolic alkalosis. Potential causes range from a renin-secreting tumor to renal artery stenosis. However, this patient has no history or physical exam findings suggestive of hyperaldosteronism (e.g., adrenal mass on prior imaging, hypertension refractory to medical management).
❌ Inhibition of carbonic anhydrase:
Incorrect: Acetazolamide is a diuretic that inhibits carbonic anhydrase in the proximal convoluted tubule. The medication causes NaHCO3 diuresis, decreasing total body bicarbonate stores, resulting in a metabolic acidosis. In contrast, this patient has elevated bicarbonate levels and a metabolic alkalosis.
✅ Excessive gastric acid loss:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Increased ketone body production:
Incorrect: Ketogenesis can occur in response to low food intake, strenuous exercise, chronic alcohol use, and inadequately treated diabetes mellitus. Ketogenesis typically results in an anion gap metabolic acidosis. In contrast, this patient has an elevated bicarbonate level, which suggests a metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of fatigue and exertional dyspnea for six months. He discloses occasional palpitations and difficulty sleeping in a supine position due to shortness of breath. His medical history includes hypertension and myocardial infarction at age 58. Medications include lisinopril, aspirin, and clopidogrel. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for thirty years. He drinks alcohol socially and does not use illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 139/87 mmHg. The patient undergoes cardiac catheterization, with hemodynamic results demonstrated on the diagram below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s cardiac catheterization hemodynamic findings are consistent with mitral regurgitation, which refers to the backflow of blood into the left atrium during ventricular systole. When the ventricles contract, some blood flows back into the left atrium, resulting in a higher left atrial pressure and a characteristic tall v-wave. Secondarily, increased pressure in the left atrium increases hydrostatic pressure in the lung capillaries, causing pulmonary edema. Additional clinical findings include paroxysmal or persistent atrial fibrillation. If left untreated, eccentric hypertrophy may occur due to cardiac remodeling.

Mitral regurgitation is most commonly due to mitral valve prolapse or secondary to causes such as ischemia, left ventricular dilation (functional MR), infective endocarditis, and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. On physical examination, a holosystolic murmur is usually heard over the cardiac apex. Surgical repair is required in severe disease.  



Option Analysis

❌ Mitral stenosis:
Incorrect: A stenotic mitral valve results in a higher pressure gradient between the left atrium and left ventricle--especially during early diastole, when the blood flow across the valve peaks. The increased pressure in left atrium pressure can lead to pulmonary edema secondary to increased pulmonary capillary hydrostatic pressure.


✅ Mitral regurgitation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Aortic stenosis:
Incorrect: A stenotic aortic valve leads to a higher pressure gradient between the left ventricle and the aortic pressure. Normally, a small pressure gradient is required to eject blood through the aortic valve, and the pressure gradient increases substantially with aortic stenosis (marked by the grey area below). Clinical manifestations include exertional dyspnea, dizziness, syncope, and angina.


❌ Aortic regurgitation:
Incorrect: Aortic regurgitation occurs secondary to backflow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle during diastole and results in a lower diastolic pressure and wide pulse pressures (e.g., 120/40 instead of 120/80). Clinically, this condition manifests as bounding pulses, diastolic heart murmur, and (rarely) head bobbing.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a syncopal episode during football practice. The patient was running towards the end-zone when he suddenly collapsed. Current temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 118/85 mmHg. ECG demonstrates downsloping ST segment and T wave inversions in leads I, aVL, V4-V6, as well as prominent Q waves in leads II, III, and aVF. On physical examination, a systolic murmur is appreciated over the lower left sternal border. Which of the following maneuvers will increase the intensity of this murmur?
questions.solution:
This young patient presents with exertional syncope and characteristic ECG findings of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HOCM), including dagger q-waves in the inferior leads. In this condition, maneuvers that increase afterload or preload will both increase left ventricular volume--which will widen the left ventricular outflow tract and decrease the intensity of this murmur.

Several maneuvers may assist in the diagnosis of common cardiac murmurs. Maneuvers that increase preload include rapid squatting or passive straight leg raise; these maneuvers will increase the intensity of the mitral regurgitation and aortic regurgitation murmurs, while decreasing the intensity of the murmur associated with HOCM. The valsalva maneuver will decrease preload, thus increasing the murmur associated with HOCM. Sustained handgrip will increase afterload, thus increasing the intensity of the mitral regurgitation and aortic regurgitation murmurs, while decreasing the murmur associated with HOCM. A summary of the effects these maneuvers have on various murmurs is demonstrated in the chart below.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Rapid standing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Sustained hand grip :
Incorrect: Sustained hand grip increases afterload. In a patient with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy, increased afterload elevates left ventricular volume and alleviates the ventricular outlet obstruction--thus decreasing the intensity of the murmur.
❌ Rapid squatting:
Incorrect: Rapid squatting increases venous return, increases afterload, and increases preload. In a patient with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy, increased afterload and preload elevates left ventricular volume and alleviates the ventricular outlet obstruction--thus decreasing the intensity of the murmur.
❌ Passive straight leg raise:
Incorrect: Passive straight leg raise increases the preload. In a patient with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, an increase in preload increases the left ventricular volume, reducing outlet obstruction and murmur intensity.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents for the evaluation of frequent falls. The parents report that the patient has had difficulty running and walking up stairs for the past year, and now they have noticed numerous unprovoked falls. Family history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows enlarged and nontender calves bilaterally. When asked to rise from the floor, the boy uses hand support to push himself to an upright position. Serum creatinine kinase is 14,000 U/L. Molecular genetic testing reveals a large defective muscle protein due to the loss of 508 amino acid residues. Based on the suspected diagnosis, which of the following mutations is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This young boy with progressive proximal muscle weakness, Gower sign (using hand support to push himself to an upright position) and elevated creatinine kinase is most likely suffering from Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), an X-linked recessive disorder caused by frameshift deletion mutation in the dystrophin gene leading to the production of truncated or absent dystrophin protein. Besides frameshift mutation, nonsense mutations are also common in patients with DMD.

The dystrophin gene is a massive gene located on the X-chromosome that has 79 exons and is over 2 million base pairs in length, increasing the chances of spontaneous mutations. The normal function of this protein is to link intracellular actin with the dystrophin-associated protein complex, which links the actin cytoskeleton and the extracellular matrix to stabilize the sarcolemma. In the absence of dystrophin, cellular proteins like creatine kinase escape the damaged cell, and calcium enters the cell, ultimately leading to myonecrosis.



Affected patients usually present at the age or 2-3 years with progressive muscle weakness that affects the proximal muscles before the distal and involves the lower extremities before the upper extremities. The patient often exhibits an abnormal waddling gait and pseudohypertrophy of the calf muscles (fibrofatty replacement of muscles). Gower sign is classic for DMD.




Later symptoms include wheelchair dependence by the age of 12, respiratory failure because of a weak diaphragm, scoliosis, and dilated cardiomyopathy and arrhythmias, since the dystrophin protein is also expressed in heart muscle. Respiratory failure was previously the most common cause of death, but because of improvements in respiratory and spinal care, heart failure has superseded it as the most common cause of death. Complications often lead to a shortened lifespan.  

Option Analysis

❌ Missense mutation:
Incorrect: Missense mutation refers to the base substitution code of one amino acid for a different amino acid one. Examples include sickle cell disease (substitution of glutamic acid with valine). The function of the resultant protein may be altered, but the size remains unchanged, unlike this patient’s genetic results.
❌ Repeat expansion mutation:
Incorrect: Repeat expansion mutations can be seen in trinucleotide repeat disorders; an expansion of a nucleotide triple ultimately results in improper functioning of the protein. Examples include Huntington disease, fragile X disease, and myotonic dystrophy.
❌ Conservative mutation:
Incorrect: Conservative mutation refers to the base substitution code of one amino acid for a different amino acid with a similar chemical structure. The function and size of the protein remains unchanged.
❌ Silent mutation:
Incorrect: Silent mutation refers to the base substitution code for the same amino acid so that the same protein is produced. Silent mutation does not alter the protein function.
✅ Frameshift mutation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to his primary care doctor’s office after he felt a left testicular mass approximately a month ago while taking a shower. He has no pain or discomfort. He states that he had not noticed it before. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient’s left testicle is non-tender, but a firm and fixed mass is palpated. Transillumination is negative. An ultrasound of the left testicle demonstrates a homogenous mass with low echogenicity compared to the normal testicular tissue. Blood work reveals increased placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP) with normal serum levels of AFP and beta-hCG. The primary care physician is concerned about metastasis. Which of the following would most likely be the first area of metastasis?

choices.text: Left superior lobe of the lung

questions.solution:
This male patient’s presentation with a painless testicular mass raises concern for a testicular tumor. The transillumination test, which is performed by shining a light behind the scrotum, confirms the mass being solid, as light is blocked by the mass. If a firm mass is identified, a scrotal ultrasound should be performed, as ultrasound is the first-line imaging in patients that present with a testicular abnormality. While a painless mass is the most common manifestation of a testicular tumor, approximately 1/3 of patients complain of a dull ache or heavy sensation in the lower abdomen, perianal area, or scrotum, and acute pain is the presenting symptom in 10% of patients.

On ultrasound, seminomas usually appear as a homogenous intratesticular mass of low echogenicity compared to the normal testicular tissue. Typically, when suspecting a testicular tumor, serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP), human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) should be measured. These serum markers allow for further categorization of the testicular tumor to a particular type, and they are shown in the table below.

Based on the serum markers in this patient, increased PLAP with normal AFP and beta-hCG typically correlates with a seminoma. Testicular tumors most commonly metastasize via lymphatic drainage. They typically disperse in a predictable fashion through the native lymphatic system, and as such, they often encounter the retroperitoneal lymph nodes (also called paraaortic lymph nodes) first.

An important exception to note is choriocarcinoma, which can also metastasize hematogenously. Lung metastasis from choriocarcinoma occurs in 80-85% of the cases, and intraparenchymal brain metastases occur in 10-20% of the cases.



Option Analysis

❌ First part of the duodenum:
Incorrect: Gastrointestinal metastasis is seen in 5% of germ cell tumors and is a rare presentation. Testicular tumors most commonly metastasize via lymphatic drainage. Thus they typically disperse in a predictable fashion through the native lymphatic system.
❌ Left superior lobe of the lung:
Incorrect: Testicular tumors most commonly metastasize via lymphatic drainage. However, choriocarcinoma is an important exception to this rule, as it can also metastasize hematogenously. Lung metastasis from choriocarcinoma occurs in 80-85% of the cases. However, the blood work in this patient suggests a seminoma, meaning that the most likely pattern of metastasis is through the native lymphatic system.
✅ Retroperitoneal lymph nodes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inferior gyrus of frontal lobe:
Incorrect: Testicular tumors most commonly metastasize via lymphatic drainage, though choriocarcinoma can also metastasize hematogenously. However, choriocarcinomas typically present with elevated serum levels of beta-hCG concentration, which is not seen in this patient. The most likely pattern of dispersion of this patient’s testicular tumor is likely through the native lymphatic system.
❌ Left adrenal gland:
Incorrect: Seminoma has a high metastatic capacity. Metastases initially occur in the retroperitoneal nodes before additional systemic involvement. After that, the most common metastatic sites of germinal tumors are the lungs, liver, CNS, and bone. Other localizations are atypical.

questions.text: An 86-year-old man comes to the clinic for a routine physical evaluation. The patient has a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, major depressive disorder and chronic back pain. His current medications include metformin, amlodipine, hydrochlorothiazide, escitalopram, atorvastatin and oxycodone as needed. The patient uses illicit drugs including cocaine and has a 30-pack year smoking history. He consumes alcohol with his friends on the weekends. His last drink was two days ago. The patient’s father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 60, and his uncle died of an acute aortic dissection at the age of 70. Temperature is 98°F (36.6 °C), pulse is 90 bpm, blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg. Abdominal examination reveals a central pulsatile mass. HbA1c level on this visit is 9.0%. Which of the following risk factors places the patient in a high risk category necessitating ultrasonographic screening for this patient’s finding on the abdominal exam?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of tobacco use and a central, pulsatile abdominal mass likely has an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Patient’s over the age of 60 with any smoking history should be screened for the presence of this pathology. The primary risk factors for abdominal aortic aneurysm include male sex, history of smoking, and age >60. A one time screening abdominal ultrasound is recommended by the US preventive task force for all men between the ages of 65-75 who have ever smoked in the past.

In addition, the most important causes of mortality associated with smoking use are lung cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. Nicotine induces coronary vasoconstriction, stimulates thrombus formation, promotes hypercoagulability and endothelial dysfunction. Long-term cardiovascular complications with tobacco use include acute coronary syndrome, stroke and peripheral vascular disease.

Tobacco use acts as a significant causative factor for the development of multiple malignancies including lung cancer, squamous cell cancer of the esophagus, renal cell carcinoma, and head and neck cancer. Cigarette smoking is also an independent risk factor in the development of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Smoking cessation reduces the risk of progression of early COPD and has been shown to reduce severity of symptoms in the first 12 months after cessation.



Option Analysis

✅ Tobacco use:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hyperlipidemia:
Incorrect: Hyperlipidemia is not as strong an association to the progression of abdominal aortic aneurysm as tobacco use. It is also not used as a screening criteria for abdominal aortic aneurysm.
❌ Hypertension:
Incorrect: Abdominal aortic aneurysms are more common in patients with hypertension; however, tobacco use and age >60 are the critical risk factors when considering the screening for abdominal aortic aneurysms.
❌ Cocaine use:
Incorrect: Cocaine use is associated with an increased risk of acute aortic dissection. It is not associated with an increased risk of abdominal aortic aneurysm and is not considered a criteria for screening.
❌ Uncontrolled diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Uncontrolled diabetes mellitus is a significant risk factor for atherosclerosis and acute coronary syndrome; however, tobacco use and age >60 are the critical risk factors when considering the screening for abdominal aortic aneurysms.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to her primary pediatrician for evaluation of recurrent infections. In the past year, the patient has had two bouts of lobar pneumonia and several episodes of otitis media. Since birth, she has had multiple skin and soft tissue infections that resolve with oral antibiotics. She was born at 38 weeks gestation to a 28-year-old healthy mother. The patient’s umbilical cord separation was delayed by forty days after birth. She eats and drinks normally and has achieved all developmental milestones. Family history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical exam, a 2 cm x 2 cm well-circumscribed fluctuant lesion is noted. Incision and drainage of this skin lesion expresses a moderate amount of sero-sanguinous fluid. Follow up fluid culture grows Staphylococcus aureus, and flow cytometry studies reveal absence of CD18 antigens on the surface of the patient’s leukocytes.  Which of the following immunoprotective mechanisms is defective based on this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with recurrent skin and mucosal infections with absent purulence following incision and drainage of an abscess. These findings, in combination with absence of the CD18 antigen on the leukocyte surface is consistent with leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD), an autosomal recessive disorder. This immunodeficiency results from a defect in CD 18 (LFA-1 integrin)--a cell surface component responsible for leukocyte adherence and transmigration through the endothelium.

This defect results in failure of leukocyte migration and chemotaxis, an increased number of phagocytes  trapped in circulation, and their subsequent inability to invade infected or damaged tissue. Ultimately, this disorder allows pathogens to replicate and spread unchecked by the innate immune system with subsequent tissue damage, an inability to clear cellular debris, and delayed wound healing.

Symptoms of leukocyte adhesion deficiency include recurrent or chronic bacterial or fungal infections of the skin or mucosal membranes (never accompanied by pus or abscess formation), delayed wound healing, poorly formed, thin, bluish scars and delayed umbilical cord sloughing in infants.

Life expectancy without treatment is extremely shortened, with many individuals not surviving past infancy. Diagnosis is based on an elevated number of phagocytes on blood analysis. Flow cytometry can detect absence of expression of the CD18 on the leukocyte membrane. 

Option Analysis

❌ Complement production:
Incorrect: Terminal complement deficiency results from deficiency of C5-C9--a component of the membrane attack complex. A defective membrane attack complex can cause recurrent infections with Neisseria gonorrhoeae or meningitidis. Recurrent pneumonia, otitis media and skin infections are atypical.
❌ Antibody production:
Incorrect: X-linked agammaglobulinemia, an immunodeficiency characterized by a defect in B-cell maturation and severely low immunoglobulin levels, results from a mutation in the BTK gene. Affected patients are susceptible to infections with pyogenic bacteria, enterovirus, and giardia due to paucity of opsonizing and neutralizing antibodies. This disease does not cause peripheral leukocytosis and is inherited in an X-linked pattern; thus it is unlikely to affect a female infant.
❌ Interferon signaling:
Incorrect:  Interferon gamma (INF-ɣ) enhances mycobacterial intracellular killing via formation phagolysosomes. Autosomal recessive deficiency of the INF-ɣ receptor can result in disseminated mycobacterial disease. Recurrent pneumonia, otitis media and skin infections are atypical. Moreover, the CD18 antigen is responsible for leukocyte adhesion to the endothelial cells and would not affect interferon signaling.
❌ Isotype switching:
Incorrect: Isotype switching depends on the interaction of CD40 with its ligand and occurs in naive B cells. The CD18 antigen is responsible for leukocyte adhesion to the endothelial cells.
✅ Leukocyte adhesion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with visual changes. The patient has been seeing colored halos around lights for the past six months and has also noticed her vision has become progressively blurrier. Since symptom onset, she has not experienced any pain or conjunctival erythema. Past medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and asthma. She is currently retired but formerly worked as a national park ranger. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), blood pressure is 151/83 mmHg, and pulse is 76/min. Visual acuity is 20/20 in the right eye and 20/70 in the left eye. A slit-lamp examination is shown below. Which of the following is the most common risk factor for the development of this patient’s condition?
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with progressively worsening, painless visual disturbances, reduced visual acuity, and lens opacification. She likely has a left-eye cataract. Among the risk factors for cataract formation, increased age is the most common.

Cataracts most frequently develop in adults in the fifth or sixth decades of life. In rarer cases, cataracts can be congenital or arise in pediatric patients. The condition is caused by degenerative processes that denature and coagulate proteins within the ocular lens, resulting in opacification, which impairs transmission of light onto the retina. Etiologies and risk factors are numerous and include both inherited and acquired conditions.

Inherited risk factors include congenital TORCH infections, which includes the organisms toxoplasma, syphilis, rubella, cytomegalovirus, and herpes simplex virus. Additional inherited risk factors include genetic conditions, such as trisomies 13, 18 and 21, Marfan syndrome, Alport syndrome, Refsum disease, myotonic dystrophy, neurofibromatosis type 2, and inborn errors of metabolism like galactosemia. Acquired risk factors include advanced age, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, ultraviolet radiation, prolonged corticosteroid use, smoking, nutritional deficiencies (e.g. vitamin C), and ocular trauma/infections.



Option Analysis

✅ Age:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Radiation exposure:
Incorrect: Ultraviolet radiation is a risk factor for the development of cataracts. However, age-related degeneration of the ocular lens is the most common risk factor.
❌ Diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Diabetes mellitus is a known risk factor for the development of cataracts. This association exists because in patients with hyperglycemia, the excess circulating glucose is converted to sorbitol by aldose reductase. Sorbitol then accumulates in the lens, causing osmotic cellular injury. However, age is a more common risk factor for the development of cataracts.
❌ Corticosteroids:
Incorrect: Prolonged use of corticosteroid, both local and systemic, is a risk factor for the development of cataracts. While this patient has a history of asthma and has likely experienced exacerbations in the past, there is little evidence of chronic steroid use (e.g., oral thrush, stretch marks, truncal obesity).
❌ In utero rubella infection:
Incorrect: In utero rubella infection is known to cause congenital cataracts. However, this patient is currently in her 70s, and the visual disturbances developed recently, which makes congenital cataracts unlikely the cause of her symptoms.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presents to the emergency department because of an exquisitely painful rash on the right side of his chest wall. He states it started with a burning sensation in the same region over the past several days that mildly improved with acetaminophen, but then he began noticing the formation of “blisters” in the region. He states he had a fever and feelings of malaise several days ago. Past medical history is significant for chronic kidney disease secondary to diabetic nephropathy and renal transplantation two months ago. Current medications include insulin and cyclosporine. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination findings are shown.  


Reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following terminologies best describes these skin lesions?
questions.solution:
This patient’s raised lesions with <1 cm fluid-containing blisters in a dermatomal distribution are called vesicles. Given his history of immunosuppression (renal transplantation), herpes zoster is the most likely diagnosis.

Herpes zoster, also known as shingles, results from reactivation of the latent varicella-zoster virus that gained access to sensory ganglia at the time of primary infection (chickenpox). Herpes zoster is a painful, unilateral vesicular eruption that is usually restricted by dermatomal distribution. Zoster characteristically presents with a prodrome of fever, malaise, and excruciating burning pain, followed by the outbreak of vesicles that appear over the following three to five days.

Other macroscopic morphologies of common dermatological lesions are described below:  



Option Analysis

❌ Wheal  :
Incorrect: A wheal is characterized as an itchy, erythematous, raised plaque with well-defined margins and a pale center. It results from type I hypersensitivity reaction causing dermal edema and is seen in urticaria. Painful vesicular eruptions, as seen in this patient, are not wheals.  
❌ Macules  :
Incorrect: Macules are described as flat, <1 cm changes in skin color, such as freckles. Instead, this patient has raised lesions with blisters.  
❌ Papules  :
Incorrect: Papules are defined as <1 cm solid elevated skin lesions with no fluid. It is characteristically seen in acne or a mole. This patient has fluid-containing lesions.  
❌ Plaques  :
Incorrect: Plaques are elevated, solid skin lesions >1cm in diameter and are most commonly associated with psoriasis.  
✅ Vesicles  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl is brought to her pediatrician by her parent due to concerns that she has not undergone puberty. The patient feels well, with no specific complaints. Her temperature is 98.3 F°(37 C°), blood pressure of 129/92 mmHg, and a heart rate of 71/min. The physician notes undeveloped breasts and normal appearing genitalia in Tanner stage I of development. She is at the 40<sup>th</sup> percentile for height. A hormone panel is sent and shows an increase in 17-ketosteroids. CT imaging of the abdomen and pelvis demonstrates bilaterally enlarged adrenal glands. Which of the following terms appropriately describes this disorder?
questions.solution:
This 17-year-old patient presents with delayed onset of puberty, a hormonal panel that shows an increase in 17-ketosteroids, and imaging revealing bilaterally enlarged adrenal glands. Together, these findings are suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia, a disorder of sexual development (DSD).

DSD encompasses an array of conditions due to aberrations in sexual development, including congenital adrenal hyperplasia, androgen insensitivity syndrome, 5-alpha-reductase-deficiency, ovotesticular disorder, Kleinfelter syndrome, XYY syndrome, mullerian agenesis, and Turner syndrome.

The term DSD, while currently accepted, has also been controversial. The argument over terminology as it pertains to interventions for these conditions, and whether physicians and parents should make irreversible treatment decisions on behalf of children, continues to be debated. Ultimately, this has led to a continued discussion of medical terminology surrounding and defining these conditions.  



Option Analysis

❌ Intersex disorder  :
Incorrect: Although “intersex disorder” was a common term for a larger family of sexual development disorders, this term is dated and considered pejorative. It should be noted that the term has been reclaimed by some individuals when referring to themselves (i.e. someone may identify as “intersex” or as an “intersex person”). However, the proper medical term for the condition in this question is a disorder of sexual development (DSD).  
❌ True hermaphrodite:
Incorrect: “True hermaphrodite” refers to having both male and female external genitalia; however, this term is dated and considered pejorative.  
❌ Pseudohermaphrodite  :
Incorrect: Similar to “true hermaphrodites,” this term refers to having external genitalia incongruent with their karyotype. However, this is considered a dated and pejorative term no longer in use.  
✅ Disorder of sexual development  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Eunuch  :
Incorrect: An eunuch is an antiquated term that refers to a castrated male. This is not a congenital medical disorder.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl comes to the office for an evaluation of a rash. The rash has been on her abdomen for the past week and is nonpruritic. She returned from a trip to Puerto Rico 10 days ago. She has no other specific complaints at this visit. Past medical history is significant for type 1 diabetes mellitus controlled with insulin. The patient’s mother has Hashimoto thyroiditis, and her sister has severe facial acne. Vitals are within normal limits. A physical examination of the rash is shown below. Which of the following best describes the individual lesions of this patient's rash? 


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with tinea versicolor, which typically presents with hypopigmented or hyperpigmented, flat, <1 cm lesions known as macules, especially on the chest and back. The majority of tinea versicolor is caused by the fungus Malassezia globosa. These yeasts are typically found on the human skin and become troublesome only under certain circumstances, such as in warm and humid environments (e.g. Puerto Rico).  

Other macroscopic morphologies of common dermatological lesions with examples are described below.



Option Analysis

❌ Wheals:
Incorrect: Wheals are characterized by itchy, erythematous, raised plaques with well-defined margins and pale centers. They result from a type I hypersensitivity reaction causing dermal edema, and they are seen in urticaria. The flat, <1 cm changes in skin color seen in this patient are not wheals. 
✅ Macules:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Papules:
Incorrect: Papules are defined as <1 cm solid elevated skin lesions with no oozing fluid. They are characteristically seen in acne or moles. The flat, <1 cm changes in skin color seen in this patient are not papules. 
❌ Plaques:
Incorrect: Plaques are elevated, solid skin lesions >1 cm in diameter and are most commonly seen in association with psoriasis. The flat, <1 cm changes in skin color seen in this patient are not plaques. 
❌ Patches:
Incorrect: A patch is a flat skin lesion > 1 cm in size that differs in color from surrounding skin (e.g. congenital nevus). The flat, <1 cm changes in skin color seen in this patient are not patches.

questions.text: A 34-year-old pregnant primigravid woman at 26 weeks gestation presents to the OB/Gyn clinic. Previous routine checkups done during this pregnancy were unremarkable. An amniocentesis is performed in order to ascertain the karyotype of the child. Ultrasound at the time of the amniocentesis shows a male fetus with head circumference and total body length at the 53<sup>rd</sup> and 67<sup>th</sup> percentile, respectively. The resulting karyotypic analysis reveals the child has an accessory Y chromosome. Which of the following is a key characteristic associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
A karyotype was performed and revealed this patient’s fetus has an accessory Y chromosome. As a result, the karyotype is 47 XYY.  

XYY Syndrome (also termed Jacobs syndrome and double Y syndrome) presents with few symptoms. These can include tall stature, severe acne during puberty, and intellectual disability. Patients are also at increased risk for developing autism spectrum disorder. Overall, individuals with XYY are phenotypically normal and do not have fertility problems. For this reason, the condition is frequently undiagnosed.  

Of note, unlike other chromosomal abnormalities like the trisomies (21, 18, and 13), Triple X syndrome, and Kleinfelter syndrome, XYY syndrome is unrelated to maternal age. There is no correlation since the condition arises due to paternal meiotic nondisjunction, not maternal.  



Option Analysis

❌ Anosmia:
Incorrect: Anosmia is often associated with Kallmann syndrome, which can arise due to defective migration of GnRH-releasing neurons. In contrast, the fetus has an accessory Y chromosome and will likely develop symptoms associated with double Y syndrome.  
❌ Vertebral dislocation  :
Incorrect: Patients with trisomy 21 are at risk for developing atlantoaxial instability, which is instability between the C1 (atlas) and C2 (axis) vertebrae; this instability predisposes patients to vertebral dislocations. Dislocations can be precipitated by intubation, which is why asking about other medical conditions is a key part of the history and physical obtained in the preoperative period.  
✅ Intellectual disability  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.    
❌ Osteoporosis  :
Incorrect: Patients with conditions associated with hypoestrogenemia, such as Turner syndrome, are at risk for developing osteoporosis. In contrast, this patient has double Y syndrome, which would not typically lead to osteoporosis.  
❌ Short stature  :
Incorrect: Double Y syndrome is associated with a tall, not short, stature.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent with abdominal pain and several episodes of vomiting. The vomit is dark red. The patient’s parent also found several opened pill bottles in the bathroom. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient lives in a newly built house with his parents and two older siblings. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a tired appearing child. Dried blood is present in the oropharynx. Peripheral pulses are weak, and capillary refill is 5 seconds. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally, and no abnormal heart sounds are heard. The abdomen is soft and mildly tender at the epigastrium. An abdominal radiograph shows radiopaque pills within the stomach. Laboratory results are shown below. Ingestion of which of the following agents is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with abdominal pain and dark red emesis. Imaging reveals the presence of radiopaque pills within the abdomen. He likely has acute iron toxicity due to ingestion of iron supplement pills.

Iron poisoning often occurs in children who accidentally ingest iron tablets after mistaking them for candy. Iron causes direct mucosal damage to the intestinal tract by free radical formation and lipid peroxidation. Local toxicity causes abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and gastrointestinal bleeding. Systemic toxicity can affect the cardiovascular system and liver, leading to distributive (vasodilation) and cardiogenic (iron-induced myocardial injury) shock and liver necrosis. Patients who survive acute poisoning may develop fibrosis or scarring of the gastrointestinal tissue, which can cause obstruction.

Laboratory testing will reveal an anion gap metabolic acidosis secondary to hypovolemia and hydrogen ion production during iron absorption. Imaging may reveal radiopaque pills within the gastrointestinal tract. Diagnosis is usually based on clinical presentation. A peak serum iron concentration confirms iron ingestion. Treatment involves aggressive fluid resuscitation, gastric lavage to remove any remaining iron from the stomach, and administration of deferoxamine. Deferoxamine is an iron-chelating agent that binds free iron and forms a complex that can be renally excreted.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  

Option Analysis

❌ Lead:
Incorrect: Acute lead toxicity can present with vomiting, abdominal pain, and altered mental status. Radiopaque objects may be seen on abdominal imaging. However, affected patients do not typically develop anion gap metabolic acidosis or hematemesis. Furthermore, this patient does not have potential sources of lead exposure (e.g., paint chips, contaminated water from lead pipes).  
✅ Iron:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin toxicity can present with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Patients may also develop tinnitus. However, aspirin pills are radiolucent and would not typically appear on abdominal imaging.  
❌ Acetaminophen:
Incorrect: Acetaminophen toxicity can present with vomiting and abdominal pain. Patients may also develop symptoms of liver injury such as jaundice, coagulopathy, and hepatomegaly. However, acetaminophen would not typically cause an anion gap metabolic acidosis.  
❌ Warfarin:
Incorrect: Warfarin poisoning typically presents with hemorrhagic bleeding (e.g., nosebleeds, melena, hematuria). The condition can develop due to over ingestion of warfarin pills or rodenticides (which  contain warfarin). However, warfarin toxicity would not typically cause an anion gap metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female is brought to the emergency department in a wheelchair due to difficulty walking. Several days ago, she had back pain and a tingling sensation of the toes. Eventually, she had an inability to move her feet and then her legs. Additionally, she reports being constipated for the past week. Three weeks ago, she had the flu, which was treated with over-the-counter medications and resolved on its own. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 125/72 mmHg while sitting. After standing assisted for several minutes, the blood pressure is 104/60 mmHg. Physical examination reveals absent ankle and knee reflexes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Perimysial inflammation with an abundance of CD4+ T-cells
Endomysial inflammation with an abundance of CD8+ T-cells
Thymic germinal centers producing antibodies against neurotransmitter receptors
IgG antibody-mediated destruction of presynaptic channels

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with bilateral, ascending paralysis and autonomic dysfunction after a preceding viral infection (e.g. influenza). She likely has Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS).  

Nearly two-thirds of patients with GBS experience symptoms of upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection 2-4 weeks prior to the onset of GBS. It is thought that these infectious agents have ganglioside-like molecules on their surface that are similar to the ganglioside components of myelin; this molecular mimicry results in production of cross-reactive antibodies against myelin in peripheral Schwann cells, resulting in immune-mediated segmental demyelination and an endoneurial inflammatory infiltrate composed of lymphocytes and macrophages.  

Clinical features of GBS correlate with the peripheral nerves that are affected. Pain due to nerve root inflammation, typically located in the back and extremities, is often an early feature of the condition. As symptoms progress, there is ascending, bilateral flaccid paralysis that spreads from the lower to upper limbs. This can present as severe weakness and absent deep tendon reflexes. Autonomic dysfunction can result in constipation and orthostatic hypotension. Most importantly, the paralysis may ascend to involve the diaphragm, causing shortness of breath and potentially respiratory failure, which is an emergency and is the most common cause of death in patients with GBS.    

Option Analysis

✅ CD8+ lymphocyte-mediated endoneurial inflammation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perimysial inflammation with an abundance of CD4+ T-cells:
Incorrect: Dermatomyositis is characterized by antibody-mediated inflammation of perimysial muscle fibers with an abundance of CD4+ T cells. Patients typically present with proximal muscle weakness and tenderness, as well as Gottron papules (erythematous papules on the extensor surface of the hands) and heliotrope rash (erythematous rash on the upper eyelids). It is classically seen in patients with an underlying malignancy; the lack of dermatologic symptoms in this patient makes this diagnosis unlikely. 
❌ Endomysial inflammation with an abundance of CD8+ T-cells:
Incorrect: Polymyositis is characterized by cell-mediated inflammation of endomysial muscle fibers with an abundance of CD8+ T cells. Similar to dermatomyositis, patients present with prominent proximal muscle weakness and tenderness. This patient’s bilateral, ascending paralysis is not likely to be the result of this condition. 
❌ Thymic germinal centers producing antibodies against neurotransmitter receptors:
Incorrect: Myasthenia gravis (MG) can be seen in patients with a thymoma. The condition is characterized by production of autoreactive antibodies directed against postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors. Patients typically present with eye muscle weakness, bulbar muscle weakness (e.g., slurred speech, difficulty chewing/swallowing), and proximal limb weakness that worsens with repeated use and improves with rest. This patient’s bilateral, ascending paralysis is not likely to be the result of MG.
❌ IgG antibody-mediated destruction of presynaptic channels:
Incorrect: Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) is a condition wherein autoantibodies are directed against presynaptic calcium channels. Symptoms are similar to those of MG, but muscle weakness improves throughout the day with repeated use. Autonomic dysfunction is also prominent in LEMS. This patient's bilateral ascending paralysis after a viral infection, however, is not likely to be the result of LEMS.

questions.text: A team of scientists are examining the pathophysiology of extrinsic asthma. They observe in a group of rats that initial exposure to an allergen elicits production of an immunoglobulin. The immunoglobulins then attach to the Fc receptors located on Cell X, an immune cell identified by the researchers. On subsequent exposure to the same allergen, the allergen binds to the immunoglobulins on Cell X and induces cross-linking, resulting in immediate bronchospasm, mucus production, and eventual recruitment of additional immune cells. Which of the following cells was likely identified by the researchers as Cell X?
questions.solution:
Asthma is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction caused by inflammation and hyperresponsiveness of the bronchial smooth muscle. The condition arises due to a combination of genetic and environmental factors (e.g., air pollution, cigarette smoke, allergens), which predisposes patients with asthma to type I hypersensitivity reactions.   

Asthma begins when a trigger (e.g. allergen) causes excessive activation of type 2 helper T cells (Th2 cells) and prompts them to produce cytokines (IL-4, IL-13). These cytokines stimulate plasma cells to produce IgE antibodies, which then coat the surface of mast cells. On reexposure to the allergen, the IgEs cross-link, and the mast cells release intracellular granules containing histamines, leukotrienes, and prostaglandins. Mast cell-derived inflammatory mediators produce two waves of reaction, an early-phase and a late-phase:  

- The early-phase reaction is characterized by bronchoconstriction, mucus production, and edema, leading to airway obstruction.  
- The late-phase reaction is mainly inflammatory and is characterized by recruitment of leukocytes (eosinophils, basophils, lymphocytes) to the reaction site. These leukocytes release additional inflammatory mediators, such as major basic protein, which causes epithelial damage.  

Initially, these inflammatory changes are reversible. However, over time, irreversible changes take place. These include scarring and fibrosis of the airways, as well as smooth muscle hypertrophy and hyperplasia, which ultimately result in airway narrowing.



Option Analysis

✅ Mast cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Eosinophils:
Incorrect: Eosinophils play an integral role in the pathophysiology of asthma and are involved in the late-phase reaction. Leukocytes (e.g., neutrophils, eosinophils, basophils) are recruited by mast cell-derived mediators from the early-phase reaction. Cell X, as shown in the experiment, is involved in the early-phase reaction and is therefore unlikely to be an eosinophil. 
❌ Basophils:
Incorrect: Mast cell-derived mediators from the early-phase reaction cause recruitment of leukocytes (e.g., neutrophils, eosinophils, basophils). Cell X, as shown in the experiment, is involved in the early-phase reaction and is therefore unlikely to be a basophil. 
❌ Plasma cells:
Incorrect: The researchers noted that after allergen exposure, there was production of a specific immunoglobulin (IgE) that bound to Fc receptors on Cell X. The IgE immunoglobulins are synthesized and secreted by plasma cells. However, cross-linking of immunoglobulins found on the surface of plasma cells would not precipitate an acute asthma attack. Therefore, Cell X is unlikely to be a plasma cell. 
❌ Th2 cells:
Incorrect: Type 2 T-helper (Th2) cells are involved in the pathogenesis of asthma. These cells produce various cytokines such as interleukin (IL)-4, IL-5, IL-13, and GM-CSF. Th2 cells are involved in stimulating IgE-producing plasma cells and recruiting eosinophils. However, IgE antibodies would not bind to the surface of Th2 Cells and subsequently cross-link to induce asthma. Therefore, Cell X is unlikely to be a Th2 cell.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents to the emergency department with diffuse muscle aches and fatigue. He was brought via EMS after he suddenly collapsed while running a marathon. The patient has some shortness of breath and is having difficulty urinating. He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 107/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 121/64 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 96% on room air. On physical exam, the patient is pale-appearing, has diffuse tenderness to palpation of the upper and lower extremities, and is noted to have increased work of breathing. A catheterized urine specimen appears dark. This patient’s electrocardiogram is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Hyperacute T-waves and wide QRS complexes

questions.solution:
This patient presents following a syncopal episode while running a marathon. He has diffuse muscle aches, dark urine, and fatigue. These findings are concerning for rhabdomyolysis, of which the most common electrolyte abnormality is hyperkalemia. Hyperacute T-waves and wide QRS complexes are the characteristic ECG findings for hyperkalemia.

Potassium is primarily concentrated intracellularly and is essential for the function of excitable tissues, such as nerves, smooth muscles, and cardiac myocytes. Etiologies of hyperkalemia include pathologic states that release potassium from cells and ones that decrease renal excretion of potassium. Processes that chemically alter this balance by shifting potassium out of cells include acidosis, digitalis and beta blocker use, insulin deficiency, hyperglycemia, and hyperosmolality. Pathologic processes that release potassium via tissue catabolism include rhabdomyolysis, crush injuries, and tumor lysis syndrome.   

Potassium is largely excreted by the kidney, and alterations in kidney function or aldosterone function prevent proper handling of this electrolyte. The four major causes of hyperkalemia due to decreased renal excretion of potassium are reduced aldosterone synthesis, reduced response to aldosterone, reduced circulating volume, and acute or chronic kidney disease. 

Regardless of etiology, the clinical manifestations of hyperkalemia are similar. Patients commonly present with fatigue or diffuse muscle weakness. When hyperkalemia becomes severe, generally at levels >7mEq/L, cardiac conduction abnormalities arise resulting in syncope, chest pain, shortness of breath, and arrhythmias.    

Option Analysis

✅ Hyperacute T-waves and wide QRS complexes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Prolonged QT interval :
Incorrect: A prolonged QT interval can be due to hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, hypokalemia, or long QT-syndromes. In contrast, this patient is presenting with symptoms of rhabdomyolysis and likely has hyperkalemia.
