Incorrect: Ingestion of exogenous thyroid hormone (thyrotoxicosis factitia) is due to surreptitious ingestion and can often be confused with other causes of hyperthyroidism. Patients usually present with classic signs of hyperthyroidism in the absence of goiter. Laboratory values typically show low TSH levels, elevated or normal free T4 and/or T3, as well as a low serum thyroglobulin concentration (thyroglobulin is an indication of endogenous source). Diagnosis is based upon the clinical features, laboratory findings, and 24-hour radioiodine uptake.
❌ Subacute thyroiditis:
Incorrect: Subacute thyroiditis (subacute granulomatous thyroiditis or de Quervain thyroiditis) is an inflammatory condition of the thyroid gland that usually follows a viral infection. It is characterized by neck pain, a tender goiter, and a predictable course of hyperthyroidism, followed by euthyroidism, hypothyroidism, and eventually restoration of normal thyroid function. Laboratory values typically show low TSH levels and high free T3 and T4. Thyroid scan will show decreased uptake of radioiodine material.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the clinic complaining of hypoglycemia. Her 10-year-old son has type 1 diabetes, and the patient checks her blood sugar regularly on his glucometer. She reports that her blood sugar was 40 mg/dL this morning, and she felt weak and sweaty, which improved after eating cookies. She is upset that sugar lows are still occuring; she underwent abdominal exploration with subtotal pancreatectomy in search of an insulinoma three months ago, which showed normal pancreatic tissue. Testing was negative for anti-insulin antibodies. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. She appears healthy with well-healed abdominal laparotomy scars. Which of the following patterns would most likely be found on laboratory testing while this patient fasted?

choices.text: Insulin level  C-peptide level  Proinsulin level  Meglitinides  ↓  normal  normal  absent
Insulin level  C-peptide level  Proinsulin level  Meglitinides  ↑↑ normal  normal  absent
Insulin level  C-peptide level  Proinsulin level  Meglitinides  ↑ ↑↑ present

questions.solution:
This patient's history is concerning for factitious hypoglycemia. Factitious hypoglycemia refers to the surreptitious use of insulin or insulin secretagogues like sulfonylureas or meglitinides, often for secondary gain. This patient has a son with type 1 diabetes, therefore she has easy access to insulin, rather than insulin secretagogues, since the latter have no role in treating type 1 diabetes.  

To test for the cause of hypoglycemia in any patient, the serum levels of insulin, proinsulin, and C-peptide must be measured. C-peptide is cleaved by from proinsulin to make insulin, so C-peptide is a byproduct of endogenous insulin production in the beta-cells. High insulin levels but relatively low (or normal) C-peptide means the hypoglycemia is caused by exogenous insulin. In contrast, high insulin and high C-peptide levels indicate that the problem is coming from an insulinoma, an insulin-producing beta cell tumor, or insulin autoimmune hypoglycemia, in the case of very high levels. Sulfonylureas and meglitinides also result in a similar biochemical profile (high insulin, high c-peptide), as the beta cells respond to them by increasing endogenous insulin release, and thus you need to specifically test for the presence of the drug or its metabolites.    


Regardless of the cause, hypoglycemia can be extremely dangerous. The brain depends on glucose for its energy, and therefore, low blood sugar can lead to irreversible damage to the neurons. The symptoms of hypoglycemia include symptoms of autonomic system activation such as palpitations, sweating, shaking, nausea and, of course, hunger. The more dangerous symptoms are called neuroglycopenic symptoms, which include focal neurological deficits, mental confusion and coma. In the short term, hypoglycemia is treated with fast-acting carbohydrates (i.e., juice, crackers) or intravenous dextrose, if the patient is unconscious.  

Option Analysis

❌   Insulin level  C-peptide level  Proinsulin level  Meglitinides  ↓  normal  normal  absent :
Incorrect: Low insulin with normal insulin precursors represent an appropriate response to fasting. A mildly elevated beta-hydroxybutyrate level would also likely be found due to ketogenesis, which would be low in settings of excessive insulin exposure.
✅   Insulin level  C-peptide level  Proinsulin level  Meglitinides  ↑↑ normal  normal  absent :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌   Insulin level  C-peptide level  Proinsulin level  Meglitinides  ↑ ↑  ↑ absent :
Incorrect: Elevated insulin levels with elevated insulin precursors while fasting indicate that the body is producing excess endogenous insulin without the necessary negative feedback loop, as would be caused by an insulinoma. This patient’s negative surgical evaluation argues against an occult insulinoma.
❌   Insulin level  C-peptide level  Proinsulin level  Meglitinides  ↑ ↑↑ present:
Incorrect: Oral hypoglycemic medications (sulfonylureas and meglitinides like nateglinide and repaglinide) cause hypoglycemia by increasing pancreatic insulin release. Therefore, laboratory results appear identical to what is seen in an insulinoma, and testing for the presence of hypoglycemic drugs is necessary, as seen here. This patient more likely has access to exogenous insulin through her son.
❌   Insulin level  C-peptide level  Proinsulin level  Meglitinides  ↑↑↑↑↑↑ absent :
Incorrect: Excessive elevations in endogenous insulin are most often caused by insulin autoimmune hypoglycemia. This occurs in patients with antibodies directed to endogenous insulin. Sporadically, insulin bound up by antibodies dissociates and causes dramatic elevations in insulin and resultant hypoglycemia. This patient’s negative insulin antibody test makes this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to increased thirst and urination for the last month. The patient has no medical history, and he currently takes no medications. The patient’s mother notes that her father had a similar condition. The patient is at the 40th percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. The patient’s temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 86/58 mmHg.  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
Blood, serum, plasma 
Sodium   136 mEq/L 
 Potassium   2.8 mEq/L 
 Chloride   83 mEq/L 
 Uric Acid  10 mg/dL 
 Bicarbonate  46 mEq/L 
Urinalysis shows elevated calcium excretion. Which of the following is most likely affected in this patient?

choices.text: Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.solution:
This patient with growth retardation, polyuria, polydipsia, hyponatremia, hypokalemia, hypochloremia, and metabolic alkalosis most likely has Bartter syndrome. Bartter syndrome is an autosomal recessive renal tubular defect caused by a mutation in the Na+/K+/2Cl- cotransporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. The loss of this cotransporter leads to excretion of sodium, potassium, and chloride in the urine, as well as excessive loss of extracellular water. The depletion of extracellular water then leads to activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, which prompts the excretion of hydrogen and more potassium, as well as the reabsorption of bicarbonate. Therefore, common laboratory findings in patients with Bartter syndrome include metabolic alkalosis and hypokalemia. Despite the loss of sodium through the urine, there is no hyponatremia, due to the concomitant loss of water.

The thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is also responsible for calcium reabsorption via an electrochemical gradient created by the reabsorption of sodium, potassium, and chloride. As a result, patients with Bartter syndrome commonly present with hypercalciuria. Also, due to increased reabsorption of urate and general volume depletion, patients may also present with hyperuricemia with or without gout.  


It is also worth noting that loop diuretics act by blocking the same cotransporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. Therefore, patients with Bartter syndrome present similarly to those with chronic loop diuretic use.  

Option Analysis

❌ Glomerulus:
Incorrect: This patient has Bartter syndrome, which affects the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle (LoH). The glomerulus is affected in nephritic and nephrotic glomerulopathies, which present with hematuria and proteinuria.  
❌ Proximal convoluted tubule:
Incorrect: This patient has Bartter syndrome, which affects the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle (LoH). The proximal convoluted tubule is affected in Fanconi syndrome, which causes metabolic acidosis.  
✅ Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Distal convoluted tubule:
Incorrect: This patient has Bartter syndrome, which affects the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle (LoH). The distal convoluted tubule is affected in Gitelman syndrome. Gitelman syndrome presents similarly to thiazide diuretic therapy, meaning that urine calcium excretion would be low, not elevated as in this patient.
❌ Collecting duct:
Incorrect: This patient has Bartter syndrome, which affects the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle (LoH). The collecting duct is affected in Liddle syndrome, which causes increased sodium reabsorption, leading to hypertension with hypokalemia.

questions.text: A 19-year-old female presents with severe headaches and nausea for the last two months. The patient has no past medical history, and she takes no medications. The patient’s temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 186/92 mmHg. Laboratory tests are obtained, and she is diagnosed with a renal tubular defect that causes increased sodium reabsorption in the collecting duct of the nephron. Which of the following laboratory findings would be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with severe hypertension who is diagnosed with Liddle syndrome most likely has laboratory findings consistent with hypoaldosteronism, hyporeninism, and hypokalemia. Liddle syndrome is an autosomal dominant disease caused by a gain of function mutation that leads to increased activity of the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) in the collecting duct, thereby increasing sodium reabsorption. Normally, ENaC activity is increased by aldosterone, so patients with Liddle syndrome have a clinically identical presentation to those with hyperaldosteronism (i.e. symptomatic hypertension and hypokalemia). However, in patients with Liddle syndrome, laboratory findings show characteristically low levels of aldosterone and renin.

As more sodium is reabsorbed and potassium is excreted, the patient will develop hypertension and hypokalemia. The kidneys will attempt to compensate for these changes by increasing the activity of the K+/H+ ATPase in the collecting duct, which increases hydrogen ion excretion and subsequently causes metabolic alkalosis. Treatment for Liddle syndrome includes a potassium-sparing diuretic, such as amiloride and triamterene, which will block ENaC.  

 

Option Analysis

❌   Aldosterone  Renin  K+  ↑  ↓  ↑ :
Incorrect: These laboratory findings would be present in a patient with primary hyperaldosteronism, also known as Conn syndrome. Patients with Liddle syndrome have characteristically low levels of aldosterone.
❌   Aldosterone  Renin  K+  ↑  ↑  ↑ :
Incorrect: These laboratory findings would be present in a patient with a renin-secreting tumor. Patients with Liddle syndrome have characteristically low levels of aldosterone.
✅   Aldosterone  Renin  K+  ↓  ↓  ↓ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Aldosterone  Renin  K+  ↓  ↑  ↓ :
Incorrect: These laboratory findings would be present in a patient with type 4 renal tubular acidosis (RTA), which is characterized by hypoaldosteronism or aldosterone resistance.
❌   Aldosterone  Renin  K+  ↑  ↑  ↓ :
Incorrect: These laboratory findings would be present in a patient with Bartter syndrome or Gitelman syndrome, which affect the loop of Henle or the distal convoluted tubule, respectively.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the outpatient clinic because of intermittent left flank pain that has been ongoing for the past two weeks. She has noticed blood in her urine on a few occasions. Moreover, the pain has become more severe. She works as a personal trainer. Family and medical history are unremarkable. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 80/minute, respiratory rate is 16/minute, and blood pressure is 130/95 mm Hg. An x-ray is ordered and shown below:

Retrieved from:

Which of the following best describes the composition of this pathological structure?
questions.solution:
This patient has fever, flank pain, and hematuria, a classic presentation of nephrolithiasis.  

Struvite (magnesium ammonium phosphate) accounts for approximately 70% of staghorn calculi, which appear as branching calcified densities overlying the renal outline. The stones are radiopaque and visualized on imaging because they are usually mixed with calcium phosphate.  

These kidney stones typically occur in the setting of an infection by urease-positive bacteria. These include Proteus, Klebsiella, Pseudomonas, and Enterobacter. Urease-producing bacteria break down urinary urea into ammonia and carbon dioxide. The ammonia makes the urine more alkaline, thereby reducing the solubility of magnesium, ammonium, and phosphate. These substances then precipitate and form stones.  

Treatment involves eradicating the underlying infection and surgical removal of the stone. Microscopic analysis of the patient’s urine and stone will show coffin lid shaped crystals.  



Retrieved from:


Retrieved from:

Option Analysis

❌ Brushite:
Incorrect: Brushite, also termed calcium monohydrogen phosphate, is a type of calcium phosphate kidney stone. Calcium containing stones are radiopaque and can be visualized on plain radiograph. However, they would rarely take the shape of a staghorn calculi.
❌ Calcium oxalate:
Incorrect: Calcium oxalate accounts for about 80% of renal stones. Many conditions can predispose patients to developing calcium oxalate stones. These include ethylene glycol (antifreeze) ingestion, vitamin C overconsumption, hypocitraturia, and malabsorption (e.g. Crohn disease). Calcium oxalate stones are radio-opaque and can be visualized on plain radiograph. However, they would rarely take the shape of a staghorn calculi.
✅ Ammonium magnesium phosphate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Uric acid:
Incorrect: Uric acid stones are radiolucent and would not appear on an x-ray. Uric acid stones account for 5-10% of all stones. Dehydration, acidic urine, and increased uric acid levels promote their formation. Additionally, chronic diarrhea, which leads to loss of bicarbonate via feces and lowered urine pH, also facilitates uric acid stone formation.
❌ Cystine:
Incorrect: Cystine stones are seen in patients with hereditary cystinuria, a genetic condition in which the cystine-reabsorbing proximal convoluted tubule transporter loses function. This defect causes increased urinary cystine excretion and cystine nephrolithiasis. Although cystinuria can also cause staghorn calculi, it usually manifests with symptoms in childhood, as well as a positive family history.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe shortness of breath. The patient is currently speaking in two to three word sentences and reports “my chest hurts.” Medical history is notable for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and recent wrist surgery for a radial head fracture. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 105/min, blood pressure is 136/94 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 27/min. Oxygen saturation is 83% on room air. Physical examination is notable for a thin body habitus, accessory muscle use while breathing, reduced breath sounds over the right lung, and diffuse expiratory wheezing. EKG shows sinus tachycardia. An influenza test is ordered and returns positive. A chest radiograph reveals the following findings:

Image reproduced from

Which of the following is the strongest risk factor predisposing the patient to his current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has labored breathing, chest pain, and tachypnea in the setting of a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Imaging reveals a partially collapsed right lung. This patient likely has a secondary spontaneous pneumothorax, and COPD is the strongest risk factor associated with developing this condition.    

Secondary pneumothorax refers to a pneumothorax, or the presence of air in the pleural cavity, due to an underlying lung condition. The list of conditions is numerous, but the most common ones include COPD (57% of cases), asthma, cystic fibrosis, malignancies, tuberculosis, and interstitial lung disease. In general, secondary pneumothorax occurs when a bullae ruptures in the diseased lung tissue. This defect enables air to escape through ruptured bullae and become trapped in the pleural cavity, promoting further lung collapse.  

A unique form of secondary pneumothorax is catamenial pneumothorax, during which recurrent spontaneous pneumothoraces occur in association with menses. The etiology of this condition is unknown, but it is thought to be associated with endometriosis.  

Symptoms of secondary spontaneous pneumothorax include dyspnea, unilateral pleuritic chest pain, and reduced breath sounds in the affected lung. Vitals may show tachypnea and in severe cases, decreased oxygen saturation levels.  

Option Analysis

✅ Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Recent wrist surgery:
Incorrect: Recent surgery is a known risk factor for the development of deep vein thrombosis and  pulmonary embolism. It is more common after major surgeries (e.g., pelvic, intra-abdominal, cardiothoracic) resulting in prolonged periods of immobility. In contrast, this patient’s surgery is relatively minor, and the imaging findings of a partially collapsed right lung are more consistent with a pneumothorax.  
❌ Coronary artery disease  :
Incorrect: Coronary artery disease is a risk factor for acute coronary syndrome and angina pectoris. However, this patient’s EKG shows sinus tachycardia and no signs of ischemic changes (e.g., ST-segment elevation, ST-segment depression). Therefore, another diagnosis is more likely.
❌ Influenza  :
Incorrect: Viral infections, particularly influenza, place patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) at high risk for severe exacerbations. Some exacerbation episodes may require non-invasive ventilation or even intubation. However, viral infections are not an established risk factor for the development of pneumothorax, as seen on the chest radiograph.
❌ Body habitus  :
Incorrect: Patients with a tall, thin body habitus are at increased risk of developing a pneumothorax. This association is thought to be due to greater alveolar stretch at the lung apex in such individuals, which predisposes them to forming subpleural blebs that may subsequently rupture. However, the patient’s underlying COPD is a stronger risk factor for developing pneumothorax.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with worsening shortness of breath. The patient has difficulty lying flat at night, bilateral lower extremity swelling, worsening cough, and shoulder pain when taking deep breaths. Past medical history is notable for coronary artery disease status-post bypass surgery, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type II diabetes mellitus. Social history is notable for a 15 pack-year smoking history and chronic alcohol use. He recently traveled to Vietnam to visit his son, who was studying abroad. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 172/67 mmHg. Respiratory rate is 26/min, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. Physical examination reveals a patient in moderate respiratory distress. Cardiopulmonary examination demonstrates absent breath sounds over the bilateral lung bases and an S3 gallop. There is 2+ pitting edema in the lower extremities. Chest x-ray and laboratory values are shown below:

Reproduced from:



Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's radiographic findings?

choices.text: Poor ejection fraction and increased end diastolic volume
Fibrosis and irreversible scarring of the liver

questions.solution:
This patient has physical exam and radiographic findings demonstrating volume overload and bilateral pleural effusions in the setting of major cardiac risk factors. He most likely has a transudative effusion secondary to congestive heart failure.  

Pleural effusions are divided into three categories: 1) transudative, 2) exudative, and 3) lymphatic etiologies. In the United States, heart failure is the most common cause of transudative pleural effusions, which is defined by Light's criteria as having a fluid LDH/serum LDH < 0.6, fluid protein/serum protein < 0.5, and fluid LDH < 2/3 upper limit of normal. Transudative pleural effusions in the setting of heart failure are the result of increased hydrostatic pressure. Other causes of transudative pleural effusions include hypoalbuminemia, cirrhosis, and nephrotic syndrome due to decreased oncotic pressure.  

In contrast, exudative pleural effusions are characterized by a fluid LDH/serum LDH > 0.6, fluid protein/serum protein > 0.5, and fluid LDH > 2/3 upper limit of normal. Exudative effusions result from processes that increase protein synthesis (e.g., malignancy, pneumonia) or increase vascular permeability to proteins (e.g., trauma, collagen vascular diseases).  

Lymphatic pleural effusions, also termed chylothorax, arise from thoracic duct injury secondary to malignancy or trauma. These effusions will meet Light's criteria for exudative effusions but will also have an elevated triglyceride content.  


Option Analysis

✅ Poor ejection fraction and increased end diastolic volume:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pulmonary infection with a mycobacteria  :
Incorrect: Tuberculosis is the most common cause of pleural effusions in developing nations. The recent visit to Vietnam places the patient at risk for acquiring tuberculosis. However, he lacks other symptoms associated with this condition, such night sweats, hemoptysis, or weight loss.
❌ Fibrosis and irreversible scarring of the liver:
Incorrect: This patient is at risk for cirrhosis given the history of chronic alcohol use. Cirrhosis can cause a transudative effusion secondary to impaired hepatic synthesis of proteins (e.g. hypoalbuminemia). However, this patient’s albumin level and coagulation assays are within normal limits, reflecting adequate hepatic function and protein synthesis.  
❌ Hilar mass arising from bronchus:
Incorrect: This patient is at high risk for squamous cell carcinoma given his smoking history. However, this patient’s effusion is characterized as transudative based on Light's criteria. In contrast, if this patient had an underlying malignancy, he would more likely have an exudative effusion.
❌ Injury to the thoracic duct:
Incorrect: Chylothorax refers to a pleural effusion in the setting of lymphatic injury, usually the thoracic duct. A chylothorax will usually present in the setting of malignancy or trauma, with fluid that appears milky white and with an elevated level of triglycerides. In contrast, this patient’s pleural effusion has normal triglyceride levels.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old man comes to his outpatient provider for evaluation of epigastric abdominal pain and unintentional weight loss. The symptoms began 6 months ago and the patient has lost 4 kg (8.8 lb) during this time period. Review of systems is notable for fatigue and pruritus over this same time period. Past medical history is notable for alcohol use disorder. The patient has a 35-pack-year smoking history. In the office, his temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure is 125/77 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. Physical examination shows an enlarged, palpable, but non-tender, gallbladder. Examination of the patient’s eyes reveals the following finding:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
Cardiac and pulmonary exams are noncontributory. Serum carbohydrate antigen 19-9 levels are elevated. Which of the following laboratory findings would most likely be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has pancreatic cancer. The tumor can impinge the bile duct, obstruct outflow, and cause conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Patients with pancreatic cancer can develop jaundice, scleral icterus, epigastric pain, weight loss, and night sweats. Of note, the image in this vignette shows scleral icterus. Patients can also have the Trousseau sign of malignancy (superficial blood clots; also known as Trousseau syndrome) and, as in this patient, the Courvoisier sign (enlarged, palpable, yet non-tender gallbladder and accompanying jaundice).  

Other causes of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia include reduced bilirubin excretion (e.g. Dubin-Johnson syndrome), biliary tract conditions (e.g. primary sclerosing cholangitis), and biliary tract obstruction (e.g. choledocolithiasis). In the aforementioned etiologies, conjugated bilirubin can deposit in tissues and cause pruritus. In these conditions, less conjugated bilirubin reaches the intestines. As a result, there is less conversion of bilirubin into urobilinogen, and therefore, less urobilinogen is reabsorbed and excreted via urine. Ultimately, patients will have low urine urobilinogen levels.   

In contrast, for patients with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, bile outflow is unaffected. Thus patients with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia have either normal or elevated urine urobilinogen levels (depending on the specific etiology). 

Option Analysis

❌  Unconjugated bilirubin Conjugated bilirubin Urine urobilinogen Normal  Normal  Normal :
Incorrect:  These findings would be seen in a healthy individual. However, this patient has jaundice and scleral icterus, which are concerning for elevated bilirubin levels. Hence, either unconjugated or conjugated bilirubin levels should be elevated.
❌  Unconjugated bilirubin Conjugated bilirubin Urine urobilinogen  ↑ Normal  ↑:
Incorrect: Prehepatic and intrahepatic etiologies can cause unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Since bile outflow is not affected, urine urobilinogen levels are either normal or elevated. However, this patient's history, physical exam findings, and elevated CA 19-9 are concerning for pancreatic cancer. Pancreatic cancer can compress the biliary tree, impair bile outflow, and cause elevated conjugated bilirubin levels.  
✅  Unconjugated bilirubin Conjugated bilirubin Urine urobilinogen Normal  ↑ ↓:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌  Unconjugated bilirubin Conjugated bilirubin Urine urobilinogen ↑ ↑ ↓:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with mixed hyperbilirubinemia, which is often due to jaundice or cirrhosis. However, this patient’s symptoms are more consistent with pancreatic cancer, which would most likely cause purely conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and reduced urine urobilinogen levels secondary to impaired bile outflow.
❌   Unconjugated bilirubin  Conjugated bilirubin  Urine urobilinogen  ↑ Normal  Normal :
Incorrect: Prehepatic and intrahepatic etiologies can cause unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Since bile outflow is not affected in these etiologies, urine urobilinogen is either normal or elevated. However, this patient’s history and physical exam findings are suggestive of pancreatic cancer, which would cause conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

questions.text:
A 69-year-old woman comes to her physician for evaluation of  “gritty,” red, itchy eyes for the past three months. The patient has also had intermittent episodes of associated blurry vision. The patient's visual acuity acutely worsens during periods of reading, driving, and watching television. She reports a past medical history of “seasonal allergies” and takes oral antihistamines without relief of symptoms. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals bilateral conjunctival injection. Visual acuity testing demonstrates 20/80 vision in both eyes bilaterally. Slit-lamp examination using fluorescein stain reveals “spotty” uptake. Oral examination reveals multiple dental caries and halitosis. Laboratory results are demonstrated below:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  11.3  g/dL 
 Hematocrit  39 % 
 Leukocyte count  9,100 /mm3 
 Platelet count  375,000/mm3 
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate  5 mm/h 
 Antinuclear antibodies   Negative 
 Rheumatoid factor  Negative 
 Anti-dsDNA  Negative 
 Anti-Ro/La  Negative 
Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Autoimmune destruction of salivary and lacrimal glands

questions.solution:
Keratoconjunctivitis refers to ocular inflammation involving both the cornea and the conjunctiva, and it is divided into infectious and non-infectious etiologies. Infectious keratoconjunctivitis is most commonly caused by viruses--involving adenovirus in greater than 90% of cases.  Among non-infectious causes of keratoconjunctivitis, keratoconjunctivitis sicca, also known as dry eye disease, is due to age-related atrophy of the lacrimal glands.   

Keratoconjunctivitis, in addition to typical symptoms of conjunctivitis, also presents with blurry vision due to corneal involvement. A particularly pathognomonic finding is that reading, computer use, television or other electronic use, or driving (when the natural blink reflex is decreased) exacerbates the decreased visual acuity. For keratoconjunctivitis sicca, eye dryness and irritation are common, which are characteristically described as a sensation of sand (“grittiness”) in the eyes. Further diagnostic testing, such as slit lamp examination using fluorescein, may reveal a “spotty” or diffuse uptake stain.  

Option Analysis

✅ Age-related atrophy of glandular tissue  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Allergen-induced ocular inflammation:
Incorrect: Vernal keratoconjunctivitis is a severe allergic conjunctivitis that is likely caused by the immunoglobulin E (IgE) mast cell-mediated pathway. Although this patient has a history of allergies, her current symptoms are not relieved by antihistamines, suggesting another diagnosis. 
❌ Autoimmune destruction of salivary and lacrimal glands:
Incorrect: Although this patient has symptoms suggestive of Sjogren syndrome (e.g., keratoconjunctivitis, dental caries, halitosis), her laboratory results are negative for the autoimmune condition, making this an unlikely diagnosis. 
❌ Herpes simplex virus reactivation:
Incorrect: HSV reactivation can result in keratoconjunctivitis with similar symptoms; however, diagnosis is confirmed via slit lamp examination, which demonstrates branching dendritic lesions on the cornea--not diffuse uptake. 
❌ Adenovirus-induced ocular inflammation:
Incorrect: Viral keratoconjunctivitis has an associated antecedent upper respiratory illness in up to 50% of cases. Patients initially present with unilateral eye involvement that later spreads to the contralateral eye. Adenovirus-related keratoconjunctivitis typically lasts for a few weeks before self-resolving, making this etiology unlikely.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath. He has a history of asthma and feels like he is currently “having a flare up” due to seasonal allergies. The patient uses an albuterol inhaler at home. He does not consume alcohol, tobacco, or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 62/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 122/72 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% O2 on room air. There are faint end expiratory wheezing bilaterally, and the electrocardiogram from triage is demonstrated below:  

 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s electrocardiographic findings?

choices.text: Pre-excitation through an accessory bypass tract
Enhanced automaticity from atrial non-sinus node sites

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a mild asthma exacerbation and has an electrocardiogram demonstrating beat-to-beat variation in the P-P interval and an irregular ventricular rate. These findings are consistent with sinus arrhythmia.   

Sinus arrhythmia is a normal physiologic variant of sinus rhythm and is due to changes in vagal tone throughout the respiratory cycle. As patients inspire, vagal tone decreases and heart rate increases. With subsequent onset of expiration, vagal tone is restored, leading to a decrease in heart rate. On an electrocardiograph, this condition manifests with variations in the P-P interval of more than 120 ms (3 small boxes), normal sinus P-waves with a constant morphology, and a constant P-R interval.  



Option Analysis

✅ Changes in vagal tone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Multiple atrial micro-reentrant circuits :
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation is defined electrocardiographically as irregularly irregular QRS complexes with absent P-waves. The condition arises due to the presence of multiple atrial micro-reentrant circuits. In contrast, this patient has a regular rhythm and P-waves are present.
❌ Pre-excitation through an accessory bypass tract:
Incorrect: Pre-excitation syndromes, such as Wolff-Parkinson White syndrome, are characterized by the presence of an accessory bypass tract (e.g. bundle of Kent). Electrocardiographically, these conditions are characterized by delta waves, broad QRS complexes, and short PR intervals. 
❌ Metabolic abnormality:
Incorrect: Metabolic abnormalities such as hypomagnesemia or hypokalemia can produce premature ventricular complexes or a prolonged QT interval. However, metabolic disturbances are not associated with sinus arrhythmia. 
❌ Enhanced automaticity from atrial non-sinus node sites:
Incorrect: Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is defined by an irregularly irregular rhythm with varying R-R intervals and at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies in the same lead. The condition results from enhanced automaticity at non-sinus node sites.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with shortness of breath. She reports worsening shortness of breath and fatigue over the past several months and states, “I just don’t feel like myself.” Her past medical history includes obesity and hypertension. She smokes one half-pack of cigarettes per day. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 21/min, blood pressure is 120/94 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. Physical examination reveals coarse bilateral breath sounds and red tender lumps on the anterior shins. A chest x-ray is performed and shown below.  


Reproduced from: Radiopedia    

Which of the following is most likely to be seen on pulmonary function testing for this patient?

choices.text: Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV)  Diffusing capacity for CO (DLCO)  Arterial -alveolar gradient (A-a gradient)  ↓  ↑  ↓  ↓  ↑

Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV)  Diffusing capacity for CO (DLCO)  Arterial -alveolar gradient (A-a gradient) ↑   ↓  ↑  normalnormal

Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV)  Diffusing capacity for CO (DLCO)  Arterial -alveolar gradient (A-a gradient)  ↓  ↑  ↓  normal normal

Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV)  Diffusing capacity for CO (DLCO)  Arterial -alveolar gradient (A-a gradient)  ↑ normal  ↑ ↓  normal

Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV)  Diffusing capacity for CO (DLCO)  Arterial -alveolar gradient (A-a gradient) ↑   ↑  ↑   ↓  ↑

questions.solution:
This patient presents with shortness of breath, fatigue, erythema nodosum (red tender nodules on the shins), and a chest x-xray demonstrating hilar lymphadenopathy, consistent with sarcoidosis. Sarcoidosis is a type of restrictive lung disease, of the diffuse parenchymal lung disease subtype. These patients present with usual parameters of restrictive lung disease (decreased TLC, increased FEV1/FVC, and decreased RV) in addition to a decreased diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) and increased arterial -alveolar gradient (A-a gradient).  

Diffuse parenchymal lung disease (DPLD) refers to a subtype of restrictive lung diseases characterized by fibrotic, rigid lungs with decreased compliance and increased elasticity. The causes of DPLD are numerous and include sarcoidosis, pneumoconiosis, idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, vasculitis such as Goodpasture syndrome and granulomatosis with polyangiitis, and drug toxicities (e.g. amiodarone). Regardless of the etiology, scarring and fibrosis of lung parenchyma results in stiff lungs that cannot adequately fill during inhalation. On pulmonary function testing, this restriction manifests with decreased TLC, decreased RV, and a decreased FEV1. Due to increased elasticity of lung tissue in this disease state, the FEV1 or volume of air exhaled over one second, increases in proportion to the forced vital capacity.  

The distinguishing feature of DPLD from other forms of restrictive lung disease is a decreased DLCO and increased A-a gradient. The DLCO refers to how easily gases are transferred between the alveoli and the bloodstream using carbon monoxide as a surrogate marker. Fibrosis at the alveolar-capillary level impairs gas transfer and increases the A-a gradient, or difference between the amount of oxygen in the alveoli and the bloodstream.  

During respiration, affected portions of the lung receive less oxygen, resulting in reflexive pulmonary vasoconstriction to shunt blood towards more adequately ventilated areas of the lung. Over time, this shunting results in pulmonary hypertension, right ventricular hypertrophy, and subsequent right heart failure or cor pulmonale.   

Option Analysis

✅   Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV)  Diffusing capacity for CO (DLCO)  Arterial -alveolar gradient (A-a gradient)  ↓  ↑  ↓  ↓  ↑ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV)  Diffusing capacity for CO (DLCO)  Arterial -alveolar gradient (A-a gradient) ↑   ↓  ↑  normalnormal :
Incorrect: Obstructive lung diseases, not restrictive lung diseases, present with these parameters. While this patient does smoke, the chest x-ray does not demonstrate findings consistent with the diagnosis of COPD, such as flattened diaphragms or hyperinflated lungs. 
❌   Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV)  Diffusing capacity for CO (DLCO)  Arterial -alveolar gradient (A-a gradient)  ↓  ↑  ↓  normal normal:
Incorrect: Restrictive lung diseases due to poor breathing mechanics (e.g., scoliosis, obesity hypoventilation) will demonstrate similar spirometry findings; however, they will have a normal DLCO and A-a gradient because these diseases do not have structural abnormalities at the alveolar-capillary interface impairing gas exchange. 
❌   Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV)  Diffusing capacity for CO (DLCO)  Arterial -alveolar gradient (A-a gradient)  ↑ normal  ↑ ↓  normal :
Incorrect:  These findings are not indicative of obstructive or restrictive lung disease.
❌   Total Lung Capacity (TLC)  Forced expiratory volume in one second/Forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)  Residual volume (RV)  Diffusing capacity for CO (DLCO)  Arterial -alveolar gradient (A-a gradient) ↑   ↑  ↑   ↓  ↑ :
Incorrect: An increased FEV1/FVC in the setting of increased TLC and RV is rarely found and is more commonly due to measurement error.

questions.text:
An 87-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with worsening shortness of breath. Per paramedics, the patient was found down at his assisted living facility with increased work of breathing. Yesterday, the patient was in no acute distress but was noted by nursing staff to be acting “more confused” than usual. The patient’s past medical history is notable for coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type II diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 32/min, blood pressure is 79/50 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 89% on room air. On physical exam, the patient is obtunded, ill appearing, and has both suprasternal and intercostal retractions. Laboratory findings are demonstrated below:


This patient is likely to have which of the following additional clinical findings?
questions.solution:
This elderly patient presents with increased work of breathing, fever, hypotension, and lactic acidosis. His overall clinical presentation is consistent with septic shock and hypoxemic respiratory failure, likely in the setting of community acquired pneumonia. Septic shock falls under the umbrella of distributive or “warm shock,” which presents with warm, perfused peripheral extremities.  

Distributive shock refers to severe peripheral vasodilation resulting in inadequate perfusion to vital organs. There are three primary causes of distributive shock: sepsis, anaphylaxis, and neurogenic.  Overall, septic shock is the most common cause and refers to a systemic physiologic response to severe infection. Anaphylaxis refers to an extreme systemic response to allergens. Neurogenic shock refers to impaired sympathetic outflow in response to severe neurological trauma.  

Regardless of etiology, the overall clinical and physiologic presentation of distributive shock is similar. Profound peripheral vasodilation results in decreased systemic vascular resistance, decreased venous return, and decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure. In response, the heart compensates by increasing cardiac output (via increased heart rate) in an attempt to perfuse vital organs. However, as blood moves faster through capillary beds, the tissues cannot extract the necessary oxygen needed to perform metabolic functions. This phenomenon results in increased anaerobic metabolism, lactic acidosis, and increased mixed venous oxygen saturation.  



Option Analysis

✅ Perfused peripheral extremities:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Delayed capillary refill:
Incorrect: “Cold shock” presents with cool extremities and is most commonly associated with cardiogenic, obstructive, or hypovolemic shock. These etiologies are less likely in this patient who is febrile and has a metabolic acidosis.  
❌ Muffled heart sounds:
Incorrect: Patients with pericardial tamponade, a type of obstructive shock, can present with Beck triad. Beck triad consists of muffled heart sounds, jugular venous distention, and hypotension. Clues to this diagnosis include a history of penetrating trauma to the chest, uremia, or malignancy. In contrast, this patient has fever, altered mental status, and metabolic acidosis, which raises greater concerns for infection and sepsis.
❌ Bilateral pulmonary rales:
Incorrect: Cardiogenic shock often presents with pulmonary edema due to decreased cardiac output, increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, and subsequent pooling of blood in the pulmonary vasculature. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with sepsis secondary to community acquired pneumonia, which typically presents with unilateral rales.
❌ Jugular venous distension:
Incorrect: Obstructive shock, which may be due to cardiac tamponade, tension pneumothorax, or pulmonary embolism, falls under the umbrella of “cold shock.” These conditions can present with jugular venous distension due to impaired cardiac outflow.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with shortness of breath. He reports worsening shortness of breath ever since he started working as a foundry-man where he is frequently outside using a stone cutter. He has no symptoms of arthralgias, fatigue, or malaise. His past medical history is notable for obesity and hypertension. He does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is non-contributory. A chest x-ray is performed which shows innumerable, small, rounded opacities in the upper lung zones and is demonstrated below:  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia    

Laboratory studies show negative rheumatoid factor antibodies and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (CCP) antibodies. If left untreated, this patient is at increased risk for which of the following disease processes?
questions.solution:
This patient, who works in a foundry, presents with increasing dyspnea on exertion. His chest x-ray demonstrates nodular opacities of the upper lobes, consistent with silicosis. This pneumoconiosis is known to increase the risk of pulmonary tuberculosis by three fold, due to silica’s ability to disrupt phagolysosome formation. Mycobacterial infection, particularly tuberculosis, is a well-established complication of silicosis and should be suspected when a patient with silicosis develops constitutional symptoms, worsening respiratory impairment, hemoptysis, or changes in the chest radiograph.  

Silicosis refers to a fibrotic pneumoconiosis caused by the inhalation of fine particles of crystalline silicon dioxide. Patients at increased susceptibility to inhalation of these particles include those who work in foundries, sandblasting, and silica mines. Development of silicosis occurs when these crystalline particles become lodged in small airways. Alveolar macrophages attempt to remove the particles and initiate a cascade of inflammation resulting in collagen deposition and fibrosis surrounding the silicate particles, forming silicotic nodules. As these nodules mature, the center becomes a dense fibrotic scar, giving rise to an “onion skin” appearance. Unless exposure is terminated, these nodules eventually merge, resulting in diffuse lung fibrosis.   

Clinically, silicosis manifests most commonly with dyspnea or a non-productive cough. As fibrosis progresses, more severe complications may occur including hypoxia, pulmonary hypertension, and cor pulmonale. Diagnosis of silicosis rests on history, physiologic, radiographic, and histologic findings. Patients will often have restrictive physiology on pulmonary function testing, as well as nodular opacities and hilar lymph node calcification of the upper lobes. Lung biopsy will typically demonstrate birefringent particles of silica surrounded by fibrosis. Treatment of silicosis involves removal from the exposure and supportive care.  



Option Analysis

✅ Pulmonary tuberculosis :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Mesothelioma :
Incorrect: Asbestos exposure is associated with the development of mesothelioma—a malignancy of the arising from the pleura. Patients with exposure to asbestos typically have a history of working in shipbuilding, plumbing, roofing, or the textile industry. Silicosis is not associated with this malignancy.
❌ Caplan syndrome:
Incorrect: Caplan syndrome refers to a combination of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and pneumoconiosis. RA alters how the immune system responds to foreign particles (such as silica) and results in the rapid development of multiple peripheral basilar nodules and lung fibrosis. This patient does not have any signs or symptoms of RA, and his negative antibody studies make this diagnosis unlikely.  
❌ Acute respiratory distress syndrome :
Incorrect: Acute respiratory distress syndrome or ARDS typically results after an acute pulmonary insult such as acute pneumonia, near drowning, or a massive pulmonary embolism. It does not typically occur after chronic lung fibrosis. 
❌ Superior sulcus tumor:
Incorrect: A superior sulcus tumor, also known as a Pancoast tumor, is not typically associated with chronic silicosis. This type of tumor can manifest with Horner syndrome, hoarseness, or brachial plexus injury.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to his primary care physician’s office for evaluation of worsening low back pain and stiffness for 2 years. The pain is worse in the morning or after a prolonged period of rest. Review of systems is positive for exertional dyspnea. Recently, he began taking over-the-counter acetaminophen, providing some relief. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates restricted forward flexion of lumbar spine. When the patient is asked to raise his arms above his head and exert a maximal forced expiration followed by a maximal inspiration, the chest expansion observed is1.4 cm (normal 6.5 cm). Chest x-ray is normal. His spinal radiograph is shown below.  


Reproduced from: Radiopedia.org  

Which of the following findings is most likely to be observed in this patient on spirometry?

choices.text: Forced expiratory volume in 1 second to forced vital capacity ratio (FEV1/FVC) Diffusion lung capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) Normal  ↓
Forced expiratory volume in 1 second to forced vital capacity ratio (FEV1/FVC) Diffusion lung capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) ↑ Normal
Forced expiratory volume in 1 second to forced vital capacity ratio (FEV1/FVC)  Diffusion lung capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO)  ↓  ↓
Forced expiratory volume in 1 second to forced vital capacity ratio (FEV1/FVC)  Diffusion lung capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) ↑ ↓
Forced expiratory volume in 1 second to forced vital capacity ratio (FEV1/FVC) Diffusion lung capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) ↓  Normal

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of chronic back pain, morning stiffness and x-ray findings of fused vertebral bodies is consistent with ankylosing spondylitis (AS). This patient’s exertional dyspnea and finding of restricted chest expansion are highly suspicious of restrictive lung disease (RLD), a known complication of long term AS.  

AS is a chronic inflammatory seronegative spondyloarthropathy that primarily affects spinal and sacroiliac joints. Chronic back pain is the predominant presenting symptom and usually occurs before the age of 40 years. The back pain is classically described as initial morning stiffness that improves with movement and exercise but not with rest. Involvement of thoracic spine often leads to diminished chest wall expansion, resulting in a restrictive lung disease pattern on spirometry (↑FEV1/FVC ratio). In AS, the lung parenchyma is not typically affected, so diffusion of gases across the alveolar capillaries remains intact, resulting in a normal DLCO. Diagnostic findings of AS on radiography includes sacroiliitis (joint space narrowing, sclerosis or erosions), square-shaped vertebral bodies, and fusion of the vertebral bodies (bamboo spine). If plain radiographs are inconclusive, an MRI may be obtained.  

Option Analysis

❌  Forced expiratory volume in 1 second to forced vital capacity ratio (FEV1/FVC) Diffusion lung capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) Normal  ↓ :
Incorrect: These findings are suggestive of a pulmonary embolism or pulmonary hypertension, where the diffusion capacity is diminished due to obstruction by an embolus or arterial intimal hypertrophy, respectively. In these conditions, the lung parenchyma is not affected, resulting in a normal FEV1/FVC.
✅  Forced expiratory volume in 1 second to forced vital capacity ratio (FEV1/FVC) Diffusion lung capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) ↑ Normal:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌   Forced expiratory volume in 1 second to forced vital capacity ratio (FEV1/FVC)  Diffusion lung capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO)  ↓  ↓ :
Incorrect: A decreased FEV1/FVC ratio is the hallmark finding of obstructive lung disease. This, together with a decreased DLCO (due to alveolar damage), is suggestive of emphysema. This patient’s progressive low back pain, along with signs of decreased lung expansion, points towards a mechanical cause.
❌   Forced expiratory volume in 1 second to forced vital capacity ratio (FEV1/FVC)  Diffusion lung capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) ↑ ↓ :
Incorrect: An increased FEV1/FVC ratio, in association with decreased DLCO, is characteristic of interstitial lung disease (ILD). Though ankylosing spondylitis can be associated with ILD, chest x-ray in these patients will reveal fibrosis, nodules or parenchymal bands. This patient’s chest x-ray is normal.
❌  Forced expiratory volume in 1 second to forced vital capacity ratio (FEV1/FVC) Diffusion lung capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) ↓  Normal:
Incorrect: A decreased FEV1/FVC ratio with a normal DLCO is typical of asthma, an obstructive lung disease. In these patients, dyspnea is usually accompanied by cough, wheezing, and tachypnea. Progressive low back pain, along with typical x-ray findings of ankylosing spondylitis, makes a restrictive pattern more likely to be seen on spirometry.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of left knee pain and swelling. The patient became concerned when she developed a fever and could not bear weight on her left leg due to pain. Her past medical history includes gout, and her mother has rheumatoid arthritis. The patient was treated for recurrent sexually transmitted infections in her twenties. She denies tobacco or illicit drug use. Her temperature is 38.8 °C (102°F), pulse is 101/minute, respirations are 18/minute, and blood pressure is 110/80 mmHg. Physical examination shows an erythematous, swollen, tender right knee with restricted active and passive range of motion. A small abrasion is noted at the inferior aspect of the patella. Arthrocentesis of the left knee performed, and synovial fluid analysis shows a leukocyte count of 160,000/mm3 with 92% neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation  of knee pain with swelling, erythema and tenderness following recent trauma, in combination with synovial fluid findings of elevated leukocyte count with 92% neutrophils, is highly suggestive of septic arthritis.  

Septic arthritis is an infection of a joint space caused by direct inoculation of pathogens into the joint (bite wounds, trauma or iatrogenic), by hematogenous seeding, or rarely via extension from an adjacent tissue into the joint space. These patients present with a painful, warm, tender and erythematous joint with restricted range of motion and an inability to bear weight. The knee is the most commonly affected joint space; followed by the wrist, ankles and hips. The majority of the patients are febrile. Diagnosis is based on synovial fluid analysis and culture which reveals leukocyte counts of 50,000-150,000/mm3 with >80% neutrophils. A positive gram-stain or culture confirms the diagnosis. Plain radiographs, CT, MRI or ultrasound can be obtained when the diagnosis remains unclear or a complication is suspected. Treatment includes source control via emergency joint aspiration or arthroscopy and initiation of empiric antibiotics until culture results are available.  

Option Analysis

❌ Reactive arthritis:
Incorrect: Reactive arthritis is a seronegative arthropathy that occurs days to week after a urinary tract or gastrointestinal tract infection. It is thought to be an autoimmune process triggered by molecular mimicry, rather than a pathogen directly infecting the joint. Synovial fluid is sterile, with leukocyte count <100,000/mm3.
✅ Septic arthritis:
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Crystal-induced arthritis:
Incorrect: Gout and pseudogout are common crystal-induced arthritis that usually present with acute onset joint pain and swelling. Arthrocentesis shows leukocyte count <100,000/mm3 with birefringent crystals under polarized light. High-grade fever is also atypical.
❌ Rheumatoid arthritis:
Incorrect: Rheumatoid arthritis typically affects the joints of hands and presents with subacute pain, swelling, and morning stiffness lasting for >1 hour. Although septic arthritis is a common complication in joints affected by RA, this patient’s isolated right knee pain is more likely due to septic arthritis secondary to trauma. 
❌ Osteomyelitis:
Incorrect: Osteomyelitis is an infection of bone (not joint) and involves the periosteum, medullary cavity, or the cortical bone. It presents with erythema, redness, warmth and swelling on or near the affected bone. Presence of >150,000 leukocytes/mm3 in synovial fluid is atypical.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her friend after being found unconscious on the street. According to the friend, the patient has been drinking a liter of whiskey daily for the last 16 years. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 93/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 146/85 mmHg. Physical examination reveals jaundice and palmar erythema. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is mildly distended and mildly tender to palpation; there is a change in resonance from dull to tympanitic when the patient is moved from the supine to lateral decubitus position. With the patient in a supine position, a wave is produced by tapping one side of the abdomen. The liver is not palpable. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient’s abdominal findings?

choices.text: Elevated hepatic hydrostatic pressures due to splanchnic vasodilation
Backflow of blood into the vena cava inhibiting venous outflow from the liver
Hepatic vein obstruction resulting in venous congestion
Decreased intravascular osmotic pressure due to urinary excretion of protein
Accumulation of pancreatic fluid in the peritoneal cavity

questions.solution:
Portal hypertension plays a critical role in the pathogenesis of ascites in patients with liver cirrhosis. Portal hypertension triggers the release of vasodilators (e.g. nitric oxide), which leads to splanchnic and systemic vasodilation. This in turn decreases the effective circulating blood volume and activates vasoconstriction pathways, such as the renin-angiotensin–aldosterone system, leading to subsequent sodium and fluid retention. Over time, pressure in the portal vein increases, leading to an increase in the hydrostatic pressure within the hepatic vessels, and eventually, fluid is “squeezed” into the surrounding tissue. The end result is ascites formation.  

Diagnosis of ascites can often be done with a thorough physical examination. Shifting dullness refers to a change of resonance from dull to tympanitic when the patient changes from a supine to lateral decubitus position. A positive fluid wave test is signified by production of a wave by tapping one side of the abdomen; this wave will be transmitted to the other side of the abdomen through the ascitic fluid.



Option Analysis

✅ Elevated hepatic hydrostatic pressures due to splanchnic vasodilation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Backflow of blood into the vena cava inhibiting venous outflow from the liver:
Incorrect: Right-sided heart failure is caused by impaired right ventricular function, and results in the backup of blood in the systemic circulation (e.g. vena cava, jugular veins) and portal venous system. The backup of blood would be unlikely to cause ascites alone, and her chronic alcohol use makes cirrhosis more likely to be the cause of her ascites.
❌ Hepatic vein obstruction resulting in venous congestion:
Incorrect: Budd-Chiari syndrome occurs when the major hepatic veins are obstructed, resulting in liver enlargement, pain, and ascites. The condition can occur in pregnant women, patients with polycythemia, and patients with clotting disorders. This patient’s constellation of cirrhotic signs (e.g., jaundice, palmar erythema) and history of alcohol abuse makes Budd-Chiari syndrome less likely.
❌ Decreased intravascular osmotic pressure due to urinary excretion of protein:
Incorrect: Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by renal loss of protein (>3.5 g/day), resulting in edema, hypercoagulability, and increased risk of infection. Loss of intravascular osmotic pressure can cause movement of water to the peritoneal cavity and result in ascites, such as in this patient. However, nephrotic syndrome would not account for the patient’s jaundice or palmar erythema.
❌ Accumulation of pancreatic fluid in the peritoneal cavity:
Incorrect: Acute pancreatitis results in the release of inflammatory cytokines and subsequent vascular injury by pancreatic enzymes. The injured vessels are more permeable to fluids and give rise to ascites. Pancreatitis, however, typically presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of increased urination and constant thirst despite drinking more than 7 liters of water each day. The symptoms began two weeks ago. Past medical history is notable for bipolar disorder and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient takes lithium and metformin. At the time of arrival, temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 125/78 mmHg. The remainder of the examination is noncontributory. Laboratory results are as follows:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Sodium   154 mEq/L 
 Potassium   3.9 mEq/L 
 Glucose  118 mg/dL 
 Creatinine  0.9 mg/dL 
 HbA1c  6.7% 
 Serum Osmolarity   287 mOsm/kg 
 Urine Osmolality  115 mOsm/kg 

A trial of vasopressin is administered. However, there is no significant increase in urine osmolality within 2 hours. Which of the following best describes the most likely pathophysiology of this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Resistance of kidney V2 receptors to antidiuretic hormone (ADH)
Inadequate ADH secretion from the pituitary gland
Increased presence of osmotically-active substances in the urine
Reduced antidiuretic hormone production in response to excessive fluid intake

questions.solution:
The clinical findings of polydipsia and polyuria in a patient taking lithium should raise the suspicion of diabetes insipidus (DI). The inability to raise urine osmolality after a trial of vasopressin makes the diagnosis of nephrogenic DI most likely.  

DI is characterized by excessive urination, thirst, and an inability to concentrate the urine due to a lack of, or poor response to, antidiuretic hormone (ADH). It is categorized into nephrogenic DI and central DI. Nephrogenic DI occurs when V2 receptors develop resistance to ADH. It is often caused by medications (e.g. lithium, demeclocycline) and electrolyte anomalies (e.g. hypokalemia, hypercalcemia). In contrast, central DI is caused by a lack of ADH secretion from the posterior pituitary. It can be idiopathic or secondary to brain malignancies, pituitary ischemia or CNS infections.  

Individuals with DI present with mild hypernatremia, high-normal serum osmolality, and low urine osmolality. A trial of desmopressin (an ADH analog) administration helps in differentiating central from nephrogenic DI. In the former, the urine osmolality tends to rise after administering desmopressin, while there is no change in the latter. This patient’s persistently low urine osmolality and high serum osmolality after administration of desmopressin is consistent with nephrogenic DI.  

Option Analysis

✅ Resistance of kidney V2 receptors to antidiuretic hormone (ADH):
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Inadequate ADH secretion from the pituitary gland:
Incorrect: This answer describes central diabetes insipidus (DI). Individuals with central DI often exhibit a greater than 50% increase in urine osmolality after administration of vasopressin (since their kidneys are capable of responding to the hormone by increasing water reuptake). In contrast, the patient in this vignette had no significant increase in urine osmolality, making nephrogenic DI more likely.
❌  Increased presence of osmotically-active substances in the urine:
Incorrect: Osmotic diuresis can sometimes be seen in patients with uncontrolled diabetes. While this patient has diabetes, his blood sugar level is not significantly elevated. Moreover, even in patients with poorly-controlled diabetes, an increase in urine osmolality would be expected after vasopressin administration, since the kidneys should be capable of responding to the hormone.  
❌  Reduced antidiuretic hormone production in response to excessive fluid intake:
Incorrect: This answer describes primary polydipsia. Patients with this condition consume excessive fluids even in the absence of physiologic stimuli to drink. Primary polydipsia is often associated with psychiatric conditions, such as schizophrenia or anxiety disorder. Patients with psychogenic polydipsia have both reduced serum osmolality (due to increased water content) and urine osmolality (since the body is trying to eliminate surplus water via urine).
❌ Glomerular hyperfiltration:
Incorrect: Glomerular hyperfiltration is the hallmark of early diabetic nephropathy. It arises secondary to non-enzymatic glycation of tissue proteins in patients with chronic hyperglycemia. It is generally asymptomatic and is diagnosed based on laboratory abnormalities (e.g. elevated GFR).

questions.text:
A 30 year-old woman comes to her primary care physician because of muscle cramps, nausea, and fatigue. The patient endorses a history of depression and seizure disorder, both of which are currently managed with medications. Family history is notable for Addison disease in her maternal uncle. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 14/min and blood pressure is 115/80 mmHg. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal examinations are noncontributory. Additional laboratory results are as follows:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
Sodium   122 mEq/L 
 Potassium   3.7 mEq/L 
 Creatinine  0.9 mg/dL 
 Glucose  102 mg/dL 
 Serum osmolality   240 mOsm/kg 
 Urine osmolality  445 mOsm/kg 

Which of the following is the most likely explanation of the patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation (i.e. symptomatic hyponatremia, low serum osmolality and high urine osmolality) is consistent with the diagnosis of syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) secondary to medication(s). Antidepressants, such as selective-serotonin reuptake inhibitors, and antiepileptics, such as carbamazepine, can cause SIADH as a side-effect.

SIADH is a diagnosis of exclusion. In patients who are suspected of having this condition, the diagnostic workup involves obtaining a history, performing a physical examination, and obtaining laboratory testing. Symptoms can range from fatigue and nausea/vomiting in milder cases to coma and seizures in severe cases.  

Laboratory testing involves obtaining a serum sodium, serum osmolality, and urine osmolality. Results in patients with SIADH will show hyponatremia (secondary to dilution caused by fluid retention and reduced aldosterone secretion), reduced serum osmolality, and elevated urine osmolality. The workup also entails ruling out other conditions (e.g., hypothyroidism, adrenal insufficiency) by ordering TSH, T3 and T4 levels, and testing for serum cortisol concentration (e.g. morning serum cortisol).  

Option Analysis

❌ Diabetes insipidus:
Incorrect: Diabetes insipidus (DI) results from either decreased production of ADH from the posterior pituitary or resistance of the kidneys to ADH. The end result is significant water loss via urine that can cause dehydration. Individuals with DI present with elevated serum osmolality, which is inconsistent with this patient’s presentation.
❌ Adrenal insufficiency:
Incorrect: Adrenal insufficiency may cause hyponatremia. The patient’s family history of Addison disease (autoimmune destruction of the adrenal glands) increases her risk of developing the condition. Patients with adrenal insufficiency often become hypovolemic, resulting in an elevated serum osmolality and creatinine. While the patient has hyponatremia, her normal creatinine and reduced serum osmolality are suggestive of euvolemic hyponatremia.
❌ Primary polydipsia:
Incorrect: Primary polydipsia is a condition caused by abnormally increased thirst that leads to excessive intake of fluids. It is often associated with psychiatric conditions. Primary polydipsia presents with low serum and urine osmolality. In contrast, this patient’s urine osmolality is high, which is inconsistent with this diagnosis.
❌ Surreptitious diuretic use:
Incorrect: Inappropriate diuretic use can contribute to excess renal loss of water and salt, resulting in hyponatremia. However, given that diuretics cause volume depletion, evidence of hypovolemia (e.g., dry mucous membranes, elevated creatinine) would also be expected.     
✅ Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH):
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text:
A three-year-old boy presents to his pediatrician with fatigue and concern for seizures. His parents describe that he has not been acting like himself lately and has had intermittent sustained jerking movements of his arms and legs. In addition, the patient has had intermittent vomiting and diarrhea but no fevers. He has met most developmental milestones but has difficulty copying a circle with a pencil and does not understand what “two” means. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is unremarkable. His workup is notable for a mutation in the ABCD1 gene, and a chemistry panel yields the following results:



Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Accumulation of very long chain fatty acids in adrenal tissue
Accumulation of phytanic acid in plasma and peripheral tissue
De novo mutation of MECP2 on X chromosome
Inability to convert hypoxanthine to IMP and guanine to GMP

questions.solution:
This patient presents with features consistent with adrenal insufficiency (e.g., nausea, vomiting), as well as seizures and cognitive delay. Laboratory testing demonstrates a mutation in the ABCD1 gene, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia, which are consistent with a diagnosis of adrenoleukodystrophy.  

Adrenoleukodystrophy is a rare inborn error of metabolism that is inherited in an X-linked recessive fashion. The disease is due to accumulation of very long chain fatty acids in adrenal, central nervous, and gonadal tissues as a consequence of impaired beta oxidation in peroxisomes. Accumulation of very long chain fatty acids in these tissues manifests with primary adrenal insufficiency, seizures, and hypogonadism.  

The disease is variable and manifests in childhood or adulthood, but overwhelmingly the first clinical sign of the disease is adrenal insufficiency. If untreated, the disease can lead to worsening cognitive decline, dementia, cortical blindness, quadriparesis, coma, and death.  

Diagnosis of the disease involves performing genetic analysis for mutations in the ABCD1 gene. Treatment is multifactorial and depends on the clinical stage of diagnosis. If diagnosed in childhood, allogeneic stem cell transplant is often recommended in addition to life-long hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency. If diagnosed as an adult, treatment is primarily supportive in addition to life-long hydrocortisone.



Option Analysis

✅ Accumulation of very long chain fatty acids in adrenal tissue:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Accumulation of phytanic acid in plasma and peripheral tissue:
Incorrect: Refsum disease is a rare autosomal recessive disorder affecting alpha-oxidation of fatty acids. The condition manifests with scaly skin, ataxia, and cataracts/night blindness. Treatment involves plasmapheresis. However, this patient has no cutaneous findings, and Refsum disease is not associated with a mutation in the ABCD1 gene.
❌ Deficiency of arylsulfatase A enzyme:
Incorrect: Metachromatic leukodystrophy manifests with central and peripheral demyelination, ataxia, and dementia. The condition arises due to deficient arylsulfatase A enzyme and accumulation of cerebroside sulfate. However, the disorder is not associated with a mutation in the ABCD1 gene.
❌ De novo mutation of MECP2 on X chromosome:
Incorrect: Rett syndrome manifests with regressive motor, verbal, and cognitive features as well as ataxia, seizures, growth failure, and stereotyped hand movements. It is due to a mutation of the MECP2 gene. Rett syndrome would not account for the hyponatremia and hyperkalemia seen on this patient’s laboratory testing.
❌ Inability to convert hypoxanthine to IMP and guanine to GMP:
Incorrect: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is characterized by a defective purine salvage pathway due to absence of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT), which converts hypoxanthine to IMP and guanine to GMP. Clinically, this disease manifests with intellectual disability, self-mutilation, aggression, and gout.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman comes to the outpatient provider for evaluation of fatigue and muscular pain for the past 4 months. The patient also reports muscle stiffness that is worse when waking up in the morning and improves after several hours. Family history is notable for rheumatoid arthritis in the patient’s mother. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg, pulse is 68/min, and respiratory rate is 12/min. There is tenderness to palpation in the muscles of the bilateral shoulders and hips. No muscle weakness is noted. Laboratory testing reveals the following results:  
 
Laboratory value  Result
 Hemoglobin  14.7 g/dL 
 Leukocyte  7,900/mm3 
 Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR)   105 mm/h 
 Serum creatinine kinase  76 U/L 

Which of the following symptoms is the patient at the greatest risk of developing?

choices.text: Ulnar deviation of the bilateral wrists
Purplish discoloration and swelling of the bilateral eyelids
Localized jaw pain that is exacerbated by chewing
Knee pain that is exacerbated by physical activity

questions.solution:
This patient has polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR). It is an inflammatory disease that often affects patients (women>men) over 50 years of age. The condition causes symptoms like pain and stiffness of the shoulder and hip, which often starts on one side, but typically progresses to both sides within weeks. The symptoms are usually more severe in the morning and at night, often lasting for more than an hour, and they typically improve after activity. Morning stiffness in PMR is always present, and its absence excludes the diagnosis of PMR. The pain can make it hard to get out of bed or up from a chair, and lifting the arms above shoulder height can be difficult. It can also cause a low-grade fever, fatigue, and loss of appetite which can lead to weight loss.  

Many patients with PMR can develop temporal arteritis. Temporal arteritis causes inflammation of the body’s large- and medium-sized arteries, including the carotid arteries, its major branches, and the aorta. The condition can present with symptoms including headaches, jaw claudication and visual disturbances. Jaw claudication is a very common symptom and can be seen in over 50% of patients with temporal arteritis. Since temporal arteritis affects the internal carotid artery, it can affect the branches, including the ophthalmic artery; therefore, the most feared complication of GCA is permanent loss of vision, which commonly is painless and sudden, can be partial or complete, and can be unilateral or bilateral. In contrast to other symptoms, vision loss only occurs in 10% of patients.    

Option Analysis

❌ Ulnar deviation of the bilateral wrists:
Incorrect: Ulnar deviation would be observed in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), an autoimmune condition characterized by joint pain, swelling, and synovial destruction. The patient’s family history puts her at increased risk of developing RA. Patients with RA can present with morning stiffness. The condition most often affects distal joints (e.g., metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, wrist, knee). In contrast, it would be atypical for RA to present with muscle tenderness at the shoulders and hips.
❌ Purplish discoloration and swelling of the bilateral eyelids:
Incorrect: This answer describes a heliotrope rash. The condition is observed in patients with dermatomyositis, which can also present with proximal muscle tenderness. Patients with dermatomyositis also have muscle weakness and an elevated serum creatinine kinase. In contrast, this patient has no muscle weakness and a serum creatinine kinase within normal range.
❌ Permanent monocular vision loss:
Incorrect: The patient has proximal muscle tenderness but no weakness and a normal creatinine kinase. This presentation is consistent with polymyalgia rheumatica. Patients with this condition are at increased risk of developing temporal arteritis, which can cause headaches, jaw pain, and permanent vision loss. However, the incidence of irreversible vision damage is low (12%) when compared with other symptoms. For instance, over 80% of patients complain of headaches and over 40% complain of jaw pain/difficulty chewing. 
✅ Localized jaw pain that is exacerbated by chewing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Knee pain that is exacerbated by physical activity:
Incorrect: Osteoarthritis presents with pain in weight-bearing joints. The pain worsens with activity and improves with rest. In contrast, this patient’s pain is worse in the morning and subsequently improves throughout the day. Moreover, osteoarthritis would not explain the patient’s fever and elevated ESR.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for dyspnea and wheezing. The patient is diagnosed with a COPD exacerbation. Despite appropriate medical management, endotracheal intubation is required for 2 days. On the 6th day of hospitalization, as he is recovering, he develops a fever with increasing productive cough. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 104/min, and blood pressure is 121/75 mmHg. A chest radiograph reveals new, dense infiltrates in the left lower lobe with no blunting of the costophrenic angle. Sputum microscopy shows Gram-negative bacilli. Which of the following physical findings are likely to be present on physical examination of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, purulent respiratory secretions, and new pulmonary infiltrates in the left lower lobe. He likely has related to his recent mechanical ventilation or hospitalization. In patients with lobar consolidation, the following physical exam findings may be present over the affected area:  

  •  Dullness to percussion occurs because air in the alveoli is replaced by exudate and fluid. Therefore, sound will lose its normal tympanic quality. 
  •  Tactile fremitus is when there are increased vibrations felt on the patient's chest during low frequency vocalization, such as when the patient says “99.” This phenomenon occurs because sound waves travel better through the fluid-filled consolidated tissue than air-filled healthy tissue.
