  •  Similarly, bronchophony and bronchial breath sounds are characterized by increased transmission of voice and sounds produced by air movement within the affected area.  
  •  Egophony is caused by conversion of high-frequency sounds to lower-frequency sounds during auscultation due to transmission through consolidated areas. As a result, when patients say the letter “E,” it will sound like the letter “A.”  
  • Crackles are popping sounds made when air passes through fluid in collapsed alveoli. 


Option Analysis

❌   Percussion  Fremitus  Normal  Normal  :
Incorrect: These physical examination findings are likely to be present in a healthy lung. This patient has a history and radiographic findings consistent with pneumonia, which makes another set of physical exam findings more likely. 
✅  Percussion  Fremitus  Dull Increased:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Percussion  Fremitus  Hyperresonant Decreased:
Incorrect: These findings are likely to be present in patients with pneumothorax. Although mechanical ventilation increases the risk of barotrauma and can lead to pneumothorax, this patient is no longer ventilated and has clinical findings more suggestive of pneumonia.
❌  Percussion  Fremitus  Hyperresonant Increased:
Incorrect: This patient has fever, purulent secretions, and chest radiograph demonstrating a new infiltration. These findings are concerning for pneumonia, which would not present with the physical exam findings described in this answer choice.
❌   Percussion  Fremitus  Dull Decreased  :
Incorrect: These physical exam findings are likely to be present in patients with pleural effusion, which is characterized by the accumulation of fluid between the pleural layers. The pleural fluid separates the lung tissue from the body wall, leading to diminished sound transmission.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of darkening of the skin on her face and neck. The patient spends most of her day working indoors as a lawyer. She is currently pregnant and at 31-weeks gestational age. Medical history is notable for type I diabetes mellitus, for which she is currently taking insulin injections. Family history is notable for Addison disease in her maternal grandmother. Temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), blood pressure is 122/78 mmHg, and pulse is 77/min. Physical examination reveals the presence of brown hyperpigmented macules on the forehead, cheeks, upper lips, and neck. The macules are neither pruritic nor painful. No similar lesions are found on the remainder of the patient’s body. The rest of the patient’s examination is noncontributory. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for developing the patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has melasma, also known as chloasma. It typically manifests as hyperpigmented macules on the face (cheeks, chin, nose bridge, upper lip, forehead) and neck (Figure 1). Melasma is usually seen in individuals with darker skin and is associated with pregnancy and the use of oral contraceptive pills (OCPs).    

The pathogenesis of melasma is not fully understood. However, it is believed that increased estrogen levels and impaired skin barrier function secondary to chronic UV exposure, which reduces skin lipid synthesis, contribute to the condition.  

Diagnosis is clinical, and treatment options include sunscreen and skin depigmentation therapy (e.g., skin lightening agents, chemical peels, and laser/light based therapy).


Figure 1: Individual with melasma on the cheeks

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Reduced UV-light exposure :
Incorrect: This patient has patches of hyperpigmentation in the setting of pregnancy, which is most consistent with the presentation of melasma. Sun exposure/damage is one of the most important avoidable risk factors. Hence, reduced UV-light exposure would actually be protective against melasma. 
❌ Family history of adrenal insufficiency :
Incorrect: Addison disease (adrenal insufficiency) can result in skin hyperpigmentation. In response to reduced serum cortisol levels, the body will increase ACTH production. Melanocyte stimulating hormone (MSH) is cleaved from the same precursor as ACTH, and therefore, increased ACTH production would also lead to increased MSH production. However, hyperpigmentation in Addison disease tends to be generalized, whereas this patient’s lesions are localized to the face. 
❌ History of diabetes mellitus :
Incorrect: Patients with diabetes mellitus are at risk of developing acanthosis nigricans. The condition manifests with hyperpigmentation of flexural skin, such as the axillary and neck fold regions. In contrast, it would be atypical for acanthosis nigricans to manifest with hyperpigmentation of the face. 
✅  Current pregnancy :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ History of fungal skin infection :
Incorrect: Infection by fungal species, such as Malassezia, can result in changes to skin pigmentation in a condition termed tinea versicolor. This symptom occurs since the fungus degrades lipids in the skin, which produces acids that damage melanocytes and cause inflammation. Patients can develop either hypo- or hyperpigmentation. However, lesions secondary to Malassezia infection tend to be pruritic and are most commonly found on the chest and trunk.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider because of facial muscle weakness that began about four months ago. She reports having intermittent episodes of drooping of eyelids and difficulty chewing food, which usually happen in the evenings and resolve the subsequent morning. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. She takes amlodipine. Social history is notable for a 20-pack-year smoking history. Family history is notable for systemic lupus erythematosus in her older sister. In the office, her temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 146/80 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is observed to have drooping of the left eyelid and impaired adduction of the right eye. The findings appear to be exacerbated by repeated muscle use. Antibodies against which of the following components will most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with ptosis, extraocular muscle weakness and fatigable chewing most likely has myasthenia gravis (MG). The hallmark symptom is muscle weakness that worsens after repeated activity and improves after rest (as in this patient).

The first step in work-up for this autoimmune condition is to test for the presence of anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies. However, it is worthy to note that around a quarter of patients may test negative. As a result, these individuals should also be tested for the presence of muscle-specific receptor tyrosine kinase antibodies.

In patients with high clinical suspicion but negative antibody test results, single-fiber electromyography should be performed. The test involves repeatedly stimulating a muscle via electrical stimuli. In patients with MG, there will be a progressive decline in the muscle action potential with repeated stimulation.  Once MG is diagnosed, further workup should be tailored towards ruling out the disorders that are frequently associated with MG. For instance, thyroid function tests should be performed to rule out associated Graves disease. Similarly, chest CT/MRI should be performed to check for thymic hyperplasia or thymoma.

Option Analysis

❌ Double-stranded DNA:
Incorrect: Patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can be positive for anti-dsDNA antibodies. SLE often manifests with a malar rash, photosensitivity, and arthritis. In contrast, it would be atypical for SLE to cause isolated extraocular and bulbar muscle weakness. 
❌ Histidyl tRNA synthetase:
Incorrect: Anti-histidyl tRNA synthetase antibodies may be seen in patients with polymyositis. It is an inflammatory myopathy that frequently affects proximal muscles, such as those in the hip and shoulder. It would be atypical for polymyositis to predominantly affect the extraocular and bulbar muscles.
❌ Voltage-gated calcium channel:
Incorrect: Patients with Lambert-Eaton syndrome develop antibodies against presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels. The condition can cause weakness in the proximal extremities and oculobulbar muscles that temporarily improves with repeated use. In contrast, this patient has muscle weakness that worsens with use, which is more consistent with the presentation of MG.  
❌ Ganglioside proteins:
Incorrect: Antibodies against ganglioside proteins (anti-GQ1b) are found in patients with Miller-Fisher syndrome, a variant of Guillain-Barre syndrome that can manifest with acute ophthalmoplegia, areflexia, and ataxia in the setting of a preceding bacterial or viral infection. In contrast, this patient has no recent history of infection. Moreover, it would be unusual for it to present with intermittent episodes of muscle weakness that are exacerbated by activity and improve with rest.
✅ Postsynaptic acetylcholine receptor:
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents because they are concerned he is not growing as fast as other children of his age. The patient was adopted, and his family history is unknown. Past medical history is unremarkable, and the patient does not have any history of infections. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 27/min, and blood pressure is 115/74 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient’s height is below the 5th percentile and weight exceeds the 75th percentile. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Examination of the bilateral hands reveals hypoplastic 4th and 5th digits. The patient’s intelligence quotient (IQ) is well below other children of his age. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:
 
Laboratory value  Result 
Serum sodium  140 mmol/L 
 Serum potassium  4.5 mmol/L 
 Serum chloride  97 mmol/L 
 Serum bicarbonate  25 mmol/L 
 Serum calcium  9.3 mmol/L 
 Serum phosphorus  4.1 mmol/L 
   Which of the following conditions has the same inheritance pattern as this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
In the vignette is presented a 5-year-old boy with intellectual disability, developmental delay, obesity, short stature, short 4th/5th metacarpal bones. This constellation of findings is termed Albright hereditary osteodystrophy (AHO). His laboratory findings are suggestive of pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism, an autosomal dominant condition caused by paternal inheritance of a mutated GNAS gene. The maternal GNAS gene is imprinted, meaning that it is silenced and not expressed.  

Patients with pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism have organs that respond to parathyroid hormone (PTH). They have normal serum calcium and phosphate levels. In contrast, patients with pseudohypoparathyroidism present with low serum calcium and elevated serum phosphate. It is important to note, however, that patients with pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism present with AHO as do patients with pseudohypoparathyroidism.  

A diagnosis of pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism can be made in patients with features of Albright hereditary osteodystrophy but no PTH-resistance. Blood tests will reveal normal serum calcium, normal serum phosphate, and normal PTH levels. Genetic testing can be used to identify the GNAS mutation and confirm the diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cystic fibrosis:
Incorrect: Cystic fibrosis is typically inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. The condition is due to a defect in chloride-channels encoded by the CFTR gene. In contrast, this patient has pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism, an autosomal dominant condition caused by paternal inheritance of a mutated GNAS gene. 
❌  Angelman syndrome :
Incorrect: Angelman syndrome occurs when the maternal allele is deleted or mutated, and the paternal allele is imprinted (silenced). The condition is characterized by inappropriate laughter, seizures, and intellectual disability. However, the patient in this vignette has pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism, which occurs when the paternal allele is mutated, and maternal allele is imprinted. 
❌ Hemophilia A:
Incorrect: Hemophilia A is typically inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern. The condition causes increased bleeding due to a defect in factor VIII. In contrast, the patient in this vignette has an autosomal dominant condition that is caused by maternal imprinting (silencing) and paternal inheritance of the mutated gene. 
✅ Prader-Willi syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌  Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency :
Incorrect:  Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency usually presents in an autosomal codominant pattern, which means that the phenotype of both the maternal and paternal allele are exhibited. In contrast, this patient has an autosomal dominant condition.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to her primary care physician with worsening motor coordination. She has been frequently stumbling while playing basketball. Past medical history is otherwise unremarkable aside from scoliosis. The patient does not consume illicit substances, alcohol, or tobacco. She does not take any medications. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 12/min, blood pressure is 124/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 96% on room air. Physical exam is notable for scoliosis, gait ataxia, and decreased vibratory sensation in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. Her screening blood glucose level is 210 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism causing this patient’s clinical features?

choices.text: Neuronal cell loss and atrophy of the caudate and putamen
Abnormal expression of myotonin protein kinase
Disruption of the dystrophin-associated protein complex

questions.solution:
This patient presents with multiple features consistent with Friedreich ataxia, including gait ataxia, diminished vibratory sensation, scoliosis, and evidence of diabetes mellitus. The disease is caused by impaired iron metabolism secondary to abnormal expression of the frataxin gene.    

Friedreich ataxia is an autosomal recessive trinucleotide repeat disorder due to GAA repeats on chromosome nine. These repeats result in limited expression of the frataxin gene, which encodes an iron binding protein that regulates iron chaperoning, detoxification, antioxidation, and mitochondrial iron storage in neurologic tissue, cardiac myocytes, and pancreatic tissue. Current theories postulate that limited frataxin causes mishandling of iron and subsequent impairment of mitochondrial functioning, causing cellular injury and oxidative stress in the affected tissue.  

Damage to neural tissue results in the clinical features of Freidrich ataxia, including limb ataxia due to spinocerebellar tract degeneration, spastic paralysis due to lateral cortiospinal tract degeneration, and decreased vibratory and proprioceptive sensation due to dorsal column degeneration. Diabetes mellitus results from damage of pancreatic beta cells, which leads to diminished insulin secretion. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy ensues due to myocyte disruption. Additional features include a high heel arch (pes cavus), hammer toes, scoliosis, nystagmus, and dysarthria.

   

Option Analysis

✅  Impaired iron regulation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Neuronal cell loss and atrophy of the caudate and putamen :
Incorrect: Huntington disease results in atrophy of the caudate and putamen as well as ex vacuo ventriculomegaly. The condition is associated with increased aggression, choreiform movements, and depression. In contrast, this patient has ataxia, scoliosis, and reduced vibratory sensation, which is more concerning for Friedreich ataxia. 
❌ Abnormal expression of myotonin protein kinase  :
Incorrect: Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant trinucleotide repeat expansion disorder in the DMPK gene. This disease results in abnormal myotonin protein kinase and muscle wasting. Important associated clinical features include muscle stiffness, balding, cataracts, and gonadal atrophy.  
❌ Impaired neuroplasticity:
Incorrect: Fragile X syndrome is the most common cause of intellectual disability and is due to a CGG repeat expansion. This results in hypermethylation of the FMR1 gene, which is an important regulator of synapse formation. Clinical features associated with this disease include macroorchidism, long face with a large jaw, large everted ears, and mitral valve prolapse. 
❌ Disruption of the dystrophin-associated protein complex:
Incorrect: Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophies are associated with mutations in the dystrophin gene, which anchors myofilaments to the extracellular matrix. These disorders tend to present with only motor deficits but no sensory deficits (e.g. loss of vibratory sensation).

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider for a routine visit. The patient has no acute complaints. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, for which she is currently taking propranolol. She consumes 3-4 glasses of wine per week and smokes half-a-pack of cigarettes per day. The patient’s brother passed away from multiple myeloma 4 years ago. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 138/75 mmHg, and BMI is 19 kg/m2. The physician is concerned that the patient may have osteoporosis. Which of the following findings will most likely confirm this diagnosis?

choices.text: T-score one standard deviation below the population average
Bone mineral density that is three standard deviations below the mean

questions.solution:
Osteoporosis is usually diagnosed with a dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan, which tests for bone density. The test compares the individual's total lumbar spine, hip, and femoral neck bone density to that of the average bone density found in a healthy young individual. This comparison yields a T-score. A T-score of ≤ -2.5 standard deviations is diagnostic of osteoporosis. A T-score between -1.0 and -2.5 means the individual has osteopenia, a condition also characterized by decreased bone strength but less severe than osteoporosis.  

In addition, a diagnosis of osteoporosis can also be established with a fragility fracture at the hip or vertebra in the absence of other metabolic bone disorders. According to the United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF), one time screening by DEXA scan is recommended in all females 65-years-old and above. In addition, younger females with risk factors (e.g., smoking, excessive alcohol consumption, low body weight) may also require a DEXA scan.  

Option Analysis

❌ T-score one standard deviation below the population average:
Incorrect: The T-score compares the patient’s bone mineral density with that of the average bone density found in a healthy young individual. T-scores between -1 and -2.5 indicate low bone density, also called osteopenia. T-score ≤ -2.5 SD, however, is necessary to diagnose a patient with osteoporosis. 
❌ Reduced blood estrogen levels:
Incorrect: Reduced estrogen production after menopause can cause increased osteoclast activity, which in turn leads to osteoporosis. However, a low blood estrogen level itself is not a diagnostic criteria for osteoporosis.
❌  Elevated IgG levels on serum electrophoresis:
Incorrect: Elevated levels of IgG are one of the diagnostic criteria for multiple myeloma. Although the patient has a family history of the condition, she herself has none of the symptoms (e.g., hypercalcemia, renal insufficiency, anemia, bone pain) typically associated with multiple myeloma. 
❌ Reduced serum calcium levels:
Incorrect: Low serum calcium levels can impair bone mineralization and result in osteomalacia. This condition can present with bone pain and muscle weakness. In contrast, patients with osteoporosis typically have normal calcium levels.
✅ Bone mineral density that is three standard deviations below the mean:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes to the office because of deep and aching hip pain. The pain is constant throughout the day and worsens with weight-bearing activity. The patient also reports that his shoe size has increased over the past year, and he has progressively lost hearing from both ears. Medical history includes admission for a renal calculus one-month ago. Laboratory investigations demonstrate an isolated increase in serum alkaline phosphatase. A pelvic x-ray is obtained, and the results are as follows:

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

The patient’s current condition places him at risk of developing which of the following pathologies?
questions.solution:
This patient has Paget disease of the bone (also termed osteitis deformans), which places him at increased risk of developing osteosarcoma.

Paget disease of the bone is a condition characterized by abnormal bone remodelling. There is an initial lytic phase, followed by a mixed lytic/blastic phase and sclerotic phase, and finally a quiescent phase. This sclerotic phase, which is when new bone formation exceeds bone resorption, is likely the period during which osteosarcoma arises due to rapid, disorganized bone growth. The net result of these various phases is disorganized bone that is weaker than normal bone. In addition, the bone in patients with Paget disease is more vascular than normal bone.

Patients present with bone pain due to microfractures, erythema/warmth over affected areas (due to increased vascularity), and increased shoe size after puberty. In addition, changes in the shape of the skull can cause facial changes and cranial nerve impingement, which can present with sensorineural hearing loss. Radiographic studies will reveal sclerotic and lytic lesions, since both osteoblast and osteoclast activity are increased.

Paget disease of the bone predisposes patients to high-output heart failure, due to the hypervascularity of the new bone, and osteosarcoma, since accelerated bony growth can lead to genetic mutations.  

Option Analysis

❌ Osteochondroma:
Incorrect: Osteochondroma generally manifests in young adults at the metaphysis of long bones. It presents as a pedunculated mass on x-ray. The patient’s current condition of Paget disease of the bone, which presents with bone pain and hearing loss, does not predispose him to developing an osteochondroma.
❌ Metastatic bone tumors:
Incorrect: Metastatic bone tumors can present with lytic ‘punched out’ lesions. However, this patient’s symptoms of increased shoe size and progressive hearing loss, in combination with the presence of both sclerotic and lytic lesions on x-ray, make Paget disease of the bone a more likely diagnosis. Paget disease of the bone is non-neoplastic and will not metastasize.
❌ Osteoporosis:
Incorrect: Osteoporosis is characterized by decreased bone density. Many conditions may predispose patients to developing osteoporosis, including menopause, anorexia, chronic kidney disease, and hyperthyroidism. However, patients with Paget disease of the bone are not at increased risk of developing osteoporosis.  
✅ Osteosarcoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Osteomalacia:
Incorrect: Osteomalacia (also termed rickets) is secondary to defective mineralization of osteoid. Patients with deficiencies in calcium, phosphate, or vitamin D are at risk of developing osteomalacia. However, Paget disease of the bone is not a risk factor for developing osteomalacia.

questions.text: A 3-hour-old male neonate is observed to have profuse drooling and coughing in the nursery after the first attempt at feeding. The patient was born at 39-weeks gestational age to a 27-year-old, gravida 2 para 2, mother via vaginal delivery. The pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios. Cardiac exam reveals a harsh holosystolic murmur most prominent at the left lower sternal border. The nurse attempts to pass a nasogastric tube into the patient’s stomach but encounters resistance after advancing 12 cm. Which of the following physical exam findings will most likely also be present in this patient?

choices.text: Protrusion of intestines through a paraumbilical defect
Presence of blood in the feces
Reduced breath sounds in the left chest

questions.solution:
This patient likely has esophageal atresia, which is when the esophagus does not develop properly and ends in a blind pouch. Since these babies have difficulty swallowing, they can present with excess drooling and vomiting after eating. In addition, this patient has coughing, which raises concerns for a fistula between the esophagus and trachea. The presence of a tracheoesophageal fistula allows food to enter the respiratory tract, causing choking, cyanosis, and aspiration pneumonia. Lastly, the patient’s heart murmur is concerning for a ventral septal defect (VSD).    

Taking into account the aforementioned symptoms, the patient likely has the VACTERL association. This acronym stands for: Vertebral abnormalities, Anal atresia, Cardiac defects, Tracheoesophageal fistula, Esophageal atresia, Renal abnormalities, and Limb defects. Among the answer choices, only hypoplasia of the upper extremities (Option D) is part of the VACTERL association.  

A diagnosis of esophageal atresia can be made by attempting to pass a catheter (e.g. nasogastric tube) into the stomach. The tube often cannot be passed farther than 10-15 cm. The diagnosis can then be confirmed by a chest x-ray, which will show the catheter coiled in the esophageal pouch.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Protrusion of intestines through a paraumbilical defect :
Incorrect: This answer describes gastroschisis, which is when a child’s intestines extend outside of the abdomen through a hole next to the umbilicus. However, gastroschisis is usually an isolated pathology, and it is not associated with esophageal atresia.  
❌ Presence of blood in the feces :
Incorrect: A Meckel diverticulum can cause abdominal pain and bloody stools. However, this patient most likely has esophageal atresia. Studies have not demonstrated an association between esophageal atresia and Meckel diverticulum. 
❌ Frequent sweating and sneezing :
Incorrect: Patients with neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome can have increased drooling, sweating, and sneezing. However, this patient’s increased drooling is more likely due to esophageal atresia. This diagnosis is supported by the history of polyhydramnios (due to impaired swallowing of amniotic fluid) and resistance encountered while inserting a nasogastric tube.  
✅ Hypoplasia of the upper extremities :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Reduced breath sounds in the left chest :
Incorrect: Pulmonary hypoplasia or a diaphragmatic hernia can cause this finding. However, this patient’s history of polyhydramnios, increased drooling, and difficulty passing a nasogastric tube is most consistent with the presentation of esophageal atresia. Studies have not demonstrated an association between esophageal atresia and the aforementioned conditions.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician because of shortness of breath. Her symptoms started about a year ago and have progressively worsened. She complains of reduced exercise tolerance and now quickly becomes out of breath while jogging or climbing stairs. She has no chronic cough or excessive mucus production. Past medical history is notable for rheumatoid arthritis. She has been inconsistent with follow-up due to a lack of insurance. She has a 35-pack-year smoking history. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals swelling and deformation of the bilateral proximal interphalangeal and wrist joints. Ulnar deviation is noted at the metacarpophalangeal joints. Lung auscultation reveals bibasilar inspiratory crackles. Pulmonary function testing yields the following results:

 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 FEV1  91% of predicted 
 FVC  93% of predicted 
 FEV1/FVC Ratio  85% 

Which of the following best describe the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Accumulation of fluid in the pleural cavities
Pulmonary collagen deposition secondary to chronic inflammation

questions.solution:
This patient has pulmonary fibrosis secondary to rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune condition that triggers cytokine release by the immune system. These cytokines can travel throughout the body and manifest with extra-articular symptoms.

In the lungs, cytokines can activate fibroblasts, causing scar tissue deposition, resulting in pulmonary fibrosis. This scar tissue ultimately impairs alveolar gas exchange. As a result, patients can exhibit shortness of breath and reduced exercise tolerance. Physical examination typically reveals crackles, which are thought to be produced by the sudden opening of abnormally closed small airways. Pulmonary function testing will reveal a restrictive pattern wherein the FEV1/FVC ratio exceeds 80%.

The pleural cavities surrounding the lungs can become inflamed as well, causing them to fill up with fluid; this pathology is known as a pleural effusion. It can also impair lung expansion and interfere with gas exchange. Physical examination will reveal reduced breath sounds over the affected area on auscultation, dullness to percussion, and decreased tactile fremitus.

 Lastly, there is Caplan syndrome, in which the patient has both pneumoconiosis and rheumatoid arthritis. This condition tends to manifest as intrapulmonary nodules.




Option Analysis

❌ Accumulation of fluid in the pleural cavities:
Incorrect: This answer describes a pleural effusion. Rheumatoid arthritis can cause inflammation of the pleura and subsequent fluid accumulation. A large pleural effusion can impair normal lung expansion and result in a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function testing. However, a pleural effusion would not account for the inspiratory crackles.
✅ Pulmonary collagen deposition secondary to chronic inflammation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Proliferation of neoplastic lung cells:
Incorrect: This answer describes lung cancer, which can cause unintentional weight loss, coughing, and hemoptysis. Although this patient has a smoking history, she lacks the other symptoms typically associated with lung cancer. 
❌ Hyperplasia of bronchial mucus cells:
Incorrect: This answer describes chronic bronchitis, a condition that can develop in patients with a long smoking history. The condition causes coughing that produces large quantities of sputum. In contrast, this patient has no history of coughing or mucus production.
❌ Eosinophil-mediated lung damage:
Incorrect: Patients with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA) can have eosinophil-mediated lung damage. This damage occurs because the eosinophils release granule proteins that cause tissue destruction, which eventually leads to fibrosis and restrictive lung disease. However, this patient lacks the other symptoms found in EGPA (e.g., allergies, sinusitis).

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes to his primary care provider for evaluation of pain in both knees. His symptoms worsen with activity and improve with rest and ibuprofen. The patient had previously been an avid runner but had to stop due to the joint pain. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and a right fibular fracture, which occurred after a biking accident. Vitals are within normal limits. Examination of the affected joints reveals crepitus and mildly reduced range of motion. The remainder of the patient’s physical examination is noncontributory. Knee imaging is ordered, and the results are as follows:




Reproduced from: Radiopedia

Which of the following additional findings, if present, would best support the patient’s diagnosis?

choices.text: Ulnar deviation of the metacarpophalangeal joints
Paravertebral ossification of the lumbosacral spine
Subchondral sclerosis at the hip joints
Pencil-in-cup deformity of the distal interphalangeal joints
Juxta-articular osteoporosis in the proximal interphalangeal joints

questions.solution:
This patient has osteoarthritis, which occurs secondary to mechanical wear and tear that destroys the joint cartilage and underlying bone. X-rays are used in the diagnosis of the condition. Imaging can reveal the following findings:

 1) Joint space narrowing   

2) Subchondral sclerosis, which manifests as poorly defined areas within the bone that are more radiodense (whiter) than the surrounding bone.  

3) Osteophytes, which often present as an uneven bony protrusion into the joint space.

4) Subchondral cysts, which manifests as a radiolucent (darker) area within the bone.

Figure 1: Radiographic findings in osteoarthritis  


Caption: A) Normal radiograph, B) joint space narrowing in the medial tibiofemoral compartment, C) osteophyte in the joint space, D) subchondral sclerosis, E) subchondral cyst.

Option Analysis

❌ Ulnar deviation of the metacarpophalangeal joints:
Incorrect: This finding is seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis, which typically affects joints in the hands and causes stiffness/pain that improves with activity. In contrast, this patient has pain in weight-bearing joints that worsens with activity, which is more consistent with osteoarthritis.
❌ Paravertebral ossification of the lumbosacral spine:
Incorrect: This answer describes ankylosing spondylitis, a condition that typically manifests in young males. Patients often report reduced spinal mobility and morning stiffness that improves with activity. In contrast, these symptoms are absent in this patient.
✅ Subchondral sclerosis at the hip joints:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pencil-in-cup deformity of the distal interphalangeal joints:
Incorrect: The “pencil-in-cup” deformity occurs due to periarticular erosions and bone resorption. This finding is classically associated with psoriatic arthritis, but it can also be seen in systemic sclerosis and rheumatoid arthritis. However, this finding would not be seen in patients with osteoarthritis.
❌ Juxta-articular osteoporosis in the proximal interphalangeal joints:
Incorrect: Juxta-articular osteoporosis can be seen in patients with inflammatory arthritis because persistent inflammation induces osteoclast differentiation and impairs osteoblast maturation. The net result is increased bone reabsorption. However, this patient’s history of pain in weight-bearing joints that is exacerbated with activity is more consistent with osteoarthritis.

questions.text:
A 2-hour-old male infant is evaluated in the nursery for suspected hearing loss. He was born at 39-weeks gestational age via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The patient’s mother immigrated to the United States three months ago and had limited access to prenatal care in her home country. The patient is at the 15th percentile for height and weight. Vitals are within normal limits. Auditory brainstem response test shows findings consistent with hearing loss. Examination of the patient’s eyes reveals the following finding:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

 Which of the following findings will be most likely present on this patient’s cardiac examination?

choices.text: Machine-like murmur loudest at the left infraclavicular area
Fixed splitting of the S2 heart sound
Systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border with radiation to the right sternal border
Blowing diastolic murmur loudest at the right upper sternal border

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has congenital rubella syndrome, which is characterized by deafness, cataracts, blueberry muffin rash, and a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).    

PDA occurs when the ductus arteriosus fails to close after birth. This patency leads to a left-to-right shunt, wherein high-pressure blood in the aorta is able to enter the low-pressure pulmonary artery. Other risk factors for developing a PDA include preterm birth and in utero alcohol exposure.    

Clinically, it presents with a continuous machine-like murmur at the left infraclavicular area. In addition, patients can develop differential cyanosis, which is when the lower extremities are cyanotic but the upper extremities are acyanotic. This finding is because the ductus arteriosus originates in the aortic arch distal to where the subclavian arteries branch off. As a result, sufficiently oxygenated blood reaches the upper extremities, but inadequate blood reaches the lower extremities. Cardiac catheterization will reveal increased oxygen saturation in the pulmonary artery.  

Indomethacin, a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medication, blocks synthesis of prostaglandin E and is used to treat PDA. If this fails, surgical intervention is needed.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Pericardial friction rub :
Incorrect: A pericardial friction rub can be secondary to pericarditis, which is often triggered by a viral illness. However, this patient’s hearing loss and cataracts raise concerns for congenital rubella syndrome. It would be atypical for it to cause pericarditis. 
✅  Machine-like murmur loudest at the left infraclavicular area :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Fixed splitting of the S2 heart sound :
Incorrect: This finding would be heard in a patient with an atrial septal defect (ASD). Alcohol exposure in utero and trisomy 21 are associated with ASD. However, this patient’s physical examination findings of hearing loss and cataracts are more consistent with congenital rubella syndrome, which is associated with a different cardiac finding. 
❌ Systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border with radiation to the right sternal border :
Incorrect: This finding is consistent with the presentation of tricuspid regurgitation. Children exposed to lithium in utero are at risk of developing tricuspid regurgitation and atrialization of the right ventricle (Ebstein anomaly). However, it would be atypical for in utero lithium exposure to cause hearing loss or cataracts, and thus another congenital syndrome is more likely. 
❌ Blowing diastolic murmur loudest at the right upper sternal border :
Incorrect: This answer describes aortic regurgitation. The condition is seen in patients with connective tissue disorders, such as Marfan syndrome. However, this patient’s symptoms of hearing loss and infantile cataracts are more consistent with the presentation of congenital rubella infection.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman is scheduled to undergo a routine screening colonoscopy for colorectal cancer. She does not have any abdominal pain, changes in bowel habits, unintentional weight loss, or noticeable blood in the stool. Past medical history is significant for coronary artery disease. There is no family history of colorectal cancers. Colonoscopy is performed, which reveals a few polyps in the colon. The polyps are biopsied and examined for abnormal histology. Which of the following pathologic findings is at the highest risk for malignant transformation?
questions.solution:
The most common and clinically important neoplastic polyps are adenomatous polyps, as they give rise to the majority of colorectal adenocarcinomas. Adenomatous polyps are characterized by the presence of epithelial dysplasia. They are caused by a mutation in adenomatous polyposis coli (APC), a tumor suppressor gene located on chromosome 5 that is responsible for regulating cell growth and adhesion. The two predictors of a polyp’s likelihood of undergoing malignant transformation are: 1) size and 2) histological appearance.  

Increasing polyp size is the most important characteristic that correlates with malignancy risk. Adenomatous polyps less than 1-cm are less likely to acquire subsequent mutations and undergo malignant transformation. In contrast, adenomatous polyps greater than 4-cm are much more likely to progress to adenocarcinoma.    

Furthermore, based on histological appearance, there are three types of adenomatous polyps: villous, tubular, and tubulovillous. Villous polyps, which have a cauliflower-like appearance, have the highest malignant potential. Tubular polyps, which are pedunculated polyps that protrude out into the intestinal lumen, have the lowest malignant potential. Tubulovillous polyps, which have characteristics of both tubular and villous polyps, have an intermediate malignant potential.    

Clinically, adenomatous polyps are mostly asymptomatic. In some cases, they can cause bleeding, secretory diarrhea, and partial intestinal obstruction.
 

Option Analysis

✅ 4-cm villous adenomatous polyp:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ 3-cm villous adenomatous polyp:
Incorrect: Villous adenomas are more likely to undergo malignant transformation than other subtypes of adenomatous polyps. However, amongst villous polyps, those of greater size are at higher risk of malignant transformation. Therefore, another answer choice is at higher risk of malignant transformation.
❌ 2-cm tubulovillous adenomatous polyp:
Incorrect: Tubulovillous adenomatous polyps, which have characteristics of both tubular and villous polyps, have an intermediate malignant potential.
❌ 2-cm tubular adenomatous polyp:
Incorrect: Tubular adenomatous polyps are pedunculated polyps that protrude out in the lumen of the intestine. They have lower malignant potential than villous or tubulovillous polyps.
❌ 3-cm inflammatory polyp:
Incorrect: Inflammatory polyps are non-neoplastic projections of mucosa consisting of stromal and epithelial components as well as inflammatory cells. They are commonly seen in patients with underlying inflammatory bowel disease. Inflammatory polyps do not undergo neoplastic transformation.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man comes to the physician due to difficulty walking. The patient describes his gait as though his feet are “glued to the ground.” Additionally, he has been having difficulty finishing his daily crossword puzzle, which he attributes to impaired concentration. He has not experienced headaches, nausea, vomiting, or visual changes, but he has experienced episodes during which he has a sudden urge to urinate. The patient frequently has difficulty making it to the bathroom due to his gait dysfunction. Past medical history is notable for a subarachnoid hemorrhage that occurred several years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient’s Mini-Mental Status Examination score is 22/30 (normal: ≥ 24). Physical examination is notable for a broad-based and shuffling gait. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Obstruction of cerebrospinal fluid flow between ventricles
Loss of brain parenchyma with an apparent increase in cerebrospinal fluid

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a triad of urinary incontinence, gait abnormalities, and imapired cognitive function. He likely has normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH), which occurs due to impaired cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) drainage.

CSF is produced in the lateral ventricles by the choroid plexus and then flows into the third and fourth ventricles. CSF is reabsorbed into the systemic circulation primarily across the arachnoid villi of the sagittal sinus. If CSF reabsorption is interrupted, normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) can occur. Most causes are idiopathic, but potential secondary causes include previous subarachnoid hemorrhage or meningitis that resulted in fibrosis of the arachnoid granulations.

As CSF accumulates within the ventricular system, there is compression and dysfunction of motor areas in the frontal lobe and periventricular white matter tracts. This pressure can contribute to various clinical symptoms. The three characteristic symptoms of NPH can be remembered with the phrase “wet (urinary incontinence), wacky (dementia) and wobbly (impaired gait)”:

  •  Gait abnormalities are the predominant clinical sign. Patients often have a broad-based gait with short steps, which is also termed “magnetic” or “glued” gait.  
  •  Dementia often manifests with decreased concentration, apathy, and impaired executive functioning.  
  •  Urinary incontinence often presents as increased urgency and frequency. It is caused by frontal lobe compression and a subsequent inability to suppress the voiding reflex.
Diagnosis of NPH is made with head imaging showing ventriculomegaly. Confirmatory testing involves a lumbar puncture, which would demonstrate a slightly elevated opening pressure and improvement of symptoms after CSF removal. Definitive treatment involves placing a cerebral shunt to drain the excess CSF.



Option Analysis

✅ Impaired cerebrospinal fluid reabsorption:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased cerebrospinal fluid production:
Incorrect: Increased cerebrospinal fluid production is rare but can be seen in choroid plexus papilloma. This benign tumor of the choroid plexus results in increased CSF production, causing symptoms of intracranial hypertension (e.g., headache, nausea). However, this patient’s symptoms are better explained by another condition.
❌ Obstruction of cerebrospinal fluid flow between ventricles:
Incorrect: Non-communicating hydrocephalus is characterized by impaired flow of CSF between ventricles. The condition can be caused by brain tumors, current subarachnoid or intraventricular hemorrhage, and inflammation following recovery from meningitis. Symptoms are secondary to elevated intracranial pressure and include headaches, nausea, and vomiting.
❌ Loss of brain parenchyma with an apparent increase in cerebrospinal fluid:
Incorrect: Hydrocephalus ex vacuo describes a condition wherein loss of brain tissue makes the ventricles larger and appear as if there is increased cerebrospinal fluid volume. The condition is a misnomer, as it is not true hydrocephalus. Hydrocephalus ex vacuo is associated with Alzheimer dementia, which causes profound cortical atrophy.
❌ Normal aging:
Incorrect: Normal aging can cause degenerative joint disease and manifest with gait impairment. However, this patient’s constellation of urinary incontinence, gait abnormalities, and imapired cognitive function is more indicative of a different underlying pathology.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her partner due to recent behavioral changes. The symptoms began four months ago. According to the partner, the patient would be doing daily activities, such as chopping vegetables, and she would abruptly stop and appear to "blank out,” followed by resumption of the activity. Additionally, the patient recently got lost in the parking lot of a nearby grocery store that she has been visiting for many years. Past medical history is noncontributory. She does not smoke cigarettes or consume alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals rigidity in the bilateral upper and lower extremities. Tremors, which began two months ago, are present in both hands at rest. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Two very similar causes of irreversible dementia are dementia with Lewy bodies (DBL) and Parkinson disease. Both are alphas-synucleinopathies and can cause dementia and Parkinsonism (e.g., tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia). However, differentiation can be made based on whether dementia occurs prior to or at the same time as Parkinsonism. For instance, this patient who is presenting with dementia, fluctuating cognition, and Parkinsonism at roughly the same time likely has DBL. In contrast, Parkinson disease typically has Parkinsonism that predates cognitive impairment by >1 year.

Clinical features of DBL vary, but all patients present with signs of dementia. There are early impairments in attention as well as executive and visuospatial function, and memory is affected later in the disease course. Moreover, a likely diagnosis of DLB requires ≥2 of the following core clinical features:  

  1.  Cognitive fluctuations: Fluctuations in cognition can present as a brief decline in ability to perform an activity of daily living or can be dramatic enough to mimic a stroke or seizure 
  2.  Visual hallucinations: Seeing animals or people (e.g. deceased loved ones) 
  3.  REM sleep behavior disorder: Dream enactment behavior occurs after loss of REM sleep atonia. It is a common prodromal sign and can predate symptoms of dementia by many years. 
  4.  Parkinsonism: Tremors, rigidity, bradykinesia, and postural instability must occur at the same time or after dementia begins.  



Option Analysis

✅ Dementia with Lewy bodies :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Parkinson disease dementia:
Incorrect: Parkinson disease and dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) are similar conditions, with the exception being that Parkinson disease has Parkinsonism (e.g., tremors, rigidity, bradykinesia) that predates cognitive impairment by >1 year. In contrast, patients with DLB have symptoms of cognitive impairment and Parkinsonism that emerge at roughly the same time.
❌ Alzheimer disease:
Incorrect: Alzheimer disease presents with prominent memory impairment early in the disease course. Fluctuating cognition and motor signs would be abnormal, especially considering this patient’s symptoms began just several months ago. 
❌ Vascular dementia:
Incorrect: Vascular dementia classically presents with a stepwise and gradual decline in neurocognitive cognition. The condition occurs due to recurrent small and large cerebral vessel disease. Patients typically have risk factors for cardiovascular disease, such as hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia, which are absent in this patient. 
❌ Frontotemporal dementia:
Incorrect: Frontotemporal dementia presents with early changes in personality and behavior that manifest as apathy and/or disinhibition. Motor deficits are seen much later in the disease course, and they would not manifest within several months of onset of dementia signs, such as in this patient.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to his physician by his mother due to headaches and difficulty walking for the past several weeks. The patient has had worsening nausea, vomiting, and irritability over this same time period. He has also been experiencing recurrent constipation and has occasionally noticed blood in his stool. The patient’s father and paternal grandmother died before the age of 50 from colon cancer. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a broad-based gait and head bobbing. Nystagmus is present. Rectal examination reveals guaiac-positive brown stool. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This young patient is presenting with signs concerning for an intracranial mass (e.g., headaches, nausea, ataxia). In addition, he has signs of gastrointestinal obstruction and a family history of colorectal cancer. In combination, these findings are concerning for Turcot syndrome.    

Turcot syndrome can be associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and Lynch syndrome; the differences can be seen in the number of polyps present on colonoscopy, as well as the type of intracranial mass that forms.    

Turcot syndrome as a variant of FAP is seen in two-thirds of Turcot cases. It is characterized by hundreds of intestinal adenomas and tumors of the central nervous system. The condition is caused by APC gene mutations, and patients are likely to develop medulloblastomas. Medulloblastomas are highly malignant tumors derived from primitive neuroectodermal tissue and most commonly arise in the cerebellum. Therefore, patients typically present with signs of cerebellar dysfunction (e.g., broad-based gait, nystagmus). Additionally, patients may have features of raised intracranial pressure (e.g., papilledema, headache, vomiting).    

Turcot syndrome as a variant of Lynch syndrome is seen in the remaining one-third of Turcot cases and is characterized by few intestinal adenomas as well as tumors of the central nervous system. The condition is caused by mutations in one of several genes involved in DNA mismatch repair (e.g., MSH2, MLH1). Lynch syndrome-associated Turcot syndrome typically gives rise to glioblastomas. These patients may also present with signs of elevated intracranial pressure, but they typically lack signs of cerebellar dysfunction.  

Option Analysis

✅ Turcot syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Gardner syndrome:
Incorrect: Gardner syndrome is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). Patients with Gardner syndrome typically present with multiple bone and soft tissue tumor growths, congenital hypertrophy of the retinal epithelium, and supernumerary impacted teeth. However, none of these symptoms are seen in this patient.
❌ Peutz-Jeghers syndrome:
Incorrect: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is a genetic condition that causes the growth of multiple hamartomatous polyps throughout the gastrointestinal tract, which can similarly cause features of obstruction and hematochezia. However, patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome also present with mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation, which is not seen in this patient.
❌ Cronkhite-Canada syndrome:
Incorrect: Cronkhite-Canada syndrome is a nonfamilial condition that also results in polyposis in the gastrointestinal tract. Patients typically present with alopecia and cutaneous hyperpigmentation. This patient’s symptoms and family history make another diagnosis more likely. 
❌ Cowden syndrome:
Incorrect: Cowden syndrome is a condition that results in multiple gastrointestinal polyps, as well as prominent skin manifestations (e.g., papules, hyperkeratosis). These patients are at increased risk of developing thyroid disorders and benign breast conditions (e.g., fibroadenomas). This patient’s symptoms suggest a different underlying condition.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man goes to his primary care physician for evaluation of hearing loss. The patient has had worsening hearing loss out of the right ear for the past six to nine months. He has also been experiencing intermittent ringing in the affected ear. Family history is notable for similar symptoms in his father, who developed progressive hearing loss starting at the age of 35. On physical exam, temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 147/88 mmHg, and pulse is 73/min. Otoscopy of the patient's right tympanic membrane demonstrates the finding below. Audiometric testing demonstrates low-frequency hearing loss in the right ear.



  Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons 

Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Bony overgrowth involving the footplate of the stapes
Growth of benign trabecular bone and fibrofatty marrow

questions.solution:
This patient has progressive conductive, low-frequency hearing loss with a normal appearing tympanic membrane. Given these findings and his family history, he most likely has otosclerosis.

Otosclerosis is a relatively common type of hearing loss affecting the adult population. The underlying pathophysiology of the disease is thought to be due to bony remodeling of the middle ear ossicles, and in particular, the footplate of the stapes. This process leads to impaired conduction of sound; the bony overgrowth impairs movement of the stapes and reduces transmission of sound from the tympanic membrane to the cochlea.

The condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern and has incomplete penetrance. Approximately 60% of adults with otosclerosis report having a family history of the condition.

Diagnosis is primarily clinical, with the majority of patients presenting with progressive conductive, low-frequency hearing loss, tinnitus, or dizziness. Otoscopic evaluations are normal in the majority of affected individuals. The Rinne test will demonstrate bone conduction greater than air condition. The Weber test will localize to the affected ear. CT imaging will often demonstrate thickening of the stapes, which confirms the diagnosis.    

Option Analysis

✅ Bony overgrowth involving the footplate of the stapes:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Accumulation of keratinized squamous epithelium:
Incorrect: Cholesteatomas are caused by the accumulation of keratinized squamous epithelium, most commonly in the middle ear. In contrast, this patient’s physical examination reveals a normal right ear tympanic membrane.
❌ Fracture of middle ear ossicles:
Incorrect: Osteogenesis imperfecta is a hereditary condition characterized by decreased synthesis of type I collagen. The condition results in ossicles that are prone to malformation, dislocation, and fracture. However, patients with osteogenesis imperfecta typically would not have primarily a low frequency hearing loss and would often have other findings, such as blue sclera and a history of multiple bone fractures.
❌ Growth of benign trabecular bone and fibrofatty marrow:
Incorrect: External auditory osteomas are a rare type of tumor composed of benign bone and marrow tissue. Osteomas typically present as a smooth mass growing from the walls of the ear canal. No such findings were observed on this patient’s physical exam.  
❌ Growth of a hypervascular neoplasm:
Incorrect: Jugulotympanic paragangliomas are highly vascular, typically benign neuroendocrine tumors that arise either from the promontory of the middle ear or the adventitia of the dome of the jugular bulb. This condition can cause progressive conductive hearing loss. However, these tumors are extremely rare. Furthermore, this patient has a family history of progressive hearing loss, which raises concerns for a hereditary condition.

questions.text: A researcher is investigating the function of a gene in a patient population that is predisposed to developing malignant tumors. Study of one particular female patient revealed the development of breast cancer and adrenocortical carcinoma before the age of 45. Her father passed away from a bone sarcoma at the age of 43, and her brother died at an early age after developing leukemia. Molecular analysis of the protein product of the wild-type gene reveals that it activates phosphoprotein 21, which subsequently inhibits progression of the cell cycle. Which of the following genes is most likely implicated in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient and her family likely have a mutation in the tumor suppressor gene TP53, which encodes the p53 protein. When DNA damage is detected, normal-functioning p53 activates phosphoprotein 21 (p21), which inhibits the function of cyclins. Since cyclins act to progress the cell cycle, p53 therefore is involved in blocking the G1 to S phase transition when DNA damage is detected. However, when p53 is mutated, the checkpoint between the G1 and S phase is lost, and uncontrolled cell proliferation occurs.

Li-Fraumeni syndrome is an inherited autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations of the TP53 gene. The condition leads to a wide range of malignancies that appear at an unusually early age. Li-Fraumeni syndrome is also known as the Sarcoma, Breast, Leukemia, and Adrenal Gland (SBLA) cancer syndrome, due to the cancers it can cause.



Option Analysis

✅ TP53:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ RB1:
Incorrect: Retinoblastoma protein, encoded by the RB1 gene, is a tumor suppressor protein that also inhibits progression of the cell cycle from G1 to S phase. This protein, however, binds instead to E2F transcription factors. Furthermore, a mutation in the RB1 gene is more strongly associated with malignancies such as retinoblastoma.
❌ BRCA1:
Incorrect: The BRCA1 gene encodes a protein that is heavily involved in DNA repair. Mutations in this gene are associated with an increased risk of breast cancer, as well as ovarian and colon cancers. This patient’s family history of adrenocortical tumors, leukemia, and sarcoma are suggestive of another gene mutation.
❌ VHL:
Incorrect: The VHL gene encodes a tumor suppressor protein that normally inhibits hypoxia-inducible factor 1a. A mutation in this gene can result in von Hippel-Lindau disease, which would present with hemangioblastoma in the retina and cerebellum, bilateral renal cell carcinoma, and pheochromocytomas.
❌ KRAS:
Incorrect: The KRAS gene, when mutated, produces an oncogenic protein that results in overproliferation of cells. It can be the cause of colorectal, lung, or pancreatic cancers. KRAS is not involved in activating phosphoprotein 21 or inhibition of the cell cycle.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden onset left-sided weakness and lethargy. The patient lives at home with her son, who found the patient lethargic and unable to move the left side of her body. The son states over the past year, the patient has been forgetting names of common people as well as losing her abilities to perform activities of daily living.  She recently became lost in the parking lot of a grocery store she has been shopping at for decades. She has no past medical history. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min and regular, and blood pressure is 171/94 mmHg. The patient appears somnolent but is arousable to voice and pain. Physical examination reveals marked weakness of the left upper and left lower extremity with associated decreased sensation in the left arm and leg. The patient’s eyes are currently deviated towards the right. A noncontrast CT of the head is shown below:


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  

Which of the following best describes the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Arterial occlusion via medial hypertrophy and lipid admixed with fibrinoid material
Arterial-venous connections without an intervening capillary network
Embolic occlusion of the right middle cerebral artery
Rupture of arterial outpouchings at branch points within the circle of Willis
Smooth muscle degeneration with amyloid fibril deposition

questions.solution:
Cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA) refers to a condition where amyloid peptides, similar to those found in Alzheimer disease, deposit in the walls of medium and small-sized cerebral blood vessels. Amyloid deposition weakens blood vessel walls making them more prone to rupture and bleeding. Initially, amyloid fibrils deposit within the outer basement membrane, but they later accumulate in the media, resulting in degeneration of smooth muscle cells.

CAA-associated hemorrhages occur in the lobes of the cerebral cortex (lobar hemorrhages), which helps to distinguish them from hypertensive ICH, which more commonly affects the putamen, thalamus, and pons. Large lobar hemorrhages can cause hemiplegia and depressed consciousness, whereas smaller lobar hemorrhages result in focal deficits, seizure, or headache. 

Option Analysis

❌ Arterial occlusion via medial hypertrophy and lipid admixed with fibrinoid material:
Incorrect: Hypertensive vasculopathy occurs in the setting of chronic, uncontrolled hypertension. Intracerebral hemorrhage associated with hypertension is typically located in the deep brain structures (e.g., putamen, thalamus, and pons), as opposed to this patient’s lobar hemorrhage. While this patient is hypertensive, her clinical history of dementia makes another diagnosis more likely.
❌ Arterial-venous connections without an intervening capillary network:
Incorrect: Arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) can result in intraparenchymal hemorrhage; however, they are more commonly seen in children and young adults. This older patient with a history consistent with dementia developed her intracerebral hemorrhage secondary to another pathophysiology.
❌ Embolic occlusion of the right middle cerebral artery:
Incorrect: Embolic strokes typically occur in the setting of atrial fibrillation, in which a thrombus forms, dislodges, and occludes a cerebral artery. This patient has a regular heart rate, making atrial fibrillation unlikely.
❌ Rupture of arterial outpouchings at branch points within the circle of Willis:
Incorrect: A ruptured berry aneurysm presents with severe, sudden onset headache, seizures, and meningismus. Additionally, noncontrast head CT typically shows hyperdense fluid (blood) in the subarachnoid space.
✅ Smooth muscle degeneration with amyloid fibril deposition:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman is scheduled to undergo an aortobifemoral bypass due to severe aortoiliac occlusive disease. Additional medical history includes hypertension, as well as a 45-pack-year smoking history. During the operation, the patient sustains significant blood loss and requires transfusion of 5 units of packed red blood cells. After the surgery, the surgeon and care staff note neurological deficits. Subsequent spinal MRI reveals infarction of the ventral segment of the spinal cord at the T4-5 level. Which of the following associated clinical findings is most likely to be observed in this patient?

choices.text: Hemiplegia and loss of pain/temperature sensation below the lesion
Ipsilateral hemiplegia and contralateral loss of sensation
Loss of motor function and vibratory sensation below the lesion
Quadriplegia and inability to speak with preserved consciousness

questions.solution:
At the confluence of the two vertebral arteries, two small branches arise and fuse to form a single anterior spinal artery that courses along the midline of the ventral surface of the spinal cord. This artery supplies the medial structures of the medulla in the brainstem, as well as the anterior two thirds of the spinal cord housing the corticospinal tract and spinothalamic tract. Ischemia in this territory often occurs during trauma or aortic surgery, resulting in anterior spinal cord syndrome.

In anterior spinal cord syndrome, MRI may show prominent high T2 signals with hyperintensities in the anterior aspect at affected spinal levels. Clinically, this results in contralateral paralysis below the level of the lesion, as well contralateral loss of pain and temperature due to associated damage to the corticospinal and spinothalamic tracts. Pressure, vibration, fine touch, and proprioception are spared, since these regions are supplied by the posterior spinal artery.



Option Analysis

❌ Contralateral hemiparesis and hemineglect:
Incorrect: A right middle cerebral artery stroke would cause left-sided weakness and hemineglect. This patient presents with anterior spinal cord infarction following a vascular surgery. 
✅ Hemiplegia and loss of pain/temperature sensation below the lesion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ipsilateral hemiplegia and contralateral loss of sensation:
Incorrect: Spinal cord hemisection, aka Brown-Séquard syndrome, results in weakness or paralysis (hemiparaplegia) on one side of the body, with loss of sensation (hemianesthesia) on the opposite side.
❌ Loss of motor function and vibratory sensation below the lesion:
Incorrect: Posterior cord syndrome involves posterior columns with extension into the posterior horns. This syndrome manifests with loss of vibration and position sensation below the affected level.
❌ Quadriplegia and inability to speak with preserved consciousness:
Incorrect: A stroke affecting the basilar artery, specifically the pontine arteries, results in locked-in syndrome.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation following a 30-minute episode of left hand weakness. During the episode, the patient was unable to pick anything up with his left hand. He was able to lift his arm during the incident. He denies any difficulty with ambulation or speaking during the episode. The patient has a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has a 20-pack-year history of smoking cigarettes. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min and irregularly irregular, and blood pressure is 196/98 mmHg. The patient’s pulse oximetry is 99% on room air. He is alert and oriented, with fluent, clear speech. Motor strength is normal in all extremities, and there are no focal deficits appreciated. Non-contrast CT-brain does not demonstrate an acute intracranial process. CT angiogram of the head and neck demonstrates diffuse calcific atherosclerosis. Without appropriate medical treatment, which of the following adverse events is this patient most likely to sustain?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department with resolved neurological deficits; he likely suffered a transient ischemic attack (TIA). TIAs result from a regional reduction in blood flow (i.e. ischemia) to the brain, causing transient neurologic deficits. Recognition of TIAs remains paramount, as 20% of these patients will go on to develop a full blown ischemic stroke in the hours to days following resolution of the neurologic deficits. Absence of infarcts on CT or MRI can help to confirm the diagnosis.

A TIA is managed via calculation of the risk of suffering a subsequent stroke by taking into account the patient’s age, blood pressure, clinical findings, duration of the TIA, and presence of associated risk factors. If the individual is deemed high risk, further hospitalization for advanced testing is appropriate. In addition, risk factor modification is appropriate for all patients with TIA, including blood pressure reduction, statins, antiplatelet therapy, lifestyle modification, and smoking cessation.

Option Analysis

✅ Cerebral ischemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Subdural hemorrhage:
Incorrect: This patient’s recent transient ischemic attack (TIA) puts him at an elevated risk for a stroke in the coming days and weeks without appropriate medical management. Subdural hemorrhages more commonly occur due to associated blunt head trauma.
❌ Pulmonary embolism:
Incorrect: Pulmonary emboli are more common in patients with risk factors included in the Wells score--recent surgery, history of malignancy, hypoxia, or signs of a DVT.
❌ Seizure:
Incorrect: This patient had a transient ischemic attack (TIA), which places him at risk for a future stroke without appropriate medical management.
❌ Subarachnoid hemorrhage:
Incorrect: This patient likely had a transient ischemic attack (TIA), which is defined as a brief episode of neurological dysfunction caused by loss of blood flow and ischemia in the brain, spinal cord, or retina but without cellular death or infarction. Although this patient is at risk for hemorrhagic stroke (from hypertension), his recent TIA puts him at increased risk of a future ischemic event in the brain.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to vaginal lesions, bleeding, and pruritus. Medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. The patient has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day for the past 20 years. She does not use alcohol excessively and has no history of sexually transmitted diseases. The patient has had 4-lifetime sexual partners and used condoms inconsistently. She has been in a monogamous relationship with her partner for the past 15 years. The patient has regular menstrual cycles; the last period was two weeks ago. In the office, the patient’s temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 135/84 mmHg. On physical examination, 2 foci of ulcerated, warty-like, fleshy masses that easily bleed are observed over the left labia majora. Following a biopsy, the diagnosis of vulvar carcinoma is confirmed. Further history will most likely reveal which of the following?

choices.text: Chronic irritation and leathery like lesion
Chronic inflammation and thin paper-like plaques

questions.solution:
Vulvar carcinoma accounts for about 3% of all female genital tract cancers. Approximately 90% of vulvar carcinomas are squamous cell carcinomas. Less common types include adenocarcinomas and basal cell carcinomas. There appear to be 2 independent pathways for the development of vulvar squamous cell carcinoma:  
  1.  Human papillomavirus infection (HPV) infection: the less common form, these occur in young and middle-aged women and is associated with HPV type 16,18, and 33. Risk factors include cigarette smoking, multiple sexual partners, early age at first intercourse and immunodeficiency. This form is usually preceded by precancerous changes known as vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) which may eventually progress to carcinoma in situ. The lesions are usually warty or Bowenoid type, multifocal, and tend to be poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinomas.  
  2. Chronic inflammation (vulvar dystrophy) or autoimmune processes: also known as HPV-negative tumors, these are the more common type of vulvar tumors and are typically seen in elderly women. They are associated with vulvar dystrophies such as lichen sclerosus or chronic venereal granulomatous disease. The lesions are usually unifocal and are well-differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinomas. 

Option Analysis

❌ Infection with HPV type 11:
Incorrect: Low-risk HPV subtypes 6 and 11 are associated with vulvar condylomata acuminata, also termed anogenital warts. However, low-risk HPV is not a risk factor for developing vulvar cancer. 
✅ Infection with HPV type 16:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Chronic irritation and leathery like lesion:
Incorrect: Lichen simplex chronicus refers to thickening and hyperkeratosis as a result of chronic scratching and irritation. Patients often present with pruritic, leathery, thick skin and enhanced skin markings on the vulva. It is not associated with an increased risk of cancer.  
❌ Chronic inflammation and thin paper-like plaques:
Incorrect: Lichen sclerosis is a benign skin condition seen in prepubertal girls and perimenopausal women and is associated with low estrogen state. Patients often present with vulvar pruritus, dyschezia, dyspareunia, and dysuria. The lesion manifests as porcelain-white, thin paper-like plaques. It is associated with increased risk for developing non-HPV vulvar cancer, however, it is usually seen in women > 65 years of age. This patient is not perimenopausal and is presenting with a classic, warty lesion which is associated with HPV 16, 18, and 33, and found in younger women.  
❌ Exposure to diethylstilbestrol in utero:
Incorrect: Exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES) in utero is associated with the development of clear cell vaginal adenocarcinoma, not squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva. DES is a synthetic form of estrogen that was prescribed to pregnant women between 1940-1971 to prevent miscarriage, premature labor, and other complications of pregnancy.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 36-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to headaches, lightheadedness, diffuse arthralgia, and numbness in the hands for the past week. She also reports fatigue and waking up in the middle of the night “soaked in sweat.” She does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), and blood pressure is 140/95 mmHg in the left arm and 110/65 in the right arm. Physical examination reveals a weak right radial pulse. A systolic bruit is heard over the right subclavian artery. Laboratory results are obtained and shown below:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  10.1  g/dL 
 Hematocrit  31% 
 Leukocyte count  12,100 /mm3 
 Platelet count  550,000/mm3 
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate  80 mm/h 
 Serum C-reactive protein  35 mg/dL (N=0.08–3.1) 
 
 Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Takayasu arteritis (TA) is a large-vessel vasculitis that mainly affects the aorta and its branches. It is most often seen in women at ages 10-40 years, especially of Asian descent. Patients initially present with constitutional symptoms (e.g., night sweats, fatigue), followed by symptoms associated with vascular damage.    

The pathogenesis is poorly understood but appears to occur in a similar pathogenetic mechanism to temporal arteritis. TA is characterized as an inflammatory granulomatous vasculitis of medium- and large-sized arteries, which leads to transmural fibrous thickening of the arterial walls, resulting in multiple vascular obstructions and eventual ischemic changes. Arterial wall inflammation is characterized by a predominance of CD4+ T lymphocytes and macrophages, which undergo granulomatous organization and formation of giant cells. The inflammation induces vascular remodeling that leads to intimal hyperplasia and lumen occlusion.  

The following features may be seen:  
  •  Constitutional symptoms: low-grade fever, weight loss, fatigue 
  •  Cardiovascular: Absent or weak peripheral pulses, limb claudication, blood pressure discrepancy between arms, hypertension, angina, myocardial infarction 
  •  Musculoskeletal: arthralgias, myalgias 
  •  Dermatological: skin lesions similar to erythema nodosum or pyoderma gangrenosum 
  •  Neurologic symptoms, caused by involvement of the carotid and vertebral arteries: lightheadedness, vertigo, syncope, headaches, and strokes 
  •  Laboratory findings: elevated ESR, CRP, anemia of chronic disease, thrombocytosis and leukocytosis 
Since TA is primarily an autoimmune condition, initial treatment of symptomatic TA begins with corticosteroids. In more severe conditions, surgical revascularization is a possible therapy as well.




Option Analysis

❌ Polyarteritis nodosa:
Incorrect: Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) also presents with constitutional symptoms (e.g., night sweats, fatigue) and signs of systemic inflammation (e.g. elevated ESR and CRP); however, weak pulses are not seen in PAN. Instead, patients often present with renal insufficiency/hypertension and mononeuropathy multiplex.  
❌ Temporal arteritis:
Incorrect: Temporal arteritis (giant cell arteritis) also presents with constitutional symptoms (e.g., night sweats, fatigue) and signs of systemic inflammation (e.g. elevated ESR and CRP); however, patients are usually above the age of 50. Moreover, patients often present with a history of scalp/temporal pain and jaw claudication. 
✅ Takayasu arteritis :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌  Microscopic polyangiitis :
Incorrect: Microscopic polyangiitis (MP) also presents with constitutional symptoms (e.g., night sweats, fatigue) and signs of systemic inflammation (e.g. elevated ESR and CRP); however, patients often present with skin lesions (palpable purpura), renal involvement, neurologic deficits, and ear, nose, and throat manifestations. In addition, weak pulses are not expected because MP involves small-sized arteries.     
❌ Thromboangiitis obliterans:
Incorrect: Thromboangiitis obliterans typically affects men who smoke and presents with distal signs of ischemia and ulcerations and Raynaud phenomenon. Due to segmental inflammatory disease affecting small to medium-sized arteries and veins of the extremities, decreased pulses can also be seen. However, this patient does not smoke, and her clinical presentation favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Granulomatosis with polyangiitis:
Incorrect: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), also called Wegner Granulomatosis, also presents with constitutional symptoms (e.g., night sweats, fatigue) and signs of systemic inflammation (e.g. elevated ESR and CRP); however, patients often present with skin lesions (palpable purpura), renal involvement, neurologic deficits, and ear, nose, and throat manifestations. In addition, weak pulses are not expected because GPA involves small-sized arteries. The presentation of GPA is similar to microscopic polyangiitis.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the office because of abdominal pain and intermittent diarrhea. He reports that the pain is cramping in nature and is confined to the right lower quadrant. The diarrhea is watery in consistency and is not associated with food intake. He has had these symptoms for 2 years but has not previously sought medical attention. Past medical history is significant for joint pain. Family history is significant for colorectal carcinoma in his paternal grandfather.
