Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows pale conjunctiva. Abdominal examination reveals mild right lower quadrant tenderness. Oropharyngeal examination reveals the following (shown below). Stool for occult blood is negative, and culture shows no bacterial growth. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on the colonoscopy of this patient?



Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Atrophic mucosa with loss of folds in the duodenum
Cobblestone appearance of ileal and colonic mucosa
Small, flask-like out-pouchings in the cecum
Friable exophytic endoluminal mass in the ascending colon

questions.solution:
This patient with a chronic history of intermittent watery diarrhea, in combination with crampy abdominal pain and examination findings of anemia (pallor conjunctiva) and abdominal tenderness, is most likely suffering from Crohn disease (CD), an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).  

Crohn disease is characterized by immune-mediated transmural inflammation that can occur anywhere in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract from the mouth to anus, though it usually involves the terminal ileum and colon. Clinically, it can present with chronic watery diarrhea and abdominal pain. Systemic findings of inflammation (low-grade fever, weight loss, anemia, fatigue, joint pains) can be seen. Suspected cases are evaluated by ileo-colonoscopy with biopsies. Macroscopic features typical of Crohn disease include:  

  •  Aphthous ulcers (Fig. A): small, discrete superficial ulcers, usually the earliest lesions seen in Crohn disease. This finding was apparent on this patient’s oropharyngeal exam. 
  •  Skip lesions (Fig B): Large ulcers with normal mucosa in between, typical of the segmental distribution of Crohn disease. 
  •  Cobblestone appearance (Fig C): Characterized by nodular thickening, with deep linear or serpiginous ulcers. Rectal sparing is a distinct feature. 
  •  Creeping fat (Fig D):  Characterized by fibrofatty proliferation of the mesenteric tissue adjacent to chronically inflamed bowel loops. 

   Figure A (Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons


Figure B (Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons)


Figure C (Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons)


Figure D (Retrieved from: Radiopaedia.org)

Option Analysis

❌ Atrophic mucosa with loss of folds in the duodenum:
Incorrect: Atrophic mucosa with loss of folds in the duodenum is typical of celiac disease, which usually presents with foul-smelling bulky diarrhea and flatulence that is associated with dietary intake of gluten. This patient’s long-standing watery diarrhea is not associated with food intake.  
✅ Cobblestone appearance of ileal and colonic mucosa:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Small, flask-like out-pouchings in the cecum:
Incorrect: Diverticula are small, flask-like out-pouchings containing only mucosa and submucosa without a serosal layer. They are seen in diverticulosis and are usually asymptomatic, but they may present with bleeding. The condition is common in patients with long standing constipation and does not usually cause right lower quadrant pain.
❌ Friable exophytic endoluminal mass in the ascending colon:
Incorrect: A friable exophytic endoluminal mass in the ascending colon can be seen in patients with colorectal cancer (CRC), which usually presents with hematochezia and altered bowel habits. Although a family history of CRC increases the risk, a long-term history of intermittent watery diarrhea and negative fecal occult blood makes another diagnosis more likely. 
❌ Flask-shaped ulcers in cecum:
Incorrect: Flask-shaped ulcers in cecum or colon are typically seen in intestinal Entamoeba histolytica infection. The condition is common in developing countries and usually presents with bloody diarrhea. A long-term history of watery diarrhea and negative fecal occult blood are inconsistent with this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the office with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and diarrhea for the past 3 months. He reports that he defecates a small volume of stools 3-4 times a day, even after which he gets a sense of incomplete bowel emptying. The stools are semi-solid, admixed with a small amount of blood. Review of systems is significant for fatigue and loss of appetite. Vitals are within normal limits. Abdominal examination shows mild distension and left-sided tenderness. Colonoscopy shows edematous and friable bowel wall mucosa extending from the rectum to the sigmoid colon with small shallow ulcers throughout the involved region. This patient’s condition is most commonly associated with which of the following extraintestinal manifestations?

choices.text: Fibrosis and stricturing of the ducts in the biliary tree
Reduction in the aqueous component of tears
Pruritic papules and vesicles on extensor surfaces

questions.solution:
This patient with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain, tenesmus and bloody diarrhea most likely has inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The colonoscopy findings of edematous and friable bowel wall mucosa extending from the rectum to the sigmoid colon with small shallow ulceration throughout the involved region are highly suggestive of ulcerative colitis (UC).

UC is an immune-mediated IBD that causes recurring episodes of inflammation of the rectum that may extend in a proximal and continuous fashion to involve the sigmoid colon and beyond. Apart from the intestines, the immune-mediated destruction can sometimes involve certain extraintestinal organs. Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is one such condition that is characterized by chronic, progressive fibrosis and stricturing of the ducts in the biliary tree. It can be asymptomatic or may present with jaundice, pruritus, and hepatosplenomegaly with a cholestatic pattern and increased alkaline phosphatase on liver function tests. Other extraintestinal manifestations of IBD include pyoderma gangrenosum, erythema nodosum, uveitis, and peripheral arthritis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Urinary calcium oxalate stones formation:
Incorrect: Calcium oxalate stones are a common complication of intestinal oxaluria observed in long-standing Crohn disease. It occurs when fatty-acids (which are not reabsorbed due to mucosal damage in the terminal ileum) make complexes with the Ca++ ions, leaving behind oxalate, thereby increasing oxalate reabsorption. The increased oxalate is excreted in the urine, which then combines with calcium, forming calcium oxalate stones.
✅ Fibrosis and stricturing of the ducts in the biliary tree:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Destruction of intralobular bile ducts:
Incorrect: Autoimmune destruction of intralobular bile ducts is characteristic of primary biliary cholangitis, which is caused by a complex interplay of genetic and environmental factors (e.g., certain bacteria, viruses, or drug exposures). It is not associated with UC.
❌ Reduction in the aqueous component of tears:
Incorrect: Reduction in the aqueous component of tears (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) is observed in patients with Sjogren syndrome. Other clinical findings include dry mouth, oral candidiasis and vaginal dryness. It has no association with UC.
❌ Pruritic papules and vesicles on extensor surfaces:
Incorrect: Pruritic papules and vesicles on extensor surfaces are characteristic of dermatitis herpetiformis. It is a dermal autoimmune reaction to dietary gluten that usually presents in association with celiac disease. It is not observed in patients with UC.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the clinic due to several weeks of productive cough, dysphagia, fatigue, and weight loss. He has recently had to resort to drinking smoothies and milkshakes because of the inability to swallow food. He mentions that occasionally when coughing into a napkin, he notices red streaks in the phlegm. The patient is a manager at an electronics store. Medical history is significant for hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and smoking 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Vitals are within normal limits. Chest radiograph is obtained and shows a perihilar mediastinal mass compressing the esophagus. Histopathology demonstrates dark cells that stain positive for synaptophysin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's symptoms, x-ray findings, smoking history, and histopathology results are consistent with small cell lung cancer (“oat cell”). It arises from neuroendocrine (Kulchitsky) cells, which appear as dark blue cells and stain positive for chromogranin A, neuron-specific enolase, and synaptophysin on histopathology. The tumor is centrally located and is often associated with smoking.

Lung cancers are classified as either small cell lung cancer (SCLC) or non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The primary risk factor for the development of lung cancer is cigarette smoking, which is accounts for 90% of all lung cancers. Other risk factors include previous radiation therapy, environmental toxins (e.g., radon, asbestos), genetic factors, family history and secondhand smoke. Some lung cancers have a stronger association with specific risk factors than others; further details are described in the table below.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Small cell lung cancer:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Adenocarcinoma:
Incorrect: Adenocarcinoma of the lung is the most common primary lung cancer, is more prevalent in women than men, and is more likely to arise in nonsmokers. It is typically located in the periphery of the lung. Common causes include activating mutations in KRAS, EGFR, and ALK genes. Histopathology will likely show a glandular pattern, which often stains positive for mucin.
❌ Mesothelioma:
Incorrect: Mesothelioma is a malignancy of the pleura, often associated with asbestosis exposure. It usually presents with an exudative pleural effusion. On histology, psammoma bodies are expected, and staining with calretinin is typically positive, instead of the synaptophysin seen in this patient’s biopsy.
❌ Squamous cell carcinoma:
Incorrect: Squamous cell carcinoma arises from the bronchus and presents as a central hilar masses. It is also associated with smoking; however, histopathology will likely show keratin pearls and intercellular bridges.
❌ Large cell carcinoma:
Incorrect: Large cell carcinoma is a highly anaplastic, undifferentiated tumor that carries a poor prognosis. It usually arises in the periphery of the lung. There is also a strong association with smoking. However, histopathology will likely show pleomorphic giant cells.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to his primary care physician due to cough and shortness of breath. The patient’s cough is productive of yellow, blood-tinged sputum. The patient has had recurrent pneumonia over the past ten years treated with oral antibiotics. Past medical history is significant for eczema since the newborn period, as well as recurrent pustular and eczematous rashes on the face and scalp throughout childhood. He underwent extraction of his primary teeth at the age of 14 years due to failure of eruption of secondary teeth. Family history is significant for similar symptoms in the patient’s mother. Temperature is 38.7 C (101.7 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 25/min and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates a broad nose, prominent lower lip, deep-set eyes with a prominent forehead, and a rough complexion with exaggerated pore size. Auscultation of lungs demonstrates bilateral rales in the lower lung fields and decreased breath sounds at the right lung base. Which of the following laboratory abnormalities is most likely to be observed in this patient?

choices.text: Elevated levels of serum alpha fetoprotein

questions.solution:
This patient presents with recurrent pneumonia, an eczematous rash and pustules since childhood, and a history of retained primary teeth in combination with characteristic facies (broad nose, prominent lower lip, deep-set eyes with a prominent forehead)--consistent with hyperimmunoglobulin E syndrome (HIES), also known as Job syndrome. Affected patients usually exhibit elevated serum IgE levels and peripheral eosinophilia.

HIES is a rare primary immunodeficiency disorder that results from defects in a STAT3--a cytoplasmic protein and a component of the JAK-STAT pathway of signal transduction.



Defects in STAT3 result in deficiency of TH17 cells, which normally mediate neutrophil proliferation and chemotaxis at the site of inflammation. Affected patients present in the neonatal period with rash/eczema, impetigo, boils, and recurrent staphylococcal skin abscesses without typical signs of inflammation (“cold abscesses”). In addition, patients often develop recurrent respiratory infections, formation of lung cavities and pneumatoceles. Other features include mucocutaneous candidiasis, characteristic facies (prominent forehead, lower lip, and broad nose), retained primary teeth, and increased susceptibility to malignancies (especially lymphomas) or autoimmune disease. Laboratory analysis usually reveals markedly elevated serum IgE levels and eosinophilia. Diagnosis is based on clinical and laboratory findings in association with a confirmed genetic defect (e.g. STAT3 mutation) via molecular testing.  

Option Analysis

✅ Elevated levels of serum IgE:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Neutropenia:
Incorrect: Although patients with HIES demonstrate intermittent chemotactic defects, they are usually not neutropenic.  
❌ Elevated levels of serum alpha fetoprotein:
Incorrect: Elevated levels of serum alpha fetoprotein are characteristically seen in ataxia telangiectasia, which results from defects in the ATM gene. Affected patients present with cerebellar ataxia, spider angiomas, and IgA deficiency. This patient’s presentation is instead typical of HIES.
❌ Thrombocytopenia:
Incorrect: Thrombocytopenia can be seen in association with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS). Although eczema is common in affected patients, recurrent abscesses and retained primary teeth are atypical.
❌ Abnormal dihydrorhodamine test:
Incorrect: An abnormal dihydrorhodamine test is characteristic of NADPH oxidase deficiency. Affected patients are susceptible to infections by catalase positive organisms including Staphylococcus aureus. An eczematous rash, retained primary teeth, and the characteristic facial features in this patient are atypical.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of shortness of breath and cough. Past medical history includes two episodes of pneumonia, oral thrush, chronic diarrhea and recurrent otitis media. His vaccinations are not up to date due to frequent illnesses. Family history is non-contributory. The patient is at the 2nd percentile for height and weight. Temperature is 38.7 C (101.7 F), pulse is 151/min, respirations are 36/min and blood pressure is 70/40 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates white patches in the oral cavity and diffuse rales of the lungs bilaterally. Laboratory results are demonstrated below.

 
 Complete blood count 
 Leukocyte count  8,100 /mm3 
 Platelet count  300,000/mm3 
 Lymphocytes  5% 
 CD 19+  low 
 CD 3+  absent 
 Immunoglobulins 
 IgG  220mg/dL 
 IgA  40 mg/dL 
 IgM  15 mg/dL 

Chest X-ray demonstrates bilateral diffuse interstitial infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with multiple findings of immunodeficiency, including oral thrush, recurrent pneumonia, chronic diarrhea and failure to thrive, in combination with absent CD 3+ cells and hypogammaglobulinemia. Together, these findings are indicative of severe combined immunodeficiency syndrome or (SCID). SCID is the most severe form of primary immunodeficiency and may result from an X-linked recessive defect in IL-2R gamma chain (most common) or an autosomal recessive defect resulting in adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency.

The combined absence of humoral and cellular immunity makes affected patients susceptible to any bacterial, viral,  fungal or opportunistic (e.g. Pneumocystis) infection from birth. Additional findings include failure to thrive and chronic diarrhea, as well as absent lymphoid tissue. Laboratory evaluation demonstrates lymphopenia and hypogammaglobulinemia, as well as a decreased concentration of T cell receptor excision circles (TRECs) on polymerase chain reaction. Lymph node biopsy demonstrates hypoplasia of lymphoid tissue with absence of germinal centers. Chest x-ray often shows an absent thymic shadow. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is the only curative measure.

Option Analysis

❌ Chronic granulomatous disease:
Incorrect: Chronic granulomatous disease results from a defect in NADPH oxidase and decreased production of reactive oxygen species. Affected patients are susceptible to infections with catalase positive organisms (e.g. Staphylococcus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa). Immunoglobulin levels are usually normal in these patients. Moreover, failure to thrive and chronic diarrhea are atypical.
❌ Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome:
Incorrect: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder that results from a mutation in the WAS gene responsible for cytoskeletal function in leukocytes and platelets. Affected patients present with a triad of recurrent infections, thrombocytopenia, and eczema. This patient’s platelet count is within normal limits, and the patient does not have a history of eczema.
❌ DiGeorge syndrome:
Incorrect: DiGeorge syndrome classically presents with cardiac defects, abnormal facies, and thymic hypoplasia resulting in T-cell deficiency and hypocalcemia. Immunoglobulin levels are within normal limits. Although CD3+ cells are absent in this patient, hypogammaglobulinemia and failure to thrive suggests a combined humoral and cellular immunodeficiency.
✅ Severe combined immunodeficiency syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ X-linked hyperimmunoglobulin M syndrome:
Incorrect:  X-linked hyperimmunoglobulin M syndrome is often caused by defective CD40 ligand (CD40L) CD4+ helper T-cells. This syndrome is characterized by recurrent pyogenic and opportunistic infections. Laboratory investigations demonstrate high IgM levels and low levels of other immunoglobulins. This patient’s IgM levels are low.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents for the evaluation of a rash. Two days ago, the patient developed fever, malaise and loss of appetite, which was followed by the appearance of multiple small “fluid filled bumps” on his trunk and face. Last night, the parents noticed a similar rash on his extremities. The rash is intensely pruritic, to the extent that the patient is unable to sleep at night. The patient has not received any vaccines since birth due to parental preference and does not have any medical conditions. He regularly goes to a community school. Temperature is 38.8°C (102°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 27/min and blood pressure is 90/55 mmHg. Physical examination is shown.
 

Reproduced by WIkipedia

The oropharyngeal examination is within normal limits. The patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following?

choices.text: Painful tender joints and subcutaneous nodules
Eye redness, pain and blurred vision

questions.solution:
This child’s presentation is consistent varicella (chickenpox) which is caused by varicella zoster virus (VZV), a double-stranded DNA virus in the family Herpesviridae. Acute cerebellar ataxia is a known complication of VZV infection that can present with sudden, uncoordinated muscle movements.  

Chickenpox is highly contagious, and transmission occurs in susceptible hosts via contact with aerosolized droplets from nasopharyngeal secretions of an infected individual or by direct cutaneous contact with vesicle fluid from skin lesions. Patients present with fever, malaise, and a rash characterized by macules, papules, vesicles, and scabs. The patient with varicella typically has lesions in different stages of development on the face, trunk and extremities.The skin lesions are small with an erythematous base of 5–10 mm and appear in successive crops over 2–4 days.  

Varicella, generally, is a self-limited infection and does not require antiviral therapy. In rare cases, patients are susceptible to a number of complications, including invasive group A streptococcal soft tissue infection, acute cerebellar ataxia, encephalitis and pneumonia. 

Option Analysis

✅ Sudden, uncoordinated muscle movements:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Pale skin, fatigue and weakness:
Incorrect: Pale skin, fatigue and weakness are suggestive of aplastic anemia, which is a potential complication of parvovirus B19 infection (erythema infectiosum).  It begins with a minor febrile prodrome followed by the typical “slapped cheek” rash several days later that may spread as a lacy reticular rash all over the body. An intensely pruritic vesiculopapular rash in different stages is typical of chicken pox.
❌ Painful tender joints and subcutaneous nodules:
Incorrect: Painful tender joints and subcutaneous nodules are suggestive of acute rheumatic fever, which is a potential complication of group A Streptococcus infection, which can cause scarlet fever and pharyngitis. Patients typically present with a sandpaper-like rash that blanches with pressure along with fever, malaise and pharyngitis. This patient’s oropharyngeal examination is unremarkable.
❌ Eye redness, pain and blurred vision:
Incorrect: Eye redness, pain and blurred vision is indicative of keratitis and can be seen in herpes simplex virus infection.  This patient’s intensely pruritic vesiculopapular rash in different stages is typical of chicken pox, which is caused by varicella zoster virus.
❌ Severe testicular pain and swelling:
Incorrect: Severe testicular pain and swelling is suggestive of orchitis, a potential complication of mumps. It is characterized by fever, malaise and myalgias followed by the development of parotitis within 48 hours. An intensely pruritic vesiculopapular rash in different stages is typical of chicken pox.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of sore throat and fever, which have been ongoing for three days. The patient states that every time she swallows, “It feels like knives are going down my throat.” However, she has not experienced any coughing. Her symptoms have not improved with over the counter acetaminophen. Past medical history is noncontributory. She does not consume alcohol, tobacco, or illicit substances. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 115/67 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for tender submandibular and anterior cervical lymphadenopathy. Examination of the oropharynx reveals the following:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons


A heterophile antibody screen is performed and returns negative. If untreated,this patient is at risk for developing which of the following clinical findings?

choices.text: Anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury

questions.solution:
This adolescent patient presents with fever, sore throat, and evidence of anterior lymphadenopathy and tonsillar exudate on examination. The patient’s heterophile antibody screen is negative, making infectious mononucleosis an unlikely diagnosis. Together these findings are consistent with Streptococcus pyogenes pharyngitis, which can cause post-infectious complications such as glomerulonephritis.

Streptococcal pharyngitis is a condition that typically affects children and young adults. It clinically manifests with fever, tonsillar swelling with exudates, and tender anterior lymphadenopathy. Additional, but less common, symptoms include non-specific abdominal pain, nausea, headache, and palatal petechiae.

If the condition is not treated with antibiotics, suppurative and nonsuppurative complications of infection may arise. Suppurative complications include peritonsillar or tonsillar abscesses, sinusitis, otitis media, and systemic bacteremia. Non-suppurative complications of include rheumatic fever, scarlet fever, streptococcal toxic shock syndrome, and poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).  

Option Analysis

✅ Brown-colored urine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury:
Incorrect: Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) can arise as a sequelae of infection by Escherichia coli O157:H7. The condition occurs when the Shiga-like toxin induces microthrombi formation on damaged blood vessels. HUS can manifest with anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury.
❌ Facial nerve palsy:
Incorrect: Infection by Borrelia burgdorferi can result in Lyme disease. If untreated, Lyme disease can cause sequelae including facial nerve palsy, arthritis, and atrioventricular heart block. However, facial nerve palsy is not a known post-infectious complication of Streptococcus pyogenes pharyngitis.
❌ Bilateral lower extremity weakness:
Incorrect: Guillain-Barre syndrome is not typically associated with Streptococcus pyogenes infection but rather with Campylobacter jejuni infection.
❌ Splenomegaly:
Incorrect: Splenomegaly is a known complication of infectious mononucleosis, which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. Streptococcal pharyngitis and mononucleosis can be difficult to distinguish clinically. However, patients with mononucleosis will often have a positive heterophile antibody screen and occipital/posterior lymphadenopathy.

questions.text:
A 21-year old woman is brought to the emergency room after intentionally ingesting 60 tablets of an unknown medication in a suicide attempt. She says that her life has become unbearable, and she is constantly depressed. She notices a ringing in her ears and feels nauseated. Her medical history is significant for two prior suicide attempts and inpatient psychiatric treatment for bipolar disorder. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 124/90 mmHg. Physical examination shows a disheveled, lethargic female; external auditory canals are normal bilaterally with pinkish-grey, translucent tympanic membranes in the neutral position. Laboratory studies show the following:

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum chemistry 
 Sodium   145 mEq/L 
 Potassium   3.4 mEq/L 
 Chloride   110 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  15 mEq/L 
 Arterial blood gas  
 pH  7.30 
 PaCO2  26 mmHg 
 PaO2  120 mmHg 

Which of the following best describes this patient’s acid-base status?

choices.text: Primary metabolic acidosis with superimposed respiratory acidosis
Primary metabolic acidosis with superimposed respiratory alkalosis
​​​​​​Primary respiratory acidosis with superimposed metabolic acidosis
Primary respiratory acidosis with superimposed metabolic alkalosis

questions.solution:
This patient’s history of an intentional ingestion along with tinnitus and gastrointestinal upset clinically suggests salicylic acid (aspirin) intoxication. In addition, assessment of this patient’s acid-base status reveals an anion gap metabolic acidosis. However, further assessment is required to determine which major disorder is present and whether the degree of compensation is appropriate. If compensation is not appropriate, a second (i.e. mixed) acid-base disorder is likely present.

For our patient, we first look at the pH, which is 7.30 (low), which tells us the patient is acidotic. The direction of the pH and HCO3 change tell us whether the primary disturbance is metabolic or respiratory. Because her pH is low and her HCO3 low, we can tell that she has a metabolic acidosis. Now that we know she has metabolic acidosis, we check her anion gap (Na - Cl + HCO3), which is 20 (high). Therefore, her primary acid-base disturbance is a high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Now that we know the primary disturbance, we check for a concurrent disturbance (i.e. a second or mixed acid-base imbalance) by assessing the degree of compensation.

We can calculate if the respiratory compensation is adequate by using Winter’s formula, in which calculated pCO2 = (1.5 x HCO3 + 8) +/- 2. Our patient’s HCO3 is 15, so her calculated pCO2 = (1.5 x 15 + 8) +/- 2 = 30.5 +/- 2. Therefore, an appropriate degree of respiratory compensation would put her pCO2 between 28.5 to 32.5 mmHg. Because her actual measured pCO2  (26 mmHg) is less than this, we can state that she has a superimposed (i.e. secondary) respiratory alkalosis.


Together, this patient’s acid-base status can be described as a primary high anion gap metabolic acidosis with a superimposed respiratory alkalosis, which can occur in the setting of salicylate overdose.

PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.

Option Analysis

❌ Pure metabolic acidosis:
Incorrect: A pure metabolic acidosis without a secondary acid-base disturbance would be demonstrated by an appropriate degree of respiratory compensation for the acidosis, as calculated by Winter’s formula.
❌ Pure respiratory acidosis:
Incorrect: A pure respiratory acidosis without a secondary acid-base disturbance would be shown by an appropriate degree of renal compensation--either acute (increase of 1 mEq/L in HCO3 for every 10 mmHg of pCO2) or chronic (increase of 4 mEq/L in HCO3 for every 10 mmHg of pCO2).  
❌ Primary metabolic acidosis with superimposed respiratory acidosis:
Incorrect: A metabolic acidosis with an inappropriate degree of respiratory compensation for the acidosis (with measured pCO2 greater than calculated pCO2 by Winter’s formula) suggests a superimposed respiratory acidosis.
✅ Primary metabolic acidosis with superimposed respiratory alkalosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ ​​​​​​Primary respiratory acidosis with superimposed metabolic acidosis:
Incorrect: A respiratory acidosis with an inappropriate degree of renal compensation (more than either an increase of 1 mEq/L in HCO3 for every 10 mmHg of pCO2 for acute or an increase of 4 mEq/L in HCO3 for every 10 mmHg of pCO2 for chronic) suggests a superimposed metabolic acidosis.
❌ Primary respiratory acidosis with superimposed metabolic alkalosis:
Incorrect: A respiratory acidosis with an inappropriate degree of renal compensation for the acidosis (less than either an increase of 1 mEq/L in HCO3 for every 10 mmHg of pCO2 for acute or an increase of 4 mEq/L in HCO3 for every 10 mmHg of pCO2 for chronic) suggests a superimposed metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to his primary care physician complaining of occasional palpitations and dizziness for three months. He discloses associated exertional dyspnea. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 125/86 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient’s height is 200 cm (6’5’’) and BMI is 17.5 kg/m2. An increased arm span to height ratio is noted. Examination of the back demonstrates scoliosis. Cardiac auscultation reveals a mid systolic murmur over the left 5th intercostal space midclavicular line. Which of the following will decrease the intensity and duration of the murmur?

choices.text: Abrupt standing from a seated position

questions.solution:
This patient with increased arm span to height ratio, scoliosis and low BMI likely has Marfan syndrome, which is associated with mitral valve prolapse (MVP). MVP may be primary (idiopathic or familial) or secondary to connective tissue disease (e.g. Marfan or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome). Patients are often asymptomatic or present with specific symptoms including dyspnea, palpitations, exercise intolerance, or dizziness.

The MVP murmur is characterized by a mid systolic click followed by a systolic murmur best heard over the cardiac apex. The click is thought to occur secondary to abrupt snapping of the chordae tendineae during systole. Maneuvers that decrease the preload (e.g., valsalva, abrupt standing) will decrease ventricular wall tension and tension of the chordae tendineae--causing the prolapse to occur sooner and with greater intensity and duration. Maneuvers that increase the preload (e.g., squatting, passive leg raise) will increase ventricular wall and chordae tendineae tension, decreasing the intensity and duration of the murmur.







Option Analysis

❌ Abrupt standing from a seated position:
Incorrect: This patient likely has Marfan syndrome, which is associated with mitral valve prolapse. Abrupt standing from a seated position will reduce preload, lead to an earlier mid systolic click and a longer murmur.
❌ Valsalva maneuver :
Incorrect: This patient likely has Marfan syndrome, which is associated with mitral valve prolapse. Valsalva maneuver compresses the inferior vena cava and reduces the preload. As a result, the chordae tendineae are not tensed, and the valve leaflets are not properly positioned, leading to an earlier mid-systolic click and a longer murmur.
✅ Passive leg raise:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Nitroglycerin administration:
Incorrect: Nitroglycerin, which is primarily a venodilator, will decrease preload, thus increasing the intensity and duration of the murmur.
❌ Placement in reverse Trendelenburg position:
Incorrect: Placement in reverse Trendelenburg position will have the same effect as abrupt standing from a seated position, as both will reduce preload and increase the intensity and duration of the murmur.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of new onset shortness of breath and fatigue. She reports shortness of breath while lying flat, and she occasionally wakes up at night gasping for air. She also endorses an occasional productive cough with a “brown” tinge. Her medical history includes a “cardiac condition” in her youth that was treated with antibiotics. She immigrated to the United States from India at age 10. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 120/85 mmHg. ECG is obtained and demonstrated below. Cardiac auscultation will most likely demonstrate which of the following findings?

choices.text: Systolic murmur over the left paravertebral interscapular area
Continuous murmur at the left infraclavicular area
Systolic ejection murmur over the 3rd right intercostal space
Diastolic murmur over the cardiac apex
Holosystolic murmur over the left sternal border

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fatigue, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea and rust colored sputum. Her previous history is suspicious for rheumatic heart disease, and the ECG reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm with absent P waves, consistent with atrial fibrillation. Together, this constellation of findings suggests underlying mitral stenosis (MS).

The murmur of mitral stenosis is characterized by an opening snap and a mid-diastolic murmur best appreciated over the cardiac apex. Accentuation of the murmur is heard with the patient in a left lateral decubitus position. Patients with MS may present with dyspnea, chest pain, rust colored sputum, atrial fibrillation, pulmonary hypertension, and hoarseness secondary to left atrial enlargement.    

Option Analysis

❌ Systolic murmur over the left paravertebral interscapular area:
Incorrect: A systolic murmur over the left paravertebral interscapular area is associated with coarctation of the aorta. Signs and symptoms include hypertension in upper extremities and weak, delayed pulses in the lower extremities.
❌ Continuous murmur at the left infraclavicular area:
Incorrect: A patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) occurs when the ductus arteriosus fails to involute after birth, resulting in a left to right shunt. Infants may present with signs of heart failure, failure to thrive, poor feeding, and respiratory distress; adults may have features of Eisenmenger syndrome, such as cyanosis and clubbing. A PDA is characterized as a “machine-like murmur” best heard over the left infraclavicular area.
❌ Systolic ejection murmur over the 3rd right intercostal space:
Incorrect: A systolic ejection murmur over the 3rd right intercostal space is associated with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM). Patients with HOCM are usually young and may present with dyspnea on exertion, fatigue, atypical or anginal chest pain, exertional syncope, palpitations, and sudden cardiac death.
✅ Diastolic murmur over the cardiac apex:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Holosystolic murmur over the left sternal border:
Incorrect: A holosystolic murmur heard over the 4th left intercostal space (tricuspid area) suggests tricuspid regurgitation or a ventricular septal defect. Tricuspid regurgitation presents with right-sided heart failure (HF), hepatic congestion, ascites, and peripheral edema.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents for worsening headaches that have interfered with his ability to concentrate at school. The patient describes the pain as dull and continuous. The rest of the history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Visual testing reveals reduced peripheral vision in both eyes. A head CT is ordered, and the results are as follows:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

The mass is surgically resected. Subsequent histology reveals calcifications as well as cysts filled with brownish, cholesterol-rich fluid. The mass is most likely a derivative of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
This patient has a craniopharyngioma. The tumor originates from the residual anterior pituitary embryonic tissue, called the Rathke pouch. Symptoms depend on the tumor’s location. If it involves the area of the pituitary gland itself, the tumor can cause partial or complete pituitary hormone deficiency, leading to hypopituitarism. If the tumor compresses the pituitary stalk, it can impair antidiuretic hormone secretion from the posterior pituitary, leading to diabetes insipidus. A large craniopharyngioma can increase prolactin levels by interfering with hypothalamic dopamine release, ultimately causing galactorrhea, and can also result in compression symptoms like headaches and bitemporal hemianopia.

Diagnosis is based on a brain imaging (e.g. MRI), which shows calcifications (hyperdense) and fluid-filled cysts (hypodense). Histology of the mass will reveal a solid component, which are the tumor cells, a cystic component filled with cholesterol-rich fluid, and a calcified component. Treatment involves surgical resection of the mass.



Option Analysis

❌ Posterior pituitary gland:
Incorrect: The patient’s imaging and histological findings are concerning for a craniopharyngioma. Craniopharyngiomas are derived from surface ectoderm. In contrast, the posterior pituitary gland is derived from neuroectoderm.
❌ Astrocytes:
Incorrect: Pilocytic astrocytomas are the most common pediatric brain tumor. The condition most often arises in the cerebellum and causes symptoms related to elevated intracranial pressure (e.g., headaches, nausea, vomiting). However, histological analysis will reveal Rosenthal fibers (eosinophilic corkscrew fibers) rather than cholesterol-rich fluids.
✅ Remnants of the Rathke pouch:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Pia mater:
Incorrect: The Pia mater is the innermost layer of the meninges. It can give rise to meningiomas. These tumors are most often found near the brain’s surface, and histology will reveal Psammoma bodies. In contrast, this patient’s mass is located at the base of the brain, with histological findings of cholesterol-rich fluid.
❌ Pineal gland:
Incorrect: A pinealoma is a pediatric brain tumor that usually presents with vertical gaze palsy and obstructive hydrocephalus. The pineal gland is located in the dorsal midbrain. In contrast, this patient’s mass is in the suprasellar region.

questions.text: A study is carried out to evaluate X-linked recessive disorders in female carriers. The clinical features of eight female gene carriers of Duchenne muscular dystrophy were noted, and a relationship was established between the genotype and phenotype. Five of the eight cases were symptomatic and showed mild muscle weakness, difficulty walking, mild to moderate elevations of the serum creatinine kinase level, or myopathic changes on an electromyogram. Upon immunofluorescence, a mosaic pattern of dystrophin deficiency was found. Only two carriers were clinically asymptomatic. Which of the following genetic terms best describes the underlying cause for the difference in these patients’ symptoms?
questions.solution:
Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is an X-linked recessive disorder that results from frameshift deletion of dystrophin gene and usually manifests clinically in males. In females, however, only one X chromosome gets expressed, and the other X chromosome forms a transcriptionally inactive Barr body. This process is called X-inactivation or lyonization. If the inactivation is random, about half of the female’s cells have a functional dystrophin gene and the other half have a defective dystrophin gene. Such females are typically asymptomatic.

 

If more cells end up with the defective dystrophin gene, and less with the functional one, then the females can end up being “manifesting carriers,” meaning that they manifest or show some symptoms. This process is called skewed inactivation of the X chromosome.



Option Analysis

❌ Anticipation:
Incorrect: Anticipation refers to an increased severity or earlier onset of disease in succeeding generations and is most commonly observed in diseases caused by trinucleotide repeat expansion (e.g., Huntington disease, fragile X syndrome).
❌ Codominance:
Incorrect: When both alleles contribute to the phenotype of the heterozygote, it is referred to as codominance. This phenomenon is not responsible for the variable presentation in females with Duchenne muscular dystrophy.
❌ Uniparental disomy:
Incorrect: When the offspring receives 2 copies of a chromosome from 1 parent and no copies from the other parent, it is called uniparental disomy. Most cases are phenotypically normal, except for the cases when the parent is the carrier of autosomal recessive disorder. Examples include Prader-Willi syndrome and Angelman syndrome.
✅ Lyonization:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Loss of heterozygosity:
Incorrect: Loss of heterozygosity refers to the phenomenon where, if a patient inherits or develops a mutation in a tumor suppressor gene, the complementary allele must be deleted or mutated before cancer develops. This phenomenon is not responsible for the difference in Duchenne muscular dystrophy manifestation in females.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of a large abscess on his right arm. He was treated with oral antibiotics for two similar abscesses over the past year. Previously, these abscesses drained purulent material, and the cultures were positive for Staphylococcus aureus. The patient was hospitalized four months ago with pneumonia and associated empyema. The patient takes no medications and immunizations are up to date.  The patient’s brother died at the age of four months due to infection with Listeria monocytogenes. Temperature is 38.9 C° (102 F°), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 19/min and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates a 4x5 cm fluctuant mass with associated induration and erythema on the right arm. A dihydrorhodamine (DHR) 123 test demonstrates absence of fluorescence on flow cytometry. Which of the following best describes the etiology of this patient’s recurrent infections?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with recurrent skin abscesses, a history of empyema and an abnormal DHR test is consistent with chronic granulomatous disease (CGD), an X-linked recessive condition caused by NADPH oxidase deficiency. NADPH is a membrane bound protein complex of the phagosome that catalyzes the reduction of O2 to O2-, resulting in oxidative burst and intracellular killing of pathogens.



In CGD, impaired NADPH renders phagocytes unable to effectively phagocytize and lyse microbes--particularly catalase positive microbes.


Affected patients present with recurrent bacterial and fungal infections (e.g., pneumonia, skin and organ abscess and osteomyelitis), as well as bacteremia or fungemia, especially with catalase-positive organisms.


Diagnosis is based on the assessment of neutrophil superoxide production via two modalities:

  •  Nitroblue tetrazolium test (NBT); If neutrophils respiratory burst is working properly, superoxide ions are produced and react with the nitroblue tetrazolium dye, changing its color to a deep blue. 
  • Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) 123 test; If levels of NADPH oxidase are normal, the enzyme will oxidize dihydrorhodamine 123, causing it to fluoresce.

Option Analysis

✅ Impaired oxidative burst:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thymic hypoplasia:
Incorrect: DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.1 deletion) presents with cardiac defects (conotruncal abnormalities [eg, tetralogy of Fallot, truncus arteriosus]), abnormal facies, T-cell deficiency (recurrent viral/ fungal infections), and hypocalcemia due to parathyroid hypoplasia. An abnormal DHR test suggests an alternative diagnosis.
❌ Defective membrane attack complex:
Incorrect: A defective membrane attack complex results in terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9). Affected patients are susceptible to infection with Neisseria sp., rather than Staphylococcus sp. or Listeria sp.
❌ Impaired neutrophil chemotaxis:
Incorrect: Impaired neutrophil chemotaxis results in leukocyte adhesion deficiency. Affected patients present with recurrent skin and mucosal infections without purulence and delayed separation of the umbilical cord.
❌ Cyclic bone marrow suppression:
Incorrect: Cyclic bone marrow suppression presents with cyclic neutropenia. Affected patients present with fever and illness every 2-5 weeks. This condition is typically associated with oral lesions.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to her opthamologist for vision changes. Over the past year, the patient has been involved in several low-speed motor vehicle accidents after failing to notice incoming traffic. She has not experienced any ocular pain or erythema. Past medical history is notable for Crohn disease, type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and atrial fibrillation. Current medications include infliximab, lisinopril, metformin, metoprolol, and warfarin. Vital signs are within normal limits, and ophthalmologic examination is notable for an intraocular pressure of 25 mmHg in the right eye and 27 mmHg in the left eye. Slit lamp examination reveals thinning of the outer rim of the bilateral optic nerve heads. The patient is also noted to have bilateral peripheral vision loss. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has increased intraocular pressure, optic nerve thinning, and peripheral vision loss. She likely has glaucoma. In the absence of other associated conditions, her presentation is most consistent with primary open-angle glaucoma, which is an idiopathic etiology.

Open-angle glaucoma refers to glaucoma wherein the angle between the cornea and lens remains open. The condition can be subdivided into primary and secondary disease. The cause of primary disease remains unclear, though research postulates it may be related to a combination of cell loss, circulatory defects, and extracellular matrix factors. Secondary disease results from reduced trabecular meshwork outflow due to deposition of leukocytes from uveitis, erythrocytes from vitreous hemorrhage, or retinal fragments from retinal detachment.

Treatment involves lowering intraocular pressure, which can be accomplished via pharmacological and surgical measures. Medications used to treat glaucoma include those that decrease aqueous humor production, such as beta blockers (e.g. timolol), carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g. acetazolamide), and alpha agonists (e.g., apraclonidine, brimonidine). Medications that increase aqueous humor outflow include cholinomimetics (e.g. pilocarpine) and prostaglandins (e.g., bimatoprost, latanoprost). If the patient’s disease is advanced or refractory to medical therapy, then laser iridotomy or trabeculoplasty can be performed.



Option Analysis

✅ Idiopathic:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Uveitis:
Incorrect: An acute flare of uveitis can result in deposition of white blood cells in the trabecular meshwork, which can lead to impaired aqueous humor drainage and development of open-angle glaucoma. Although this patient has a history of Crohn disease, there is no information regarding prior uveitis flares or physical examination findings suggestive of a current flare (e.g., red eye, hypopyon).
❌ Vitreous hemorrhage:
Incorrect: Vitreous hemorrhage can result in deposition of red blood cells in the trabecular meshwork, which can lead to impaired aqueous humor drainage and development of open-angle glaucoma. Vitreous hemorrhage can present with blurry vision, floaters, and flashes of light in the visual fields. In contrast, this patient does not have these symptoms.
❌ Diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Observational studies have demonstrated that patients with diabetes are at increased risk for developing glaucoma. However, diabetes mellitus is not directly involved in the pathogenesis of glaucoma.
❌ Hypertension:
Incorrect: Observational studies have demonstrated that patients with hypertension are at increased risk for developing glaucoma. However, hypertension is not directly involved in the pathogenesis of glaucoma.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man comes to his physician for assessment of a pruritic rash for the past two months. The patient states he has tried calamine lotion and several emollients with minimal relief. He has not used any body washes or creams. The patient has a remote history of intravenous drug use but has not used in the past year. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination reveals a scaly rash over the chest, back, and legs. A photograph of the rash is shown. A biopsy of one of these lesions exhibits clusters of abundant lymphocytic cells with cerebriform nuclei within the epidermis and dermis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Reproduce from: ">Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mycosis fungoides (MF) is an extranodal cutaneous form of non-Hodgkin T-cell lymphoma. MF usually manifests as a nonspecific erythrodermic rash that progresses to a plaque phase and then to a tumor phase.

Histologically, neoplastic T-cells, most characteristically with a cerebriform appearance produced by marked infolding of the nuclear membranes, infiltrate the epidermis. A classic sign is Pautrier microabscesses within the epidermis. These are filled with neoplastic lymphocytes instead of normal neutrophils and macrophages.

Sézary syndrome is a clinical variant of MF that is characterized by a generalized exfoliative erythroderma, as well as tumor cells found in the bloodstream.  



Reproduced from: ">Wikimedia Commons  

Option Analysis

✅ Mycosis fungoides   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Bacillary angiomatosis   :
Incorrect: Bacillary angiomatosis occurs in immunocompromised patients, especially AIDS patients, and is characterized by vascular proliferation resulting in red or flesh-colored cutaneous lesions. Biopsy reveals vascular proliferation with abundant neutrophils. This patient’s biopsy results are indicative of another condition.   
❌ Kaposi sarcoma   :
Incorrect: Kaposi sarcoma occurs in immunocompromised patients, especially patients with AIDS, and is induced by infection with HHV-8. Patients present with multiple cutaneous tumors. However, biopsy demonstrates spindle-shaped cells with leukocyte infiltration. This patient’s biopsy results are indicative of another condition.   
❌ Psoriasis:
Incorrect: Psoriasis presents with silvery-white scaling plaques, unlike this patient’s cutaneous lesions. Additionally, biopsy would show Munro microabscesses, which refers to an accumulation of neutrophils within the epidermis. This patient’s biopsy results are indicative of another condition.   
❌ Contact dermatitis   :
Incorrect: Contact dermatitis typically occurs following exposure to an irritant (e.g., poison ivy, nickel, soaps), which this patient lacks. This patient’s biopsy results are indicative of another condition.

questions.text:
76-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of increased lower extremity swelling and shortness of breath. The patient has had progressive lower extremity swelling over the past several weeks to the point where she can no longer fit into her normal shoe size. In addition, she can no longer walk half a city block before becoming short of breath. Past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, and a deep vein thrombosis after a long flight ten years ago. The patient has been smoking one pack of cigarettes per day for thirty-five years. Temperature is 36.1°C (97.0°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 156/92 mmHg, and O2 is 90% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates a loud P2, jugular venous distension, faint bilateral end-expiratory wheezing, and 2+ pitting edema in the bilateral lower extremities. A chest X-ray is obtained and shown below. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s lower extremity findings?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Increased venous hydrostatic pressure and fluid transudation
Decreased venous oncotic pressure and fluid transudation

questions.solution:
This patient with a significant smoking history presents with peripheral edema, jugular venous distension, and a loud P2 on auscultation. These findings, in the absence of features of left-sided heart failure (e.g., orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, pulmonary edema), favor the diagnosis of cor pulmonale. Cor pulmonale refers to isolated right heart failure (RHF) secondary to a pulmonary condition.  

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and other lung diseases can cause pulmonary hypertension and subsequent right ventricular hypertrophy that leads to isolated right heart failure (RHF), or cor pulmonale. In cor pulmonale, the right heart cannot overcome the pressure within the pulmonary circulation, and the backward pressure leads to jugular venous distention, increased portal blood pressure, and peripheral edema. Increased pressure in the portal system can manifest with hepatosplenomegaly, hepatic pulsation, ascites, and, in severe cases, cardiac cirrhosis (i.e., liver cirrhosis due to cardiac causes). In the lower extremities, increased venous hydrostatic pressure overcomes venous oncotic pressures. These changes result in transudation of fluid into the surrounding tissues and subsequent lower extremity edema.  



Option Analysis

✅ Increased venous hydrostatic pressure and fluid transudation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased venous oncotic pressure and fluid transudation:
Incorrect: Decreased venous oncotic pressures may also result in lower extremity edema and are characteristic of low protein states, such as cirrhosis or nephrotic syndrome. However, this patient’s history and physical examination do not suggest underlying liver or renal disease states. 
❌ Impaired lymphatic drainage:
Incorrect: Impaired lymphatic drainage, such as in the case of a pelvic or abdominal malignancy, may result in lower extremity edema. However, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with COPD and cor pulmonale. 
❌ Increased pulmonary venous pressure:
Incorrect: Increased pulmonary venous pressures are associated with left-sided heart failure and pulmonary edema. This patient has an unremarkable chest radiograph and no evidence of pulmonary edema. 
❌ Recurrent deep vein thrombosis:
Incorrect: While this patient has a remote history of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT), she has evidence of bilateral lower extremity swelling. Bilateral DVTs are incredibly rare and typically occur in the setting of critical illness. Cor pulmonale is a more realistic explanation for her lower extremity findings.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a fall from a ladder. His partner, who witnessed the incident, reports that he hit his head with subsequent loss of consciousness for several minutes. On arrival, the patient reports a severe headache, feels nauseated, and vomits twice. He does not have any visual changes. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg. On physical examination, bruising is noted over the left side of the head. The pupils are round, equal and reactive to light. Motor strength in the right lower extremity is 2/5 when compared to 5/5 of the left lower extremity. A non-contrast CT is obtained and reveals an anterior midline shift of 20 mm. Which of the following best describes the intracerebral changes responsible for this patient's clinical presentation?

choices.text: Inferior shift of the parahippocampal gyrus
Shift of the cingulate gyrus under the falx cerebri
Inferior shift of the diencephalon and temporal lobes
Shift of the cerebellar tonsils into the foramen magnum

questions.solution:
This patient presents with headaches, signs of increased intracranial pressure (ICP), and lower limb hemiparesis contralateral to the injury, raising concerns for cingulate gyrus herniation secondary to traumatic intracranial bleeding.

Cingulate (subfalcine) herniation is a type of supratentorial herniation in which there is a lateral displacement of the innermost part of the frontal lobe (the cingulate gyrus) under the falx cerebri as a result of traumatic brain injury, intracranial hemorrhage, brain tumor or abscess. This herniation can cause compression of the anterior cerebral artery and infarction of the frontal and parietal lobes, resulting in contralateral leg paralysis. Hydrocephalus may also occur due to obstruction of the foramen of Monro. Clinical features of cingulate herniation are not well defined but may include unilateral/bilateral weakness, loss of bladder control, and coma. Subfalcine herniation may also be a precursor of other types of herniation (e.g. uncal herniation).  



Option Analysis

❌ Inferior shift of the parahippocampal gyrus  :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with uncal transtentorial herniation. The uncus is the anterior terminus of the parahippocampal gyrus, located at the innermost part of the temporal lobe. In uncal herniation, the uncus becomes compressed against the tentorium. This displacement may result in compression of the 3rd cranial nerve, the cerebral peduncles, and the posterior cerebral arteries, resulting in oculomotor nerve palsy, contralateral hemiparesis, and occipital lobe infarction, respectively.  
✅ Shift of the cingulate gyrus under the falx cerebri  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inferior shift of the diencephalon and temporal lobes  :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with central transtentorial herniation, in which there is a displacement of the diencephalon and parts of the temporal lobes through a notch in the tentorium cerebelli. This type of herniation may result in small, fixed pupils with paralysis of upward eye movement ("sunset eyes") and diabetes insipidus due to compression of the pituitary stalk. Central herniation may also result in rupture of branches of the basilar artery (pontine arteries), a potentially fatal complication known as Duret hemorrhages.  
❌ Shift of the cerebellar tonsils into the foramen magnum  :
Incorrect: Tonsillar herniation, also called downward cerebellar herniation, refers to downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum. Clinical manifestations include neck stiffness, flaccid paralysis, decreased level of consciousness, and signs of brain stem dysfunction due to compression of respiratory and cardiac control centers.  
❌ Transcalvarial brain herniation  :
Incorrect: External herniation, also known as transcalvarial herniation, refers to herniation of the brain parenchyma through a fracture or a surgical site in the skull. The signs and symptoms depend upon the location and size of the herniation. This patient’s skull is intact.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a fever and a rash that she first noticed this morning. Two months ago, she was diagnosed clinically with a herpes simplex genital infection and treated with antiviral therapy. She is sexually active and began a relationship with a new partner six months ago. Menstrual periods are regular and occur every 28 days for three to five days. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for a diffuse macular rash over the patient’s palms, soles, and trunk, and enlarged axillary, inguinal, and popliteal lymph nodes are palpable. The abdomen is soft and nontender. External genital examination reveals multiple wart-like lesions on the labia majora and minora. Cervical motion tenderness is absent on bimanual examination. Which of the following best describes this patient’s vulvar lesions?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with wart-like genital lesions, diffuse lymphadenopathy, fever, and a diffuse macular rash encompassing the palms and the soles. Together, these findings suggest a diagnosis of secondary syphilis infection. The wart-like genital lesions of secondary syphilis are termed condyloma lata.

Syphilis is a common sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum; it is a progressive disease with varying features dependent on the disease stage.

The clinical manifestations of primary syphilis include a single painless ulcer with raised margins and indurated borders that manifests 1-3 weeks after initial infection.

Secondary syphilis is characterized by fever, a diffuse, symmetric macular rash on the trunk and extremities involving the palms and soles, and diffuse lymphadenopathy. Additionally, condyloma lata is a characteristic clinical manifestation of secondary syphilis which appears as multiple, flat-topped, wart-like, painless mucosal growths in the genital region. These lesions hold a high concentration of spirochetes and are considered highly infectious.

Latent syphilis refers to asymptomatic individuals infected with T. pallidum identified solely based on serologic testing. Patients with early latent syphilis (an infection that occurred within the previous 12 months) can transmit the infection to their recent sexual contacts, and they therefore require treatment with penicillin.

Option Analysis

✅ Condylomata lata:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gumma:
Incorrect: Gummatous syphilitic lesions are characteristic of tertiary syphilis infection and present as granulomatous or nodular lesions that appear on skin and bones. This patient has symptoms reflective of secondary, not tertiary, syphilis.  
❌ Primary chancre:
Incorrect: Primary syphilis manifests with a single, nontender ulcer with an indurated border–referred to as a primary chancre. This patient has symptoms reflective of secondary, not primary, syphilis.  
❌ Condylomata acuminata:
Incorrect: Human papillomavirus causes anogenital warts termed condyloma acuminata. Fever, a macular rash, and diffuse lymphadenopathy are unlikely with this condition.  
❌ Granuloma inguinale:
Incorrect: Granuloma inguinale (or Donovanosis) is characterized by painless genital ulcers without associated lymphadenopathy. A diffuse macular rash that involves the palms and soles is unlikely.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the office because of weakness and amenorrhea over the past two months. Her only medications are albuterol and an inhaled glucocorticoid for asthma. Her current BMI is 28 kg/m2 (previously 23 kg/m2). Her temperature is 37.1°C (99.2°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 152/104 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a rounded face, increased fat deposition at the back of the neck, and purple lesions across the abdomen. Her 8 AM serum cortisol level is 42 μg/dL (reference range: 0800 cortisol <5 μg/dL) and her serum adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is 65 pg/mL (reference range: 0800 ACTH = 10 - 60 pg/mL). High-dose dexamethasone suppression test shows suppression of both cortisol and ACTH levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with amenorrhea and weakness, with a physical examination showing weight gain, hypertension, rounding of her face (“moon facies”), fat deposition on the back of the neck (“buffalo hump”), and abdominal striae, which are characteristic of Cushing syndrome. Other findings include hirsutism, osteoporosis, hyperglycemia (insulin resistance), immunosuppression, and skin thinning. Cushing syndrome refers to the collection of symptoms that result from hypercortisolism. The most common cause is exogenous glucocorticoid intake, leading to iatrogenic Cushing syndrome. The most common endogenous cause of Cushing syndrome is an ACTH-secreting pituitary tumor (as in this patient), which is called Cushing disease.  

Initial screening tests for Cushing syndrome can be done by first demonstrating hypercortisolism, either from an elevated late night salivary cortisol or elevated free cortisol on 24-hour urinalysis. A confirmatory screening step is an overnight low-dose dexamethasone suppression test, which, in Cushing syndrome, would demonstrate a cortisol level that is not suppressed. After high levels of cortisol has been confirmed, the next best step is to measure the ACTH levels, which determines whether the elevated cortisol is ACTH dependent or ACTH independent. If the ACTH levels are low, this is ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome, which could be either iatrogenic or caused by an adrenal mass.  

If the ACTH is high, this is ACTH-dependant Cushing syndrome. In this case, a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test can determine whether the ACTH is coming from the pituitary gland or from an ectopic source (e.g. small cell lung cancer). The high-dose dexamethasone suppression test will suppress ACTH and cortisol in the case of a pituitary adenoma (Cushing disease), but not in the case of ectopic ACTH secretion.    



Option Analysis

❌ Iatrogenic Cushing syndrome:
Incorrect: Exogenous corticosteroid intake (e.g. for autoimmune diseases) is the most common cause of Cushing syndrome. This patient is using inhaled, not systemic, corticosteroids, making this an unlikely cause. In addition, her ACTH levels were high at baseline, which excludes exogenous causes.   
✅ Cushing disease  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Adrenal adenoma:
Incorrect: An adrenal adenoma can cause Cushing syndrome by increasing endogenous glucocorticoid production. However, this would present with high levels of cortisol and low levels of ACTH at baseline. This patient’s laboratory findings, namely the high ACTH and high cortisol levels that were suppressed following a high-dose suppression test, favor the diagnosis of Cushing disease.   
❌ Small-cell lung carcinoma  :
Incorrect:  Small-cell lung cancer is a neuroendocrine tumor that can secrete ectopic ACTH and cause Cushing syndrome. The ectopic ACTH secretion from the tumor presents with high ACTH and high cortisol levels at baseline. However, no changes are expected even after a high-dose suppression test, as the tumor does not react to the negative feedback.   
❌ Adrenal carcinoma:
Incorrect: An adrenal carcinoma, similar to an adrenal adenoma, can cause Cushing syndrome by increasing glucocorticoid production. However, this would present with high levels of cortisol and low levels of ACTH at baseline, because the elevated cortisol levels lead to negative feedback on the pituitary gland. This patient has high ACTH and high cortisol levels that are suppressed following a high-dose suppression test, which favors the diagnosis of cushing disease.

questions.text: A 27-year-old primigravid woman at 14 weeks gestation comes to the office due to the recent appearance of a sore on her lower lip. She first noticed it 2 weeks ago, and since then it has rapidly grown in size and became ulcerated. The patient has had consistent prenatal care and her medical history is unremarkable. She denies any trauma or recent illness. She works as a secretary in a large law firm. Physical examination shows a large pedunculated lesion on the lower lip with central ulceration and bleeding. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This previously healthy pregnant woman who is presenting with a rapidly growing vascular lesion most likely has pyogenic granuloma.

Pyogenic granuloma (PG), also known as lobular capillary hemangioma, is a benign vascular tumor of the skin or mucous membranes. It is characterized by rapid growth and a friable surface that tends to ulcerate and bleed. PG can occur at any age but are most commonly seen in children and young adults. It often appears after trauma or during pregnancy (granuloma gravidarum). The lesions may regress spontaneously (especially after pregnancy) or undergo fibrosis, but they often require surgical excision. On histology, the lesions demonstrate a proliferation of immature vessels similar to granulation tissue.    

 



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
Pyogenic granuloma of the skin  

Option Analysis

❌ Basal cell carcinoma:
Incorrect: Basal cell carcinoma typically presents as a slow-growing, waxy, pink, pearly nodule, commonly with telangiectasias and rolled borders. Surface crust or ulceration may also be present. It can be found in sun-exposed areas of the body and classically appears on the upper lip. On histology, blue cells with a palisading pattern are expected. Although biopsy is needed for confirmation, this patient’s lesion characteristics favor another diagnosis.    
❌ Squamous cell carcinoma:
Incorrect: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) typically presents as a slow-growing lesion with a scaly hyperkeratotic surface. It commonly appears on the face, lower lip, ears, and hands. It is associated with excessive exposure to sunlight, immunosuppression, chronic wounds, and arsenic exposure. Although biopsy is needed for confirmation, this patient’s lesion characteristics and the absence of risk factors favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Herpes simplex virus:
Incorrect: Herpes labialis, also known as a cold sore, is an infection caused usually by HSV type 1 and less commonly type 2. Primary infection can be accompanied by fever, sore throat, enlarged lymph nodes and a painful vesicular sore on the lips. Recurrent infections are common and may be preceded by pain, burning, tingling, and pruritus prior to the appearance of the first vesicles. The rash usually heals within 10 days, but the virus remains dormant in the dorsal root of the trigeminal ganglion. This patient’s lesion characteristics favor another diagnosis.    
✅ Pyogenic granuloma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bacillary angiomatosis:
Incorrect: Bacillary angiomatosis is a condition caused by Bartonella henselae or Bartonella quintana and usually occurs in immunocompromised patients (e.g. HIV). It is characterized by multiple vascular papules and nodules similar to pyogenic granulomas. On histology, lobular, vascular proliferation of vessels lined by endothelial cells as well as clusters of neutrophils and lymphocytes are expected. This patient is immunocompetent and has a single lesion, which makes this diagnosis very unlikely.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman is evaluated for stiffness of both hands that began three months ago. The stiffness does not improve with repeated movement. For the past year, the patient has also had frequent constipation despite consuming a high-fiber diet. In addition, she previously led an active lifestyle and was an avid runner, but she had to stop due to worsening shortness of breath. In the office, her temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F) and blood pressure is 153/82 mmHg. Examination of the patient’s hands reveals the following findings:



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following additional symptoms would most likely be found on this patient’s physical examination?

choices.text: Decreased mouth opening and increased dental caries
Normal appearing skin on chest and abdomen
S3 heart sound most prominent at left lower sternal border

questions.solution:
This patient has diffuse cutaneous systemic scleroderma, which is differentiated by severe visceral organ involvement and diffuse skin involvement.  

In the gastrointestinal tract, patients can have esophageal dysmotility and acid-reflux secondary to replacement of the esophageal sphincter muscle by collagen. The intestines can also be involved, leading to malabsorption and constipation secondary to dysmotility. In the lungs, small blood vessels can be damaged. This causes pulmonary arterial hypertension and pulmonary fibrosis, which presents with dyspnea, reduced exercise tolerance, and coughing. Kidney involvement is also common. The small arteries in the kidneys undergo concentric hypertrophy and this results in ischemia. In some cases the damaged blood vessels trigger thrombosis. This causes capillary blockage and can lead to a form of acute kidney injury called scleroderma renal crisis.    

The skin in patients with scleroderma appears tight, stiff, shiny, and smooth. When it happens on the fingers it is called sclerodactyly. This can cause tapering of the fingertips and finger contractures. On the face, the mouth can become narrowed resulting in microstomia. Microstomia can impair speaking, eating, and brushing teeth. The last factor can predispose patients to dental caries.  

Option Analysis

❌ Metacarpophalangeal joint warmth and tenderness:
Incorrect: This finding would be observed in patients with rheumatoid arthritis, which presents with joint pain and stiffness that is worse in the morning and improves with movement. Additionally, it would be atypical for rheumatoid arthritis to cause the fingertip tapering or the taut and shiny skin observed in this patient's hands.  
✅ Decreased mouth opening and increased dental caries:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Normal appearing skin on chest and abdomen:
Incorrect: This would be seen in patients with limited scleroderma. In this condition, there is minimal internal organ involvement, and the skin changes are restricted to the face and distal extremities. In contrast, this patient has dyspnea and constipation, which suggest that internal organs such as the intestines, heart, and lungs may be affected. It would be atypical for this magnitude of internal organ involvement to occur in limited scleroderma.    
❌ Increased anteroposterior chest diameter:
Incorrect: Increased anteroposterior chest diameter may be observed in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), specifically emphysema. COPD can cause dyspnea and reduced exercise tolerance. Hypoxia secondary to COPD may cause finger clubbing. However, it would not cause the fingertip tapering seen in this patient.  
❌ S3 heart sound most prominent at left lower sternal border:
Incorrect: A S3 sound may be heard in patients with dilated cardiomyopathy. In contrast, this patient’s symptoms of skin stiffness, dyspnea, and constipation are concerning for diffuse scleroderma. Diffuse scleroderma can affect both the skin and visceral organs. It can lead to pulmonary arterial hypertension, heart muscle hypertrophy, and/or restrictive cardiomyopathy. However, it would be atypical for any of these conditions to cause the S3 sound associated with volume overload.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is brought by her son to the emergency room for evaluation of rapid-onset abdominal pain. The patient was watching television when her symptoms began suddenly. She describes the pain as constant and rates it as 9 out of 10 in severity. Past medical history is notable for hyperlipidemia and atrial fibrillation. She is currently taking atorvastatin and metoprolol. While in the emergency room, the patient has one episode of non-bilious, non-bloody vomiting. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 122/78 mmHg, and pulse is 86/min and irregular. Physical exam shows diffuse abdominal tenderness. No bruising or signs of trauma are observed. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Atherosclerotic narrowing of intestinal blood vessels
Embolic occlusion of intestinal blood vessels
Telescoping of proximal bowel into distal bowel

questions.solution:
This patient has diffuse abdominal pain and a history notable for hyperlipidemia and atrial fibrillation. The most likely cause of her symptoms is acute mesenteric ischemia, which occurs when the blood supply to the small intestines is suddenly reduced, most often due to embolism or thrombosis of the superior mesenteric artery. The former is more likely in this patient, given her history of atrial fibrillation and irregular pulse on physical examination.  

Decreased blood flow causes bowel necrosis and results in severe abdominal pain. Later on, patients can develop hematochezia and red “currant jelly” stools, which occur when the necrotic mucosa sloughs off and mixes with blood and mucus to take on a jelly-like consistency.  

CT angiography is the gold standard for the diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia, and it can identify the site of occlusion. Treatment options include vasodilator therapy, anticoagulant therapy, and surgical laparotomy with embolectomy.    



Option Analysis

❌ Atherosclerotic narrowing of intestinal blood vessels:
Incorrect: This describes the pathophysiology of chronic mesenteric ischemia. The condition causes abdominal pain that is worse 30-60 minutes after eating. This is because the atherosclerotic arterioles are unable to dilate in response to increased blood requirements. However, it would be atypical for chronic mesenteric ischemia to cause sudden onset abdominal pain in the absence of food consumption.  
❌ Inflammation of colonic outpouchings:
Incorrect: Diverticulitis occurs when colonic outpouchings, termed diverticula, become inflamed. Diverticulitis usually causes left lower quadrant pain. It can manifest with diffuse abdominal pain if the outpouchings rupture, leading to peritonitis. However, the patient’s history of hyperlipidemia and atrial fibrillation makes acute mesenteric ischemia a more likely explanation for the symptoms.   
✅ Embolic occlusion of intestinal blood vessels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Occlusion of the intestinal lumen:
Incorrect: This describes bowel obstruction. The small intestines are more often affected due to their narrower caliber. The condition can cause severe abdominal pain and nausea, often leading to bilious emesis. However, patients with bowel obstruction usually have a history of abdominal surgery, which can cause adhesions, or may have a mass or malignancy impairing peristalsis.  
❌ Telescoping of proximal bowel into distal bowel:
Incorrect: Intussusception describes the telescoping of one portion of the intestines into the section distal to it. The condition most often affects children. It causes cyclical abdominal pain, “currant-jelly” stools, and a palpable mass in the abdomen. In contrast, this patient age, risk factors, and the timing of her pain are more concerning for acute mesenteric ischemia.

questions.text:
