A 35-year-old woman comes to the office because of back pain. For the past four months, she has felt progressive colicky pain in the left lumbar region, which does not alleviate with medication. She endorses pain during sexual intercourse with her husband. She has no urinary symptoms. Her last menstrual period was three weeks ago. She has a history of essential hypertension and migraines. She currently takes propranolol for both conditions. Her mother died of breast cancer at 60-years-old. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a soft abdomen that is tender to deep palpation in the left lower quadrant. Lumbar percussion shows mild tenderness. Pelvic examination shows tenderness in the posterior vaginal fornix. Pap smear shows high grade squamous intraepithelial lesions. Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Renal ultrasound is obtained and results are as follows:  



Which of the following best explains the patient’s overall clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
The renal ultrasound shows hydronephrosis. This, along with the finding of an abnormal pap smear, is suggestive of cervical cancer. Based on recommendations of the International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO), an ultrasound is recommended to aid in cancer staging. In patients with advanced disease, the cancer can spread to tissue next to the cervix, called the parametria. This region is in close proximity to the ureters. Neoplastic invasion of the parametria may lead to progressive ureteral obstruction, causing hydronephrosis. If only one ureter is affected, the patient may be asymptomatic since the unaffected kidney can compensate. However, if both ureters are affected, then the patient can present with flank pain and reduced urine output.  

Option Analysis

❌ Chronic pyelonephritis:
Incorrect: Chronic pyelonephritis is characterized by renal inflammation and scarring secondary to recurrent infections. In patients with pyelonephritis, urinalysis will show increased white blood cell and bacteria counts. In contrast, this patient has a normal urinalysis and no history of prior urinary tract infections.  
❌ Ectopic endometrium:
Incorrect: Endometriosis is a common cause of dysmenorrhea with posterior vaginal fornix tenderness. However, this patient has sonographic evidence of hydronephrosis, which is not a common complication of endometriosis.  
❌ Medication-induced obstruction:
Incorrect: Many drugs are known to cause crystal-induced uropathy, such as acyclovir, sulfonamide antibiotics, protease inhibitors (indinavir and atazanavir), and methotrexate. The subsequent ureter obstruction in turn may cause hydronephrosis. The patient in this vignette, however, is currently using propranolol, which is not associated with crystallization.  
❌ Multiple cystic changes:
Incorrect: Cystic changes, most commonly found in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, present as hypoechoic lesions and multiple cysts in the renal parenchyma. However, there is no family history of kidney disease. Furthermore, the image above shows dilation within the renal pelvis, which instead indicates hydronephrosis.   
✅ Parametrial neoplastic invasion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to spinning sensation and feeling unstable. This sensation started 1 month ago and since then has gotten gradually worse. She also describes constant fatigue and tingling sensation in both of her upper extremities. She states that several months ago, she went to the emergency department for an episode of intense right eye pain with movement and the loss of color vision; this gradually improved over 2 weeks. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows ataxia and nystagmus. A head MRI shows multiple hyperintense periventricular and cerebellar ovoid lesions. Which of the following is the most likely additional finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
This young woman with a history of fatigue, optic neuritis, sensory abnormalities and head MRI showing periventricular sclerotic plaques likely has multiple sclerosis (MS). The patient’s history of the gradual onset of a spinning sensation consistent with the central vertigo that can be caused by MS. From the answers above only multidirectional nystagmus is associated with central causes.  

Vertigo can be broken down into peripheral vertigo, which is due to damage to the vestibular apparatus or the vestibular nerve, and central vertigo, which is due to damage to the vestibular structures in the brainstem or cerebellum. In MS patients, sclerotic plaque formation and demyelination within the cerebellum can result in central vertigo. Central vertigo has various characteristics, and is summarized in the table below, but one major difference is the nature of the nystagmus. In central vertigo, the direction of the nystagmus is multidirectional (e.g., horizontal, torsional or rotatory, vertical), whereas in peripheral vertigo, the nystagmus can be horizontal or torsional, but not vertical.  

For completeness of the examination, the term "dizziness" should be clarified with the patient. It is a nonspecific term often used by patients to describe symptoms for which the cause can include vertigo, nonspecific "dizziness," disequilibrium, and presyncope.

Differences between central and peripheral causes of vertigo, as well as their etiologies, are described in the table below:    



Option Analysis

❌ Sudden head movements cause vertigo:
Incorrect: This sign is characteristic of peripheral vertigo, while this patient’s presentation and associated imaging findings are more consistent with central vertigo.  
❌ Visual fixation suppresses the nystagmus:
Incorrect: This sign is characteristic of peripheral vertigo, while this patient’s presentation and associated imaging findings are more consistent with central vertigo.  
✅ Multidirectional nystagmus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Presence of deafness or tinnitus:
Incorrect: The addition to hearing loss or tinnitus is characteristic of peripheral vertigo, while this patient’s presentation and associated imaging findings are more consistent with central vertigo.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her father who is concerned that she looks very tired. For the past week, the patient has not had her usual amount of energy, and she has been taking frequent naps. The patient’s father is concerned that she might have the flu, based on recent sick contacts at school. He has been giving her lots of water, which she has been drinking constantly. The father states that the patient looks skinnier than usual, even though she has an appetite. Both parents and an 8-year-old brother are healthy. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg. The patient’s height corresponds to the 50th percentile, and weight corresponds to the 25th percentile. Physical examination shows a slightly drowsy child with a dry mouth and lips. Further laboratory tests are performed, and the diagnosis is confirmed. The physician prescribes a short-acting insulin to take with every meal. Which of the following is most likely to occur without additional pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with the insidious onset of polydipsia (drinking a lot of water) and altered mental status (drowsiness). These symptoms suggest a diagnosis of type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM). Type 1 diabetes is an autoimmune condition in which the immune system targets and destroys the beta-cells (insulin-producing cells) of the pancreas. In children, type 1 diabetes occurs in a bimodal distribution, with the first peak between 4-6 years old and the second between 10-14 years old, and it equally affects males and females.  

Compared to type 2 diabetes, patients with type 1 diabetes have no beta cells, and thus they cannot make any insulin. While treatment for patients with type 2 diabetes initially involves lifestyle modifications to reduce the factors that lead to insulin resistance (obesity, sedentary lifestyle, poor diet), initial treatment for type 1 diabetes is focused on replacing the insulin that the body cannot make.  



Without insulin, the cells of a patient with type 1 diabetes cannot absorb or utilize glucose, which is necessary for cellular energy metabolism and function. In lieu of glucose, the body creates ketones as a secondary energy source to make up for the glucose starvation. Eventually, these ketones build up and cause an anion gap metabolic acidosis, known as diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA).  

This patient, who most likely has type 1 diabetes, requires a continuous supply of insulin to prevent the rapid development of DKA. The short-acting insulin prescribed will only last for a few hours a day after each meal. Without the addition of a long-acting insulin that is present at some level all the time (especially overnight), this patient will remain at high risk of developing DKA. Long-term effects of diabetes may occur years later (retinopathy, nephropathy, neuropathy), but without a constant insulin supply, DKA is a life-threatening complication in this patient.  

Option Analysis

❌ Hyperglycemic hyperosmotic state:
Incorrect: Hyperglycemic hyperosmotic state (HHS) occurs in patients with type 2 diabetes who experience a stressor (like infection or acute illness), which causes excessive hyperglycemia leading to osmotic polyuria, dehydration, and mental status changes. It is less common in patients with type 1 diabetes.  
❌ Proliferative retinopathy:
Incorrect: Diabetic retinopathy is caused by damage to the retina from excessive blood sugar. The three types of diabetic retinopathy include non-proliferative, proliferative (neovascularization), and macular edema. Diabetic retinopathy takes years to develop after the diagnosis of diabetes.  
❌ Nephrotic syndrome:
Incorrect: Diabetic nephropathy, caused by damage to nephrons from hyperglycemia, occurs years after a diagnosis of diabetes and is characterized by variable amounts of albuminuria and decreased glomerular filtration rate. In severe cases, albuminuria levels can be above the nephrotic threshold of 3.5 g per 24 hours, resulting in the nephrotic syndrome.  
✅ Anion gap metabolic acidosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Peripheral neuropathy:
Incorrect: Diabetic neuropathy refers to damage of the peripheral and/or autonomic nervous system from elevated blood sugar in the setting of diabetes. Neuropathy takes years to develop, though it is expected that 50% of patients with diabetes will eventually develop diabetic neuropathy.

questions.text: A 1-hour-old boy is being evaluated in the nursery due to a hairy patch on the lower back. He was born to a 24-year-old primigravida who did not receive prenatal care. The patient’s mother took prenatal vitamins throughout the pregnancy and did not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. The patient’s vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a comfortable infant moving all 4 limbs spontaneously. Rectal examination reveals normal anal sphincter tone. Examination of the lower back shows a small, flat, hairy patch. Palpation of the area reveals a gap. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This asymptomatic newborn is presenting with a hair patch and a palpable gap (absent vertebral lamina) over the lower back, favoring the diagnosis of spina bifida occulta. 

Spinal dysraphism (spina bifida), is a type of neural tube defect which includes both open and closed defects. Open defects (e.g., meningocele, meningomyelocele) are typified by a protrusion of meninges or the meninges plus the spinal cord, through the defect, respectively. Spina bifida occulta, also known as closed spinal dysraphism, is a bony defect in which the posterior vertebral arches fail to fuse, but there is intact skin and no exposed neural tissue. The condition may occur as an isolated defect or in association with other more severe anomalies (e.g. split spinal cord malformation). Risk factors for developing spina bifida occulta include folic acid deficiency, gestational diabetes, maternal obesity, and certain medications (e.g., valproate, carbamazepine). Radiographic findings include posterior vertebral arches defect (as indicated by the red circle in the x-ray) and possibly minor anomalies of the overlying skin, such as nevi, a dermal sinus or dimple, hemangioma, underlying lipoma, or a hair patch.    





 Retrieved from: Wikipedia   

Option Analysis

✅ Spina bifida occulta:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Spondylolisthesis :
Incorrect: Spondylolisthesis is a spinal condition in which a vertebra slips forward onto the vertebrae beneath it. It is often seen in teenagers and athletes who perform activities that involve hyperextension of the spine, but it can also occur as a result of trauma or degenerative changes. On palpation, there is a step-off rather than a gap.  
❌ Meningomyelocele :
Incorrect: Meningomyelocele is a type of spina bifida in which both the meninges and spinal cord herniate through a defect in the spinal cord. At birth, the lesion appears as a red, fleshy growth. Since this defect contains portions of the spinal cord, it is more likely to present with other neurologic abnormalities (e.g., sensory, motor, bladder, and bowel defects).    
❌ Tethered cord syndrome:
Incorrect: Tethered cord syndrome (TCS) refers to a group of neurological disorders caused by stretch-induced dysfunction of the caudal portion of the spinal cord. It may occur independently or in association with other spinal defects (e.g. spina bifida). In toddlers, tethered cord syndrome typically presents with motor and sensory deficits and loss of bladder control.   
❌ Syringomyelia :
Incorrect: Syringomyelia is a fluid-filled cavity within the spinal cord. Most lesions occur between C2 and T9. It may be congenital (e.g. Chiari malformation type I) or acquired (e.g., postinfectious, posttraumatic). It can be asymptomatic or present with progressive central cord deficits, depending on the distribution.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old man comes to the emergency department with fever, chills, sore throat, and abdominal pain for the past 3 days. He is a college student living on campus, and reports that many other students in his dorm are sick as well. His medical history is non-contributory. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 122/84 mmHg. Physical examination shows enlarged posterior lymph nodes on the neck and oropharyngeal examination shows bilateral tonsillar erythema with exudates. Abdominal examination shows hepatosplenomegaly. Rapid strep test is negative, and direct Coombs test is positive. Peripheral blood smear is shown below:  


 Reproduced from: Wikipedia 

Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with fever, sore throat, splenomegaly, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, and a negative rapid Strep test has infectious mononucleosis. The positive direct Coombs test and CD8+ reactive T-lymphocytes on peripheral blood smear indicate cold (IgM-mediated) autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA). This occurs as a result of the production of cold agglutinins, which are autoantibodies that target erythrocyte membranes and mark them for destruction in the spleen.  

Hemolytic anemias can be classified based on the location of erythrocyte destruction (i.e., intravascular or extravascular), as well the etiology of the hemolysis (i.e., intrinsic vs. extrinsic). Extravascular hemolysis is defined by erythrocyte destruction outside of blood vessels, typically in the reticuloendothelial system (i.e. macrophages in the spleen), and intravascular hemolysis is defined by erythrocyte destruction within blood vessels. Extrinsic anemia is defined as hemolysis resulting from a problem outside of the erythrocyte and is typically acquired (e.g., autoimmune, infections, microangiopathic), whereas intrinsic anemia is defined as hemolysis resulting from a problem with the erythrocyte itself and is typically caused by enzyme deficiencies, commonly seen in congenital conditions (e.g., sickle cell disease, G6PD, hereditary spherocytosis).  

The type of hemolysis present can be determined based on laboratory findings. In intravascular hemolysis, hemoglobin released inside blood vessels is bound by haptoglobin and both molecules are removed together. Therefore, haptoglobin levels decrease sharply. When haptoglobin levels are depleted, hemoglobin is excreted through the kidneys, resulting in hemoglobinuria and hemosiderinuria. Hemoglobinuria and hemosiderinuria can cause kidney damage, and patients may present with back pain.    

In extravascular hemolysis, erythrocytes are destroyed outside of blood vessels, so haptoglobin levels are normal and there is no hemoglobin or hemosiderin in the urine. Erythrocyte destruction occurs in the spleen and liver, so patients may present with hepatosplenomegaly.  

Option Analysis

❌ Hemosiderinuria:
Incorrect: Hemosiderinuria is associated with intravascular hemolysis. Common causes include paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and macroangiopathic hemolytic anemias.  
✅ Normal haptoglobin levels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC):
Incorrect: Increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) is associated with hereditary spherocytosis.  
❌ Pancytopenia:
Incorrect: Pancytopenia is associated with aplastic anemia, which is characterized by bone marrow and subsequent myeloid hematopoietic stem cell destruction. Common causes include radiation, certain drugs (benzene, chloramphenicol, alkylating agents, antimetabolites), viral infections (EBV, HIV, hepatitis), and Fanconi anemia.   
❌ Thrombocytopenia:
Incorrect: Thrombocytopenia is associated with a type of intravascular hemolytic anemia called microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA).

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the office by her parents due to inattentive behavior. The parents say that the patient’s teacher is concerned that the patient does not pay attention in class and has periods where she does not respond to her name. The patient was previously doing well in school, but her grades have declined over the past few months. The parents have also noticed the patient staring into space for 10-20 seconds, multiple times throughout the day. There is no history of falls or syncope associated with the episodes. The patient’s uncle has a history of attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities, and the child appears playful and active. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Absence seizure (also called petit mal) is a type of generalized seizure (i.e. affecting both the cerebral hemispheres at onset), and it is one of the most common forms of pediatric epilepsy. The seizure manifests in school-aged children and adolescents as a brief staring spell causing transient loss of consciousness without loss of body tone. It usually lasts about 10 seconds and cannot be interrupted by verbal/tactile stimuli (as opposed to staring spells that occur out of boredom or lack of focus). There is no postictal confusion or sedation, but the patient is unable to recall the event. Automatisms (lip smacking, rapid blinking) are observed sometimes, especially when the episode lasts for more than 10 seconds.  

Absence seizures can easily be provoked by hyperventilation, and electroencephalogram (EEG) exhibits classical 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges. The first line agent for the treatment of absence seizures is ethosuximide, which inhibits T-type calcium channels in thalamic neurons. Valproic acid can be used if ethosuximide is ineffective or not tolerated. Absence seizures are typically benign and resolve before puberty.  



Option Analysis

❌ Selective mutism:
Incorrect: Selective mutism is an uncommon disorder in which the child fails to communicate in a specific social place (like school) but speaks normally in other settings (like home). This child’s abnormal behavior is not limited to a specific setting.  
❌ Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with absence seizure can easily be misdiagnosed with attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Although it may present similarly with “inattention,” the staring spells observed in ADHD are actually due to lack of focus and can be interrupted by verbal or tactile stimulus. Moreover, the condition is usually accompanied by poor impulse control.  
❌ Autism spectrum disorder:
Incorrect: Although patients with autism spectrum disorder exhibit impaired social interactions, the condition is characterized by repetitive patterns of behavior or interests, and it usually presents by age 2. Staring spells are atypical.  
✅ Generalized seizure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Focal seizure:
Incorrect: Focal seizures (previously called partial seizures) affect only one hemisphere of the brain. Although patients with a focal temporal lobe seizure can present with blank staring, the episode usually lasts >30 seconds. Temporal lobe seizures are also typically accompanied by aura (olfactory hallucination or rising epigastric sensation), though this particular symptom may be difficult to elucidate in pediatric patients.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man comes to the emergency department with sudden, severe leg pain. He was watching football at home when he experienced an acute-onset, sharp pain in the right calf that has progressively worsened. The patient reports being unable to feel the sock worn on that foot, and he is having difficulty moving his toes. He denies chest pain or shortness of breath. Medical history is significant for a small intracranial aneurysm that has been monitored on serial imaging and has remained stable in size for five years. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is irregularly irregular at 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical exam shows pale and mottled skin starting 6 cm below the right tibial plateau and extending to the right toes. There is no swelling. Hair growth is normal. Carotid, radial, and femoral pulses are palpable bilaterally. The left posterior tibial artery pulse is palpable while his right is absent on palpation and has no signal on Doppler ultrasound. Which of the following locations is the most likely origin of this patient’s embolus?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with sudden onset unilateral leg pain with evidence on examination of critical limb ischemia. Acute (critical) limb ischemia, defined as occurring within 2 weeks of symptom onset, is most often caused by acute arterial occlusion in patients with known peripheral artery disease (PAD). However, the condition can occur in previously healthy patients in the setting of arterial dissection, trauma, or embolism from a more proximal source. This patient does not have risk factors for atherosclerosis (e.g., hypertension, diabetes, smoking) and the peripheral pulses are normal in all but the affected leg, suggesting an embolic occlusion, as depicted on the right in this diagram:  



The majority of peripheral emboli originate in the heart, either from atrial thrombus in the setting of atrial fibrillation, ventricular thrombus in the setting of myocardial infarction, or vegetations in the setting of infective endocarditis.

This patient has no symptoms or history of myocardial infarction and no fevers or murmur to suggest endocarditis. Therefore, the patient most likely has a thromboembolism from a left atrial appendage clot in the setting of atrial fibrillation (irregularly irregular heartbeat), which then lodged in the popliteal artery (the occlusion is usually found one joint above the line of pale skin on exam).  

On physical exam, the “six P’s” (pain, pallor, poikilothermia [cool], pulselessness, paresthesia, paralysis) suggest acute limb ischemia. Pain starts suddenly and gradually increases in severity. It is associated with cool, pale, and mottled skin. Distal pulses are severely diminished or absent. Paresthesias and paralysis indicate severe ischemia and hypoxic nerves. Urgent revascularization is necessary to prevent loss of limb.   

Option Analysis

❌ Right popliteal vein:
Incorrect: The right popliteal vein may become occluded in the setting of a deep venous thrombosis (DVT). Thromboembolism from DVT is most likely to result in pulmonary embolism, though rarely a venous thrombus can enter arterial circulation through a patent foramen ovale (PFO). DVT is usually associated with asymmetric leg swelling.  
❌ Right femoral vein:
Incorrect: The right femoral vein may become occluded in the setting of a deep venous thrombosis (DVT). Thromboembolism from DVT is most likely to result in pulmonary embolism, though rarely a venous thrombus can enter arterial circulation through a patent foramen ovale (PFO). DVT is usually associated with asymmetric leg swelling.  
✅ Left atrium:
Correct: See Main Explanation below.  
❌ Left ventricle:
Incorrect: A thrombus may form in the left ventricle following a myocardial infarction, where akinetic, infarcted myocardium becomes a nidus for clot formation. Left ventricular clots may embolize to the arterial system causing stroke or distal ischemia. This patient does not have symptoms or a history of myocardial infarction.  
❌ Ascending aorta:
Incorrect: Dissection of the ascending aorta may affect perfusion to the upper extremities if it involves the brachiocephalic or subclavian arteries. Aortic dissection usually causes severe chest pain radiating to the back.  
❌ Descending aorta:
Incorrect: Atheroembolism of an aortic cholesterol plaque distally to the leg would be less likely to cause a large arterial occlusion in a patient without evidence of peripheral artery disease. Atheroembolisms are smaller than thromboembolisms and are more likely to cause very distal ischemia in one toe.

questions.text: A female newborn is undergoing standard assessment shortly after an uncomplicated vaginal delivery at 39 weeks gestation. The patient’s 22-year-old mother, G1P1, did not receive prenatal care, has no prior medical history, and takes no medications. The newborn is alert and vocalizing loudly. Apgar scores at 1 and 5 minutes are 8 and 9, respectively. The patient is at the 35th percentile for length and the 40th percentile for weight. The patient’s temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 87/55 mmHg. Physical exam shows annular lesions with central atrophy and raised margins located over the scalp and periorbital area. Which of the following antibodies is most likely to be present in the newborn’s serum?
questions.solution:
This newborn is exhibiting clinical features of neonatal lupus, which is somewhat of a misnomer: neonatal lupus does not refer to systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) in a neonate. Rather, neonatal lupus is characterized by placental transfer of anti-Ro/SSA antibodies from a mother to her fetus. Anti-Ro/SSA antibodies, most commonly associated with Sjogren syndrome (in 80% of patients), are also present in patients with SLE (in 40% of patients). They are also found in 0.5% of the healthy female population.  



Neonatal lupus is characterized by a periorbital or diffuse rash, heart block, and hepatic or hematologic manifestations caused by these auto-antibodies. A rash may be present at birth, but most commonly it is observed a few weeks later, appearing as erythematous annular lesions or arcuate macules with slight central atrophy found mostly around the eyes and scalp. First-, second-, or third-degree heart block may occur, usually between 18 to 24 weeks gestation. Atrioventricular block causes bradycardia with a ventricular rate between 50 and 80 beats per minute, as seen in this patient. A minority of newborns with neonatal lupus will show transient, mild liver enzyme abnormalities and cytopenias.  

Mothers with known anti-Ro/SSA antibody positivity should receive weekly fetal echocardiography from the 18th through 26th weeks of pregnancy to monitor for heart block. Identification of a complete heart block may require pacemaker placement after birth. The rash of neonatal lupus resolves spontaneously after six to eight months, as maternal antibodies are cleared from circulation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Antinuclear antibody:
Incorrect: Antinuclear antibody (ANA) is sensitive for detecting systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) but does not play a role in the development of neonatal lupus.  
❌ Anti-dsDNA antibody:
Incorrect: Anti-dsDNA antibody is specific for diagnosing systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) but does not play a role in the development of neonatal lupus.  
❌ Lupus anticoagulant:
Incorrect: Lupus anticoagulant is a pro-thrombotic immunoglobulin that binds to phospholipids and cell surface proteins. It may be present in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or antiphospholipid syndrome, but it does not play a role in the development of neonatal lupus.  
❌ Anticardiolipin IgG antibody:
Incorrect: Anticardiolipin antibodies bind cardiolipin, a macromolecule that makes up 20% of the total lipids in the inner mitochondrial membrane. Anticardiolipin antibodies (IgG or IgM) may be present in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or antiphospholipid syndrome, but they do not play a role in the development of neonatal lupus.  
✅ Anti-Ro/SSA antibody:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to leg pain and swelling that started suddenly 2 days ago. History is significant for traveling back from Australia 3 days ago and smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 5 years. The patient denies any trauma, and she does not use excessive alcohol or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the right calf is red, warm, and swollen. The left calf appears normal. Lower extremity ultrasounds reveal a deep vein thrombosis. Laboratory testing shows a PTT of 30 seconds. Heparin is administered. Six hours later, PTT is 32 seconds. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has antithrombin III deficiency, a type of thrombophilia which can be inherited or acquired.  

Antithrombin III (AT, also known as heparin cofactor I) is a natural anticoagulant produced by the liver. Its primary function is to inhibit thrombin (factor IIa), factor Xa, and other factors in the coagulation cascade.  Inherited deficiencies are caused by AT gene mutations (autosomal dominant). Acquired deficiencies are associated with impaired production of AT (e.g., liver disease, warfarin therapy), protein loss (e.g. nephrotic syndrome), or accelerated consumption (e.g. disseminated intravascular coagulation).  

Patients with AT deficiency are at increased thrombotic risk and are therefore at risk of developing venous or arterial thrombosis, obstetric complications, and stroke. Another feature of the conditions is insensitivity to heparin. Normally, heparin enhances the activity of antithrombin, which in turn inhibits thrombin and factor Xa. In patients with AT deficiency aPTT cannot be adequately prolonged with heparin administration. Diagnosis is made via AT-heparin cofactor assay, which assesses plasma antithrombin activity. Genetic testing is used in laboratories but not used routinely for diagnosis. Treatment includes direct thrombin inhibitors (Argatroban), direct factor X inhibitors (Rivaroxaban), warfarin, recombinant AT, or plasma transfusions.  









Option Analysis

❌ Vitamin K deficiency:
Incorrect: Vitamin K is crucial for the coagulation cascade to function properly, as it serves as a cofactor for several key proteins with carboxyglutamic acid residues (factors 2, 7, 9, 10, C and S). Causes of vitamin K deficiency include malabsorption or intestinal conditions (e.g., celiac disease, cystic fibrosis), liver or biliary disease (e.g. liver failure), and medications interfering with vitamin K metabolism. Manifestations of vitamin K deficiency include easy bruisability, mucosal bleeding, splinter hemorrhages, melena, and hematuria. This patient, however, is presenting with signs of a hypercoagulable state.  
✅ Antithrombin III deficiency :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Factor V Leiden deficiency:
Incorrect: Factor V is a clotting factor that enhances the production of thrombin, the enzyme that converts fibrinogen into fibrin to cause clot formation. Factor V Leiden deficiency is caused by a single point mutation in the factor V gene, which makes it resistant to inactivation by protein C. The result is a hypercoagulable state. Testing will often show shortened or normal PTT. Diagnosis can be made via functional assay by demonstrating a failure to prolong PTT with addition of purified protein C (protein C resistance).   
❌ ADAMTS13 deficiency:
Incorrect: Inhibition or deficiency of ADAMTS13 is associated with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). ADAMTS13 is a metalloproteinase responsible for the degradation of vWF multimers. Deficiency results in platelet adhesion and aggregation. It is most commonly associated with Shiga-like toxin from EHEC (serotype O157:H7) infection. The classic triad includes thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and acute kidney injury.  
❌ Prothrombin gene mutation:
Incorrect: Prothrombin, also known as factor II, is the precursor of thrombin. Thrombin in turn cleaves fibrinogen to fibrin, which crosslinks to form a fibrin clot. Prothrombin deficiency occurs due to a point mutation in which adenine (A) is substituted for guanine (G) at position 20210. The result is a gain-of-function mutation, increased prothrombin function, and hypercoagulability. A definitive diagnosis is made via polymerase chain reaction (PCR).

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman comes to the office for a follow-up for chronic knee pain. Over the past 6 months, she has been suffering from knee pain that has been progressively worsening. The patient discloses a dull pain, 3/10 around the right knee, and she did not notice any aggravating or alleviating factors. The pain sometimes awakens her from sleep. The patient has tried over the counter pain medication and multiple sessions of physiotherapy with minimal relief. Family history is negative for malignancy. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, there is mild swelling around the right knee, and range of motion is limited due to pain. The left knee appears normal. An x-ray of the right knee is obtained and shown below:  


 Retrieved from: Radiopaedia

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with progressive knee pain and night pain that is unresponsive to medications. The radiograph results show a lytic “soap bubble” like lesion in the distal femur, which is consistent with the diagnosis of a giant cell tumor or osteoclastoma.   

Giant cell tumor of bone is a benign but locally aggressive bone tumor often seen in young adults between ages of 20-40. It typically presents as a lytic lesion in the epiphyses of long bones. Clinically, the tumor may produce arthritis-like pain due to its proximity to the joints and occasionally cause pathologic fracture. On radiography, the tumor forms an expansile lytic lesion sometimes described as a “soap bubble” like lesion. Grossly, it appears as red-brown masses with areas of cystic degeneration. Microscopically, it consists of sheets of osteoclast-type giant cells. Those neoplastic cells express excessive levels of RANKL, which lead to the differentiation of normal osteoclast precursors into osteoclasts. Treatment usually involves curettage, but the tumor has high rates of recurrence.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Osteosarcoma:
Incorrect: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the bone. The tumor produces an osteoid matrix or mineralized bone. Osteosarcoma has a bimodal age distribution, with a first peak seen in persons younger than 20 years of age and a smaller peak in older adults. In adolescents, it often arises in the metaphyseal regions of the distal femur and proximal tibia. Radiographs usually show destructive, mixed lytic and sclerotic mass with reactive subperiosteal bone formation. This bone formation leads to the elevation of the periosteum and characteristic appearance known radiographically as Codman’s triangle (not pathognomonic).  
❌ Ewing Sarcoma:
Incorrect: Ewing sarcoma is a highly malignant tumor that accounts for approximately 10% of primary malignant bone tumors. The majority of Ewing sarcomas contain a balanced t(11;22) translocation. It commonly affects children, 5 to 15 years of age. The tumor usually arises in the diaphysis of long bones. Symptoms include bony pain, tissue swelling, fever, fatigue, weight loss, anemia, and pathologic fractures. On x-ray, it is seen as a large lytic lesion with a significant periosteal reaction deposited in an “onion-skin” or "moth-eaten" fashion. On histology, small sheets of malignant cells are seen. This patient’s age and tumor location favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Osteoclastoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Osteoid osteoma:
Incorrect: Osteoid osteoma is a benign, bone-producing tumor often seen in adolescents. It typically arises in the cortex of the femur or tibia and has a characteristic lucent nidus of less than 2 cm with surrounding osteosclerotic reaction. Although benign, they present with severe nocturnal pain that is relieved by aspirin and other NSAIDs. This patient has had minimal relief with over-the-counter pain medication.  
❌ Fibrous dysplasia:
Incorrect: Fibrous dysplasia is a benign lesion in which bone is replaced by fibrous connective tissue and abnormal trabecular bone. It usually occurs in young adolescents more commonly in the proximal femur, tibia, ribs, and skull. Most patients are asymptomatic but some may present with pain, swelling, pathologic fractures, or bone deformity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the clinic due to right shoulder pain for the past 2 months. He works as a carpenter and initially thought it was work-related. However, it has recently become more severe and often awakens him at night. The patient describes the pain as dull, deep, and 4/10 in intensity. Medical history is remarkable for diabetes mellitus type 2 manages with metformin. The patient smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 20 years, but quit 5 years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, he has difficulty with shoulder movement due to pain. Passive range of motion is full but produces the pain as well. X-ray of shoulder shows a mixed radiolucent and sclerotic lesion with a ring-and-arc pattern of calcifications. The cortex appears thickened, but a periosteal reaction is scant. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with progressive shoulder pain and night pain. The x-ray shows a mixed radiolucent and sclerotic lesion with a ring-and-arc pattern of calcification, favoring the diagnosis of chondrosarcoma. Histopathological examination is required for definitive diagnosis.  

Chondrosarcoma is a malignant cartilage-producing tumor. It usually affects individuals in their 40s or older and more commonly affects men. It usually arises in the axial skeleton, such as the pelvis, shoulder, and ribs. On imaging, chondrosarcoma presents with mixed radiolucent and sclerotic lesions, with a punctate or ring-and-arc pattern of calcifications due to mineralization of the chondroid matrix. Other radiological findings include flocculent densities that destroy the bone cortex and formation of a soft tissue mass. Moreover, while the cortex may be thickened, periosteal reaction is scant or absent.  

It can arise as a primary lesion or secondary to preexisting enchondroma or osteochondroma. Macroscopically, chondrosarcomas are large and bulky, and consist of translucent cartilage with gelatinous areas. Histologically, it produces an abundant cartilage matrix and irregularly shaped lobules of cartilage that permeate the bony trabeculae. Cellularity, cytologic atypia, and mitotic activity vary depending on the grading. Treatment usually involves wide surgical excision with or without chemotherapy.    

Option Analysis

❌ Osteosarcoma:
Incorrect: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the bone. The tumor produces an osteoid matrix or mineralized bone. Osteosarcoma follows a bimodal age distribution, with a first peak seen in persons younger than 20 years of age and a smaller peak in older adults. In adolescents, it often arises in the metaphyseal regions of the distal femur and proximal tibia. Radiographs usually show destructive, mixed lytic and sclerotic mass with reactive subperiosteal bone formation. This bone formation leads to the elevation of the periosteum and characteristic appearance known radiographically as Codman’s triangle. This patient’s radiographic findings favor another diagnosis.  
❌ Paget disease of the bone:
Incorrect: Paget disease of bone is a disorder that interferes with normal bone metabolism and leads to accelerated bone remodeling. Bone lesions may be single or multiple and can be lytic, mixed or blastic depending on the stage. Paget disease is mostly asymptomatic, but some patients may present with bone pain or pain due to deformity or compression. Diagnosis is often incidental following a routine chemistry screen showing elevated ALP and normal serum calcium, phosphorus, and PTH levels. This patient’s radiographic findings favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Giant cell tumor:
Incorrect: Giant cell tumor of bone is a benign but locally aggressive bone tumor often seen in young adults between the ages of 20-40. It typically presents as a lytic lesion in the epiphyses of long bones. Clinically, the tumor may produce arthritis-like pain due to its proximity to the joints and occasionally pathologic fracture. On radiography, the tumor forms an expansile lytic lesion sometimes described as a “soap bubble” like lesion. This patient’s radiographic findings favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Chondrosarcoma :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Plasmacytoma of bone:
Incorrect: Plasmacytoma of bone is classified as a plasma cell neoplasm, a group of entities that typically produce monoclonal antibodies. When presenting with a solitary lesion, it is named solitary plasmacytoma. When presenting with multiple lesions, it is termed multiple myeloma. Multiple myeloma and plasmacytoma instead produce lytic “punched out” lesions. Also, the absence of anemia and renal involvement makes this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents to the primary care physician with a several month history of epigastric abdominal discomfort. The patient describes a burning sensation after eating, abdominal fullness, and distension. He reports taking omeprazole for the symptoms without relief. An endoscopy with biopsy is performed demonstrating the following histologic specimen:  



Reproduced from: Wikipedia

From which area of the gastrointestinal tract was this biopsy most likely taken?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of chronic dyspepsia and a biopsy demonstrating Gram negative bacteria with surrounding metaplasia concerning for type B chronic gastritis due to Helicobacter Pylori. A distinguishing diagnostic feature of H. pylori gastritis when compared to chronic autoimmune gastritis is the location of the metaplasia and atrophy seen on histologic specimens. Most patients with chronic gastritis due to H. pylori will demonstrate these pathologic changes in the antrum of the stomach, whereas patients with chronic autoimmune gastritis will have these changes primarily in the body/fundus.  

Clinically, chronic H. pylori gastritis presents with symptoms of dyspepsia over weeks to months but may go unrecognized entirely. H. pylori preferentially invades the antrum to avoid the acidic secretions by parietal cells in the fundus and body. In the antrum, colonization by the bacteria drives proliferation and increased secretion of gastrin by G-cells. Gastrin stimulates parietal cells to secrete additional hydrochloric acid, eroding the gastric mucosa and causing atrophy and loss of glandular cells with replacement by metaplastic epithelium. Colonization in the antrum also damages delta cells, involved in the secretion of somatostatin. With decreased somatostatin levels, gastrin becomes uninhibited, leading to increased secretion of acid by parietal cells.  With continued inflammation, MALT lymphoma, a tumor of mucosa associated lymphoid tissue, can arise.   

Option Analysis

❌ Fundus of the stomach:
Incorrect: The fundus is the most common area of the stomach affected by chronic autoimmune gastritis, which typically presents in patients with additional autoimmune disorders and pernicious anemia.   
❌ Gastroesophageal junction:
Incorrect: The gastroesophageal junction is implicated in Barrett esophagus. This metaplastic process occurs when stratified squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced by columnar epithelium and goblet cells due to uncontrolled acid reflux.  
❌ Duodenum :
Incorrect: Duodenal ulcers may occur following infection with H. pylori; however, it is not the most common site of colonization by the bacteria.   
✅ Antrum of the stomach:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Esophagus :
Incorrect: The esophagus is not a common location for colonization of H. pylori.

questions.text: A 77-year-old man presents to the primary care physician with a painless mass in his left neck. The patient reports rapid enlargement of this mass over the past several weeks. In addition, he reports a 20-lb (9.1 kg) weight loss, fatigue, and decreased appetite. Past medical history is notable for recurrent peptic ulcer disease, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. He reports a 10-pack-year smoking history but quit 25 years ago. He reports drinking 1-2 beers per day.  Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 12/min and blood pressure is 142/62 mmHg. Physical examination shows a hard 3 cm x  3 cm mass in the left supraclavicular fossa, temporal wasting, epigastric tenderness to palpation, and a small periumbilical subcutaneous nodule. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Enlargement of the Virchow node, or the left supraclavicular lymph node draining the thoracic duct, is also known as Troisier sign, which is commonly found in patients with underlying gastric adenocarcinoma. This finding, in conjunction with this patient's periumbilical metastases known as Sister-Mary Joseph nodules, weight loss, early satiety, and history of recurrent peptic ulcer disease, makes gastric cancer the most likely diagnosis.  

Other physical exam findings commonly seen with gastric adenocarcinoma include the sudden appearance of diffuse seborrheic keratoses (Leser-Trelat sign) or acanthosis nigricans, which is characterized by velvety and darkly pigmented patches of skin folds. A finding known as Blumer shelf may also be felt on digital rectal exam, which indicates metastatic tumor cells growing in the rectovesical or rectouterine pouch.  

Option Analysis

✅ Gastric adenocarcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hodgkin Lymphoma:
Incorrect: Hodgkin lymphoma may present with enlarged non-tender supraclavicular lymph nodes but usually presents with associated night sweats, fevers and splenomegaly. This patient’s epigastric pain is likely indicative of another underlying condition.  
❌ Pancreatic adenocarcinoma:
Incorrect: Pancreatic cancer typically presents with jaundice and unexplained weight loss. Metastases may be present in the supraclavicular or periumbilical nodes, but the absence of jaundice in this patient makes pancreatic cancer less likely.   
❌ Colonic adenocarcinoma:
Incorrect: Colorectal cancer typically presents with weight loss, rectal bleeding, or progressive change in bowel movements. Metastases to the supraclavicular lymph nodes are possible; however, this patient’s other clinical signs (e.g., Sister-Mary Joseph nodules) are indicative of another underlying malignancy.   
❌ Hepatocellular carcinoma  :
Incorrect: Hepatocellular carcinoma is largely a consequence of untreated cirrhosis. This patient is without evidence of ascites, jaundice, or blood dyscrasias, making this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the office following abnormal results of screening mammography. The mammogram showed suspicious microcalcifications. The patient is in good health, and medical history is unremarkable. Family history is negative for cancer. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, there are no breast changes, palpable masses, or lymphadenopathy. There is no nipple discharge. She is scheduled for a biopsy. Based on these features alone, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with clinically silent disease and microcalcifications on mammography which require further evaluation with biopsy. In light of the absence of a palpable mass and the presence of calcifications seen on mammography, the most likely diagnosis is ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS).  

DCIS is a noninvasive breast cancer which arises from the terminal duct lobular unit, spreads into the lactiferous ducts and does not cross the basement membrane. Up to 90% of the women with DCIS are diagnosed following abnormal mammography showing suspicious microcalcifications; DCIS accounts for approximately 80% of all breast cancers presenting with calcifications. Findings such as a palpable mass or other soft tissue changes are less common. The prognosis is excellent, but without treatment, DCIS progresses to invasive cancer in approximately 1/3 of cases (usually in the same breast and quadrant). Therapy usually includes surgery, radiation therapy, and adjuvant endocrine therapy.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Ductal carcinoma in situ:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lobular carcinoma in situ:
Incorrect: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is noninvasive breast cancer which arises from the terminal duct lobular unit, spreads into the lobules, and does not cross the basement membrane. It is typically clinically and radiographically silent and is almost always an incidental finding. The presence of LCIS in one breast increases the risk for invasive breast cancer in both breasts. Unlike ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), LCIS is rarely associated with calcifications on mammography.   
❌ Invasive lobular carcinoma:
Incorrect: Invasive lobular carcinomas are the 2nd most common type of invasive breast cancer. Patients often present with a palpable mass and/or mass on imaging. However, the absence of a palpable mass makes this diagnosis less likely.   
❌ Invasive ductal carcinoma:
Incorrect: Invasive ductal carcinoma is the most common type of breast cancer and arises from the terminal duct lobular unit, spreads into the ducts, and crosses the basement membrane into the stroma. It often arises from an underlying ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). Invasive ductal carcinoma typically produces an extensive desmoplastic response, which is the growth of fibrous or connective tissue that surrounds the tumor and replaces the normal breast tissue. This reaction leads to an identifiable mammographic and sonographic density, and a hard, palpable, irregular mass upon examination, which are absent in this patient.   
❌ Intraductal papilloma:
Incorrect: Intraductal papilloma is a small fibroepithelial tumor that grows within lactiferous ducts, commonly beneath the areola. It commonly presents with isolated serous or bloody nipple discharge. Occasionally, it may present as a mass and/or tenderness. Mammography is mostly unrevealing but may show duct ectasia, calcifications, or a mass. This patient has no nipple changes.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to right breast erythema and tenderness that have progressed over the past 2 weeks. She is generally healthy and has not experienced any trauma in the area. Her only medication is a daily multivitamin. Family history is negative for cancer. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 125/70 mmHg. On physical examination, the skin on the right breast is indurated and thickened with dimpling of the hair follicles. A palpable lymph node is present in the right axilla. The nipple appears normal. A core needle biopsy reveals an invasive carcinoma. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s skin findings?
questions.solution:
This patient has an invasive carcinoma. Skin thickening, induration, and dimpling of the hair follicles depict a classic picture of peau d'orange (orange peel) of inflammatory breast cancer due to tumor obstruction to the skin lymphatics. “Inflammatory” is a misnomer, as true inflammation is absent.  

Inflammatory breast cancer is rare and the most aggressive form of breast cancer, which accounts for up to 2% of invasive breast cancers diagnosed in the United States. At the time of presentation, the majority of patients already have lymph node involvement, and one-third have distant metastases. Patients often present with breast pain or a rapidly growing breast lump. Inflammatory breast cancer is associated with poor prognosis and high rates of early recurrence. On histology, inflammatory carcinoma is poorly differentiated, diffusely infiltrative and obstructs the dermal lymphatics.  

Option Analysis

❌ Involvement the suspensory ligaments:
Incorrect: The suspensory ligaments (also known as Cooper's ligaments) is a connective tissue that helps maintain the structural integrity of the breast and is connected to the skin. Tumor invasion of the suspensory ligaments is the cause of skin dimpling at the area of tumor invasion. This patient instead had dimpling of the hair follicles, a characteristic appearance of inflammatory breast cancer.    
❌ Shortening of the lactiferous ducts:
Incorrect: The lactiferous ducts arise from the lobules of the mammary gland and converge into the nipple. Shortening of the lactiferous ducts causes nipple inversion and/or nipple discharge often seen with different types of subareolar or central malignancies but also in benign conditions such as duct ectasia, periductal mastitis, and subareolar abscess. The nipple in this case appears normal.   
✅ Obstruction of the skin lymphatics:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bacterial invasion:
Incorrect: Bacterial invasion is the cause of mastitis that may progress to form breast abscess. Both conditions usually present with a firm, red, painful, and swollen area. Breast abscess also causes a local fluctuant and palpable mass, with concomitant systemic symptoms (e.g. fever).   
❌ Trauma to chest:
Incorrect: Fat necrosis is a benign breast lesion that typically occurs in the setting of trauma or surgery. Patients often present with a firm and irregular mass. Since many patients do not recall the trauma, and certain features of the lesion on physical exam and imaging resemble malignancy (e.g. calcifications), a biopsy is often required. On histology, fat necrosis is seen as necrotic fat and giant cells.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, gravida 0 para 0, comes to the office after noticing a painful breast lump in the right breast on self-examination. The patient did notice that the lump becomes larger and tender closer to menstruation, and it often self-resolves once the period has ended.  Medical history is unremarkable, she takes no medication, and she has not had any recent trauma. Family history is positive for breast cancer in her mother at age 60. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a nodular lump is present in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast accompanied by diffuse tenderness. No discharge is expressible from either nipple. No lymphadenopathy is noted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a painful, nodular mass in the upper outer quadrant of the breast that is influenced by hormonal changes, favoring the diagnosis of fibrocystic changes.   

Fibrocystic changes refer to the development of fibrous tissue and cystic spaces within the breast. These changes include cysts, fibrosis, and apocrine metaplasia. The cysts arise within the lobular unit and are affected by hormones (e.g. estrogen). Growth or rupture of these cysts induces inflammation and fibrosis of the surrounding tissue -- hence the name “fibrocystic changes.” The cysts are lined by a layer of luminal cells that often undergo apocrine metaplasia.  

Fibrocystic changes are common in premenopausal women 20-50 years old. Patients often present with unilateral/bilateral/multifocal, painful, poorly-defined nodular/lumpy tissue, typically in the upper outer quadrant. Diagnosis can be made clinically but definitive diagnosis requires imaging and biopsy.  

Fibrocystic change by itself is benign and carries no risk for invasive carcinoma; however, certain features, if present on biopsy, are associated with increased risk for cancer (shown in the table below).  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Fibroadenoma:
Incorrect: Fibroadenoma is a benign breast lesion typically seen in women < 35 years of age which presents as a small, well-defined, and mobile mass on physical examination. Fibroadenoma is a benign solid tumor containing glandular and fibrous tissue. Similar to fibrocystic changes, it varies in size under the hormonal influence of estrogen; however, fibroadenoma is a well-defined mass rather than a nodular lump, as seen in this patient.    
❌ Fat necrosis:
Incorrect: Fat necrosis typically occurs after trauma or surgery and presents as a firm and irregular mass. Fat necrosis from trauma is typically accompanied by skin ecchymosis, and the patient may not recall the specific trauma. Fat necrosis can be difficult to distinguish from a malignant mass, and biopsy is often required. Fat necrosis is not nodular and does not vary in size with the menstrual cycle.   
✅ Fibrocystic changes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intraductal papilloma:
Incorrect: Intraductal papilloma is a small fibroepithelial tumor that commonly grows within lactiferous ducts beneath the areola. It typically presents with unilateral serous or bloody nipple discharge, rather than a nodular mass as seen in this patient.  
❌ Breast abscess:
Incorrect: A breast abscess is a collection of inflammatory exudate (i.e. pus) within the breast. It can occur in the setting of mastitis or cellulitis that is left untreated or does not respond to antibiotic treatment. Patients often present with localized, painful inflammation of the breast accompanied by fever and malaise. The abscess is typically fluctuant and tender. This patient’s presentation and exam findings favor another diangosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to chest discomfort that started suddenly 20 minutes ago while he was trying to fall asleep. The patient describes the pain as a “squeezing” in the center of the chest that moves to the neck and jaw; there are no changes in pain with respiration or position. The patient has not had any recent travel, sick contacts, or illnesses. Medical history is significant for a 5-pack-year smoking history, and no alcohol or illicit drugs. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg. The patient appears to be in distress and is diaphoretic. Electrocardiogram shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads. The patient is given nitroglycerin and the pain resolves within a few minutes. Which of the following findings is most likely underlying pathophysiology responsible for this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Inflammation of the serosal lining membranes
Atherosclerotic plaque obstructing 80% of the coronary artery lumen without thrombus
Rupture of an atherosclerotic plaque with thrombus partially occluding the coronary artery lumen
Minimal atherosclerotic plaque and coronary artery spasm
Rupture of atherosclerotic plaque with thrombus fully occluding the coronary artery lumen

questions.solution:
This previously healthy young adult, with a significant smoking history and no additional risk factors for coronary artery disease, who presents with chest pain that began during rest, most likely has vasospastic angina (previously called Prinzmetal or variant angina). Vasospastic angina is a clinical entity characterized by episodic chest pain attributable to coronary artery vasospasm. The chest pain in vasospastic angina, similar to coronary artery disease, does not change with position or inspiration.  

Vasospastic angina is caused by spasm of the smooth muscle layer of the arterial wall of the coronary artery, resulting in a high-grade obstruction. Vascular smooth muscle hyperreactivity is believed to play a key role in the pathogenesis. Spasms can occur in angiographically normal coronary arteries but more often occur at the site of atherosclerotic plaques. Common triggers and risk factors include alcohol, smoking, cocaine and triptans. The diagnosis is made when patients present with recurrent episodes of typical anginal pain and are found to have transient ST-segment elevation on ECG/Holter monitor followed by insignificant findings of atherosclerosis at coronary arteriography. Treatment consists of nitrates, calcium channel blockers, and smoking cessation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Inflammation of the serosal lining membranes:
Incorrect: Inflammation of the serosal lining membranes of the heart can be seen in pericarditis, which can occur after myocardial infarction (MI) or viral illness. Patients often present with sharp chest pain that is aggravated by inspiration and relieved by sitting up and leaning forward. ECG will likely show widespread ST-segment elevation and/or PR depression. This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Atherosclerotic plaque obstructing 80% of the coronary artery lumen without thrombus:
Incorrect: Atherosclerotic plaque obstructing 80% of the coronary artery lumen will likely cause symptoms of stable angina. These symptoms include exertional chest pain which is relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Rupture of an atherosclerotic plaque with thrombus partially occluding the coronary artery lumen:
Incorrect: Rupture of an atherosclerotic plaque with thrombus partially occluding the coronary artery lumen can be seen in unstable angina or non–ST-segment elevation MI (NSTEMI). Electrocardiogram in patients with NSTEMI or unstable angina will likely show ST depression rather than ST-segment elevation. This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.  
✅ Minimal atherosclerotic plaque and coronary artery spasm :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Rupture of atherosclerotic plaque with thrombus fully occluding the coronary artery lumen:
Incorrect: Rupture of atherosclerotic plaque with thrombus fully occluding the coronary artery lumen can be seen in patients with ST-segment elevation MI (STEMI). Symptoms of STEMI are unlikely to resolve with nitroglycerin.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a witnessed syncopal episode. The patient’s parents report they had just finished dinner when their son spontaneously passed out. The patient does not recall the event and had no prodromal features. He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications, use alcohol, tobacco, or illicit substances. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is unremarkable. Electrocardiogram is demonstrated below:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

If left untreated this patient is at risk for which of the following complications?

choices.text: Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia and cardiac arrest

questions.solution:
This otherwise young, healthy patient presents after a witnessed episode of drop syncope without prodrome features. The screening electrocardiogram demonstrates the classic features of Brugada syndrome, including “coved” ST segments (see Figure 1). Without appropriate treatment, patients with Brugada syndrome are at high risk of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia and sudden cardiac death.   

Brugada syndrome is a rare, autosomal dominant sodium channelopathy that tends to affect males of Asian descent. The condition is most commonly attributed to mutations in the gene SCN5A, which is responsible for the cardiac sodium channel. Mutations in this gene result in a decrease of sodium ion flow during cardiac conduction, predisposing patients to ventricular arrhythmias--notably polymorphic ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation.  

The typical electrocardiogram for Brugada syndrome demonstrates coved ST segment elevation >2mm in >1 of V1-V3 followed by a negative T wave, which can also appear as a pseudo-right bundle branch block with the widened QRS presenting similar to a RSR’ configuration. Patients who have these electrocardiographic features and a corresponding clinical history should undergo treatment with an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator to prevent sudden cardiac death from associated ventricular arrhythmias.  

Figure 1: Classic electrocardiogram findings for Brugada syndrome  

 


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons 

Option Analysis

✅ Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia and cardiac arrest:
Correct: See main explanation  
❌ Atrial fibrillation and embolic stroke:
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation and embolic stroke do not typically occur from long-standing Brugada syndrome. It is more likely in patients with long-standing, untreated hypertension and coronary artery disease.
❌ Third degree heart block:
Incorrect: Third degree heart block occurs when the atria and ventricles beat independently of one another and occurs more commonly due to coronary ischemia. Third degree heart block is not a well documented complication of Brugada syndrome.   
❌ Cor pulmonale:
Incorrect: Cor pulmonale refers to isolated right ventricular failure; it has multiple well documented causes including pulmonary hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and pulmonary embolism.   
❌ Dilated cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Dilated cardiomyopathy has multiple well known causes including hypertension, chronic alcohol use, beri-beri syndrome, and Chagas disease. Brugada syndrome is not a well established etiology of dilated cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with 3 days of progressively worsening lethargy, irritability, and confusion. The child’s grandmother noticed the boy had trouble walking earlier in the day. He has no significant past medical history, but he recently returned from a camping trip 7 days ago. The grandmother is unable to provide further details. The patient’s temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 115/72 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a stuporous child that is arousable with sternal rub. Nuchal rigidity is absent. Ocular examination reveals intense pain with eye movements. Head MRI shows multiple lesions in the subcortical white matter, characteristic of demyelination. The patient receives proper treatment and recovers fully within a week. Which of the following is likely to be found in this patient’s history on further questioning?

choices.text: Hiking in the woods of the northeastern United States
Episode of monocular blindness that spontaneously resolved
Recent contact with a child with fever, headache, and neck stiffness

questions.solution:
This child has acute-onset altered mental status and pain on extraocular movement in the setting of an MRI revealing multiple subcortical demyelinating lesions. He most likely has acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM).  

ADEM is a rare type IV (cell-mediated) hypersensitivity reaction. In this condition, T-cells are activated by myelin proteins and release cytokines (e.g., IL-1, IL-6, TNF-alpha), which dilate blood vessels, allowing more immune cells (e.g., macrophages, B-cells) to infiltrate and damage oligodendrocytes. B-cells begin synthesizing antibodies that mark the myelin sheath proteins. Macrophages then use the antibody markers to engulf and destroy the oligodendrocytes, leading to diffuse demyelination at multiple locations throughout the brain and spinal cord.  

The underlying trigger for ADEM is unclear, but since some pathogens have proteins similar to oligodendrocytes proteins, molecular mimicry may be an underlying etiology. A variety of viral infections are associated with ADEM, including influenza, measles, mumps, rubella, and various human herpes viruses. Although vaccines were previously thought to be a trigger for ADEM, this theory has largely been disproven.  

Symptoms of ADEM have acute-onset, and usually begin 1-3 weeks after exposure to the trigger. Since ADEM is associated with systemic inflammation, most individuals have fever, headache, nausea, and vomiting. Eventually, demyelination breaks down communication between neurons, leading to visual problems (e.g. optic neuritis), seizures, weakness, irritability, confusion, lethargy, and even coma. The diagnosis can be made with MRI, which classically show multiple subcortical lesions.    

Option Analysis

✅ Recent upper respiratory viral infection:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hiking in the woods of the northeastern United States:
Incorrect:  Hiking in the woods of the northeastern United States would predispose patients to contracting Lyme disease from a tick bite. Untreated Lyme disease may eventually cause progressive encephalomyelitis, but this occurs much later in the disease course. Earlier stages of Lyme disease present with a characteristic bullseye rash (erythema migrans) and migratory arthralgia, which are absent in this patient’s history. 
❌ Episode of monocular blindness that spontaneously resolved:
Incorrect: Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) may have optic neuritis, which can present with loss of color vision, visual blurriness, or blindness. MS can also cause pain on extraocular movements and altered mental status. However, MS typically affects individuals between 20-40 years of age and presents with periventricular lesions. In contrast, it would be unusual for MS to affect a child or present with only subcortical lesions.  
❌ Family history of demyelinating condition:
Incorrect: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is a hereditary condition that results in peripheral neuropathy due to impaired Schwann cell growth and function. Patients typically present with distal symmetric sensorimotor polyneuropathy with atrophy of the calf muscles and pes cavus deformity. Acute encephalopathy, such as in this patient, is highly unlikely. 
❌ Recent contact with a child with fever, headache, and neck stiffness:
Incorrect: Meningitis can present with acute lethargy, fever, and headaches. However, this patient is missing the characteristic neck stiffness (nuchal rigidity) typically seen in meningitis. Additionally, the MRI findings suggest a different diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy is brought to the office for the evaluation of a sunburn. He had just returned from a week-long vacation to Florida, where his activities included swimming in the ocean, playing football at the shore, and river rafting. On the 2nd day, he started developing painful redness on his extremities and face, after which he began applying sunscreen before going out in the sun. His condition did not improve, and his skin started peeling off and developing blisters in the affected areas by the 4th day. The patient is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a fair-skinned adolescent with tender, blanching erythema and blisters on his shoulder and extremities as shown:  


Reproduced from: ">Wikimedia Commons   

Reproduced from: ">Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Fourth-degree burns extending to deep tissues

questions.solution:
This young boy with extensive exposure to sunlight during vacation has developed sunburn. The clinical findings of tender, blanching erythema, together with blister formation and peeling of skin, make superficial partial-thickness burn the most likely diagnosis.

Superficial partial-thickness burns involve the epidermis and papillary layer of the dermis. The problematic areas are usually painful to touch, erythematous, weeping, and blanch with pressure. These can be differentiated from first-degree burns by their tendency to form blisters.  


Reproduced from: ">Wikimedia Commons  
The healing process usually takes 7 to 21 days, depending on the total body surface area (TBSA) involved in the injury, and scarring is unusual. Supportive management is required and includes appropriate analgesia, cleaning with antiseptic soap, and daily dressing with or without topical antibiotics.  

Option Analysis

❌ First-degree superficial burn  :
Incorrect: A first-degree (superficial) burn involves only the epidermal layer of skin. It typically appears as an erythematous, dry, blanching rash that is painful to touch. Although this patient may have initially developed first-degree burns, his continuous sunlight exposure extended the damage into the superficial (papillary) dermis, resulting in the formation of blisters.  
✅ Second-degree superficial partial-thickness burn  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Second-degree deep partial-thickness burn  :
Incorrect: Deep partial-thickness burns extend into the deeper dermis and are characterized by varying mottled colorization (yellow to cheesy white), blister formation, and damage to the hair follicles. They are painful to pressure only and are usually non-blanchable. This patient’s blisters are blanchable and are tender to touch, making superficial partial-thickness burn more likely.  
❌ Third-degree full-thickness burn  :
Incorrect: Third-degree burn extends through the entire dermis. Affected areas appear white, leathery, and charred. Blisters are not a typical feature, and penetration into the reticular layer damages the sensory nerve endings; hence the wound is not (or is minimally) painful.  
❌ Fourth-degree burns extending to deep tissues  :
Incorrect: Fourth-degree burns are considered those which extend through the skin into underlying soft tissue and include the subcutaneous fat, muscles, and bone. They are relatively painless due to the destruction of nerve endings and appear as dry, charred black lesions with patches of dead skin. This patient’s burn has not breached the skin barrier completely.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to his physician for evaluation of fever and weight loss for the past two months. The patient states he has noted various non-tender lumps on his body, in particular one in his neck that has grown rapidly over the past few weeks. The patient has no significant past medical history. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals several nontender, enlarged supraclavicular and axillary lymph nodes. A CT chest-abdomen-pelvis reveals enlarged mesenteric and mediastinal lymph nodes. Analysis of a biopsied axillary lymph node demonstrates lymphocytes with a high proliferative index that stain positive for CD20. Further genetic analysis reveals a translocation involving the BCL6 gene on chromosome 3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), a variant of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL), is the most common type of lymphoma in adults, accounting for nearly 35% of adult NHLs. The pathogenesis of DLBCL typically involves the BCL6 gene – either via chromosomal rearrangement of this gene, or an activating mutation in the promoter region of this gene – and upregulation of transcriptional regulators in germinal center B-cells. Another genetic etiology of DLBCL involves a t(14;18) translocation involving the BCL2 gene.

Patients typically present with a rapidly enlarging symptomatic mass, most commonly in the neck or abdomen. Systemic B symptoms (i.e., fever, weight loss, drenching night sweats) are often present. The diagnosis of DLBCL relies on excisional tissue biopsy, most commonly from a lymph node. Further immunophenotyping reveals tumor cells expressing pan B-cell antigens (CD19, CD20, CD22, CD79a).  



Option Analysis

✅ Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Burkitt lymphoma   :
Incorrect: Burkitt lymphoma (BL) is an aggressive form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that can also present with B symptoms, painless lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly. However, BL is more common in children and typically associated with EBV infection. In adults, BL occurs in association with an immunocompromised state, such as HIV infection. Therefore, it is not the most likely diagnosis in this patient’s case.   
❌ Hairy cell leukemia   :
Incorrect: Hairy cell leukemia is an indolent, low-grade variant of B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Patients typically present with fatigue and splenomegaly. The indolent nature of this disease contrasts with this patient’s diffuse lymphadenopathy following a short period of symptoms.   
❌ Hodgkin lymphoma   :
Incorrect: Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) may also present with lymphadenopathy and B symptoms (fevers, night sweats, weight loss). However, Hodgkin lymphomas lack the usual B-cell markers, such as CD19 and CD20 seen in this patient; instead, immunophenotyping in Hodgkin lymphoma demonstrates CD15/30-positive Reed-Sternberg cells. Therefore, HL is not the most likely diagnosis.  
❌ Follicular lymphoma   :
Incorrect: Follicular lymphoma is an indolent form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that presents with B symptoms and painless lymphadenopathy. However, follicular lymphoma is indolent and would not explain this patient’s diffuse lymphadenopathy after a short period of symptoms.

questions.text: A 58-year-old individual with a history of chronic kidney disease presents to the physician to discuss the option of kidney transplantation. The patient developed renal failure secondary to glomerulosclerosis 15 years ago. The patient underwent a successful kidney transplantation 10 years ago from a related donor, but the transplant failed and was removed three years ago. The patient is currently on hemodialysis. Past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and a deep venous thrombosis in the left lower extremity, now resolved. After significant deliberation, the patient undergoes a kidney transplantation from a non-related donor. Eight hours after the surgery,  the patient develops chills, malaise, and fever. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), blood pressure is 104/70, and pulse is 102/minute. The patient has not made urine in the past five hours. The surgeon suspects complications with the transplanted organ, and the patient is brought back to the operating room. On open laparotomy, the transplanted kidney appears mottled and cyanotic. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Mixed type II and IV hypersensitivity reaction

questions.solution:
